description: Apple Certified Support Professional (ACSP) certification confirms the candidate's understanding of OS X's core functionality as well as having the ability to configure key services, perform basic troubleshooting, and support multiple users  with essential OS X capabilities. Candidates for this course may be in a role of help desk professional, technical coordinator, or power user who supports OS X users, manages networks, or provides technical support for the Mac.
name: Certified Support Professional 10.11
subtitle: OS X Support Essentials 10.11

episodes.description: In this episode Don walks us through the Apple Certified Support Professional certification. He takes a look at the topics covered, as well as basic information on how to take the exam.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.333
[SOUND]

2
00:00:04.333 --> 00:00:09.531
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:09.531 --> 00:00:13.412
In this video, we're gonna take a look at
the Apple Certified Support Professional

4
00:00:13.412 --> 00:00:15.920
certification show, here on ITPROTV.

5
00:00:15.920 --> 00:00:18.970
Now the ACSP's been around for awhile,
we've actually filmed it a few times.

6
00:00:18.970 --> 00:00:22.990
This time we're doing an update to
the El Capitan operating system release.

7
00:00:22.990 --> 00:00:26.870
With each new version of Mac OS,
we get changes, changes to the UI,

8
00:00:26.870 --> 00:00:28.160
changes to the software.

9
00:00:28.160 --> 00:00:31.860
And we update to refresh and reflect
that in our certification training.

10
00:00:31.860 --> 00:00:33.457
So that's what we're doing right here.

11
00:00:33.457 --> 00:00:37.497
If you want to learn all about supporting
El Capitan out there in the real world,

12
00:00:37.497 --> 00:00:41.008
if you're trying to support OS 10.11,
this is where it's at.

13
00:00:41.008 --> 00:00:43.320
Now, there's a lot of overlap
with previous versions.

14
00:00:43.320 --> 00:00:45.080
If you're already certified
in a previous version,

15
00:00:45.080 --> 00:00:47.250
you'll find that this is mostly the same.

16
00:00:47.250 --> 00:00:50.760
Just a handful of utilities have changed,
and things that you may encounter.

17
00:00:50.760 --> 00:00:55.950
But on a bigger side, we have some new
security features in OS 10.11 that

18
00:00:55.950 --> 00:00:57.890
can impact how we deploy applications and

19
00:00:57.890 --> 00:00:59.830
support the machines out
there in the real world.

20
00:00:59.830 --> 00:01:04.740
Well, before I get ahead of myself,
let's start with what is the ACSP?

21
00:01:04.740 --> 00:01:09.400
The Apple Certified Support Professional
is a certification designed for anybody

22
00:01:09.400 --> 00:01:13.630
who's out there supporting Macintosh
computers in a business environment.

23
00:01:13.630 --> 00:01:14.770
We're not talking about home users.

24
00:01:14.770 --> 00:01:18.320
You might have one, two,
even five Macs at home, and

25
00:01:18.320 --> 00:01:20.660
those you really just
manage them individually.

26
00:01:20.660 --> 00:01:26.420
But when you have a 100 Macs, a 1,000,
when you've got MacBook laptops,

27
00:01:26.420 --> 00:01:29.860
and Mac Pro desktops, and iPads, and
iPhones, and you've got all these

28
00:01:29.860 --> 00:01:33.910
different Apple devices, it sure would be
nice if we had some kind of way to manage

29
00:01:33.910 --> 00:01:37.680
them in a network where they all play
together and, well, perform nicely.

30
00:01:37.680 --> 00:01:40.730
And then when you had problems,
that you knew the steps to go

31
00:01:40.730 --> 00:01:43.920
through to troubleshoot and
resolve those issues without having

32
00:01:43.920 --> 00:01:46.700
to rush right out to the Apple Store and
get them to fix it for you.

33
00:01:46.700 --> 00:01:48.620
That's what the ACSP is all about.

34
00:01:48.620 --> 00:01:51.700
If you're one of those people that's
out there having to support Macs

35
00:01:51.700 --> 00:01:54.210
in your environment,
this is the show for you.

36
00:01:54.210 --> 00:01:56.850
Now, you might have Windows
machines in your environment.

37
00:01:56.850 --> 00:01:58.420
You might have just a handful of Macs, but

38
00:01:58.420 --> 00:02:00.590
there's still a lot you need to
know just to keep them up and

39
00:02:00.590 --> 00:02:04.480
running and healthy, and
that's all stuff that we see right here.

40
00:02:04.480 --> 00:02:07.432
All right, now the ACSP,
it covers a lot of different topics.

41
00:02:07.432 --> 00:02:10.428
It's a bit all over the place.

42
00:02:10.428 --> 00:02:13.910
And the reason is it's part of the whole
certification track from Apple.

43
00:02:13.910 --> 00:02:16.440
So let me bring up Apples's Training and
Certification page here.

44
00:02:16.440 --> 00:02:19.610
And what you'll see is that they
have a number of certifications.

45
00:02:19.610 --> 00:02:23.350
And at the time of this filming, some of
them have been updated to El Capitan,

46
00:02:23.350 --> 00:02:24.910
some them are still at Yosemite, so

47
00:02:24.910 --> 00:02:27.080
you'll see several down here
listed here under Yosemite.

48
00:02:27.080 --> 00:02:28.820
But on the El Capitan side,

49
00:02:28.820 --> 00:02:31.470
we've got the Apple Certified
Support Professional right there.

50
00:02:31.470 --> 00:02:32.790
That's the name of the certification.

51
00:02:32.790 --> 00:02:36.130
When you pass the exam you get your ACSP.

52
00:02:36.130 --> 00:02:37.770
The required exam, though,

53
00:02:37.770 --> 00:02:43.239
is actually called
the OS X Support Essentials 10.11 exam.

54
00:02:43.239 --> 00:02:46.500
And that exam gets updated
with each release of Mac OS.

55
00:02:46.500 --> 00:02:48.730
They have to update to
reflect the new changes.

56
00:02:48.730 --> 00:02:53.160
So, if you take this one exam,
you get this one certification, the ACSP.

57
00:02:53.160 --> 00:02:56.190
Now, the ACSP is one certification map.

58
00:02:56.190 --> 00:02:57.800
Well, there's actually two others.

59
00:02:57.800 --> 00:03:02.760
The ACA, or Apple Certified Associate,
that's considered the entry point.

60
00:03:02.760 --> 00:03:05.659
So if you're just getting started
with Apple certifications,

61
00:03:05.659 --> 00:03:08.676
it's better to start with the ACA
than to jump right into the ACSP.

62
00:03:08.676 --> 00:03:12.951
Now, they don't show it here cuz it hasn't
been updated yet, but there's actually two

63
00:03:12.951 --> 00:03:16.790
ACAs right here, Mac Management Basics and
Mac Integration Basics.

64
00:03:16.790 --> 00:03:21.430
One of them focuses just on Macs,
Mac Management Basics.

65
00:03:21.430 --> 00:03:23.430
That one has a lot of
overlap with the ACSP,

66
00:03:23.430 --> 00:03:27.720
so that's a great place to start
before going into the ACSP.

67
00:03:27.720 --> 00:03:29.240
Mac Integration Basics, on the other hand,

68
00:03:29.240 --> 00:03:32.610
focuses more on getting Windows
to play nice with Mac OS.

69
00:03:32.610 --> 00:03:35.270
It's not necessarily tied
in to what we do in ACSP.

70
00:03:35.270 --> 00:03:39.044
So if you're just starting out, I do
recommend doing the Mac Management Basics

71
00:03:39.044 --> 00:03:42.500
certification first, and
we've already filmed that here at ITProTV.

72
00:03:42.500 --> 00:03:45.340
It's in our course library,
you can jump right over and watch it.

73
00:03:45.340 --> 00:03:48.747
And even though Apple hasn't updated
it for 10.11 yet, we already have.

74
00:03:48.747 --> 00:03:49.627
So it's in there in 10.11.

75
00:03:49.627 --> 00:03:53.674
I mean, you can go back and watch our 10.9
content, or whatever, if you want, but

76
00:03:53.674 --> 00:03:56.460
we've already updated it for El Capitan.

77
00:03:56.460 --> 00:04:01.070
Now, once you get your ACSP, you are now
an Apple Certified Support Professional.

78
00:04:01.070 --> 00:04:04.250
You've shown that you're able
to support Macs in a network.

79
00:04:04.250 --> 00:04:06.440
And if you wanna go the next step up,

80
00:04:06.440 --> 00:04:10.170
the next step up is
the Apple Certified Technical Coordinator.

81
00:04:10.170 --> 00:04:14.180
And this is designed not for somebody
who's just supporting Macs in the field,

82
00:04:14.180 --> 00:04:16.290
but somebody who's running
the IT department.

83
00:04:16.290 --> 00:04:20.720
You might not be the person that's
actually out there doing the grunt work,

84
00:04:20.720 --> 00:04:22.900
but you're the one calling
the shots on the bigger picture.

85
00:04:22.900 --> 00:04:26.410
So, designing that overall infrastructure,
what solutions do I deploy?

86
00:04:26.410 --> 00:04:27.930
That's the ACTC.

87
00:04:27.930 --> 00:04:32.043
And if you want to get your ACTC,
you have to have the ACSP first.

88
00:04:32.043 --> 00:04:36.171
You've gotta pass the ACSP, and
you've gotta pass the ACTC exam.

89
00:04:36.171 --> 00:04:41.140
And once you pass both of them, then you
get your ACTC, so you've gotta have both.

90
00:04:41.140 --> 00:04:44.427
You can actually skip the ACA if you want,
you don't have to do those.

91
00:04:44.427 --> 00:04:48.028
If you have been working with Macs for
years and you're really comfortable with

92
00:04:48.028 --> 00:04:50.943
them, you can start right off with
the ACSP and jump right in it.

93
00:04:50.943 --> 00:04:55.351
But if you have no experience, you
wanna start at the ACA level first, and

94
00:04:55.351 --> 00:04:56.640
then jump up to ACSP.

95
00:04:56.640 --> 00:05:00.860
All right, so that's where this falls
in the Apple certification scheme,

96
00:05:00.860 --> 00:05:03.140
let's talk about what's on the exam.

97
00:05:03.140 --> 00:05:04.770
It covers a lot of great content,

98
00:05:04.770 --> 00:05:08.626
which are topics that are things that
we're gonna deal with in the real world.

99
00:05:08.626 --> 00:05:11.440
And I've kind of made a quick list here of
the topics that we cover in the show, so

100
00:05:11.440 --> 00:05:12.750
let's bring that up.

101
00:05:12.750 --> 00:05:14.810
We start with Installation and
Configuration.

102
00:05:14.810 --> 00:05:16.590
How do you get Mac OS installed?

103
00:05:16.590 --> 00:05:18.730
If you've only worked with
this in a home environment,

104
00:05:18.730 --> 00:05:21.860
you know that when you buy a Mac
it's already got Mac OS on it.

105
00:05:21.860 --> 00:05:24.460
But there's many times where you
might want to deploy it yourself.

106
00:05:24.460 --> 00:05:26.360
You might have 1,000 Macs that
are out there already and

107
00:05:26.360 --> 00:05:30.720
they're all running Mavericks, and you
need to get them upgraded to El Capitan.

108
00:05:30.720 --> 00:05:32.650
Or you might want to
build a standard image so

109
00:05:32.650 --> 00:05:35.780
that all your machines already have
software installed when you deploy them.

110
00:05:35.780 --> 00:05:37.130
We talk about that.

111
00:05:37.130 --> 00:05:38.580
Then we talk about User Accounts.

112
00:05:38.580 --> 00:05:42.160
Having individual user accounts on
everybody's computer is fine, but when

113
00:05:42.160 --> 00:05:46.030
you've got 1,000 computers, it's tough to
maintain that, it's tough to manage it.

114
00:05:46.030 --> 00:05:49.960
So having centralized user accounts and
special network type authentication

115
00:05:49.960 --> 00:05:52.960
is a really valuable thing to have,
so we talk about those.

116
00:05:52.960 --> 00:05:54.370
We talk about File Systems.

117
00:05:54.370 --> 00:05:58.140
When it comes to storage on a Mac,
it supports a number of different things.

118
00:05:58.140 --> 00:06:05.900
Internal and external storage, we have
our Apple OS X Extended Journal format.

119
00:06:05.900 --> 00:06:06.760
It's a big name.

120
00:06:06.760 --> 00:06:10.920
We have Microsoft's NTFS and FAT32 and
all these different file systems.

121
00:06:10.920 --> 00:06:13.530
And we talk about how they function inside
of the Mac, and how you can use them and

122
00:06:13.530 --> 00:06:15.810
some of the little caveats involved there.

123
00:06:15.810 --> 00:06:18.910
We talk about Data Management,
just backing up our systems,

124
00:06:18.910 --> 00:06:22.070
keeping them healthy, keeping our
data safe, where to store data,

125
00:06:22.070 --> 00:06:25.220
how permissions work on our data
when it's on those file systems.

126
00:06:25.220 --> 00:06:28.150
Then we talked about Applications and
Processes.

127
00:06:28.150 --> 00:06:32.170
Mac OS is great, it's really easy to use,
but out of the box it doesn't have a ton

128
00:06:32.170 --> 00:06:34.670
of software in it, it's got all
the Apple software and that's about it.

129
00:06:34.670 --> 00:06:37.730
So you're likely going to have to
support third party applications, and

130
00:06:37.730 --> 00:06:38.670
we talk about that.

131
00:06:38.670 --> 00:06:42.060
How to get the applications loaded, how to
manage them, how to troubleshoot them when

132
00:06:42.060 --> 00:06:46.300
they start eating up too much CPU or too
much memory, we cover all that content.

133
00:06:46.300 --> 00:06:48.050
Then we jump into the networking world.

134
00:06:48.050 --> 00:06:51.220
How to get our system setup to
communicate on the network.

135
00:06:51.220 --> 00:06:54.130
And on the networking side,
we start off really with just IP networks.

136
00:06:54.130 --> 00:06:57.150
So how do you get two Macs to where
they can even see each other?

137
00:06:57.150 --> 00:06:59.290
And once they can see each
other on the network,

138
00:06:59.290 --> 00:07:00.650
then we move into Network Services.

139
00:07:00.650 --> 00:07:03.495
All right, great, your two computers
see each other, what do you do now?

140
00:07:03.495 --> 00:07:06.399
How can you share files,
how can you share folders,

141
00:07:06.399 --> 00:07:08.650
or printers, or even CD and DVD drives?

142
00:07:08.650 --> 00:07:11.840
How do you share any of those
resources when two computers see each

143
00:07:11.840 --> 00:07:12.690
other on the network?

144
00:07:12.690 --> 00:07:13.820
We cover all of that.

145
00:07:13.820 --> 00:07:17.090
And then we wrap up the show just
talking about System Management,

146
00:07:17.090 --> 00:07:20.950
and a better name for that section
would really be troubleshooting.

147
00:07:20.950 --> 00:07:24.270
What do you do when the Mac is not
behaving the way it's supposed to?

148
00:07:24.270 --> 00:07:27.900
We know it has all these great features
that are supposed to work like magic, but

149
00:07:27.900 --> 00:07:31.800
sometimes it just doesn't work out that
way and we've got to troubleshoot it.

150
00:07:31.800 --> 00:07:35.454
So I spend a lot of time in that
section covering all the really amazing

151
00:07:35.454 --> 00:07:39.935
troubleshooting tools that are built into
Mac OS and built into the Apple hardware.

152
00:07:39.935 --> 00:07:42.848
And it's part of what makes that
ecosystem so valuable to us.

153
00:07:42.848 --> 00:07:45.670
So those are the topics that we're gonna
be covering throughout this series.

154
00:07:45.670 --> 00:07:48.478
It's all broken up into 30 minute
episodes that are nice and

155
00:07:48.478 --> 00:07:50.120
easy to consume and watch.

156
00:07:50.120 --> 00:07:52.630
We cover it all,
it's a great certification.

157
00:07:52.630 --> 00:07:55.860
I really like this one because
it covers real world skills.

158
00:07:55.860 --> 00:07:58.850
Every one of these technologies are ones
that I've used in the real world.

159
00:07:58.850 --> 00:08:01.410
Sometime you get these certifications
where they cover technologies and

160
00:08:01.410 --> 00:08:02.130
you look at it and you're like, wow,

161
00:08:02.130 --> 00:08:06.130
this is more like a marketing slide,
I'm never gonna us this is real life.

162
00:08:06.130 --> 00:08:07.170
But this is stuff you will.

163
00:08:07.170 --> 00:08:10.000
Everything in here are things you'll
encounter on a regular basis, and

164
00:08:10.000 --> 00:08:11.880
it's excellent knowledge to know.

165
00:08:11.880 --> 00:08:14.453
So I encourage anybody who
supports Macs in a school or

166
00:08:14.453 --> 00:08:18.170
business environment, anywhere where
you have more than, say, ten Macs,

167
00:08:18.170 --> 00:08:22.390
it's really valuable to do
the certification, it's a great one to do.

168
00:08:22.390 --> 00:08:25.660
All right, so let's say you watched the
show, you learn all the great information,

169
00:08:25.660 --> 00:08:27.970
you're ready to take the test,
you wanna get certified.

170
00:08:27.970 --> 00:08:31.570
Well, the ACSP is a little
bit different than the ACA.

171
00:08:31.570 --> 00:08:34.070
The ACA exams,
the Mac Management Basics and

172
00:08:34.070 --> 00:08:37.780
Mac Integration Basics, you can take those
online from the comfort of your own home.

173
00:08:37.780 --> 00:08:40.770
You sign up right on Apple's website and
that's it.

174
00:08:40.770 --> 00:08:42.910
But with ACSP and ACTC,

175
00:08:42.910 --> 00:08:47.606
you can only take them at Apple
Authorized Training Centers, or AATCs.

176
00:08:47.606 --> 00:08:49.640
Now, there are AATCs all over the world,
so

177
00:08:49.640 --> 00:08:51.630
you just need to find one that's near you.

178
00:08:51.630 --> 00:08:54.550
And if you go to Apple's website,
if you go to training.apple.com,

179
00:08:54.550 --> 00:08:56.390
they've actually got a lot of
them located right on there.

180
00:08:56.390 --> 00:08:58.580
You can search and find them and
register for the exam.

181
00:08:58.580 --> 00:09:00.890
But the point is you've gotta
drive there to take it.

182
00:09:00.890 --> 00:09:03.620
So you've gotta go somewhere and
actually take this exam.

183
00:09:03.620 --> 00:09:06.050
The exam is two hours long,
so it's a long exam,

184
00:09:06.050 --> 00:09:07.940
you're gonna be in that
testing booth a while.

185
00:09:07.940 --> 00:09:12.080
It's got 80 questions, so it's about
a minute and a half per question.

186
00:09:12.080 --> 00:09:15.400
As long as you stick to that, you'll
come in on time and finish the exam.

187
00:09:15.400 --> 00:09:18.433
If you take more then a minute and a half
on a question then you might run out of

188
00:09:18.433 --> 00:09:21.142
time, right, so you've gotta stay
focused and move through it.

189
00:09:21.142 --> 00:09:24.260
Of the 80 questions,
there's 5 that aren't scored.

190
00:09:24.260 --> 00:09:27.378
They're kind of like demographic
survey-type questions where they're just

191
00:09:27.378 --> 00:09:30.100
testing out something, and
so they don't count those.

192
00:09:30.100 --> 00:09:31.470
But you don't know which five they are.

193
00:09:31.470 --> 00:09:33.670
So it really doesn't matter
that five of them are unscored,

194
00:09:33.670 --> 00:09:36.020
you need to do well on all of them.

195
00:09:36.020 --> 00:09:37.760
The questions are mostly multiple choice.

196
00:09:37.760 --> 00:09:39.760
You'll find that almost every
one is multiple choice.

197
00:09:39.760 --> 00:09:44.220
Some will be true and false, and
others might be a media experience,

198
00:09:44.220 --> 00:09:47.360
where it shows you a picture of
the system preferences screen.

199
00:09:47.360 --> 00:09:50.980
And it says click on the system
preference that does xyz task, and

200
00:09:50.980 --> 00:09:51.740
you've got to click on the one.

201
00:09:51.740 --> 00:09:54.920
So, its a graphical element
involved in the question.

202
00:09:54.920 --> 00:09:57.860
But the bulk of them are just multiple
choice and so you can use process of

203
00:09:57.860 --> 00:10:01.290
elimination and the other things we've
honed through years of public schooling,

204
00:10:01.290 --> 00:10:03.320
right, to figure out what
that right answer is.

205
00:10:03.320 --> 00:10:06.180
And I'll be honest with you guys,
this exam is really straightforward,

206
00:10:06.180 --> 00:10:09.070
there's no trick questions on there,
everything is really practical.

207
00:10:09.070 --> 00:10:12.830
It really is a great certification,
I've always been pleased with this one.

208
00:10:12.830 --> 00:10:14.430
It's a neat one.

209
00:10:14.430 --> 00:10:18.400
Now, the exam cost, I can't really
tell you that because it varies based

210
00:10:18.400 --> 00:10:19.940
on region, whichever country you're in.

211
00:10:19.940 --> 00:10:23.610
They have different pricing,
and so it can vary.

212
00:10:23.610 --> 00:10:25.980
But it's not a terribly expensive exam.

213
00:10:25.980 --> 00:10:32.000
The only hard part is having to go to
an AATC to take it, so just remember that.

214
00:10:32.000 --> 00:10:35.080
But, otherwise,
that's basically it for the exam.

215
00:10:35.080 --> 00:10:39.330
So I've talked about the ACSP
certification is, I've talked about what

216
00:10:39.330 --> 00:10:42.370

00:32:16.710 --> 00:32:20.180
Well, I just formatted mine so

00:32:20.180 --> 00:32:22.550

00:32:22.550 --> 00:32:25.536

Yours will be /Volumes/whatever

00:32:39.091 --> 00:32:43.750
Then [LAUGH] this is kind of weird, but

00:32:43.750 --> 00:32:45.070
I'm running the script.

But it's possible that I've moved

I have to say --applicationpath,

00:32:56.840 --> 00:33:00.310
applicationpath, yes, and
then tell it where that installer is.

And so I've got to say, //applications,

00:33:04.010 --> 00:33:10.884
applications, and then /Install

there we go,
Install\ OS\ X\ El\ Capitan.app, right.

And then the last thing

Time Machine, I'm gonna say don't use.

So that I'll be able to attach

I'll be able to boot off of this disk and

00:34:15.300 --> 00:34:19.590

00:34:32.220 --> 00:34:35.190

But once it's done,

742
00:35:05.826 --> 00:35:11.260

00:35:13.108 --> 00:35:16.076
We did that, we went to the App Store,

we updated to 10.10.5.

00:35:17.620 --> 00:35:20.184

00:35:25.807 --> 00:35:27.458

>> That's about it on this one.

Lastly, you have terminal.

301
00:14:12.310 --> 00:14:14.090
And, the terminal is the important one.

302
00:14:14.090 --> 00:14:16.910
If you really have
a problem with your disk,

303
00:14:16.910 --> 00:14:20.040
You might have to drop to terminal to do a
few things, and I know I've had to do this

304
00:14:20.040 --> 00:14:24.250
to remove things like EFI partitions that
don't show up in disk utility by default.

305
00:14:24.250 --> 00:14:27.310
So you can jump in and
take a look at that.

306
00:14:27.310 --> 00:14:28.490
Hopefully you don't have to do that,

307
00:14:28.490 --> 00:14:30.990
it's not something that we commonly
have to do, but it is available.

308
00:14:30.990 --> 00:14:33.950
Available, so those are some hidden
away tools because they're less common.

309
00:14:33.950 --> 00:14:36.830
>> Don, with the disk utility, would you
ever use that in a situation where you're

310
00:14:36.830 --> 00:14:39.740
trying to provision the drive prior
to installing the operating system?

311
00:14:39.740 --> 00:14:42.420
Now you mentioned if there is something
damaged I'm going to use it, go in there

312
00:14:42.420 --> 00:14:45.840
and try to fix the drive, but how about
provisioning the drive before hand?

313
00:14:45.840 --> 00:14:47.760
>> Yeah, great question,
so if I just go and

314
00:14:47.760 --> 00:14:50.600
choose install os ten
>> It's gonna take a look at whatever

315
00:14:50.600 --> 00:14:52.560
drive I have, and
it's gonna install on it.

316
00:14:52.560 --> 00:14:55.960
And so, if I've got a 1 terabyte
hard drive like I do in this system,

317
00:14:55.960 --> 00:14:57.260
it's gonna have just a 1

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at what to do when your Mac doesn't "just work." They demonstrate how to use the built-in recovery partition found on most Macs, as well as some alternatives for Macs not featuring a recovery partition.
episodes.title: OS Recovery
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:10.230
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.121 --> 00:00:14.930
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.930 --> 00:00:18.781
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and in today's
episode we're gonna be moving through our

4
00:00:18.781 --> 00:00:22.054
Apple Certified Support Professional and
we've got none other than Mr.

5
00:00:22.054 --> 00:00:23.178
Don Pezet to help us out.

6
00:00:23.178 --> 00:00:24.690
Don, how are you doing today, sir?

7
00:00:24.690 --> 00:00:25.450
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

8
00:00:25.450 --> 00:00:28.642
Thanks for having me on the show and
ready to jump into another fun one.

9
00:00:28.642 --> 00:00:31.916
In our other episodes, we've kind of
talked a lot about getting OS 10 installed

10
00:00:31.916 --> 00:00:33.917
and other different things
we need to be aware of.

11
00:00:33.917 --> 00:00:37.501
And this episode, we're gonna do
the thing that Apple doesn't like to talk

12
00:00:37.501 --> 00:00:40.700
about which is told them what to
do when things don't work, right?

13
00:00:40.700 --> 00:00:43.930
When things aren't going the way we
expected, and we need some help.

14
00:00:43.930 --> 00:00:45.540
We've got some various tools
that are available, and

15
00:00:45.540 --> 00:00:48.110
we've got several troubleshooting
episodes that are down the road.

16
00:00:48.110 --> 00:00:50.720
But in our first couple of episodes,
I know more than once, I mentioned

17
00:00:50.720 --> 00:00:54.000
the recovery partition, so we're gonna
focus on that from this episode.

18
00:00:54.000 --> 00:00:56.620
Take a look at what the recovery
partition is, what it does and

19
00:00:56.620 --> 00:01:01.050
how we can use it, and see how it can
save our bacon when we're in trouble and

20
00:01:01.050 --> 00:01:02.230
get us by on a tough spot.

21
00:01:02.230 --> 00:01:04.448
So that's kind of what we've got lined up.

22
00:01:04.448 --> 00:01:05.985
All right, so let's kick this thing off.

23
00:01:05.985 --> 00:01:11.537
I have my Mac Mini that I was installing
El Capitan on in the last episode,

24
00:01:11.537 --> 00:01:16.648
and what I did is halfway through
the install I just powered it off.

25
00:01:16.648 --> 00:01:19.541
Wes was teasing me he was like
why didn't you let it finish and

26
00:01:19.541 --> 00:01:23.370
I was like well I need a broken system for
the show, so I've got a broken system.

27
00:01:23.370 --> 00:01:27.438
I got half-way through the installer and
turned it off.

28
00:01:27.438 --> 00:01:32.360
So, if I power it on now,
it's only got half the system right?

29
00:01:32.360 --> 00:01:33.390
It's not gonna work.

30
00:01:33.390 --> 00:01:36.880
Well, you'd actually be surprised to
how resilient the installer is and

31
00:01:36.880 --> 00:01:41.220
I bet if I powered it on right now, it
would probably resume the installation and

32
00:01:41.220 --> 00:01:42.070
try and complete it out.

33
00:01:42.070 --> 00:01:45.273
Apple's really thought that stuff through,
but lets say, that it doesn't.

34
00:01:45.273 --> 00:01:48.744
Lets say, I power it on and
I get the old sad Mac.

35
00:01:48.744 --> 00:01:52.839
I don't know if you guys have ever seen
that logo but when a Mac can't boot,

36
00:01:52.839 --> 00:01:56.882
it makes this little it's an old SE20 or
SE2 one of the really old Macs.

37
00:01:56.882 --> 00:02:01.410
And it's got a frowny face on it with Xs
on it's eyes and it's called the sad Mac.

38
00:02:01.410 --> 00:02:04.126
It can't boot up, so what do you do?

39
00:02:04.126 --> 00:02:07.625
Well, you've got to boot to recovery and
when you boot to recovery you get a whole

40
00:02:07.625 --> 00:02:10.883
suite of utilities that are available
to help you get over those problems.

41
00:02:10.883 --> 00:02:13.065
So, let's start with the basics,

42
00:02:13.065 --> 00:02:17.370
what are some of those problems that
might lead me to need these tools?

43
00:02:17.370 --> 00:02:17.944
Right?

44
00:02:17.944 --> 00:02:20.830
And I mentioned a failed
operating system install.

45
00:02:20.830 --> 00:02:22.720
If your operating system is corrupt and

46
00:02:22.720 --> 00:02:25.140
you can't boot it,
you're dead in the water, right?

47
00:02:25.140 --> 00:02:26.960
You got to have an operating system for
everything else going.

48
00:02:26.960 --> 00:02:31.870
Your applications run on top of the
operating system we got to have it, right?

49
00:02:31.870 --> 00:02:35.910
Other things, maybe I'm booting up and
the system just freezes.

50
00:02:35.910 --> 00:02:38.993
I've seen this were you get the Apple
logo, and that little black bar is going

51
00:02:38.993 --> 00:02:42.440
across to its halfway, and
then it just stops and just sits there.

52
00:02:42.440 --> 00:02:46.910
Sits there for minutes, hours, days,
however long it is that you have patience

53
00:02:46.910 --> 00:02:49.330
for, it just sits there,
it's stuck, right?

54
00:02:49.330 --> 00:02:52.710
Something has gotten corrupted under
the hood and we can't see what that is.

55
00:02:52.710 --> 00:02:55.940
There's ways that you can make the Mac
show you a little more information, but

56
00:02:55.940 --> 00:02:59.320
it doesn't give you a ton and so you
don't know why it's basically freezing.

57
00:02:59.320 --> 00:03:02.040
So we're stuck,
we're kinda trapped, all right?

58
00:03:02.040 --> 00:03:06.480
Other things, maybe your system seems that
it's running fine but then, every now and

59
00:03:06.480 --> 00:03:07.830
then you run an application and

60
00:03:07.830 --> 00:03:11.134
you get the little spinning
pinwheel of doom right?

61
00:03:11.134 --> 00:03:14.970
And your system just freezes and then
later on it does it again and it does it

62
00:03:14.970 --> 00:03:18.035
again and there's no real pattern to it,
it just happens a lot and it's annoying.

63
00:03:18.035 --> 00:03:21.015
And your system freezes, and
maybe you have to reboot, maybe you don't.

64
00:03:21.015 --> 00:03:24.405
Well, a lot of times I
communicate failing memory and

65
00:03:24.405 --> 00:03:27.495
there's ways that we can test on our
Mac to see if we have failing memory,

66
00:03:27.495 --> 00:03:30.845
see that's what the issue is cuz
that's often what results in that.

67
00:03:30.845 --> 00:03:33.035
But it could be a corrupted
operating system also, and

68
00:03:33.035 --> 00:03:35.485
the solution there really is to
reinstall the operating system.

69
00:03:35.485 --> 00:03:39.620
If you reinstall the OS, that'll clean
up all the files back to factory and

70
00:03:39.620 --> 00:03:40.940
then you should be able to boot it and
get by.

71
00:03:40.940 --> 00:03:43.650
It could be third party
software stopping it though.

72
00:03:43.650 --> 00:03:47.410
And if I reinstall the OS,
it's really creating the broken OS.

73
00:03:47.410 --> 00:03:51.220
And so your application stays, so I might
need to get that application out of there.

74
00:03:51.220 --> 00:03:54.601
And I can't do that if I can't
boot my operating system, so

75
00:03:54.601 --> 00:03:56.099
I need some way to do that.

76
00:03:56.099 --> 00:04:00.769
Those are some of the key ones, failing
ram is one, bad sectors on a hard drive,

77
00:04:00.769 --> 00:04:01.270
right?

78
00:04:01.270 --> 00:04:04.100
If you hard drive starts to fail and
there's a lot of third

79
00:04:04.100 --> 00:04:06.260
party programs out there that say,
we can fix your hard drive.

80
00:04:06.260 --> 00:04:09.030
And you run it and it'll scan your hard
drive, i t'll find bad sectors and

81
00:04:09.030 --> 00:04:10.850
it'll try and move your data off.

82
00:04:10.850 --> 00:04:12.870
But the reality is those programs,

83
00:04:12.870 --> 00:04:16.470
I'm not gonna say they're a complete
waste of money, there's a use for them.

84
00:04:16.470 --> 00:04:19.390
If your data is locked
away in bad sectors,

85
00:04:19.390 --> 00:04:21.950
that software can sometimes get your
data back and there's value in that, so

86
00:04:21.950 --> 00:04:25.380
there is certainly value, but
there's no long-term value.

87
00:04:25.380 --> 00:04:27.690
As soon as you get your
files out of there,

88
00:04:27.690 --> 00:04:29.210
you need to replace that hard drive.

89
00:04:29.210 --> 00:04:33.340
Because when a hard drive starts to fail,
it doesn't stop to fail.

90
00:04:33.340 --> 00:04:36.800
It doesn't say, well, you got the data
off that bad sector, we're all good now.

91
00:04:36.800 --> 00:04:40.250
No, it started to fail, it's just
gonna get worse and worse and worse.

92
00:04:40.250 --> 00:04:43.400
So the very first time that happens,
that's your warning, right?

93
00:04:43.400 --> 00:04:44.425
That's your warning,

94
00:04:44.425 --> 00:04:47.458
get your data off of here quick make
sure you got a time machine backup.

95
00:04:47.458 --> 00:04:50.894
But, if you fix that little problem,
you run DiskWarrior.

96
00:04:50.894 --> 00:04:53.658
DiskWarrior is great, it'll cover up
all sorts of data off your drive.

97
00:04:53.658 --> 00:04:57.431
So you run DiskWarrior, it gets your data
off of there and you say, okay, well,

98
00:04:57.431 --> 00:04:59.335
now my data's good, you keep running.

99
00:04:59.335 --> 00:05:02.253
Well, you've got a ticking time
bomb inside your computer and so

100
00:05:02.253 --> 00:05:05.234
you definitely don't want that,
you need to replace that drive.

101
00:05:05.234 --> 00:05:07.934
Our problem could just be user accident,
I've seen this,

102
00:05:07.934 --> 00:05:10.259
where a user's browsing
around on the hard drive.

103
00:05:10.259 --> 00:05:12.805
And they've got admin
rights on the machine,

104
00:05:12.805 --> 00:05:16.340
cuz that's what most people do and
they start deleting things.

105
00:05:16.340 --> 00:05:17.470
They install some software.

106
00:05:17.470 --> 00:05:20.940
They do some things that damage
the computer and now it won't boot.

107
00:05:20.940 --> 00:05:24.950
All of these are things that lead
to a system that's not usable, and

108
00:05:24.950 --> 00:05:29.870
our first line of defense,
our first tool Is the recovery console.

109
00:05:29.870 --> 00:05:33.460
If we've got failing memory,
our operating system will be locking up.

110
00:05:33.460 --> 00:05:37.190
If you boot to the recovery console, the
recovery console will be locking up also.

111
00:05:37.190 --> 00:05:38.640
It's a great way to diagnose that.

112
00:05:38.640 --> 00:05:42.220
When you boot to recovery, it's a very
stripped-down version of Mac OS.

113
00:05:42.220 --> 00:05:44.890
It's not running any applications or
third-party drivers.

114
00:05:44.890 --> 00:05:47.462
It's just running the base system for
the recovery.

115
00:05:47.462 --> 00:05:51.580
And so the problem is still exhibited
there, that kind of takes the operating

116
00:05:51.580 --> 00:05:54.750
system out of the mix and
all that is left is your hardware.

117
00:05:54.750 --> 00:05:57.470
The recovery council is a great
way to just make that judgement.

118
00:05:57.470 --> 00:06:01.380
Now, there is actually a hidden hardware
diagnostics inside of your MAC.

119
00:06:01.380 --> 00:06:04.950
It's one of those documented but
undocumented features.

120
00:06:04.950 --> 00:06:06.442
Apple doesn't talk about it much,

121
00:06:06.442 --> 00:06:08.838
cuz they really expect the genius
bars to use it, right?

122
00:06:08.838 --> 00:06:10.880
You take it to an Apple Store and
they will use it.

123
00:06:10.880 --> 00:06:14.080
But if you put up your Mac while
holding the D key on your keyboard,

124
00:06:14.080 --> 00:06:17.480
it'll boot to a diagnostic mode, and we'll
see that in a troubleshooting episode.

125
00:06:17.480 --> 00:06:20.750
And so it can check and look for
bad memory, bad hard drive, and so on.

126
00:06:20.750 --> 00:06:23.500
The only negative thing about
the diagnostic tool is that it

127
00:06:23.500 --> 00:06:24.580
takes a long time.

128
00:06:24.580 --> 00:06:27.000
So it's one of those where I usually
start up before going to bed and

129
00:06:27.000 --> 00:06:27.880
then you check it in the morning,

130
00:06:27.880 --> 00:06:31.220
or start up before going lunch, cuz it'll
take an hour or two to do its thing.

131
00:06:31.220 --> 00:06:32.900
And then tell you whether
your machine is healthy,

132
00:06:32.900 --> 00:06:35.600
so it can take a while if
it's scanning the hard drive.

133
00:06:35.600 --> 00:06:37.270
If it's not scanning the hard drive,
it's a lot faster but

134
00:06:37.270 --> 00:06:38.920
if it's scanning the drive,
it does take a while.

135
00:06:40.090 --> 00:06:44.670
All right, so let's say that
my system is not able to boot.

136
00:06:44.670 --> 00:06:48.440
I can't get into my operating system and
I wanna go to recovery.

137
00:06:48.440 --> 00:06:51.770
Well, there's a few things we need
to be aware of ahead of time,

138
00:06:51.770 --> 00:06:53.280
before we get to that point, right?

139
00:06:53.280 --> 00:06:55.740
So when your Mac is perfectly healthy,

140
00:06:55.740 --> 00:06:59.800
there's some steps you should take to
make sure that you're gonna be okay.

141
00:06:59.800 --> 00:07:04.230
On an older Mac, it can actually be a bit
of a challenge and let me tell you what.

142
00:07:04.230 --> 00:07:08.850
If you bought a Mac from Apple, then it
ships it to you with MAC OS loaded on it

143
00:07:08.850 --> 00:07:11.030
and with recovery partition
right there on the hard drive.

144
00:07:11.030 --> 00:07:13.570
So it's ready to go,
its got the recovery partition.

145
00:07:13.570 --> 00:07:17.158
But if your hard drive fails,
where is your recovery partition?

146
00:07:17.158 --> 00:07:18.400
It's gone.

147
00:07:18.400 --> 00:07:19.190
You don't have one.

148
00:07:19.190 --> 00:07:20.980
You lost the operating system and
the recovery partition.

149
00:07:20.980 --> 00:07:22.730
It's gone.
You can't boost to recovery.

150
00:07:24.470 --> 00:07:27.020
A newer Macs,
ones made in the last three years or

151
00:07:27.020 --> 00:07:29.980
so, they have whats
called Internet recovery.

152
00:07:29.980 --> 00:07:34.010
So even if there's no hard drive
in the system, they can boot up,

153
00:07:34.010 --> 00:07:36.720
reach out across the Internet to Apple and
load recovery from Apple.

154
00:07:36.720 --> 00:07:38.290
So, we're covered from that,
on a bad hard drive.

155
00:07:39.660 --> 00:07:42.130
But, what if you got a Mac that's four or
five years old and

156
00:07:42.130 --> 00:07:43.990
doesn't have an Internet recovery?

157
00:07:43.990 --> 00:07:46.070
And your hard drive failed,
are you just out of luck?

158
00:07:46.070 --> 00:07:49.686
Well, you could take it to the Apple
Store, they'll fix it for you, but

159
00:07:49.686 --> 00:07:51.061
you could fix it yourself.

160
00:07:51.061 --> 00:07:55.400
All you need is an installation media,
remember in the very first episode I made

161
00:07:55.400 --> 00:07:59.310
a removable drive that had El Capitan
on it, so it's got an installer.

162
00:07:59.310 --> 00:08:03.281
Well, the installer for
El Capitan really is the recovery mode.

163
00:08:03.281 --> 00:08:06.435
So I can just boot off of
installation media and do it.

164
00:08:06.435 --> 00:08:10.320
That works with Maverick, Yosemite,
El Capitan, all the newer ones.

165
00:08:10.320 --> 00:08:13.520
If you got older ones like Mountain Lion,
there's actually a different utility.

166
00:08:13.520 --> 00:08:17.350
If you go to Apple's site and search for
the recovery, what is it called,

167
00:08:17.350 --> 00:08:19.690
recovery disk assistant,
recovery, yeah that's it.

168
00:08:19.690 --> 00:08:21.310
Recovery disk assistant.

169
00:08:21.310 --> 00:08:24.180
If you go to Apple's website and
do a search for recovery disk assistant,

170
00:08:24.180 --> 00:08:26.480
back in the Mountain Lion days,
they had this program you would download.

171
00:08:26.480 --> 00:08:29.370
And it would help you make a recover disk.

172
00:08:29.370 --> 00:08:31.990
And it could be a USB key, or
it could actually make DVDs too,

173
00:08:31.990 --> 00:08:33.280
in some of the older versions.

174
00:08:33.280 --> 00:08:36.430
And so you could create media
that way to do the install.

175
00:08:36.430 --> 00:08:38.550
In our newer systems we don't
have that anymore, right?

176
00:08:38.550 --> 00:08:40.660
So, the recovery disk assistant.

177
00:08:40.660 --> 00:08:41.680
It stopped with Mountain Lion.

178
00:08:41.680 --> 00:08:44.040
If you're running something newer
than Mountain Lion, do not use it.

179
00:08:44.040 --> 00:08:46.950
Instead, just make
removable install media.

180
00:08:46.950 --> 00:08:48.180
It's got everything you need.

181
00:08:48.180 --> 00:08:49.950
It's perfect and it works great.

182
00:08:49.950 --> 00:08:52.430
Or you can use Internet Recovery, right?

183
00:08:52.430 --> 00:08:55.590
So let me show you these kind of
recovery models and how they work.

184
00:08:55.590 --> 00:08:59.760
I've got my Mac mini over here that I
powered off during the install, okay?

185
00:08:59.760 --> 00:09:03.090
So, I'm gonna take it, I'm gonna
power it on and when I power it on,

186
00:09:03.090 --> 00:09:06.810
I'm just gonna hold the alt key
on it while it boots, okay.

187
00:09:06.810 --> 00:09:08.840
So, let's gonna boot up right now,
I'm holding my alt key and

188
00:09:08.840 --> 00:09:12.810
what I should see is a list of
hard drives that I can boot from.

189
00:09:12.810 --> 00:09:16.640
And here they are and
my Mackintosh HD doesn't show up.

190
00:09:16.640 --> 00:09:19.940
Because I interrupted
the install it didn't finish.

191
00:09:19.940 --> 00:09:23.810
So I'm seeing the recovery partition
that's on the hard drive inside of

192
00:09:23.810 --> 00:09:24.770
the machine.

193
00:09:24.770 --> 00:09:27.050
That's still intact, I can boot from that.

194
00:09:27.050 --> 00:09:29.180
Also, I see my installation media.

195
00:09:29.180 --> 00:09:31.450
That is the removable
drive I've got attached.

196
00:09:31.450 --> 00:09:35.310
I can boot to either one of those, and
they'll take me to the exact same place.

197
00:09:35.310 --> 00:09:38.470
They'll take me to
the recovery on this system.

198
00:09:38.470 --> 00:09:43.790
Okay, but what if I go to boot my system,
and it's got not hard drive.

undo some of the settings that I've got,

553
00:27:15.440 --> 00:27:18.190
but it does give me that chance
to pick and choose my settings.

554
00:27:18.190 --> 00:27:21.430
And just like when I did the Windows
machine, remember how I had the duplicate

555
00:27:21.430 --> 00:27:24.390
user account, Don Pezet on both of them,
I've got that again.

556
00:27:24.390 --> 00:27:26.530
I've got a Don Pezet
account on the Mac Mini and

557
00:27:26.530 --> 00:27:29.130
I've got a Don Pezet account here,
so it's asking me to rename it.

558
00:27:29.130 --> 00:27:31.218
But you'll see it's gonna
get my applications.

559
00:27:31.218 --> 00:27:33.054
That's something we
couldn't do with Windows,

560
00:27:33.054 --> 00:27:35.090
because Windows apps won't run on a Mac.

561
00:27:35.090 --> 00:27:37.860
But this is another Mac, so I can pull
the applications right off that Mac and

562
00:27:37.860 --> 00:27:38.950
bring them over here.

563
00:27:38.950 --> 00:27:42.892
We can bring my user account and
everything that's inside of it, desktop,

564
00:27:42.892 --> 00:27:47.389
documents, downloads, movies, and all
that good stuff, other files and folders,

565
00:27:47.389 --> 00:27:50.180
right, other files that it
finds on our hard drives.

566
00:27:50.180 --> 00:27:54.257
And then computer and network settings,,
it's gonna reach inside of that and get

567
00:27:54.257 --> 00:27:58.509
the settings that are based on, you know,
customizations we've done to the finder,

568
00:27:58.509 --> 00:28:02.520
or our energy savings settings,
all of that stuff and bring those in too.

569
00:28:02.520 --> 00:28:05.710
So it's gonna grab all of that and
bring it into that system.

570
00:28:05.710 --> 00:28:10.210
This is really incredibly useful when
you have a Mac that won't boot anymore.

571
00:28:10.210 --> 00:28:13.444
So the operating system's been
corrupted or something like that,

572
00:28:13.444 --> 00:28:15.613
you can boot into target mode and
bring it in.

573
00:28:15.613 --> 00:28:18.482
And now if you've got something that has
a real problem, like it's got a bad power

574
00:28:18.482 --> 00:28:21.077
supply, you can't boot into target
mode if it's got a bad power supply.

575
00:28:21.077 --> 00:28:22.290
It's not gonna work.

576
00:28:22.290 --> 00:28:25.830
So then that's where you start thinking,
okay, well, can I crack this case open?

577
00:28:25.830 --> 00:28:27.440
Can I get that hard drive outta there?

578
00:28:27.440 --> 00:28:30.886
Because then I can hook it up externally
to my system it will show up as a start up

579
00:28:30.886 --> 00:28:32.485
disc and we can bring it in that way.

580
00:28:32.485 --> 00:28:35.435
>> Great information as we've been
continuing along in the Apple

581
00:28:35.435 --> 00:28:37.450
certified support professional series.

582
00:28:37.450 --> 00:28:41.780
Now, we've got more to go in this episode,
but it looks like we come to well,

583
00:28:41.780 --> 00:28:42.980
the end of our time here Don.

584
00:28:42.980 --> 00:28:44.412
You got anything else here for us?

585
00:28:44.412 --> 00:28:48.270
>> All right, so what I've been doing in
this episode is kind of cheating, right?

586
00:28:48.270 --> 00:28:51.550
We wanna get the initial
setup of El Capitan done, so

587
00:28:51.550 --> 00:28:53.910
let's just take our settings from
somewhere else and bring them over.

588
00:28:53.910 --> 00:28:55.020
But what if we don't do that?

589
00:28:55.020 --> 00:28:57.680
What if we want to start from scratch and
really get it set up?

590
00:28:57.680 --> 00:29:00.390
Well that's what we're gonna
see in the next episode.

591
00:29:00.390 --> 00:29:01.200
I know we don't have time here so

00:29:01.200 --> 00:29:04.280
we'll do a part two on this one and
we'll start going through all the little

593
00:29:04.280 --> 00:29:07.470
settings that we might wanna customize
when you first get a new Mac.

594
00:29:07.470 --> 00:29:10.042
If we don't bring our settings
in from another system.

595
00:29:10.042 --> 00:29:12.520
>> All right, well thank you Don, and
thank you everybody out there for

596
00:29:12.520 --> 00:29:13.170
watching us.

597
00:29:13.170 --> 00:29:15.421
Were going to go ahead and
sign out here at ITPro TV.

598
00:29:15.421 --> 00:29:16.639
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

599
00:29:16.639 --> 00:29:17.579
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

600
00:29:17.579 --> 00:29:19.623
>> And we'll see you next time.

601
00:29:19.623 --> 00:29:27.270

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don continue their discussion on the configuration items that most users will take immediately after installing Mac OS X. They demonstrate the steps to get a freshly installed Mac OS X operating system connected to the network. They look at the different steps to get wired and wireless network connection configured.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.102 --> 00:00:10.102
[MUSIC]

2

00:00:18.700 --> 00:00:22.460

7

10

11

12

14

What if this is just

Well that's what we're gonna

20
00:01:00.660 --> 00:01:01.780
I'm gonna try and get through it here, but

00:01:01.780 --> 00:01:03.410
we might have to do
a part three on this one.

22
00:01:03.410 --> 00:01:05.980
So we're just gonna run through some of
the initial things that we've gotta do on

23
00:01:05.980 --> 00:01:09.000
a Mac to get it set up and
configured the way that we want it, and

24
00:01:09.000 --> 00:01:11.160
just get it working the right way for us.

25
00:01:11.160 --> 00:01:13.440
Now, whenever I fire up a new system,

26
00:01:13.440 --> 00:01:17.510
one of the first things I wanna do,
is get it up to date, right?

27
00:01:17.510 --> 00:01:20.690
When you order a Mac, Apple's really
good about shipping stuff to you pretty

28
00:01:20.690 --> 00:01:24.530
quickly, but
they release updates all the time.

29
00:01:24.530 --> 00:01:27.310
And so it might be that you

31
00:01:30.670 --> 00:01:35.443

32

10.11, and

34

36

functionality right away.

38

So when I get a new machine,

I need to have network connectivity and

43

44

You turn on your Mac and
it automatically jumps onto the network.

45
00:02:09.365 --> 00:02:12.650
But most of the time, you're gonna have
to go in there and set some things up.

46
00:02:12.650 --> 00:02:15.310
And so that's what we're gonna take a look
at here at the beginning of this episode,

47
00:02:15.310 --> 00:02:18.660
is getting the network
configured in our new system.

48
00:02:18.660 --> 00:02:24.270
Unfortunately, it doesn't matter if you
have a Mac Mini, a MacPro, a Macbook,

49
00:02:24.270 --> 00:02:28.750
a Macbook Air, or whatever it is, they
all base we could figure the same way.

50
00:02:28.750 --> 00:02:30.890
Its always tend,
you jump in new settings need,

51
00:02:30.890 --> 00:02:32.020
weve got your options right in there.

52
00:02:32.020 --> 00:02:34.340
So let start with that.

53
00:02:34.340 --> 00:02:36.240
Now, when you look out the Mac,

54

connectivity weve got.

55
00:02:38.760 --> 00:02:41.200
This is actually three but
two that we care about here.

56
00:02:41.200 --> 00:02:44.160
Theres wired and wireless.

57
00:02:44.160 --> 00:02:46.990
So wireless, you're gonna have a radio
antennae built into your Mac that will

58
00:02:46.990 --> 00:02:48.640

there on the network and

59
00:02:48.640 --> 00:02:53.070
find wireless systems and connect up and
go without plugging in a cable.

60
00:02:53.070 --> 00:02:55.540
Wired, you're gonna have a physical jack.

61
00:02:55.540 --> 00:02:59.310
If you have an iMac, then on your iMac,
you'll have a physical jack, and you might

62
00:02:59.310 --> 00:03:03.400

Mac plugged in to a physical network.

63
00:03:03.400 --> 00:03:06.740
If you're on a Macbook like mine,
I don't have a physical jack.

64
00:03:06.740 --> 00:03:09.850
And so instead,
I need to connect to a wireless network.

65
00:03:09.850 --> 00:03:12.860
Well, I said I don't have a physical jack,
I actually do.

66
00:03:12.860 --> 00:03:14.070
I'm gonna show this here.

67
00:03:14.070 --> 00:03:18.030
So what we use here in the studio,
wireless networks are great but sometimes

68
00:03:18.030 --> 00:03:24.420

little thunder bolt to RJ 45 adapters.

69
00:03:24.420 --> 00:03:27.280
Apple, they use to include
these with the iMacs but

70
00:03:27.280 --> 00:03:29.040
be always end up having
to by them separate.

71
00:03:29.040 --> 00:03:32.050
But you can pop these on to get a physical
network connection on your device even

72
00:03:32.050 --> 00:03:33.450
though it might not have that jack.

73
00:03:33.450 --> 00:03:37.050
Now, if you have an iMac or
a Mac Pro, even the Mac minis,

74
00:03:37.050 --> 00:03:38.450
they've got the physical jack on them.

75
00:03:38.450 --> 00:03:41.030
But if you have a Mac Book,
Mac Book Air or

76
00:03:41.030 --> 00:03:44.590
any of the laptop devices, they're not
gonna have it, so these come in handy.

77
00:03:44.590 --> 00:03:48.330
So you can add a physical jack
to your system if you want.

78
00:03:48.330 --> 00:03:51.310
And that does make life
a little bit easier for

79
00:03:51.310 --> 00:03:54.730
us if we're trying to get connected and
have a reliable connection.

80
00:03:54.730 --> 00:03:55.930
Wired is really the way to go.

81
00:03:55.930 --> 00:03:59.640
All right, so if you look at my laptop,
and this isn't like a lab machine,

82
00:03:59.640 --> 00:04:01.180
this is my actual laptop.

83
00:04:01.180 --> 00:04:04.190
When I look at it, I just unplugged
that physical network jack, so

84
00:04:04.190 --> 00:04:05.470
I'm not plugged in.

85
00:04:05.470 --> 00:04:10.430
And up here in my menu bar,
you can see up by my clock, I've got this

86
00:04:10.430 --> 00:04:14.130
little symbol right here, and that lets
me know that I'm on a wireless network.

87
00:04:14.130 --> 00:04:17.710
So I'm using the wireless network here
in the studio and that's great, right?

88
00:04:17.710 --> 00:04:20.670
But wireless networks,
they only go so fast, right?

89
00:04:20.670 --> 00:04:23.964
So our network here,
I don't remember Wes, is ours 802.11?

90
00:04:23.964 --> 00:04:24.800
It's not 802.11AC is it?

91
00:04:24.800 --> 00:04:26.750
>> It's not AC, it's N, yeah.

92
00:04:26.750 --> 00:04:29.490
>> N, okay.
So we've got 802.11N, and that means that

93
00:04:29.490 --> 00:04:34.330
we're pushing anywhere from,
I guess it could be as low as 11 megabit,

94
00:04:34.330 --> 00:04:37.700
but all the way up to about 200 megabit,
on the 802.11N network.

95
00:04:37.700 --> 00:04:42.230
Normally you're gonna get somewhere
more like 54 megabit in bandwidth on it.

96
00:04:42.230 --> 00:04:46.350
If I switch to a wired connection though,
I might be able to get 100 megabit or

97
00:04:46.350 --> 00:04:48.280
a gigabit, or even 10 gigabit,

98
00:04:48.280 --> 00:04:50.500
they've got some really fast
networks that are out there.

99
00:04:50.500 --> 00:04:54.620
And a wired connection is always
available, a wireless network,

100
00:04:54.620 --> 00:04:55.990
there's things that can interfere.

101
00:04:55.990 --> 00:04:58.400
I might have a wall in between me and
there,

102
00:04:58.400 --> 00:05:01.090
I might have all sorts of different
things that interfere with that signal.

103
00:05:01.090 --> 00:05:02.830
And the signal starts to degrade.

104
00:05:02.830 --> 00:05:06.090
So when you look at all this wireless
networks that are our there,

105
00:05:06.090 --> 00:05:11.520
this little symbol, well,
those bars all represent signal strength,

106
00:05:11.520 --> 00:05:14.460
and there's five or four bars,
four bars, here we go.

107
00:05:14.460 --> 00:05:19.070
And right now all these wireless networks
from here showing up as four bars each.

108
00:05:19.070 --> 00:05:20.560
That means these are really strong.

109
00:05:20.560 --> 00:05:23.790
The reason they are strong is the access
point is just on the other side of that

110
00:05:23.790 --> 00:05:24.370
wall there.

111
00:05:24.370 --> 00:05:25.680
So, I'm really close.

112
00:05:25.680 --> 00:05:29.220
But the further away from the access
point I get, the weaker that signal gets.

113
00:05:29.220 --> 00:05:31.810
And the weaker that signal gets,
the less bandwidth I can push.

114
00:05:31.810 --> 00:05:36.950
So, I might have 54 megabit when I'm
right next to that 802.11g wireless.

115
00:05:36.950 --> 00:05:41.980
And then as I move 100 feet away, I drop
down to 11 megabit or something like that.

116
00:05:41.980 --> 00:05:43.500
Wireless is not consistent.

117
00:05:43.500 --> 00:05:44.320
Let me just show you.

118
00:05:44.320 --> 00:05:46.270
I know my system was showing four bars.

119
00:05:46.270 --> 00:05:48.500
But I've got a Wi-Fi analyzer here.

120
00:05:48.500 --> 00:05:51.760
And what you'll see is that the ITProTV
wireless here in the studio,

121
00:05:51.760 --> 00:05:54.840
there's actually four
different wireless networks.

122
00:05:54.840 --> 00:05:57.210
Some of them are 2.4 gigahertz.

123
00:05:57.210 --> 00:05:58.840
Some of them are 5 gigahertz.

124
00:05:58.840 --> 00:06:03.262
5 gigahertz is faster, but
it doesn't penetrate walls as well.

125
00:06:03.262 --> 00:06:06.680
2.4 gigahertz is slower, but
it does penetrate walls better.

126
00:06:06.680 --> 00:06:10.400
And so our access points have both of them
built in, and they're Apple access points,

127
00:06:10.400 --> 00:06:11.830
they're little AirPorts.

128
00:06:11.830 --> 00:06:13.580
And we've got two of them,

129
00:06:13.580 --> 00:06:18.600
so I see the two antennas on the first one
and the two antennas on the second one.

130
00:06:18.600 --> 00:06:21.790
Now I had four bars on my laptop and
if I look over here,

131
00:06:21.790 --> 00:06:26.360
you'll see where on this access
point I've got a good strong signal.

132
00:06:26.360 --> 00:06:29.350
But on the other access points
it gets weaker and weaker and

133
00:06:29.350 --> 00:06:30.380
this one is nonexistent.

134
00:06:30.380 --> 00:06:32.370
In fact, I'm not even seeing that anymore.

135
00:06:32.370 --> 00:06:33.870
I'm too far away from it.

136
00:06:33.870 --> 00:06:36.070
But it's remembering here in this
program that if I move closer,

137
00:06:36.070 --> 00:06:37.310
the signal will light up.

138
00:06:37.310 --> 00:06:40.230
So, these change based
on just little things.

139
00:06:40.230 --> 00:06:44.420
Even if I were to lift my laptop up and
start moving it around,

140
00:06:44.420 --> 00:06:47.670
like this, we'll start to see
the signals adjust because,

141
00:06:47.670 --> 00:06:50.270
the antennas are built
into the lid of my laptop.

142
00:06:50.270 --> 00:06:52.420
So, it's going to adjust that setting and
put it in different places.

143
00:06:52.420 --> 00:06:56.550
So understand that wireless
networks are not as reliable.

144
00:06:56.550 --> 00:06:59.880
So when you get that nice new Mac and
you're ready to set it up,

145
00:06:59.880 --> 00:07:03.960
you may want to set up a wired connection,

146
00:07:03.960 --> 00:07:06.930
It's entirely up to you which

147
00:07:06.930 --> 00:07:12.500

149
00:07:15.620 --> 00:07:19.370

150
00:07:19.370 --> 00:07:23.440
And when you go on the network this is
where we could go for wired and wireless.

151
00:07:23.440 --> 00:07:26.880
What you're gonna see on the left is
a list of all your network connections.

152
00:07:26.880 --> 00:07:29.290
And see this one has an ethernet
connection and that's it.

153
00:07:29.290 --> 00:07:30.580
That's the only thing that I've got,

154
00:07:30.580 --> 00:07:34.240
I just have a wired connection,
was kind of I'm in a virtual machine.

155
00:07:34.240 --> 00:07:37.720
Every Mac these days has
a wireless adapter built into it.

156
00:07:37.720 --> 00:07:41.450
So you normally see a minimum of
one ethernet and one wireless.

157
00:07:41.450 --> 00:07:43.670
Well, I guess you don't
always see an ethernet.

158
00:07:43.670 --> 00:07:44.740
Take my actual laptop.

159
00:07:44.740 --> 00:07:46.330
So let me go back to
my actual laptop here.

160
00:07:47.660 --> 00:07:49.450
If I go into my system preferences.

161
00:07:50.540 --> 00:07:55.196
And, I go into network,
I've got all sorts of networks on mine.

162
00:07:55.196 --> 00:07:59.146
You'll notice this list is full of all
sorts of other stuff that wasn't In

163
00:07:59.146 --> 00:08:00.430
that virtual machine.

164
00:08:00.430 --> 00:08:01.571
Well the virtual machine is nice and
clean.

165
00:08:01.571 --> 00:08:03.430
It's a brand new install of El Capitan.

166
00:08:03.430 --> 00:08:06.290
My laptop on the other hand,
I've installed all sorts of junk on here.

167
00:08:06.290 --> 00:08:09.250
So I do see my Wi-Fi connection,
right here.

168
00:08:09.250 --> 00:08:11.798
So I have Wi-Fi, and as I scroll down,

169
00:08:11.798 --> 00:08:15.747
I'll see other things like
a Thunderbolt Ethernet bridge.

170
00:08:15.747 --> 00:08:18.330
And see how it's not connected and
it's red?

171

00:26:09.347 --> 00:26:12.055
settings, does that include any
permissions that are set on any

539
00:26:12.055 --> 00:26:14.479
of the folders or
applications he might have had as well?

540
00:26:14.479 --> 00:26:18.440
>> [LAUGH] Glad you asked that,
Wes, cuz it's yes and no.

541
00:26:18.440 --> 00:26:21.788
Yes on his folder, he now will have
all his permissions on the folder.

542
00:26:21.788 --> 00:26:26.609
But because I created a new account for
him, any groups that he was in,

543
00:26:26.609 --> 00:26:28.600
he's not a part of anymore.

544
00:26:28.600 --> 00:26:31.880
So if we look at it here,
I made Mike a standard user,

545
00:26:31.880 --> 00:26:35.140
I even forgot to make him an admin because
he was an admin before, now he's not.

546
00:26:35.140 --> 00:26:38.270
So I need to make him an admin if
I want him to be back that way, so

547
00:26:38.270 --> 00:26:39.620
I can check that and make it.

548
00:26:39.620 --> 00:26:41.500
But I had also put him in a group.

549
00:26:41.500 --> 00:26:43.220
We have this show host group.

550
00:26:43.220 --> 00:26:46.390
And well, actually you know what
it did go on back in there.

551
00:26:46.390 --> 00:26:48.450
Well now that really is interesting,
I didn't know it did that.

552
00:26:48.450 --> 00:26:52.210
I was pretty certain that it didn't
because it's a different UUID, but

553
00:26:52.210 --> 00:26:56.500
in this case maybe he miraculously got
the same, that would be scary if he did.

554
00:26:56.500 --> 00:26:58.890
That shouldn't happen, but
yeah I guess it did put him back in there.

555
00:26:58.890 --> 00:27:02.195
You definitely want to double-check it,
because it is technically a new user

556
00:27:02.195 --> 00:27:04.720
account and
it very well may not be in those groups.

557
00:27:04.720 --> 00:27:06.340
And so you may need to add him back in.

558
00:27:06.340 --> 00:27:07.710
Normally I would say
you definitely need to,

559
00:27:07.710 --> 00:27:11.100
but in this case I can see he made
it right back into that group.

560
00:27:11.100 --> 00:27:13.850
So sometimes things go strange.

561
00:27:13.850 --> 00:27:16.638
But once that's done, the user account
is back and now you're recovered.

562
00:27:16.638 --> 00:27:18.518
So he's back to normal and
you're in there.

563
00:27:18.518 --> 00:27:21.100
So there's no official way
to undelete the account.

564
00:27:21.100 --> 00:27:22.530
You just create a new one
with the same name and

565
00:27:22.530 --> 00:27:25.730
if you've got the existing folder,
it will connect those.

566
00:27:25.730 --> 00:27:28.730
If you don't have the existing folder
though then it is an all new account and

567
00:27:28.730 --> 00:27:29.590
he won't have that data.

568
00:27:31.078 --> 00:27:34.980
All right, so that's basically how we get
those restored and get those in place.

569
00:27:34.980 --> 00:27:38.351
But we had a question in our Q &
A forums the other day that was centered

570
00:27:38.351 --> 00:27:39.800
around this.

571
00:27:39.800 --> 00:27:40.960
Where somebody said, hey,

572
00:27:40.960 --> 00:27:45.390
when I join an open directory I might have
a Don Pezet account here on this machine.

573
00:27:45.390 --> 00:27:47.328
But I just joined an Open Directory, and

574
00:27:47.328 --> 00:27:49.958
I've got a Don Pezet account
up in the Open Directory.

575
00:27:49.958 --> 00:27:53.368
When I sign it with my Open Directory
account, do I get an all-new profile?

576
00:27:53.368 --> 00:27:54.340
And the answer is yes.

577
00:27:54.340 --> 00:27:57.200
Your Open Directory account is
different from your local account, and

578
00:27:57.200 --> 00:27:59.080
so you lose everything.

579
00:27:59.080 --> 00:28:02.430
But it's not lost, it's just in
a different folder on the hard drive.

580
00:28:02.430 --> 00:28:06.930
So after you log in that first time,
you can browse to your old folder and

581
00:28:06.930 --> 00:28:07.845
get your data out of there.

582
00:28:07.845 --> 00:28:09.870
You'll have to clear permissions on it,
right, so

583
00:28:09.870 --> 00:28:11.440
you have to provide your user name and
password.

584
00:28:11.440 --> 00:28:14.280
But once you do that you can grab
your data and bring it over and

585
00:28:14.280 --> 00:28:15.410
now you've got it copied over.

586
00:28:15.410 --> 00:28:19.200
So you do kind of get a new profile when
you join a directory and I'm talking about

587
00:28:19.200 --> 00:28:22.260
Apple's Open Directory but it's the same
thing with Microsoft's Active Directory.

588
00:28:22.260 --> 00:28:23.100
That's a different account.

589
00:28:23.100 --> 00:28:24.200
It's an account stored somewhere else.

590
00:28:24.200 --> 00:28:25.478
It's not your local account.

591
00:28:25.478 --> 00:28:26.798
>> All right, great information.

592
00:28:26.798 --> 00:28:30.490
Remember in this episode, we've been
talking about managing the user accounts.

593
00:28:30.490 --> 00:28:32.158
Do remember this is a Part 2.

594
00:28:32.158 --> 00:28:35.200
In Part 1, we talked about the type
of accounts you can encounter when

595
00:28:35.200 --> 00:28:36.565
you're in the Mac world here.

596
00:28:36.565 --> 00:28:38.450
Don, got anything else for us in this one?

597
00:28:38.450 --> 00:28:40.000
>> That's about it for user accounts.

598
00:28:40.000 --> 00:28:41.910
We are gonna do some other
episodes that address user

599
00:28:41.910 --> 00:28:43.190
accounts in a different manner.

600
00:28:43.190 --> 00:28:46.540
So I want to talk about multiple user
accounts and a few other things there.

601
00:28:46.540 --> 00:28:47.620
So stay tuned for those.

602
00:28:47.620 --> 00:28:50.468
But as far as the creation and use of
the accounts, this is pretty much it.

603
00:28:50.468 --> 00:28:55.182
>> All right, this does look like a good
place to wrap it up before I'm hired and

604
00:28:55.182 --> 00:28:57.846
fired, so many times in a single episode.

605
00:28:57.846 --> 00:28:58.900
>> Been a rough episode for you.

606
00:28:58.900 --> 00:29:01.780
>> It really has, so while I'm still
employed, we're gonna go ahead and

607
00:29:01.780 --> 00:29:02.408
sign off here.

608
00:29:02.408 --> 00:29:04.588
For ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Brian.

609
00:29:04.588 --> 00:29:05.388
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

610
00:29:05.388 --> 00:29:07.368
>> And we'll see you next time.

611
00:29:07.368 --> 00:29:14.850
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don highlight the differences between using a Mac with a single user account, versus sharing a system with multiple users. They demonstrate how to quickly move between users with Fast User Switching and ends the show discussion some of the security concerns that come along with sharing your machine.
episodes.title: Multiple User Accounts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.033 --> 00:00:10.033
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:13.087 --> 00:00:17.023
Another exciting episode here at ITProTV,
I'm your host Wes Bryan,

3
00:00:17.023 --> 00:00:21.228
and in today's episode we're gonna be
moving through our Apple certified

4
00:00:21.228 --> 00:00:25.720
support professional program and we've
got none other than Don Pezet to help.

5
00:00:25.720 --> 00:00:27.220
Don, how you doing sir?

6
00:00:27.220 --> 00:00:28.220
>> I am doing great, Wes.

7
00:00:28.220 --> 00:00:31.400
Ready to kind of continue on with what
we've done in our last few episodes,

8
00:00:31.400 --> 00:00:32.870
we've been talking about user accounts,
right?

9
00:00:32.870 --> 00:00:35.260
And we got a chance to see how to create
them and work with them and all that.

10
00:00:35.260 --> 00:00:36.690
I want to switch gears a bit here.

11
00:00:36.690 --> 00:00:40.020
And I want to talk about some of
the things you need to be aware of,

12
00:00:40.020 --> 00:00:42.070
when you have more than one user account.

13
00:00:42.070 --> 00:00:44.450
When you get a brand new Mac,
you power it on the first time,

14
00:00:44.450 --> 00:00:47.230
it runs a setup assistant, and
it asks you to pick a user name.

15
00:00:47.230 --> 00:00:50.760
And it makes an admin account for
you, so you have one account.

16
00:00:50.760 --> 00:00:54.650
And the system runs great,
it runs just fine with that one account.

17
00:00:54.650 --> 00:00:58.580
But, if you want to create
more than one user account

18
00:00:58.580 --> 00:01:00.140
it starts to behave
a little differently and

19
00:01:00.140 --> 00:01:04.020
we need to understand what that behaviour
is and how it works, all right.

20
00:01:04.020 --> 00:01:06.631
So, basically let's start with why I
would want more than one user account.

21
00:01:06.631 --> 00:01:10.141
And if you watch the user episodes
you already kind of understand why.

22
00:01:10.141 --> 00:01:13.390
Users may want to have different settings.

23
00:01:13.390 --> 00:01:16.260
If I want users to have
nice separate environments,

24
00:01:16.260 --> 00:01:17.960
multiple user accounts is the way to go.

25
00:01:17.960 --> 00:01:21.410
So let's say that I share
my computer with Wes.

26
00:01:21.410 --> 00:01:23.920
So this laptop I just leave
right here on the desk and

27
00:01:23.920 --> 00:01:28.410
at any point during the day one of
the show hosts can come in and use it.

28
00:01:28.410 --> 00:01:32.560
I might want to set a Star Trek wallpaper,
and

29
00:01:32.560 --> 00:01:34.820
Wes wants to set a Star Wars wallpaper.

30
00:01:34.820 --> 00:01:37.600
And we can have our Star Wars
versus Star Trek battle.

31
00:01:37.600 --> 00:01:39.240
And so you want the different wallpaper.

32
00:01:39.240 --> 00:01:42.760
Well I don't wanna come in and
have stinking Kylo Ren on my laptop or

33
00:01:42.760 --> 00:01:44.410
something so
I'm gonna want to change that.

34
00:01:44.410 --> 00:01:47.360
If we just have one account,
you're battling against each other.

35
00:01:47.360 --> 00:01:49.190
You also have no privacy.

36
00:01:49.190 --> 00:01:51.810
So if I create documents,
like a termination notice for

37
00:01:51.810 --> 00:01:54.860
Wes, he could just browse right in the
documents and see that and be like, ooh,

38
00:01:54.860 --> 00:01:56.700
I might need to get my resume ready,
right.

39
00:01:56.700 --> 00:02:01.380
So if we wanna keep things private or just
have your own separation, keep your own

40
00:02:01.380 --> 00:02:04.300
settings and preferences, you'll want
to create more than one user account.

41
00:02:04.300 --> 00:02:06.340
It's easy enough,
we've seen it in other episodes.

42
00:02:06.340 --> 00:02:09.760
You just jump in and
you start to create new accounts, right.

43
00:02:09.760 --> 00:02:14.700
But, the moment you create
a second account on your system,

44
00:02:14.700 --> 00:02:16.900
the behavior of that system changes,
all right.

45
00:02:16.900 --> 00:02:17.870
Let me show you what I mean.

46
00:02:17.870 --> 00:02:20.920
So here I'm on a,
this is a stock install of Yosemite.

47
00:02:20.920 --> 00:02:24.590
I just installed it and
in the Wizard, the set-up assistant,

48
00:02:24.590 --> 00:02:27.130
I created an account called Don Pezet,
and that's who I'm logged in as.

49
00:02:27.130 --> 00:02:30.700
So if I go into my system preferences and
I go into users and

50
00:02:30.700 --> 00:02:33.170
groups, we've just got one account,
Don Pezet.

51
00:02:33.170 --> 00:02:37.170
I'm an admin, the guest user is
turned off, and that's it, okay?

52
00:02:37.170 --> 00:02:41.960
Now if I log out,
when I first power on the computer,

53
00:02:41.960 --> 00:02:43.490
it's gonna take me to the log on screen.

54
00:02:43.490 --> 00:02:46.550
And at the log on screen,
I'm just gonna see, Don Pezet.

55
00:02:46.550 --> 00:02:47.510
That's it, right there.

56
00:02:47.510 --> 00:02:50.010
And if I hit this little back arrow,
it doesn't really do anything,

57
00:02:50.010 --> 00:02:51.830
cuz I've only got one account.

58
00:02:51.830 --> 00:02:52.980
And I provide my password.

59
00:02:52.980 --> 00:02:56.290
If somebody wants to use the computer
they've got to have my password,

60
00:02:56.290 --> 00:02:56.970
it's the only one.

61
00:02:58.170 --> 00:03:02.280
But the moment I create a second account,
now I'll have more than one icon

62
00:03:02.280 --> 00:03:05.540
on that screen, one for
each of the users on the system.

63
00:03:05.540 --> 00:03:07.430
And now other people can log in.

64
00:03:08.460 --> 00:03:14.180
Now, when they log in they have
exclusive access to that system.

65
00:03:14.180 --> 00:03:16.650
But I might want to make
it where it's shared.

66
00:03:16.650 --> 00:03:19.380
Let me explain the problem
that we bump into.

67
00:03:19.380 --> 00:03:21.620
So, right now, I've got one user account.

68
00:03:21.620 --> 00:03:26.260
If I lock my screen, a screensaver
comes on, it's got a password on it,

69
00:03:26.260 --> 00:03:29.070
anybody who walks up to this computer,
they can't use it.

70
00:03:29.070 --> 00:03:31.780
It's locked, it's locked just for me.

71
00:03:31.780 --> 00:03:35.850
But when I create a second account,
when I go into system preferences here and

72
00:03:35.850 --> 00:03:38.400
go into users and groups,
I can create a second account.

73
00:03:38.400 --> 00:03:41.500
Because I want somebody else
to be able to use my machine.

74
00:03:41.500 --> 00:03:45.790
The moment I do that, it's gonna turn
on what's called fast user switching.

75
00:03:45.790 --> 00:03:50.120
If you look up here at my menu bar, right
now I've got the clock and spotlight and

76
00:03:50.120 --> 00:03:52.550
notifications, right, and that's it.

77
00:03:52.550 --> 00:03:55.180
But the moment I create a second user,
that's gonna change.

78
00:03:55.180 --> 00:03:58.470
So I'm gonna create an account here for
Wes Bryan.

79
00:03:58.470 --> 00:04:01.940
And so we'll create that account and
give him a password, and

80
00:04:01.940 --> 00:04:03.770
I'll just make him a standard user.

81
00:04:03.770 --> 00:04:05.790
So I'm gonna create that account.

82
00:04:05.790 --> 00:04:08.870
Now once that account's created,
watch my menu bar up here.

83
00:04:08.870 --> 00:04:10.980
Now, instead of clock, spotlight,

84
00:04:10.980 --> 00:04:15.560
notifications, I have clock,
my name, spotlight, notifications.

85
00:04:15.560 --> 00:04:16.930
What's that all about?

86
00:04:16.930 --> 00:04:19.430
Well, this is fast user switching.

87
00:04:19.430 --> 00:04:22.940
I can click that and I can see
the other users on the system and

88
00:04:22.940 --> 00:04:25.780
I can switch over to one of them,
all right?

89
00:04:25.780 --> 00:04:28.880
So I could come in here and I could
say I wanna switch over to Wes Bryan.

90
00:04:28.880 --> 00:04:33.620
And when I do that,
it's me because I'm still logged in, but

91
00:04:33.620 --> 00:04:35.080
now he's logged in also.

92
00:04:35.080 --> 00:04:38.040
You can have more than one person
logged in at the same time and

93
00:04:38.040 --> 00:04:42.580
you can switch back and forth by using
this menu right here, all right?

94
00:04:42.580 --> 00:04:45.000
Now if I choose Login Window,

95
00:04:46.400 --> 00:04:48.440
what that's gonna do is it's gonna
take me back to the login screen.

96
00:04:48.440 --> 00:04:52.400
And on the login screen I now see
two icons, one for each user.

97
00:04:52.400 --> 00:04:53.660
One for me and

98
00:04:53.660 --> 00:04:57.500
that little orange check mark, that lets
me know that I'm currently logged in.

99
00:04:57.500 --> 00:05:00.750
I'm already logged in and
I'm running stuff and I'm doing things.

100
00:05:00.750 --> 00:05:02.180
Wes doesn't have a check mark.

101
00:05:02.180 --> 00:05:04.380
He's never logged in before, okay.

102
00:05:04.380 --> 00:05:06.102
So he can log in right now,

103
00:05:06.102 --> 00:05:10.350
my stuff's still running in the background
and he logs in and he's able to work too.

104
00:05:10.350 --> 00:05:14.630
So let me just log back in as me,
and I'm gonna run some programs.

105
00:05:14.630 --> 00:05:17.980
So I've got this thing fired up.

106
00:05:17.980 --> 00:05:22.140
I'll fire up text edit and
maybe I'll start writing a document.

107
00:05:22.140 --> 00:05:26.320
So this is an important document,
only I'm not gonna save it,

108
00:05:26.320 --> 00:05:28.000
I'm just gonna leave it right
there running in memory.

109
00:05:28.000 --> 00:05:30.870
If you shut your computer off you
kind of lose what's in memory.

110
00:05:30.870 --> 00:05:34.420
Well, actually there's that local time
machine now where it'll kinda save it, but

111
00:05:34.420 --> 00:05:36.040
anyhow normally you'd lose it.

112
00:05:36.040 --> 00:05:38.610
If I fire up Safari and go to a webpage,

113
00:05:38.610 --> 00:05:41.392
maybe I go to our page,
let's go to Itpro.tv.

114
00:05:41.392 --> 00:05:43.230
So I'm just gonna browse around, so

115
00:05:43.230 --> 00:05:47.470
I'm doing a couple of different things
here on the system logged in as me.

116
00:05:48.490 --> 00:05:51.650
When I switch to Wes, so
I'm gonna jump over to Wes and

117
00:05:51.650 --> 00:05:54.610
I just hit that little name menu and
chose Wes's name.

118
00:05:54.610 --> 00:06:00.030
I can log in as him, he's logging in,
I'm still logged in in the background.

119
00:06:00.030 --> 00:06:01.790
All those programs that I'm running?

120
00:06:01.790 --> 00:06:03.970
Theyre still running in the background,
too.

121
00:06:03.970 --> 00:06:05.070
And he's gonna log in and

122
00:06:05.070 --> 00:06:08.550
now he can use the computer and
my stuff is still there, right.

123
00:06:08.550 --> 00:06:11.760
This way we can easily share the computer,
he can jump in,

124
00:06:11.760 --> 00:06:15.990
he's got his own account, he has his
own home folder, profile and all that.

125
00:06:15.990 --> 00:06:20.370
He can change the wallpaper all he wants,
and at the end of the day I can come back

126
00:06:20.370 --> 00:06:23.400
and switch it back to me and everything's
back to the way that it was for me.

127
00:06:23.400 --> 00:06:26.670
In fact, all my applications
are still running, right?

128
00:06:26.670 --> 00:06:29.290
All the programs I was in, they're
running, they're doing their thing.

129
00:06:29.290 --> 00:06:31.760
Maybe I left some long running task going,
and so

130
00:06:31.760 --> 00:06:33.310
it's still doing that in the background.

131
00:06:34.530 --> 00:06:37.400
But there's certain behaviors that
are now going to be different.

132
00:06:38.700 --> 00:06:41.640
The biggest difference is going to
be that we have concurrent use.

133
00:06:41.640 --> 00:06:45.490
We have more than one user
running at the same time.

134
00:06:45.490 --> 00:06:47.790
Wes is running and I'm running.

135
00:06:47.790 --> 00:06:51.530
We both have little orange
check marks by our name now.

136
00:06:51.530 --> 00:06:55.570
And that means that I can have contention
that I wouldn't really normally have.

137
00:06:55.570 --> 00:06:58.880
Contention is when two people try and
access the same thing at the same time.

138
00:07:00.270 --> 00:07:05.125
As far as the built-in software in Mac OS,
all of it is designed for

139
00:07:05.125 --> 00:07:07.230
multi-user environments.

140
00:07:07.230 --> 00:07:09.310
But what if I load third-party software?

141
00:07:09.310 --> 00:07:14.260
What if I've got Microsoft Word or
QuickBooks or Adobe Photoshop,

142
00:07:14.260 --> 00:07:15.430
something like that installed?

143
00:07:16.590 --> 00:07:21.442
They're not really designed for two copies
to be running at the same time, and

144
00:07:21.442 --> 00:07:25.050
even the ones that are aren't designed
to be able to access the same

145
00:07:25.050 --> 00:07:26.650
file at the same time.

146
00:07:26.650 --> 00:07:29.960
What if Wes fires up Photoshop and
he's editing a picture, and

147
00:07:29.960 --> 00:07:33.470
I fire up Photoshop and
I'm editing the same picture.

148
00:07:33.470 --> 00:07:34.830
What's gonna happen?

149
00:07:34.830 --> 00:07:40.460
Well usually it lets us do it and
one person saves and

150
00:07:40.460 --> 00:07:43.640
the other person saves and
