>> And we'll see you next time.

664
00:31:41.090 --> 00:31:49.280
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don introduce us to the ways Mac OS handles disks and their associated data. They discuss the types of media options when supporting OS X including internal and external as well as removeable media types.
episodes.title: File Storage
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.035 --> 00:00:15.050
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITPro.tv.

3
00:00:15.050 --> 00:00:16.428
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and

4
00:00:16.428 --> 00:00:20.239
in today's episode we're continuing along
the journey that leads ultimately to

5
00:00:20.239 --> 00:00:23.350
the Apple certified support
professional certification.

6
00:00:23.350 --> 00:00:25.731
We've got none other than Mr.
Don Pezet here to help us out with that.

7
00:00:25.731 --> 00:00:26.787
Don, how you doing, sir?

8
00:00:26.787 --> 00:00:28.342
>> I am doing great, Wes.

9
00:00:28.342 --> 00:00:31.126
Ready to continue on with
our professional adventure.

10
00:00:31.126 --> 00:00:34.350
In this episode, we're gonna be
taking a look at disk storage.

11
00:00:34.350 --> 00:00:38.070
I know we've briefly touched on disk
storage back when we were talking about

12
00:00:38.070 --> 00:00:41.330
installing OS X, cuz you have to
pick what hard drive to install.

13
00:00:41.330 --> 00:00:44.030
But that's only the tip of the iceberg,
right.

14
00:00:44.030 --> 00:00:44.951
You do have your internal hard drive.

15
00:00:44.951 --> 00:00:45.705
That's great.

16
00:00:45.705 --> 00:00:47.041
But as you use your system,

17
00:00:47.041 --> 00:00:50.123
there's gonna be quite a bit of
removable media you bring in and

18
00:00:50.123 --> 00:00:54.045
out of your environment, and there's
a number of different types of storage.

19
00:00:54.045 --> 00:00:57.123
And so we just need to be familiar
with what's supported by OS X,

20
00:00:57.123 --> 00:00:59.346
what we can do with it,
what it looks like, and

21
00:00:59.346 --> 00:01:02.770
what's kind of required of us to use
those different types of storage.

22
00:01:02.770 --> 00:01:05.350
So we're gonna see all of that
right here in this episode.

23
00:01:05.350 --> 00:01:08.367
And I've been a little aggressive in
my note taking for this episode, so

24
00:01:08.367 --> 00:01:09.806
we might have to do a part two on it.

25
00:01:09.806 --> 00:01:13.070
Just be prepared,
[LAUGH] and see how it goes.

26
00:01:13.070 --> 00:01:16.862
But let's just kick things
off talking about storage.

27
00:01:16.862 --> 00:01:21.355
Now, when you buy a Mac,
it doesn't matter if it's a laptop, or

28
00:01:21.355 --> 00:01:23.680
a desktop, or whatever.

29
00:01:23.680 --> 00:01:26.745
At a minimum,
it's gonna have one hard drive in it.

30
00:01:26.745 --> 00:01:28.911
Because the operating system
has to go somewhere, and

31
00:01:28.911 --> 00:01:30.800
it's going to be on that hard drive.

32
00:01:30.800 --> 00:01:33.420
Now, when you go and
buy a device from Apple,

33
00:01:33.420 --> 00:01:36.230
there's two different types of hard
drives you can pick from these days.

34
00:01:36.230 --> 00:01:37.280
There used to be three.

35
00:01:37.280 --> 00:01:38.894
I think there's really only two now.

36
00:01:38.894 --> 00:01:42.854
So there's traditional hard drives,
or what Apple calls HDDs,

37
00:01:42.854 --> 00:01:47.174
the hard disk drives, and
then there's the newer Flash based drives,

38
00:01:47.174 --> 00:01:50.690
which are solid state digital drives,
or SSDs.

39
00:01:50.690 --> 00:01:54.790
Now the SSDs are way faster
than the older hard drives,

40
00:01:54.790 --> 00:01:57.566
the older magnetic spinning disks.

41
00:01:57.566 --> 00:02:01.020
They were called spinning discs because
inside of them there's actually

42
00:02:01.020 --> 00:02:04.080
these platters, kind of like a CD or
a record player or whatever,

43
00:02:04.080 --> 00:02:07.720
and it has to spin around, and a little
motorized arm has to move to find data.

44
00:02:07.720 --> 00:02:09.278
And that process is slow.

45
00:02:09.278 --> 00:02:10.983
It takes a while.

46
00:02:10.983 --> 00:02:15.026
Versus SSDs, with Solid State Digital,
they've got flash chips inside them,

47
00:02:15.026 --> 00:02:16.720
they've got memory.

48
00:02:16.720 --> 00:02:18.513
And if I want to read
data out of that memory,

49
00:02:18.513 --> 00:02:20.514
I just go right to that address and
get that data.

50
00:02:20.514 --> 00:02:24.196
There's no mechanical arm, there's
no motor, there's no disk spinning,

51
00:02:24.196 --> 00:02:26.750
there's no moving parts whatsoever.

52
00:02:26.750 --> 00:02:28.703
And that makes SSD more durable.

53
00:02:28.703 --> 00:02:32.110
If you drop your laptop,
a spinning disk can get damaged.

54
00:02:32.110 --> 00:02:34.450
But if you drop your laptop,
your SSD is likely gonna be fine.

55
00:02:34.450 --> 00:02:38.090
Your display is more likely
to break than your SSD is.

56
00:02:38.090 --> 00:02:41.292
It's also faster so
it's really the ideal solution.

57
00:02:41.292 --> 00:02:43.010
We want to go with SSD's.

58
00:02:43.010 --> 00:02:48.050
If they're so much better, why does Apple
still sell traditional hard drives?

59
00:02:48.050 --> 00:02:49.568
Well, it comes down to two things.

60
00:02:49.568 --> 00:02:52.100
There's two things that we
can't do well with SSD.

61
00:02:52.100 --> 00:02:54.460
One is money, right?

62
00:02:54.460 --> 00:02:56.794
SSD's cost more money.

63
00:02:56.794 --> 00:03:00.029
So for me to get 256 gig SSD,

64
00:03:00.029 --> 00:03:05.960
cost about the same as a one
terabyte spinning disc.

65
00:03:05.960 --> 00:03:08.758
So I can get lot more storage for
a lot less money if

66
00:03:08.758 --> 00:03:13.346
I stick with the traditional spinning
disc, but it's lower if I get more of it.

67
00:03:13.346 --> 00:03:15.331
So I kinda had to choose.

68
00:03:15.331 --> 00:03:17.247
The other thing is heat.

69
00:03:17.247 --> 00:03:20.620
SSDs put off more heat than
traditional spinning disks.

70
00:03:20.620 --> 00:03:22.978
Now, in a desktop we don't
necessarily worry about that.

71
00:03:22.978 --> 00:03:26.671
If you have a Mac Pro it's got a big fan
inside of it and it can move air and

72
00:03:26.671 --> 00:03:28.810
temperature is not a problem.

73
00:03:28.810 --> 00:03:33.093
But if you've got a Mac Mini, that's a lot
of hardware jammed in a very small space.

74
00:03:33.093 --> 00:03:36.615
If you've got a Macbook Air that's
a lot of hardware jammed in

75
00:03:36.615 --> 00:03:38.290
an even smaller space.

76
00:03:38.290 --> 00:03:40.084
Then that heat dissipation
becomes a problem.

77
00:03:40.084 --> 00:03:43.487
And so large quantities of SSD aren't
necessarily possible cuz they put out too

78
00:03:43.487 --> 00:03:44.010
much heat.

79
00:03:44.010 --> 00:03:48.227
Now, they have gotten way better in recent
years than they were even five years ago.

80
00:03:48.227 --> 00:03:51.890
So you're starting to see more and
more and more storage available.

81
00:03:51.890 --> 00:03:53.218
You can get Macs with 500 GB of SSD.

82
00:03:53.218 --> 00:03:55.210
Thats what I have in my laptop.

83
00:03:55.210 --> 00:03:57.637
Or you can get,
they've creeped up a little higher.

84
00:03:57.637 --> 00:03:59.030
You're starting to see bigger numbers.

85
00:03:59.030 --> 00:04:02.283
I don't think anybody's
really broken a terabyte.

86
00:04:02.283 --> 00:04:04.255
You can go out and
get more than a terabyte but

87
00:04:04.255 --> 00:04:07.346
I think if you go to Apple Store,
a terabyte is about the most SSD based

88
00:04:07.346 --> 00:04:10.920
storage that you can get versus spinning
disc where you can get three terabyte,

89
00:04:10.920 --> 00:04:14.210
four terabyte even six terabyte
options that are out there.

90
00:04:14.210 --> 00:04:18.115
So those are the two main options HDD and
SSD right?

91
00:04:18.115 --> 00:04:23.740
The traditional spinning hard discs and
the newer solid state digital discs.

92
00:04:23.740 --> 00:04:25.261
Theres few other ones that are out there.

93
00:04:25.261 --> 00:04:28.170
For example, you might hear
whats called a Fusion Drive.

94
00:04:28.170 --> 00:04:30.564
So for a little while Apple
was producing these and

95
00:04:30.564 --> 00:04:32.502
I dont think they sell them anymore but

96
00:04:32.502 --> 00:04:36.041
it was really up until like last year
they were doing these Fusion Drives.

97
00:04:36.041 --> 00:04:40.950
And what a Fusion Drive was, was actually
not one drive, it was two drives.

98
00:04:40.950 --> 00:04:46.892
With a Fusion Drive, you had a traditional
hard drive that was a spinning disk,

99
00:04:46.892 --> 00:04:50.364
and you had an SSD, but
it was a very small SSD.

100
00:04:50.364 --> 00:04:54.090
So for example, I think I was using
a Mac Mini on the show the other day.

101
00:04:54.090 --> 00:04:59.123
It had a one terabyte spinning disk,
and a 128 gig SSD,

102
00:04:59.123 --> 00:05:05.418
and Mac OS will take those and bond
them together to create a Fusion Disk.

103
00:05:05.418 --> 00:05:10.110
And the way a fusion disk works is the
data you access the most frequently gets

104
00:05:10.110 --> 00:05:11.770
moved to the SSD.

105
00:05:11.770 --> 00:05:15.414
And data that you access less frequently
gets put over on the spinning disk.

106
00:05:15.414 --> 00:05:17.474
And that way, you get a ton of storage and

107
00:05:17.474 --> 00:05:21.300
you get the benefits of speed without
having to dump all that money into it.

108
00:05:21.300 --> 00:05:25.253
So Fusion Disks are kinda neat, but the
price of SSD has come down a good bit, and

109
00:05:25.253 --> 00:05:28.970
so we're gonna see those go away because
there's some added problems with

110
00:05:28.970 --> 00:05:31.288
Fusion Disks that make
them not really ideal.

111
00:05:31.288 --> 00:05:34.960
It's two disks, but
your system sees it as one.

112
00:05:34.960 --> 00:05:37.614
Well, what happens if one
of those disks fails?

113
00:05:37.614 --> 00:05:38.682
You lose everything.

114
00:05:38.682 --> 00:05:41.390
It's not like you can salvage
what's left on the other disk.

115
00:05:41.390 --> 00:05:42.970
There's ways, but not officially.

116
00:05:42.970 --> 00:05:45.260
So you lose that data.

117
00:05:45.260 --> 00:05:47.914
So they're more prone to failure,
versus if you had a single disk.

118
00:05:47.914 --> 00:05:51.211
Now, single disk is prone to failure too,
but you just do a time machine backup,

119
00:05:51.211 --> 00:05:53.120
you can restore,
it's not that big of a deal.

120
00:05:53.120 --> 00:05:55.034
Fusion Disk is a little bit more complex,
so

121
00:05:55.034 --> 00:05:57.226
they're not the greatest
solution in the world.

122
00:05:57.226 --> 00:05:59.325
If you can go all SSD,
that's certainly the best, but

123
00:05:59.325 --> 00:06:01.250
you're gonna have to come
out of pocket for that.

124
00:06:01.250 --> 00:06:02.118
It's expensive.

125
00:06:02.118 --> 00:06:05.059
All right, so those are the two main
types of storage were gonna see,

126
00:06:05.059 --> 00:06:07.430
spinning disc and solid state disc.

127
00:06:07.430 --> 00:06:09.203
But those aren't the only ones.

128
00:06:09.203 --> 00:06:12.890
If you have an older Mac, you might have
other types of removable media that can be

129
00:06:12.890 --> 00:06:14.670
all sorts of different things.

130
00:06:14.670 --> 00:06:16.043
Yeah Don.
I was going to ask about that,

131
00:06:16.043 --> 00:06:18.007
because we've got a couple
of MacBook Pros here and

132
00:06:18.007 --> 00:06:20.882
one of the things I don't see on these,
and it's kind of interesting, and

133
00:06:20.882 --> 00:06:22.910
it seems like a lot of
the markets are going this way.

134
00:06:22.910 --> 00:06:24.617
I don't see any optical trays anymore.

135
00:06:24.617 --> 00:06:25.463
>> Yeah, absolutely.

136
00:06:25.463 --> 00:06:26.923
I mean, If you walk around our office,

137
00:06:26.923 --> 00:06:29.120
we've got a whole mix of
different things here.

138
00:06:29.120 --> 00:06:33.172
We've got iMacs, MacBook Pros,
we've got Mac Minis, and

139
00:06:33.172 --> 00:06:35.486
I can see two Mac Minis over there.

140
00:06:35.486 --> 00:06:41.400
And I think we might still have one
Mac Mini that has an optical drive in it.

141
00:06:41.400 --> 00:06:44.300
Other than that, there's really

142
00:06:44.300 --> 00:06:47.810
not any device coming out of Apple
these days that has an optical drive.

143
00:06:47.810 --> 00:06:50.906
And by an optical drive I
mean a CD/DVD drive, and

144
00:06:50.906 --> 00:06:53.727
Apple calls theirs the SuperDrive, right.

145
00:06:53.727 --> 00:06:56.830
It used to be that if you bought a Macbook
Pro, it had that optical drive in it.

146
00:06:56.830 --> 00:06:58.796
You could pop a DVD in there.

147
00:06:58.796 --> 00:07:00.780
People just don't use them anymore.

148
00:07:00.780 --> 00:07:04.656
We used to like watch movies or
make backups, but USB keys, right,

149
00:07:04.656 --> 00:07:08.872
little flash thumb drives, really
took that world by storm; and so now,

150
00:07:08.872 --> 00:07:12.350
it's very common for
people to have USB keys laying around.

151
00:07:12.350 --> 00:07:13.315
I got one right here.

152
00:07:13.315 --> 00:07:15.920
But I don't know that I
could find my DVD drive.

153
00:07:15.920 --> 00:07:18.006
I have one.
I have an Apple Superdrive.

154
00:07:18.006 --> 00:07:21.520
I'm at a loss as to where I put it because
that's how long since I've used it.

155
00:07:21.520 --> 00:07:23.593
But I have one laying around
just in case I need it.

156
00:07:23.593 --> 00:07:24.624
Most people don't.

157
00:07:24.624 --> 00:07:27.980
And so you're probably not going to see
CDs and DVDs on your systems anymore.

158
00:07:27.980 --> 00:07:28.897
But you might.

159
00:07:28.897 --> 00:07:30.630
They are still out there.

160
00:07:30.630 --> 00:07:33.080
Just because your system doesn't have it
built in doesn't mean you can't add it.

161
00:07:33.080 --> 00:07:37.850
You can get a USB one to plug in,
and it'll have a DVD drive in it.

162
00:07:37.850 --> 00:07:41.300
It's usually a writer also, so
you can burn disks as well as read disks.

163
00:07:41.300 --> 00:07:44.553
So, those are some of the different
types of storage that are out there.

164
00:07:44.553 --> 00:07:46.225
Other ones I mentioned, USB.

165
00:07:46.225 --> 00:07:49.512
USB really common so you can find
where you've got hard drives and

166
00:07:49.512 --> 00:07:50.820
storage like this.

167
00:07:50.820 --> 00:07:56.116
This is a just a 16 gigabyte SSD so I can
pop it on and there's 16 gigs of storage.

168
00:07:56.116 --> 00:07:57.613
You can get bigger ones.

169
00:07:57.613 --> 00:08:01.704
On my desk here I've got a A USB
attached one that, I guess, yeah,

170
00:08:01.704 --> 00:08:06.690
we can't really see it, but this little
jobbie here, which is a 128 gig SSD.

171
00:08:06.690 --> 00:08:10.580
And I've got it plugged
into a USB 3.0 port, and so

172
00:08:10.580 --> 00:08:13.310
I get pretty fast access with that,
and now I've got an extra 128 gigs.

173
00:08:13.310 --> 00:08:16.260
Now, you might recognize that
one from an earlier episode.

174
00:08:16.260 --> 00:08:19.860
I made the El Capitan installer
out of that drive, so

175
00:08:19.860 --> 00:08:21.480
I could install nice and quickly.

176
00:08:21.480 --> 00:08:23.070
It's nice to have that, but

177
00:08:23.070 --> 00:08:26.400
it's a little inconvenient, cuz it is an
extra device that we have to carry around.

178
00:08:26.400 --> 00:08:30.520
So it's more ideal to have the storage
internally on your system, if you can, but

179
00:08:30.520 --> 00:08:34.180
it's so expensive, that external drives
like these almost become a necessity.

180
00:08:35.280 --> 00:08:38.320
Other things, Thunderbolt, right?

181
00:08:38.320 --> 00:08:41.180
Every Mac that you buy these days comes
with at least one Thunderbolt port on it,

182
00:08:41.180 --> 00:08:42.620
they normally have two, and

183
00:08:42.620 --> 00:08:46.320
you can get direct attached drives
that have a Thunderbolt connection.

184
00:08:46.320 --> 00:08:49.210
Thunderbolt is very fast.

185
00:08:49.210 --> 00:08:52.490
USB 3.0 is fast,
Thunderbolt is just a little bit faster.

186
00:08:52.490 --> 00:08:54.650
But I'll tell you guys from
a performance perspective,

187
00:08:54.650 --> 00:08:57.710
I see this all the time with
running virtual machines.

188
00:08:57.710 --> 00:08:59.920
I can run virtual machines
off of a USB 3.0 drive and

189
00:08:59.920 --> 00:09:04.137
it'll run just fine,
if I'm running one VM.

190
00:09:04.137 --> 00:09:07.064
If I'm running one VM, performance on
a USB 3.0 drive is about the same as

191
00:09:07.064 --> 00:09:09.590
performance on a Thunderbolt drive for me.

192
00:09:09.590 --> 00:09:14.370
But if I start running two or three VMs,
if I have more than one thing going on at

193
00:09:14.370 --> 00:09:19.390
a time, the Thunderbolt drive does
way better than the USB drive.

194
00:09:19.390 --> 00:09:22.100
Thunderbolt just handles simultaneous
reads and writes, better.

195
00:09:22.100 --> 00:09:24.250
It's got some kind of better
channel architecture,

196
00:09:24.250 --> 00:09:25.090
where it's able to handle that.

197
00:09:25.090 --> 00:09:27.340
So there is a definite
performance difference.

198
00:09:27.340 --> 00:09:28.230
>> Would you say maybe, Don,

199
00:09:28.230 --> 00:09:31.600
that that's probably a little bit closer
to maybe it runs in full-duplex, so

200
00:09:31.600 --> 00:09:33.940
you're getting that two-way
communication a little bit better?

201
00:09:33.940 --> 00:09:35.482
Or is it just the way it's built overall?

202
00:09:35.482 --> 00:09:38.140
Or both?
>> They're both full duplex.

203
00:09:38.140 --> 00:09:39.910
They just handle addressing differently.

204
00:09:39.910 --> 00:09:42.020
They handle how they do their reads and
writes differently.

205
00:09:42.020 --> 00:09:44.780
I'm not an engineer, so I don't know
the actual difference under the hood.

206
00:09:44.780 --> 00:09:47.310
I just know that it's a noticeable
performance difference

207
00:09:47.310 --> 00:09:49.340
between the two, based on that.

208
00:09:49.340 --> 00:09:52.480
So you may see FireWire,
Thunderbolt out there.

209
00:09:52.480 --> 00:09:55.650
You may see FireWire too,
it was a slip, but it is out there.

210
00:09:55.650 --> 00:09:59.930
Again, if you look at Wes's laptop,
if you look at my laptop, if you look at

211
00:09:59.930 --> 00:10:03.740
the Mac Mini over there, none of our
devices have FireWire ports anymore.

212
00:10:03.740 --> 00:10:06.522
That was the old hotness, right?

213
00:10:06.522 --> 00:10:08.810
That was the old connector
that people loved to get.

214
00:10:08.810 --> 00:10:10.987
It had 800MB of bandwidth.

215
00:10:10.987 --> 00:10:14.335
And that was awesome,
cuz it was way faster than USB 2.0.

216
00:10:14.335 --> 00:10:18.810
But USB 3.0 and Thunderbolt,
both kinda killed that off.

217
00:10:18.810 --> 00:10:22.210
And so now we don't see FireWire as much,
but you might have FireWire drives.

218
00:10:22.210 --> 00:10:23.670
Now the neat thing about FireWire, and

219
00:10:23.670 --> 00:10:26.510
Thunderbolt, is that
it's not just storage.

220
00:10:26.510 --> 00:10:30.290
I could get a FireWire camera and
hook it up to my computer.

221
00:10:30.290 --> 00:10:36.870
Or I can get a Thunderbolt, I don't know,
you don't see scanners all that much.

222
00:10:36.870 --> 00:10:38.395
But you can get these different devices,

223
00:10:38.395 --> 00:10:41.648
Thunderbolt is not
limited to just storage.

224
00:10:41.648 --> 00:10:44.960
In fact, Thunderbolt ports
double as display ports, and so

00:21:36.952 --> 00:21:40.650
So [LAUGH] I reach out to
the hard drive to get that data.

450
00:21:40.650 --> 00:21:44.200
Well, I'm telling the system
I want this file name.

451
00:21:44.200 --> 00:21:47.970
How the heck does it know where
the ones and zeroes for that file are?

452
00:21:47.970 --> 00:21:49.850
It's the file system that does that.

453
00:21:49.850 --> 00:21:53.710
The file system says I'm gonna
store this name with an index and

454
00:21:53.710 --> 00:21:57.720
the index is gonna say read from this
sector all the way from this other sector,

455
00:21:57.720 --> 00:21:59.900
that's where you're
going to find that file.

456
00:21:59.900 --> 00:22:04.190
Well, different companies do
that file system different ways.

457
00:22:04.190 --> 00:22:08.390
So like, back in the 1970s, Microsoft
started to create this file system called

458
00:22:08.390 --> 00:22:10.730
FAT, the File Allocation Table.

459
00:22:10.730 --> 00:22:13.630
And what it did is it created a little
file table at the very beginning of

460
00:22:13.630 --> 00:22:18.300
the disk, and in that file table they
would store the names of files, and

461
00:22:18.300 --> 00:22:19.870
the names of folders, and

462
00:22:19.870 --> 00:22:23.220
then little pointers to where on the hard
drive you can go to access that data.

463
00:22:23.220 --> 00:22:25.243
And it worked pretty well.

464
00:22:25.243 --> 00:22:27.577
It's a very standard system
that a lot of people use today.

465
00:22:27.577 --> 00:22:32.300
But it's extremely dated, it's very
fragile, it's very easy to break it.

466
00:22:32.300 --> 00:22:35.630
And so you're not gonna see
File Allocation Table very often anymore.

467
00:22:35.630 --> 00:22:38.980
But every other vendor
does something similar.

468
00:22:38.980 --> 00:22:42.070
And Apple, Apple actually used
the file allocation table for

469
00:22:42.070 --> 00:22:44.510
a while before they started
creating their own.

470
00:22:44.510 --> 00:22:48.220
They started creating their own file
systems to do things a little bit better.

471
00:22:48.220 --> 00:22:54.430
And on all of your modern Macs, you're
now seeing the OS X extended file system.

472
00:22:54.430 --> 00:22:57.900
And the extended file system is
proprietary to Apple, they made it,

473
00:22:57.900 --> 00:23:00.480
it's their own little thing,
and it's very good.

474
00:23:00.480 --> 00:23:02.290
It's got a lot of neat little bells and
whistles.

475
00:23:02.290 --> 00:23:04.500
And so we're gonna talk about
that file system later on.

476
00:23:04.500 --> 00:23:08.670
But understand that Unix systems,
Macs, Windows,

477
00:23:08.670 --> 00:23:12.510
Linux, they've all got different
file systems that are supported.

478
00:23:12.510 --> 00:23:17.070
And so, when you create that partition,
you've got to format it and

479
00:23:17.070 --> 00:23:18.500
put a file system on it.

480
00:23:18.500 --> 00:23:19.540
That's what formatting is,

481
00:23:19.540 --> 00:23:24.060
you're putting a file system on that disk,
and now I can start to use it.

482
00:23:24.060 --> 00:23:28.230
So in order for a disk to work I've
gotta recognize the physical hardware.

483
00:23:28.230 --> 00:23:30.550
I've gotta recognize the partition.

484
00:23:30.550 --> 00:23:33.660
And I've gotta recognize
the file system on it.

485
00:23:33.660 --> 00:23:38.560
And only when all three things are done
will I see it in my volumes folder and

486
00:23:38.560 --> 00:23:39.590
I'm ready to use it.

487
00:23:39.590 --> 00:23:42.200
So it's important to understand
those three pieces that are going on

488
00:23:42.200 --> 00:23:43.810
under the hood, all right?

489
00:23:43.810 --> 00:23:45.270
Now on the physical hardware, that's easy.

490
00:23:45.270 --> 00:23:46.010
You plug it in.

491
00:23:46.010 --> 00:23:47.980
You either have a driver for
it or you don't.

492
00:23:47.980 --> 00:23:50.040
If it's USB or SATA stuff,
you've already got that.

493
00:23:50.040 --> 00:23:51.180
It's gonna work fine.

494
00:23:51.180 --> 00:23:54.721
If it's some crazy new proprietary thing,
you might have to load drivers for it.

495
00:23:54.721 --> 00:23:57.570
But storage is usually not
proprietary on the hardware side.

496
00:23:58.710 --> 00:24:00.061
Step two is the partition.

497
00:24:00.061 --> 00:24:02.164
How do we recognize the partition?

498
00:24:02.164 --> 00:24:05.673
Well when you add a disc and
you create a partition on it,

499
00:24:05.673 --> 00:24:10.007
you have to pick what kind of partition
table you're going to have and

500
00:24:10.007 --> 00:24:13.760
there's three main types that
we need to know for the exam.

501
00:24:13.760 --> 00:24:15.670
In real life,
there's only one that we care about, but

502
00:24:15.670 --> 00:24:17.750
there's three main ones
that show up on the exam.

503
00:24:17.750 --> 00:24:22.010
The one that we care about, the one
that we're gonna use is called GPT.

504
00:24:22.010 --> 00:24:25.830
GPT is the GUID partition table.

505
00:24:25.830 --> 00:24:29.850
And GUID, I know an acronym within
an acronym, stands for global unique

506
00:24:29.850 --> 00:24:34.820
identifier, so it's the globally
unique identifier partition table.

507
00:24:34.820 --> 00:24:37.950
It's a way of listing how many partitions
you have and where they start,

508
00:24:37.950 --> 00:24:39.600
where they stop, what their names are,

509
00:24:39.600 --> 00:24:43.680
all the information about the partitions
stored in a very standard format.

510
00:24:43.680 --> 00:24:46.552
GPT is supported by Apple,
Microsoft, Linux,

511
00:24:46.552 --> 00:24:50.413
pretty much every operating system
out there can recognize GPT.

512
00:24:50.413 --> 00:24:53.815
So if I take a GPT disk and I plug it
into a system, it's gonna recognize

513
00:24:53.815 --> 00:24:57.176
the hardware, and then it's gonna
recognize the partition table.

514
00:24:57.176 --> 00:24:59.710
The first two things we need to recognize,
right?

515
00:24:59.710 --> 00:25:04.040
So GPT is what you wanna use,
but there's two others, right?

516
00:25:04.040 --> 00:25:05.550
There's another one called APM.

517
00:25:05.550 --> 00:25:12.340
And APM that's the Apple Partition Map and
that was used on old Macs.

518
00:25:12.340 --> 00:25:15.890
If you had a Mac, that was a PowerPC Mac
not an Intel processor, so

519
00:25:15.890 --> 00:25:17.400
we're talking ten years ago.

520
00:25:17.400 --> 00:25:22.520
If you had one that was a PowerPC, it
more than likely used APM for it's disks.

521
00:25:22.520 --> 00:25:25.700
Apple can still recognize those and
read them, but it's Apple proprietary,

522
00:25:25.700 --> 00:25:26.660
nobody else can.

523
00:25:26.660 --> 00:25:29.210
You plug that into a Windows machine or
a Linux machine they'll

524
00:25:29.210 --> 00:25:31.930
recognize the hardware they won't
recognize the partition app.

525
00:25:31.930 --> 00:25:34.709
In fact, they'll usually
think the disk is empty and

526
00:25:34.709 --> 00:25:38.062
ask to format it and
that's probably not what you want, right?

527
00:25:38.062 --> 00:25:39.692
So APM that's old school, but

528
00:25:39.692 --> 00:25:43.340
maybe if you're dealing with some
really old stuff you might see it.

529
00:25:43.340 --> 00:25:46.450
Then the third one
that's out there is MBR.

530
00:25:46.450 --> 00:25:48.050
MBR is Master Boot Record.

531
00:25:48.050 --> 00:25:50.489
Master boot record was the one
that Microsoft created.

532
00:25:50.489 --> 00:25:54.650
And it was designed so that the hard
drives could have this well, boot record

533
00:25:54.650 --> 00:25:59.153
that would identify what partitions were
out there and which ones were bootable.

534
00:25:59.153 --> 00:26:01.898
And that one is supported by Mac,
Windows, Linux.

535
00:26:01.898 --> 00:26:05.788
Its supported by everybody, but it has
some limitations because it was created 30

536
00:26:05.788 --> 00:26:08.879
years ago, and so it doesn't support
really, really big drives and

537
00:26:08.879 --> 00:26:11.140
it doesn't support a high
number of partitions.

538
00:26:11.140 --> 00:26:14.820
Really only supports four partitions,
so it has limitations and

539
00:26:14.820 --> 00:26:16.820
that's why GPT came about.

540
00:26:16.820 --> 00:26:19.850
And James in the chat room make
a good comment there about how

541
00:26:19.850 --> 00:26:23.310
GPT is kind of supported by UFI.

542
00:26:23.310 --> 00:26:26.600
UFI is the new BIOS replacement
that most systems use,

543
00:26:26.600 --> 00:26:30.990
including all new Macs, and that's why
they had to get that standardized system.

544
00:26:30.990 --> 00:26:34.594
So that's why I say GPT is the only one I
care about that's because all Macs are UFI

545
00:26:34.594 --> 00:26:38.370
these days and that's the one they want,
but same thing goes for Windows and Linux.

546
00:26:38.370 --> 00:26:40.310
GPT's really the one we're
going to stick with.

547
00:26:40.310 --> 00:26:45.060
>> Now Don, you have mentioned that
MBR does have some limitations.

548
00:26:45.060 --> 00:26:47.380
It's been around for a long while.

549
00:26:47.380 --> 00:26:52.273
Can you tell us a little bit about what
makes maybe the GUI partitioning scheme

550
00:26:52.273 --> 00:26:54.164
a little bit better than MBR?

551
00:26:54.164 --> 00:26:54.941
>> It's magic, Wes.

552
00:26:54.941 --> 00:26:55.569
>> It's magic?

553
00:26:55.569 --> 00:26:56.172
>> It's magic.

554
00:26:56.172 --> 00:26:57.330
GPT's magic.

555
00:26:57.330 --> 00:26:59.330
Well it's not so bad.

556
00:26:59.330 --> 00:27:01.574
GPT uses a much larger address space, so

557
00:27:01.574 --> 00:27:04.352
it can recognize partitions
that are far larger.

558
00:27:04.352 --> 00:27:07.785
And I don't know the maximum
size off the top of my head, but

559
00:27:07.785 --> 00:27:11.849
it's something like 8 is it zetabytes or
something crazy like that?

560
00:27:11.849 --> 00:27:12.429
>> Yeah.

561
00:27:12.429 --> 00:27:15.129
>> Some unit of measure that none of
us will ever have to deal with for

562
00:27:15.129 --> 00:27:16.160
100 years, right?

563
00:27:16.160 --> 00:27:18.570
But it can recognize massive disks.

564
00:27:18.570 --> 00:27:20.750
It can also recognize massive
amounts of partitions.

565
00:27:20.750 --> 00:27:24.650
In fact, remember earlier I said Apple,
you can go up to16 partitions?

566
00:27:24.650 --> 00:27:27.540
Well, that's an artificial
limit that Apple puts in there.

567
00:27:27.540 --> 00:27:30.280
There's people who are using GPT
disks to have far more than that.

568
00:27:30.280 --> 00:27:33.830
Now the reality is if you've
got more than three partitions,

569
00:27:33.830 --> 00:27:36.360
you probably need to evaluate
your use case scenario.

570
00:27:36.360 --> 00:27:37.410
Most people don't do that.

571
00:27:37.410 --> 00:27:40.740
It's normally,
three would really be probably the tops.

572
00:27:40.740 --> 00:27:42.300
If you have Boot Camp,
you probably have three.

573
00:27:43.540 --> 00:27:46.540
Even on a standard Mac where you
think you just have one partition,

574
00:27:46.540 --> 00:27:47.630
you actually have two.

575
00:27:47.630 --> 00:27:48.860
Because when you boot UEFI,

576
00:27:48.860 --> 00:27:52.840
you're going to have your main partition
where all of your data is, and

577
00:27:52.840 --> 00:27:57.770
then you're gonna have a small like 200 MB
partition that's there for the UEFI boot.

578
00:27:57.770 --> 00:28:02.930
And that one it's normally formatted
as FAT32, the file allocation table.

579
00:28:02.930 --> 00:28:06.140
So even on a Mac, you still have some
file allocation table laying around and

580
00:28:06.140 --> 00:28:08.900
that's to help your system boot, and
so that's two partitions, right?

581
00:28:08.900 --> 00:28:12.047
And then if you do something like
Bootcamp, or just divide out data,

582
00:28:12.047 --> 00:28:14.149
then you might end up
with three partitions.

583
00:28:14.149 --> 00:28:15.580
If you've got four or more,

584
00:28:15.580 --> 00:28:18.760
you really do have to evaluate that,
so 16 is more than enough.

585
00:28:18.760 --> 00:28:22.960
But that's really the part about it where
GPT is just the modern forward thing.

586
00:28:22.960 --> 00:28:26.910
It's got a much better support for
current hardware as well as UEFI and

587
00:28:26.910 --> 00:28:30.290
its security layer, so
that's the one that we want, all right?

588
00:28:30.290 --> 00:28:35.130
Now when I plug in a hard drive,
I have to make sure that my system

589
00:28:35.130 --> 00:28:38.610
recognizes that partition table or
I'm not gonna able to read the disk.

590
00:28:38.610 --> 00:28:40.250
Now how do I know if that's happening?

591
00:28:40.250 --> 00:28:42.200
Well let me take my computer here and
I'll show you.

592
00:28:42.200 --> 00:28:45.021
I'm gonna bring up the disk utility and
in the Disk Utility.

593
00:28:45.021 --> 00:28:51.190
And in the Disk Utility, notice how
all of my disks show up twice, right?

594
00:28:51.190 --> 00:28:53.990
I've got the Apple SSD and
then Macintosh HD.

595
00:28:53.990 --> 00:28:59.860
I've got the ASMT2115, and then I've
got Install OS 10 Yosemite, right?

596
00:28:59.860 --> 00:29:03.400
So all of my discs,
it's not gonna let me resize that?

597
00:29:03.400 --> 00:29:05.390
Apparently I'm not asking nice enough.

598
00:29:05.390 --> 00:29:07.140
So all of my discs show up twice.

599
00:29:07.140 --> 00:29:08.140
Why is that?

600
00:29:08.140 --> 00:29:12.990
Well the first one, that's the hardware
that's my system saying that yes,

601
00:29:12.990 --> 00:29:16.300
I recognize that there is a physical
hard drive on this system

602
00:29:16.300 --> 00:29:21.120
either internal like this one or
external like this one, right?

603
00:29:21.120 --> 00:29:23.160
So that was the first of
the three things,right?

604
00:29:23.160 --> 00:29:24.760
Recognize the physical disk.

605
00:29:24.760 --> 00:29:27.140
The second thing was the partition table,
and so

606
00:29:27.140 --> 00:29:31.490
when I click on this disk,
I'm seeing the partition table, right?

607
00:29:31.490 --> 00:29:35.390
Well sort of, I'm seeing what
Apple's allowing me to see.

608
00:29:35.390 --> 00:29:37.880
It's letting me see
there's a 500 gig disk and

609
00:29:37.880 --> 00:29:41.180
that the entire thing is blue
because I haven't divided this up.

610
00:29:41.180 --> 00:29:43.225
It's not a hybrid or anything like that.

611
00:29:43.225 --> 00:29:44.141
It's just one big disk.

612
00:29:44.141 --> 00:29:48.830
And if I look right down here,
I can see the partition map.

613
00:29:48.830 --> 00:29:52.050
And see how the partition map
shows is GUID Partition Map?

614
00:29:52.050 --> 00:29:59.900
So this is a disk that is done
with GPT and it's ready to go.

615
00:29:59.900 --> 00:30:04.880
If I look at my external disk and I click
on it, I can see that it's external.

616
00:30:04.880 --> 00:30:10.170
It's USB and it's also GPT or
GUID Partition Map, so it's

617
00:30:10.170 --> 00:30:14.670
already set up to use that partition type
and I recognize that and I'm good to go.

618
00:30:14.670 --> 00:30:16.490
That was the second requirement.

619
00:30:16.490 --> 00:30:19.960
Well if I plug in a truly blank disc,

620
00:30:21.170 --> 00:30:23.430
usually when you buy a disc, it's
already got some kind of format on it.

621
00:30:23.430 --> 00:30:28.133
But if I buy a truly blank disc, when I
plug it in, the Mac is gonna ask me to

622
00:30:28.133 --> 00:30:32.555
initialize it and initializing is
putting a partition table on it.

623
00:30:32.555 --> 00:30:34.759
And when we put that partition table on,
you actually do have choices.

624
00:30:34.759 --> 00:30:35.481
Let me show you.

625
00:30:35.481 --> 00:30:40.136
I'll take my external disc here and
if I choose the Partition button up top,

626
00:30:40.136 --> 00:30:45.060
I'm gonna partition it and it's gonna
ask me some basic information here.

627
00:30:45.060 --> 00:30:48.970
And see how the scheme is
defaulting to GUID Partition Map?

628
00:30:48.970 --> 00:30:51.248
It's gonna force me to
do GUID partition map.

629
00:30:51.248 --> 00:30:56.760
Well on older, you actually get a choice.

630
00:30:56.760 --> 00:30:59.590
Even in Yosemite, I think you still had
the choice where you could pick and

631
00:30:59.590 --> 00:31:01.970
you could partition it
as something different.

632
00:31:01.970 --> 00:31:06.680
Right now, I'm choosing OS10 Extended
Journaled, which requires GPT.

633
00:31:06.680 --> 00:31:10.810
If I were to switch to some other format
though, it might not require that and

634
00:31:10.810 --> 00:31:13.320
I may be able to choose
a different partition map.

635
00:31:13.320 --> 00:31:17.090
In In El Capitan,
they simplify the disk utility though, so

636
00:31:17.090 --> 00:31:17.910
I'm not gonna see it here.

637
00:31:17.910 --> 00:31:21.710
I would have to drop down to the command
line and use the diskutil command

638
00:31:21.710 --> 00:31:24.790
to apply a different partition map, but
that's where it's going to apply it.

639
00:31:24.790 --> 00:31:28.210
If I'm initializing a brand new disk,
whether I do 1 partition or

640
00:31:28.210 --> 00:31:31.580
5 partitions or 20 partitions,
it's not gonna matter.

641
00:31:31.580 --> 00:31:34.780
It's gonna create that partition map for
me, right?

642
00:31:34.780 --> 00:31:37.070
So that's the main one
that we see right there.

643
00:31:37.070 --> 00:31:39.850
The format that's the next
decision I have to make and

644
00:31:39.850 --> 00:31:41.160
there's a lot of choices there.

645
00:31:41.160 --> 00:31:43.780
And I wanna go through each of these and
kind of talk about what they are and

646
00:31:43.780 --> 00:31:46.580
what they do, but
I know I'm pushing my limits here.

647
00:31:46.580 --> 00:31:47.740
Wes is giving me the evil eye.

648
00:31:47.740 --> 00:31:50.440
So Wes, what do you think about
doing a part two on this one?

649
00:31:50.440 --> 00:31:53.220
>> Yeah, I think we're gonna have to
because it does look like we're coming to

650
00:31:53.220 --> 00:31:56.800
the end of another not an episode, but
our time is a little constrained on us.

651
00:31:56.800 --> 00:31:58.836
So Don, do you have anything else for
us in this episode?

652
00:31:58.836 --> 00:32:02.339
>> All right, just remember the key thing
to take away here are the three pieces to

653
00:32:02.339 --> 00:32:03.360
recognize the drive.

654
00:32:03.360 --> 00:32:06.740
We have to recognize the physical disk, we
have to recognize the partition table and

655
00:32:06.740 --> 00:32:07.780
we've got to recognize the format.

656
00:32:07.780 --> 00:32:10.420
We're gonna see that format in part two,
all right?

657
00:32:10.420 --> 00:32:13.320
>> Well thank you for that, Don and thank
you for you guys out there watching us,

658
00:32:13.320 --> 00:32:15.580
but we're gonna go ahead and
sign off here at ITProTV.

659
00:32:15.580 --> 00:32:17.050
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

660
00:32:17.050 --> 00:32:17.945
>> And I'm Don Pizet.

661
00:32:17.945 --> 00:32:20.210
>> And we'll see you next time.

662

00:33:44.873 --> 00:33:47.590
If we want the best compatibility,
we can read and write to those.

676
00:33:47.590 --> 00:33:49.720
It's just not every reliable.

677
00:33:49.720 --> 00:33:53.450
>> Great information, and we have come to
the end of another exciting episode, but

678
00:33:53.450 --> 00:33:56.310
before we go, Don,
any parting words of wisdom?

679
00:33:57.340 --> 00:33:58.160
>> That's it on this one.

680
00:33:58.160 --> 00:34:00.690
We are going to do some more file system
episodes because I want to talk a little

681
00:34:00.690 --> 00:34:02.510
bit more about disk encryption,
recovery, so

682
00:34:02.510 --> 00:34:04.020
stay tuned because those
episodes are going to come up.

683
00:34:04.020 --> 00:34:07.038
But, as far as formatting, partitions and
drives, that's a pretty good wrap up.

684
00:34:07.038 --> 00:34:10.845
>> All right, great, so we're going to
go ahead and sign out here at ITProTV.

685
00:34:10.845 --> 00:34:12.430
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

686
00:34:12.430 --> 00:34:13.290
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

687
00:34:13.290 --> 00:34:15.545
>> And we'll see you next time.

688
00:34:15.545 --> 00:34:20.793
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don demonstrate encrypting disks using FileVault v2. They also explain how to upgrade from the original FileVault. They end the episode by discussing how to securely erase files from the hard drive.
episodes.title: Securing Data
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.063 --> 00:00:14.967
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.967 --> 00:00:16.470
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.470 --> 00:00:19.077
And in today's episode we're
gonna be moving forward in our

5
00:00:19.077 --> 00:00:22.246
Apple Certified Support Professional and
we've got none other than Mr,

6
00:00:22.246 --> 00:00:23.896
Don Pezet in the studio to help us out.

7
00:00:23.896 --> 00:00:25.081
Don, how you doing today, sir?

8
00:00:25.081 --> 00:00:27.193
>> I'm doing great, Wes,
ready to jump right back in.

9
00:00:27.193 --> 00:00:28.165
And in this episode,

10
00:00:28.165 --> 00:00:31.990
I'm actually gonna tidy up some loose
ends we had from another episode.

11
00:00:31.990 --> 00:00:35.680
Earlier on in this series,
we talked about Apple's FileVault and

12
00:00:35.680 --> 00:00:38.860
how we can encrypt our hard
drive to protect our data.

13
00:00:38.860 --> 00:00:41.410
And I gave some examples of why we'd wanna
do that in case somebody steals your hard

14
00:00:41.410 --> 00:00:42.410
drive and so on.

15
00:00:42.410 --> 00:00:43.160
But there are few

16
00:00:43.160 --> 00:00:45.720
other things that I didn't get to
that I wanna address right here.

17
00:00:45.720 --> 00:00:49.350
Like for example,
we saw a generating a recovery key.

18
00:00:49.350 --> 00:00:51.550
But I never showed you how to
use that thing once you have it.

19
00:00:51.550 --> 00:00:53.580
So maybe kinda nice to see that.

20
00:00:53.580 --> 00:00:57.400
Also I wanna talk about when you
decide to get rid of the computer.

21
00:00:57.400 --> 00:00:58.820
Maybe you're done with it.

22
00:00:58.820 --> 00:01:01.780
You got a new computer so you gonna
give your old one to a friend or sell

23
00:01:01.780 --> 00:01:05.900
it on eBay or whatever, but there's ways
that we can sanitize the data on our hard

24
00:01:05.900 --> 00:01:09.170
drive to make sure that other people can't
get at it and recover that information.

25
00:01:09.170 --> 00:01:10.680
So, that's what we're doing right here.

26
00:01:10.680 --> 00:01:14.490
We're gonna call it data security, making
sure that our data is nice and secure and

27
00:01:14.490 --> 00:01:17.780
safe, and that only the people
we want to see it can see it,

28
00:01:17.780 --> 00:01:20.360
and just kinda tidy up
some of those loose ends.

29
00:01:20.360 --> 00:01:25.840
So, let's kick things off with a quick,
I'll just do like a quick summary of

30
00:01:25.840 --> 00:01:30.040
File Vault because some of you guys have
all ready seen that episode, but for those

31
00:01:30.040 --> 00:01:35.920
of you that didn't, FileVault is Apple's
disk encryption that's built into OS 10.

32
00:01:35.920 --> 00:01:43.087
And really ever since, I believe it
was 10, shoot, was it 10.5 or 10.6?

33
00:01:43.087 --> 00:01:46.421
We've had file vault there was an older
form of FileVault called Legacy FileVault

34
00:01:46.421 --> 00:01:48.160
that we really don't see anymore.

35
00:01:48.160 --> 00:01:52.000
But the new FileVault will encrypt your
entire hard drive and protect your data.

36
00:01:52.000 --> 00:01:56.620
And it's super easy to turn on so there's
really not a reason not to be using it.

37
00:01:56.620 --> 00:01:58.720
You should use it,
it encrypts your disk and

38
00:01:58.720 --> 00:02:01.240
you get really great security out of it.

39
00:02:01.240 --> 00:02:03.410
And from a performance standpoint,

40
00:02:03.410 --> 00:02:07.180
if I can say it, it really doesn't create
much impact on your system at all.

41
00:02:07.180 --> 00:02:10.640
So once you turn it on, you're nice,
you're safe, you're secure and

42
00:02:10.640 --> 00:02:12.320
you just don't have to
worry about it anymore.

43
00:02:12.320 --> 00:02:14.440
So it's an all-win kind of scenario.

44
00:02:14.440 --> 00:02:16.040
There's no real negative.

45
00:02:16.040 --> 00:02:18.170
So let's say that I wanna use FileVault.

46
00:02:18.170 --> 00:02:19.800
Let's see that process
of turning it on again.

47
00:02:19.800 --> 00:02:23.680
So I've got a machine here that
is a stock install of El Capitan.

48
00:02:23.680 --> 00:02:26.180
My disk is not currently encrypted.

49
00:02:26.180 --> 00:02:30.630
Even if it were, as an end user, you don't
really see whether it's encrypted or not.

50
00:02:30.630 --> 00:02:33.280
The way we tell is we go
into our System Preferences.

51
00:02:33.280 --> 00:02:37.686
And in your System Preferences,
you can go to Security & Privacy.

52
00:02:37.686 --> 00:02:42.600
And in Security & Privacy,
you've got the FileVault tab.

53
00:02:42.600 --> 00:02:46.140
All right, if your disk is encrypted,
it'll tell you that.

54
00:02:46.140 --> 00:02:48.820
But in my case, it tells me right
here FileVault is turned off for

55
00:02:48.820 --> 00:02:51.700
the disk Macintosh HD, it's not encrypted.

56
00:02:51.700 --> 00:02:56.540
So if somebody steals my computer,
they could rip the hard drive out,

57
00:02:56.540 --> 00:02:59.210
stick it in another computer and
read all my data.

58
00:02:59.210 --> 00:03:01.640
No big deal there,
they'd be able to access that.

59
00:03:01.640 --> 00:03:02.950
They don't even have to
rip the hard drive out.

60
00:03:02.950 --> 00:03:04.560
They could boot this system into recovery,

61
00:03:04.560 --> 00:03:07.730
and then they'd be able to browse
the drive and get to everything on there.

62
00:03:07.730 --> 00:03:11.300
Or they could boot from removable media,
and get at the hard drive and

63
00:03:11.300 --> 00:03:12.430
browse everything.

64
00:03:12.430 --> 00:03:16.200
So, my data is not safe if somebody
has physical access to my machine.

65
00:03:16.200 --> 00:03:18.640
Now, if it's remote access, they have
to have a user name and password,

66
00:03:18.640 --> 00:03:19.790
I'm protected there.

67
00:03:19.790 --> 00:03:23.090
But if they have physical access
to my machine, I'm not protected.

68
00:03:23.090 --> 00:03:26.100
So if I want to turn it on, well,
I need to be an administrator so

69
00:03:26.100 --> 00:03:27.240
I'm gonna unlock this panel.

70
00:03:28.510 --> 00:03:30.330
And then you just hit Turn On FileVault.

71
00:03:30.330 --> 00:03:32.610
And the process is super easy.

72
00:03:32.610 --> 00:03:35.690
The first thing it asks us is how
do we want to handle recovery?

73
00:03:35.690 --> 00:03:39.410
And that's what we're gonna see later
in this episode is if my system for

74
00:03:39.410 --> 00:03:41.820
whatever reason, I lose my password.

75
00:03:41.820 --> 00:03:43.850
Well, I can't decrypt the data.

76
00:03:43.850 --> 00:03:46.900
When you encrypt the drive,
it generates a key.

77
00:03:46.900 --> 00:03:48.990
And the key is used to
encrypt your hard drive.

78
00:03:48.990 --> 00:03:52.540
And then that key is attached
to your user account.

79
00:03:52.540 --> 00:03:56.040
So when I log in with my user account, the
key is present, I can decrypt the drive,

80
00:03:56.040 --> 00:03:57.800
and I can access the system.

81
00:03:57.800 --> 00:04:01.100
If I can't login as my user account,
I can't get the key,

82
00:04:01.100 --> 00:04:03.630
I can't decrypt the system,
I'm now locked out.

83
00:04:03.630 --> 00:04:04.970
And so I need a way to recover.

84
00:04:04.970 --> 00:04:07.150
And there's two options.

85
00:04:07.150 --> 00:04:11.200
One option is to tie it to
my iCloud account, right?

86
00:04:11.200 --> 00:04:13.960
What happens if you forget
the password to your iCloud account?

87
00:04:13.960 --> 00:04:16.660
You just go to Apple's website and you
fill out the little password reset form,

88
00:04:16.660 --> 00:04:17.990
you reset your password and you're fine.

89
00:04:19.010 --> 00:04:21.520
What happens if you forget
the password on your Mac?

90
00:04:21.520 --> 00:04:23.150
Well, you gotta boot to recovery and

91
00:04:23.150 --> 00:04:26.850
go into the password recovery utility that
won't run if your drive is encrypted.

92
00:04:26.850 --> 00:04:29.780
You're just locked out,
you're out of luck, right?

93
00:04:29.780 --> 00:04:31.220
So they give you another option.

94
00:04:31.220 --> 00:04:34.720
If I choose not to use iCloud,
I can create a recovery key.

95
00:04:34.720 --> 00:04:37.300
And on the next screen
it'll show me that key.

96
00:04:37.300 --> 00:04:39.430
This is my get out of jail free card.

97
00:04:39.430 --> 00:04:43.470
If I forget my user's password or for some
reason can't log in as my user account,

98
00:04:43.470 --> 00:04:46.700
maybe the computer is completely dead and
I have to take that hard drive out and

99
00:04:46.700 --> 00:04:49.610
add it to another machine,
so I can't boot off of it.

100
00:04:49.610 --> 00:04:53.340
Well, I can use this recovery
key to get that data.

101
00:04:53.340 --> 00:04:58.170
Now, the recovery key,
it's a long mixed code, right?

102
00:04:58.170 --> 00:05:01.020
So it's letters and numbers,
and it's not hexadecimal.

103
00:05:01.020 --> 00:05:04.600
It's letters all the way up, and
you see I've got the letter P here.

104
00:05:04.600 --> 00:05:06.410
So it's all these letters and numbers.

105
00:05:06.410 --> 00:05:10.430
And what you need to do is back it
up somewhere, save it somewhere.

106
00:05:10.430 --> 00:05:13.010
Now notice how Apple doesn't
give you a save button here,

107
00:05:13.010 --> 00:05:16.360
and that's because they don't want you
to save it right here to this computer.

108
00:05:16.360 --> 00:05:19.160
If I save it on this hard drive, and
I get locked out of the hard drive,

109
00:05:19.160 --> 00:05:20.790
what good's this code gonna do me?

110
00:05:20.790 --> 00:05:22.050
Nothing.

111
00:05:22.050 --> 00:05:26.710
I could copy it and email it to myself,
but that would be bad.

112
00:05:26.710 --> 00:05:28.450
Because email's done in plain text.

113
00:05:28.450 --> 00:05:30.510
Anybody could intercept that email,
now they've got the key,

114
00:05:30.510 --> 00:05:32.140
they could decrypt my computer.

115
00:05:32.140 --> 00:05:36.050
So ideally, you write it down on a piece
of paper and you stick it in a safe,

116
00:05:36.050 --> 00:05:36.830
you stick it in a vault,

117
00:05:36.830 --> 00:05:39.490
you stick it somewhere secure
where nobody can get at it.

118
00:05:39.490 --> 00:05:42.670
Because if somebody gets this key,
they can decrypt your drive,

119
00:05:42.670 --> 00:05:45.750
that's the recovery process I'm gonna show
a little bit later here in this episode.

120
00:05:45.750 --> 00:05:47.820
This key is really important.

121
00:05:48.880 --> 00:05:51.220
Now, if you know you're never
gonna forget your user password,

122
00:05:51.220 --> 00:05:54.830
then maybe you don't care about the key,
and you can just hit Continue.

123
00:05:54.830 --> 00:05:56.840
But ideally, we'll write it down.

124
00:05:56.840 --> 00:06:00.420
So I'll write this key down, and
if I ever need it, I can recover with it.

125
00:06:00.420 --> 00:06:02.480
When we hit Continue,
it's got all the information it needs,

126
00:06:02.480 --> 00:06:04.550
we can hit Restart and it's gonna reboot.

127
00:06:04.550 --> 00:06:09.860
Now the reason it's gotta reboot, it's
gonna encrypt the entire hard drive and

128
00:06:09.860 --> 00:06:12.330
the number of the files on the hard
drive are currently in use.

129
00:06:12.330 --> 00:06:14.220
Right?
So my operating system files like

130
00:06:14.220 --> 00:06:18.620
the Kernel and the UI and stuff,
they're in use, they can't be encrypted.

131
00:06:18.620 --> 00:06:22.670
So it's gotta reboot so
that those files won't be in use and

132
00:06:22.670 --> 00:06:25.260
then it will encrypt those files.

133
00:06:25.260 --> 00:06:29.110
And once they're encrypted, then it can
boot the rest of the operating system and

134
00:06:29.110 --> 00:06:32.040
it'll just encrypt that as it has time,
right.

135
00:06:32.040 --> 00:06:34.130
So this is gonna boot up and
i'm gonna get to my desktop and

136
00:06:34.130 --> 00:06:36.780
I can start using the Mac, but
it's not actually done, right.

137
00:06:36.780 --> 00:06:39.690
It could take,
on a brand new, empty system,

138
00:06:39.690 --> 00:06:42.350
it usually takes about 15 minutes
to encrypt the hard drive.

139
00:06:42.350 --> 00:06:44.490
But a business system that
I've been using for months or

140
00:06:44.490 --> 00:06:48.460
years, it could take hours upon
hours to encrypt the drive.

141
00:06:48.460 --> 00:06:51.550
Well, you can still use your
computer while it's encrypting,

142
00:06:51.550 --> 00:06:54.670
it'll just keep running in
the background and get encrypted, but

143
00:06:54.670 --> 00:06:57.410
you need to monitor it, and
watch and see whether or

144
00:06:57.410 --> 00:07:00.150
not it's finished encrypting, and
it'll give you a little status bar.

145
00:07:00.150 --> 00:07:02.950
You just go into your System Preferences,
go into Privacy and

146
00:07:02.950 --> 00:07:05.450
Security, go to the FileVault tab, and

147
00:07:05.450 --> 00:07:08.530
you'll see that little status
bar until it's finally complete.

148
00:07:08.530 --> 00:07:13.630
Once it's complete your entire hard drive
is encrypted, and you're in business.

149
00:07:13.630 --> 00:07:15.610
So that process is pretty straightforward.

150
00:07:15.610 --> 00:07:19.430
Now I don't wanna wait for this
machine to actually finish encrypting,

151
00:07:19.430 --> 00:07:20.910
cuz I'm an impatient person.

152
00:07:20.910 --> 00:07:23.650
So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna switch
to another machine that's already

153
00:07:23.650 --> 00:07:26.840
encrypted, and
we'll use this one to be able to see that.

154
00:07:26.840 --> 00:07:30.540
So here I've got a machine that, again,
it's another stock install of El Capitan.

155
00:07:30.540 --> 00:07:33.350
I guess I have a couple
extra hard drives on it, but

156
00:07:33.350 --> 00:07:35.220
this one's already
encrypted with FileVault.

157
00:07:35.220 --> 00:07:39.540
And I can verify that by going into system
preferences, and going into security and

158
00:07:39.540 --> 00:07:42.620
privacy, and
going in the FileVault tab, and

159
00:07:42.620 --> 00:07:47.070
right here I can see FileVault is
turned on for the disk Macintosh HD.

160
00:07:47.070 --> 00:07:48.970
And a recovery key has been set.

161
00:07:48.970 --> 00:07:53.679
There is a recovery key somewhere that
will allow me to recover the system if I

162
00:07:53.679 --> 00:07:54.274
need to.

163
00:07:54.274 --> 00:07:55.688
It's not tied to an iCloud account,

164
00:07:55.688 --> 00:07:57.566
that would be the other
thing you would see here.

165
00:07:57.566 --> 00:08:01.293
Now as long as I can
provide a valid user name.

166
00:08:01.293 --> 00:08:03.802
I'm gonna be able to
log in to this system,

167
00:08:03.802 --> 00:08:07.640
I'm gonna be able to access
the data on the drive.

168
00:08:07.640 --> 00:08:10.380
If I can't provide a valid username,
then I've got a problem.

169
00:08:10.380 --> 00:08:14.840
So for example, if I reboot this computer,
I'm gonna restart.

170
00:08:14.840 --> 00:08:16.400
Logging out's not enough, if I log out,

171
00:08:16.400 --> 00:08:20.200
I've already cleared FileVault at that
point, so I'm already past the encryption.

172
00:08:20.200 --> 00:08:25.220
But if I reboot, when it goes to boot,
it doesn't boot from the Macintosh HD

173
00:08:25.220 --> 00:08:29.970
anymore, it boots from the little UEFI
partition, is what it boots from.

174
00:08:29.970 --> 00:08:35.230
And then, it hits a special partition that
has the stripped down operating system

175
00:08:35.230 --> 00:08:36.600
that FileVault uses.

176
00:08:36.600 --> 00:08:39.080
And that's why my login screen looks so
different.

177
00:08:39.080 --> 00:08:43.560
My normal login screen has a nice gray
background that actually fits the screen.

178
00:08:43.560 --> 00:08:45.310
So I've got black bars
on the side of this one,

179
00:08:45.310 --> 00:08:47.830
that's because it hasn't loaded
all the video card drivers yet.

180
00:08:47.830 --> 00:08:50.450
It's not supporting all
that extra screen space.

181
00:08:50.450 --> 00:08:55.550
And, my icon here for my user account
shows up, but the screen looks different.

182
00:08:56.570 --> 00:08:59.300
Normally I have a little back arrow
that I can hit here to provide

183
00:08:59.300 --> 00:09:01.230
other user credentials, I don't have that.

184
00:09:01.230 --> 00:09:04.440
And that's because this is not Mac OS,
this is FileVault.

185
00:09:04.440 --> 00:09:07.470
I've booted a small
FileVault operating system

186
00:09:07.470 --> 00:09:12.240
that's going to allow me to decrypt
the drive, and then we can boot the OS.

187
00:09:12.240 --> 00:09:14.430
I can't boot the OS right now
because it's encrypted, and

188
00:09:14.430 --> 00:09:17.940
I can't decrypt it unless
I have valid credentials.

189
00:09:17.940 --> 00:09:23.150
Now, if I know my password, I just
punch that in right here and I log in.

190
00:09:23.150 --> 00:09:26.800
My password opens up my account,
my account can see the encryption key.

191
00:09:26.800 --> 00:09:29.570
The encryption key lets me decrypt
the drive and I boot up and

192
00:09:29.570 --> 00:09:30.760
everything's happy.

193
00:09:30.760 --> 00:09:33.570
The end user just sees a login screen,
they don't notice this is different.

194
00:09:33.570 --> 00:09:35.210
They log in like normal,
they use the system,

195
00:09:35.210 --> 00:09:38.150
they don't recognize that
the encryption is even there.

196
00:09:38.150 --> 00:09:41.000
And that's the best part,
we want it to be transparent.

197
00:09:41.000 --> 00:09:44.310
But if I boot to recovery,
I can't read this disk.

198
00:09:44.310 --> 00:09:46.280
If I boot to this screen and
I can't provide a username and

199
00:09:46.280 --> 00:09:48.960
a password, then I'm not gonna
be able to read this disk.

200
00:09:48.960 --> 00:09:53.460
So that's where we need to recover,
that's where the recovery key comes in.

201
00:09:53.460 --> 00:09:57.000
And it's not immediately
obvious what to do here.

202
00:09:57.000 --> 00:10:01.030
If I put the wrong password in,
it just tells me it's a wrong password.

203
00:10:02.400 --> 00:10:08.440
But, what you can do is this little
question mark right here, so on

204
00:10:08.440 --> 00:10:12.218
that password field, see how it's asking
me to enter my password, whoa, sorry guys.

205
00:10:12.218 --> 00:10:14.290
[LAUGH] I'm gonna get motion sickness.

206
00:10:14.290 --> 00:10:17.270

00:21:07.420 --> 00:21:10.350
Actually I'm not,
why am I not seeing my option?

428
00:21:11.580 --> 00:21:13.690
Well, for some reason my virtual machine
doesn't wanna show me the option.

429
00:21:13.690 --> 00:21:16.200
I'm just gonna jump over to my regular
desktop and I'll show you here.

430
00:21:16.200 --> 00:21:18.470
I've got that USB drive
attached to my system.

431
00:21:18.470 --> 00:21:22.030
And again let's say I wanna take this
USB drive and give it to somebody.

432
00:21:22.030 --> 00:21:22.980
Give it to Wes or whoever.

433
00:21:22.980 --> 00:21:24.770
So I wanna Secure Erase that.

434
00:21:24.770 --> 00:21:26.130
And the option that I'm looking for is,

435
00:21:26.130 --> 00:21:29.210
what you should be able to
do is choose the drive.

436
00:21:29.210 --> 00:21:32.210
And when you choose Erase, there it is.

437
00:21:32.210 --> 00:21:34.610
In my virtual machine,
I just said Cancel and Erase.

438
00:21:34.610 --> 00:21:36.700
But here on my actual desktop
I've got security options.

439
00:21:36.700 --> 00:21:38.000
That's what I'm looking for.

440
00:21:38.000 --> 00:21:40.842
If I just hit Erase,
it does the standard erase.

441
00:21:40.842 --> 00:21:44.080
It's just going to wipe that disk,
but not really wipe it.

442
00:21:44.080 --> 00:21:47.650
The data's technically still there and
software could recover that and

443
00:21:47.650 --> 00:21:48.580
bring it back.

444
00:21:48.580 --> 00:21:52.520
But if I had security options, say I was
showing it set to the fastest option, and

445
00:21:52.520 --> 00:21:56.270
it says this option does not
securely erase files on the disk.

446
00:21:56.270 --> 00:21:58.527
A disk recovery application might
be able to recover the files.

447
00:21:58.527 --> 00:22:01.620
Right, that's what it does by default,
cuz it's fast.

448
00:22:01.620 --> 00:22:05.590
But I have three more choices
that I can move through, and

449
00:22:05.590 --> 00:22:09.930
the very first choice does
what's called a write pass.

450
00:22:09.930 --> 00:22:16.040
It does one pass of random data across
that drive to overwrite what I've got.

451
00:22:16.040 --> 00:22:20.030
It's ensuring that every sector gets
written to at least one time, to make sure

452
00:22:20.030 --> 00:22:23.690
that if somebody runs recovery software,
they might not be able to recover data.

453
00:22:23.690 --> 00:22:24.980
But they might still.

454
00:22:24.980 --> 00:22:26.687
This might not be enough.

455
00:22:26.687 --> 00:22:28.893
And I said one time,
actually it does it two times.

456
00:22:28.893 --> 00:22:31.250
So it says it's gonna write
over the data two times.

457
00:22:31.250 --> 00:22:34.450
So it's gonna take that and
hopefully give us that level.

458
00:22:34.450 --> 00:22:37.510
But the Department of Energy and
the Department of Defense,

459
00:22:37.510 --> 00:22:40.510
they have their own standards, and their
own standards are a little bit stronger.

460
00:22:40.510 --> 00:22:43.230
So if I continue to slide over,
we'll see the DOE right here.

461
00:22:43.230 --> 00:22:47.130
This is a DOE compliant
3-pass secure erase.

462
00:22:47.130 --> 00:22:49.240
So instead of the normal 2-pass,

463
00:22:49.240 --> 00:22:52.380
this one is gonna be a 3-pass
to get in there and erase it.

464
00:22:52.380 --> 00:22:57.270
And then Most Secure, if I go up to that
one, this is the Department of Defense

465
00:22:57.270 --> 00:23:01.250
standard and
you'll see it's doing a seven time pass.

466
00:23:01.250 --> 00:23:05.940
It's gonna write to every single
bit seven times, ones and zeros,

467
00:23:05.940 --> 00:23:10.240
random data, to make sure that
nobody can recover this information.

468
00:23:10.240 --> 00:23:14.780
This way I can assure that when I give
this disc to someone else, they won't be

469
00:23:14.780 --> 00:23:18.120
able to run forensic software and
lift my old deleted data off of it.

470
00:23:18.120 --> 00:23:23.410
Now, as you pick the stronger ones notice
how this lowest one is labelled fastest.

471
00:23:23.410 --> 00:23:25.230
How fast did it erase that drive?

472
00:23:25.230 --> 00:23:27.190
It just took seconds and it was erased.

473
00:23:27.190 --> 00:23:29.470
So if I choose that option,
the default, and

474
00:23:29.470 --> 00:23:32.080
I hit Erase it's gonna erase
that thing super fast.

475
00:23:32.080 --> 00:23:33.710
There, done.

476
00:23:33.710 --> 00:23:35.480
It just took a few seconds.

477
00:23:35.480 --> 00:23:39.920
But when I choose the stronger levels,
so if I do

478
00:23:39.920 --> 00:23:45.840
the two pass, and
I start that one erasing.

479
00:23:45.840 --> 00:23:48.820
Here it goes, starting Secure Erase.

480
00:23:48.820 --> 00:23:52.235
If I drop it down I can see it's starting
the Secure Erase, and now we wait.

481
00:23:52.235 --> 00:23:56.498
That drive's 128 gigs, so
it's a pretty small drive.

482
00:23:56.498 --> 00:24:01.285
It is an SSD drive hooked up with USB 3.0,
so that's pretty fast, But

483
00:24:01.285 --> 00:24:05.298
I'm gonna be waiting awhile,
and this is just the two pass.

484
00:24:05.298 --> 00:24:09.950
Imagine if I did the seven pass, this
could take hours upon hours upon hours.

485
00:24:09.950 --> 00:24:13.260
So this is one of those things where
you start up and then go have dinner,

486
00:24:13.260 --> 00:24:16.260
go to bed, come back the next day and
check and it'll be done.

487
00:24:16.260 --> 00:24:17.770
It takes a long time.

488
00:24:17.770 --> 00:24:20.630
I've got pretty much the fastest
drive I can have attached here,

489
00:24:20.630 --> 00:24:22.460
and it's taking a long time.

490
00:24:22.460 --> 00:24:24.050
The bigger the drive,
the longer it'll take.

491
00:24:24.050 --> 00:24:27.400
If it's a terabyte drive, be ready,
it's gonna take a long time.

492
00:24:27.400 --> 00:24:31.770
On a seven pass, it could take 24 hours,
but your data is safe,

493
00:24:31.770 --> 00:24:33.450
that's the trade-off that you make.

494
00:24:33.450 --> 00:24:38.093
You wanna make sure that your data is safe
and intact, so that you don't lose it.

495
00:24:38.093 --> 00:24:40.669
Now, another thing to be careful with,
I mentioned I've got an SSD.

496
00:24:40.669 --> 00:24:43.084
SSDs have a lifetime.

497
00:24:43.084 --> 00:24:44.072
They only last so long.

498
00:24:44.072 --> 00:24:46.103
They only support so
many reads and writes.

499
00:24:46.103 --> 00:24:50.088
And when I do the secure pass I'm reading
and writing to every single sector,

500
00:24:50.088 --> 00:24:52.436
but it is only seven times so
it's not so bad.

501
00:24:52.436 --> 00:24:54.464
But if you do enough of
these erases over time,

502
00:24:54.464 --> 00:24:56.754
you can start to shorten
the lifetime of your drive,

503
00:24:56.754 --> 00:24:59.880
so you want to make sure you don't
go too crazy with the things.

504
00:24:59.880 --> 00:25:03.850
But, this will secure erase this one and
eventually it'll be ready.

505
00:25:03.850 --> 00:25:05.090
But yeah.

506
00:25:05.090 --> 00:25:07.800
A two pass, a three pass,
that's good enough for most people.

507
00:25:07.800 --> 00:25:10.070
Department of Defense,
you're talking about sensitive data and so

508
00:25:10.070 --> 00:25:11.410
they go seven pass.

509
00:25:11.410 --> 00:25:12.660
And a lot of times they
don't even do that.

510
00:25:12.660 --> 00:25:14.683
If you talk to people in
the Department of Defense,

511
00:25:14.683 --> 00:25:16.386
they normally destroy their hard drives.

512
00:25:16.386 --> 00:25:19.184
There's not enough passes in the world
to guarantee the data is safe.

513
00:25:19.184 --> 00:25:22.880
But if you destroy the drive,
that's a guarantee.

514
00:25:24.610 --> 00:25:27.390
All right, so that is how we
can securely erase that stuff.

515
00:25:27.390 --> 00:25:29.856
I think that's about all I've got.

516
00:25:32.155 --> 00:25:33.559
>> You know, Don, I do have one question.

517
00:25:33.559 --> 00:25:35.485
One of the things that I do a lot is,

518
00:25:35.485 --> 00:25:39.354
I put files that I don't want on my
Mac anymore, I put it in the trash.

519
00:25:39.354 --> 00:25:43.336
What happens to those files once I right
click on it and I delete the trash?

520
00:25:43.336 --> 00:25:45.600
Are they still there,
can they still be recovered as well?

521
00:25:45.600 --> 00:25:46.488
Is it no different?

522
00:25:46.488 --> 00:25:47.649
>> It's a little bit different.

523
00:25:47.649 --> 00:25:49.925
When you put them in the trash,
the files still exist.

524
00:25:49.925 --> 00:25:52.444
You can actually browse to it and
see it in the operating system,

525
00:25:52.444 --> 00:25:54.180
you still have that visibility.

526
00:25:54.180 --> 00:25:56.960
When you empty the trash,
that's when it actually gets deleted.

527
00:25:56.960 --> 00:26:00.050
And that's the one I'm talking about where
the file name is now marked as deleted,

528
00:26:00.050 --> 00:26:03.610
and the file's hidden from the operating
system but it can still be recovered.

529
00:26:03.610 --> 00:26:06.680
So if it's in the trash,
you've got no protection whatsoever.

530
00:26:06.680 --> 00:26:08.460
If it's deleted, at least it's hidden.

531
00:26:08.460 --> 00:26:12.390
And somebody would have to work at
least a little bit harder to do it.

532
00:26:12.390 --> 00:26:15.530
Now, this secure erase is gonna happen and
it's gonna kinda churn along.

533
00:26:15.530 --> 00:26:17.151
There's one more thing
I wanted to show you.

534
00:26:17.151 --> 00:26:21.517
I chose the volume and I hit erase,
and so it's gonna churn along and

535
00:26:21.517 --> 00:26:24.200
take its time and eventually do this.

536
00:26:24.200 --> 00:26:27.341
I'm gonna get impatient, you know what,
I'm just gonna break the rules and

537
00:26:27.341 --> 00:26:30.674
unplug that thing, because I wanna show
you there is another option that pops up,

538
00:26:30.674 --> 00:26:33.600
and that disk is gonna be corrupted now,
so I'll have to recover that.

539
00:26:33.600 --> 00:26:36.651
But if I had done the erase
on the drive itself,

540
00:26:36.651 --> 00:26:42.284
there's another option where it asks about
whether you want to erase the free space,

541
00:26:42.284 --> 00:26:45.040
the empty space on that disk, all right?

542
00:26:45.040 --> 00:26:49.210
If there's empty space that hasn't been
written to, do we need to erase it?

543
00:26:49.210 --> 00:26:50.840
Well, there's a bit of a debate on that.

544
00:26:50.840 --> 00:26:53.310
Some people say yes,
some people say no, right?

545
00:26:53.310 --> 00:26:58.137
If I have a 200 GB drive, and I've written
20 GB of data to it, well technically I

546
00:26:58.137 --> 00:27:02.849
only need to do the secure scrub on the 20
GB, that'll make it go faster, right?

547
00:27:02.849 --> 00:27:06.136
But if somebody were to intercept this,
they'd kind of have an idea that I had at

548
00:27:06.136 --> 00:27:08.805
least 20 GB of data on there, so
at least that kinda leaks out.

549
00:27:08.805 --> 00:27:10.710
But the free space we
don't necessarily scrub.

550
00:27:10.710 --> 00:27:15.440
Well, you might want to scrub
that free space to make sure

551
00:27:15.440 --> 00:27:18.209
that that's completely clear.

552
00:27:18.209 --> 00:27:21.090
Now, people can't even tell how
much data you had on there.

553
00:27:21.090 --> 00:27:25.930
So if I had chosen the erase from the
drive controller itself, from the hardware

554
00:27:25.930 --> 00:27:29.340
drive instead of the volume, then I would
have had that option about the free space

555
00:27:29.340 --> 00:27:32.290
but I didn't do it and now that I've
inappropriately remove the drive,

556
00:27:32.290 --> 00:27:34.840
it's not gonna come back up for

557
00:27:34.840 --> 00:27:39.688
So, I'll have to go into the disk
utility and run a repair on that one.

558
00:27:39.688 --> 00:27:41.023
But, actually, it's sort of coming back.

559
00:27:41.023 --> 00:27:42.231
It's definitely not happy.

560
00:27:42.231 --> 00:27:44.843
So you can see it,
it recognizes my controller now.

561
00:27:44.843 --> 00:27:47.338
But the partition is
kinda grayed out here and

562
00:27:47.338 --> 00:27:49.710
unhappy because of
the way I yanked it out.

563
00:27:49.710 --> 00:27:52.462
But when we go to erase these things,
you have.

564
00:27:52.462 --> 00:27:54.099
Shoot.
Now, it doesn't even show the partition.

565
00:27:54.099 --> 00:27:54.958
So, yeah.

566
00:27:54.958 --> 00:27:58.902
You do have that option though where
you can just do the written space.

567
00:27:58.902 --> 00:28:01.317
We normally could just go and
do the whole thing and

00:28:01.317 --> 00:28:04.662
that's what it was doing when I was
wiping this partition here, so.

569
00:28:04.662 --> 00:28:06.125
A couple of different
options are out there.

570
00:28:06.125 --> 00:28:08.950
>> Well Don, it looks like we're
coming to the end of another episode.

00:28:08.950 --> 00:28:11.365
We're definitely a little

00:28:11.365 --> 00:28:13.570
Got any last words for

>> Remember that destruction
is always an option.

574
00:28:16.263 --> 00:28:17.007
You can always destroy the drive.

575
00:28:17.007 --> 00:28:18.086
That one, you can always trust.

576
00:28:18.086 --> 00:28:22.005
But on the exam, just remember
that you do have a two, three, and

577
00:28:22.005 --> 00:28:24.948
seven pass option to
securely erase your drive.

578
00:28:24.948 --> 00:28:29.788
And then back on FileVault, don't lose
your recovery key, it's important.

579
00:28:29.788 --> 00:28:33.570
It's gonna save your bacon, if you ever
lose your password and it's important.

580
00:28:33.570 --> 00:28:36.428
But if somebody else gets a hold of it,
it's a giant risk too.

581
00:28:36.428 --> 00:28:38.910
So you need to make sure that
it's stored somewhere safe.

582
00:28:38.910 --> 00:28:40.440
>> Well, thank you for
that information, Don, and

583
00:28:40.440 --> 00:28:42.160
thank you to our viewers out there for
watching.

584
00:28:42.160 --> 00:28:44.700
But we're gonna go ahead and
sign out here at IT Pro TV.

585
00:28:44.700 --> 00:28:46.380
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

00:28:46.380 --> 00:28:47.100

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain file permissions in concept and practice in Mac OS 10.11. They start by explaining the types of objects that will be affected by permissions, specifically being the User/Owner, Groups, and Other users. Then they look at what permissions can be set and define them. All this is shown in both the Graphical Interface and the Command Line.
episodes.title: File Permissions

First off what are permissions, right?

44
00:01:52.360 --> 00:01:56.550
When you create a file in Mac OS and
any file, any folder for that matter.

45
00:01:56.550 --> 00:02:01.280

46

00:02:06.930 --> 00:02:08.270

00:02:13.230 --> 00:02:13.890
the file or folder.

Now if you have a laptop for example and

But if you've got a shared computer,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don complete their coverage of file permissions by diving into the Home folder structure and default permissions. They look at default folders in the Home directory, like the Public folder which is used for sharing data with other users. They also look at the Shared folder which performs similarly to the Public folder. They also show you how to retain file permissions and protect against deletion by setting the "sticky bit". And finally they show you how to repair permissions that have be damaged as well as working with the file systems on removable media.
