00:24:40.665 --> 00:24:45.133
But, if it's not encrypted,
then we can just set it like this and

534
00:24:45.133 --> 00:24:46.690
hope for the best.

535
00:24:46.690 --> 00:24:49.880
Now, where I bump into this as a problem
is like, I have a Mac Mini at home and

536
00:24:49.880 --> 00:24:51.490
it's got two hard drives in it.

537
00:24:51.490 --> 00:24:54.465
Well, the Macintosh HD, that's the first
hard drive, that's the main one and

538
00:24:54.465 --> 00:24:55.510
it's set as normal.

539
00:24:55.510 --> 00:24:58.440
But the other one when I formatted it,
for whatever reason, even though

540
00:24:58.440 --> 00:25:03.110
it was internal drive, my system saw it as
removable and it ignored ownership on it.

541
00:25:03.110 --> 00:25:06.570
I went and turned that off because I
was no, no, this is an internal drive.

542
00:25:06.570 --> 00:25:09.480
I want to obey those permissions,
and so I had to set it.

543
00:25:09.480 --> 00:25:11.040
So always be on the lookout for that one.

544
00:25:11.040 --> 00:25:13.630
That little, it's easy to miss,
especially when it's

545
00:25:13.630 --> 00:25:17.580
the medium gray on top of a light gray,
it's real easy to miss.

546
00:25:17.580 --> 00:25:18.690
Ignore ownership on this volume.

547
00:25:18.690 --> 00:25:21.065
>> It's like it's camouflaged,
trying to keep you from seeing it.

548
00:25:21.065 --> 00:25:22.611
[LAUGH]
>> It's super annoying is what it is.

549
00:25:22.611 --> 00:25:26.199
[LAUGH] But yeah, when that's turned on,
it effectively kills the permissions on

550
00:25:26.199 --> 00:25:29.527
the disk and you might as well not have
them so, just a different behavior for

551
00:25:29.527 --> 00:25:31.503
removal of media that
you need to be aware of.

552
00:25:31.503 --> 00:25:33.200
>> Yeah, definitely something
you gotta look out for.

553
00:25:33.200 --> 00:25:35.970
You don't wanna think, yeah,
I'll just set those permissions and

554
00:25:35.970 --> 00:25:36.820
everything will work fine.

555
00:25:36.820 --> 00:25:38.000
You gotta look out for

556
00:25:38.000 --> 00:25:41.410
those caveats that they like to shove
in our operating systems for us.

557
00:25:41.410 --> 00:25:42.112
>> [LAUGH]
>> Don,

558
00:25:42.112 --> 00:25:44.395
is there anything else
about file permissions?

559
00:25:44.395 --> 00:25:46.208
We've had quite a journey here, so far.

560
00:25:46.208 --> 00:25:47.846
I'm sure you've got plenty more.

561
00:25:47.846 --> 00:25:50.835
>> I think I'm all permissioned out,
Daniel, to be honest with you.

562
00:25:50.835 --> 00:25:53.170
So, just be aware,
when we talk about permissions,

563
00:25:53.170 --> 00:25:56.010
it really is the OS X Extended Journal,
that's where that happens.

564
00:25:56.010 --> 00:25:59.845
When you go exFAT, when you go regular
FAT, when you go to any of the other

565
00:25:59.845 --> 00:26:04.280
Unix-y stuff type formats, you lose a lot
of the extra permissions that we have.

566
00:26:04.280 --> 00:26:06.610
So it is tied to that file system.

567
00:26:06.610 --> 00:26:09.530
>> All right, Don, well thank you so
much for explaining these different file

568
00:26:09.530 --> 00:26:12.540
systems and permissions that
are gonna be used on top of them.

569
00:26:12.540 --> 00:26:14.723
Especially that Extended Journal one,
wanna keep that in the brain,

570
00:26:14.723 --> 00:26:15.874
gonna need to know that for the test.

571
00:26:15.874 --> 00:26:19.130
>> [LAUGH]
>> And again, thank you for stopping by.

572
00:26:19.130 --> 00:26:20.390
Thank you guys for watching.

573
00:26:20.390 --> 00:26:21.220
We're going to go ahead and

574
00:26:21.220 --> 00:26:23.740
sign off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

575
00:26:23.740 --> 00:26:24.570
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

576
00:26:24.570 --> 00:26:26.383
>> We'll see you next time.

577
00:26:26.383 --> 00:26:33.186
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore the magical world of managing files in Mac OS 10.11. They begin the journey by discussing Aliases and Links. Both are magical ways to access a file or folder from a different location; each having its pros and cons. They also look at application files called Bundles and system packages.
episodes.title: Managing Files
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.336 --> 00:00:10.336
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.102 --> 00:00:16.150
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.150 --> 00:00:18.330
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

4
00:00:18.330 --> 00:00:21.430
in today's episode we
are continuing on with our Apple,

5
00:00:21.430 --> 00:00:25.470
if I can just say that word, Apple
Certified Support Professional Series.

6
00:00:25.470 --> 00:00:27.949
Joining us back in the studio today,
to help us out with that very endeavor,

7
00:00:27.949 --> 00:00:29.670
is none other than our good friend,
Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:29.670 --> 00:00:31.300
Don, welcome back to the show, sir.

9
00:00:31.300 --> 00:00:33.200
>> Thanks for having me back, Daniel.

10
00:00:33.200 --> 00:00:35.160
We're ready to jump right
back into the support world.

11
00:00:35.160 --> 00:00:37.940
And in this episode, we're going
to take a look at managing files.

12
00:00:37.940 --> 00:00:41.250
Now, in our last couple of episodes we
talked about managing file permissions.

13
00:00:41.250 --> 00:00:43.980
We've kind of been working
with files a bit, but

14
00:00:43.980 --> 00:00:46.486
I want to talk about the files themselves.

15
00:00:46.486 --> 00:00:49.210
Because in OS X there's actually several
different types of files that we

16
00:00:49.210 --> 00:00:52.400
encounter, and
from the user interface, from the GUI,

17
00:00:52.400 --> 00:00:56.070
you might not notice the difference on
these, a lot of them look the same.

18
00:00:56.070 --> 00:00:57.990
But we need to understand
exactly what they are,

19
00:00:57.990 --> 00:01:01.780
because as a support professional, these
are the things that we have to deal with.

20
00:01:01.780 --> 00:01:05.850
So I wanna start with a neat topic,
it's called an alias.

21
00:01:05.850 --> 00:01:09.645
And that when you have a file in your
hard drive, it's normally a single file,

22
00:01:09.645 --> 00:01:12.700
it exists in one place, and that's it.

23
00:01:12.700 --> 00:01:16.160
But we might wanna link to that
file from more than one place.

24
00:01:16.160 --> 00:01:22.220
And back in the old days, so if any of
you guys ran Mac OS 9.6 or earlier,

25
00:01:22.220 --> 00:01:27.440
you had these aliases that were there, and
that was the one system you had for it.

26
00:01:27.440 --> 00:01:31.470
But in OS X, we have not only
the old alias system that's still,

27
00:01:31.470 --> 00:01:33.610
I shouldn't call it the old alias
system cuz they kinda revamped it and

28
00:01:33.610 --> 00:01:36.310
made it a lot better, so
we still have that alias system, but

29
00:01:36.310 --> 00:01:38.800
we also have all the BSD.

30
00:01:38.800 --> 00:01:42.580
All the UNIX technologies under the hood,
so we can do soft and hard links,

31
00:01:42.580 --> 00:01:44.500
which are part of the UNIX subsystem.

32
00:01:44.500 --> 00:01:49.562
So, there's more than one way to link to
a file in multiple places on your system.

33
00:01:49.562 --> 00:01:52.027
And it does get a little confusing,
so we want to walk through those,

34
00:01:52.027 --> 00:01:55.019
as well as some other file technologies
that we're gonna see later in the episode.

35
00:01:56.260 --> 00:01:58.880
All right, well let's kick this thing off,
and I'll give you an example.

36
00:01:58.880 --> 00:02:00.730
So I've got a Mac fired up here,

37
00:02:00.730 --> 00:02:05.008
and normally,
let's say I'm making my documents, right?

38
00:02:05.008 --> 00:02:07.890
And I know we've talked
about it in other episodes,

39
00:02:07.890 --> 00:02:11.280
about how we can turn on file encryption,
and

40
00:02:11.280 --> 00:02:15.260
we can turn on file permissions, and
customize who has access to what.

41
00:02:15.260 --> 00:02:19.260
When I start creating documents, I usually
keep them in my Documents folder, and

42
00:02:19.260 --> 00:02:20.405
that's where I want them to sit.

43
00:02:20.405 --> 00:02:23.250
And if I move them out
of my Documents folder,

44
00:02:23.250 --> 00:02:26.480
I run the risk of putting them
somewhere that's not secure,

45
00:02:26.480 --> 00:02:29.890
where people might be able to gain
access to them unintentionally.

46
00:02:29.890 --> 00:02:34.620
And so I want to make sure that my
documents stay in that Documents folder.

47
00:02:34.620 --> 00:02:38.480
And thanks to Apple's defaults here, when
I go into the Finder, I've got a favorite

48
00:02:38.480 --> 00:02:42.040
for my Documents folder, and I can jump
right in, and here's all my stuff.

49
00:02:42.040 --> 00:02:45.840
I see these documents that I made, my
first draft, my second draft, and so on.

50
00:02:45.840 --> 00:02:48.550
But, there's a little bit
of a problem with this.

51
00:02:48.550 --> 00:02:49.830
So when I come under Favorites, and

52
00:02:49.830 --> 00:02:53.120
I go to Documents,
see how that just changed on me?

53
00:02:53.120 --> 00:02:56.480
What I was actually looking
at was All My Files, right?

54
00:02:56.480 --> 00:03:00.250
All My Files, is a list of,
well oddly enough,

55
00:03:00.250 --> 00:03:04.820
all of your files irrespective of
the subdirectories that they're in.

56
00:03:04.820 --> 00:03:09.230
So I am seeing these documents here,
Second Draft, First Draft, Show 1, Show 2,

57
00:03:09.230 --> 00:03:11.360
and these are all in different files.

58
00:03:11.360 --> 00:03:13.250
And these are actually
in my Documents folder.

59
00:03:13.250 --> 00:03:15.380
I'm seeing some other things
that I've downloaded,

60
00:03:15.380 --> 00:03:19.240
these are my Downloads folder, and
it's just lumped them all together.

61
00:03:19.240 --> 00:03:23.150
But if I go here to Downloads,
I can see Virtual Box, Google Chrome.

62
00:03:23.150 --> 00:03:25.990
If I go to Documents,
now I see some folders.

63
00:03:25.990 --> 00:03:28.740
I've got a Manuscript folder and
a Show Notes folder.

64
00:03:28.740 --> 00:03:31.970
And if I expand those out,
there's these documents that I've got,

65
00:03:31.970 --> 00:03:35.480
and they're all in their respective
folders, nice and organized, okay?

66
00:03:35.480 --> 00:03:38.260
But I had to go to the Finder, and
then I had to go to Documents,

67
00:03:38.260 --> 00:03:40.260
I had to browse into it and find it.

68
00:03:40.260 --> 00:03:42.481
What if you've got one of
those end users who says,

69
00:03:42.481 --> 00:03:44.870
I just don't like clicking
through all of that stuff.

70
00:03:44.870 --> 00:03:47.854
When I come in in the morning, I want to
go straight to this folder, and get at it.

71
00:03:47.854 --> 00:03:51.690
Well, they could just take this folder and
move it somewhere else.

72
00:03:51.690 --> 00:03:54.150
They can move it to their desktop,
move it elsewhere.

73
00:03:54.150 --> 00:03:55.370
What's the risk with that?

74
00:03:55.370 --> 00:03:58.980
The risk is, let's say that I'm backing up
people's computers, and I'm just backing

75
00:03:58.980 --> 00:04:03.020
up their Documents folder, but they've
moved this folder to their desktop.

76
00:04:03.020 --> 00:04:08.080
If they move it to their desktop, it's now
gone from here, and it's on their desktop.

77
00:04:08.080 --> 00:04:09.530
And so it's easier for them to get to it.

78
00:04:09.530 --> 00:04:11.720
They come in the morning,
they just click on Show Notes, and

79
00:04:11.720 --> 00:04:13.550
there's their show notes, right?

80
00:04:13.550 --> 00:04:15.980
But I'm only backing up
their Documents folder.

81
00:04:15.980 --> 00:04:17.740
So what would've been better,

82
00:04:17.740 --> 00:04:22.270
would be instead of moving the document to
the desktop, is just to put a shortcut.

83
00:04:22.270 --> 00:04:25.030
Put a link on the desktop,
to be able to get to it.

84
00:04:25.030 --> 00:04:27.050
And in Mac OS that's pretty easy.

85
00:04:27.050 --> 00:04:32.350
You can take any of these items, and if
you control-click, or right-click on it,

86
00:04:32.350 --> 00:04:36.240
you can get in here, and
you can choose to make an alias, right?

87
00:04:36.240 --> 00:04:38.930
I usually just command L,
as another way that you can do it.

88
00:04:38.930 --> 00:04:41.506
But when you make an alias,
see what it made?

89
00:04:41.506 --> 00:04:43.712
This Show Notes alias file for me.

90
00:04:43.712 --> 00:04:47.316
And the Show Notes alias file is,
I'm gonna say it Daniel,

91
00:04:47.316 --> 00:04:48.913
it's somewhat magical.

92
00:04:48.913 --> 00:04:49.872
>> [LAUGH]
>> What it is,

93
00:04:49.872 --> 00:04:51.990
is it's actually pretty interesting.

94
00:04:51.990 --> 00:04:53.400
It is a file.

95
00:04:53.400 --> 00:04:58.210
And it's a pointer that helps us
find the original data, all right?

96
00:04:58.210 --> 00:05:02.430
But the cool part about it is,
it's not really dependent on anything.

97
00:05:02.430 --> 00:05:05.470
You can rename it,
call it whatever you want.

98
00:05:05.470 --> 00:05:09.872
So If I move it to my desktop, I'm just
gonna drop that out here on my desktop.

99
00:05:09.872 --> 00:05:13.444
So now I've got the original data,
which is still in my Documents folder,

100
00:05:13.444 --> 00:05:16.976
I can browse and I can find it, and
here's the alias file that I just made.

101
00:05:16.976 --> 00:05:21.088
And I can rename that to
pretty much whatever.

102
00:05:21.088 --> 00:05:24.480
So I'm gonna rename it,
maybe I'll just call it Notes, right?

103
00:05:24.480 --> 00:05:29.070
Does it matter that the name doesn't
match the original file anymore, right?

104
00:05:29.070 --> 00:05:32.540
The name of this is Notes,
the original file is Show Notes.

105
00:05:32.540 --> 00:05:34.520
That's okay, that doesn't matter.

106
00:05:34.520 --> 00:05:38.640
If I click on this, it's gonna open up and
it's gonna take me right to my show notes,

107
00:05:38.640 --> 00:05:39.300
there they are.

108
00:05:39.300 --> 00:05:42.240
I get into it, and I can access the data,
now I've got one click to go there.

109
00:05:42.240 --> 00:05:47.120
My data stays in the Documents folder,
but I've got a link on my desktop.

110
00:05:47.120 --> 00:05:49.360
Now let's talk a little
bit about that link.

111
00:05:49.360 --> 00:05:50.230
I say it's magical.

112
00:05:50.230 --> 00:05:51.200
What the heck do I mean by that?

113
00:05:51.200 --> 00:05:52.342
Because, that's a garbage term.

114
00:05:52.342 --> 00:05:54.350
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] It's not a garbage term,

115
00:05:54.350 --> 00:05:55.330
it's a marketing term.

116
00:05:55.330 --> 00:05:56.316
>> It means it can fly.

117
00:05:56.316 --> 00:05:57.986
[LAUGH]
>> It can cure cancer,

118
00:05:57.986 --> 00:05:59.420
it can do all sorts of things.

119
00:05:59.420 --> 00:06:00.330
>> This thing's awesome.

120
00:06:00.330 --> 00:06:03.860
>> But what it really is,
is a tracker, okay?

121
00:06:03.860 --> 00:06:06.980
When you create that link, it's doing
a lot more than just saying, yeah,

122
00:06:06.980 --> 00:06:08.470
the original file's over here.

123
00:06:08.470 --> 00:06:10.860
It's actually tracking the original file.

124
00:06:10.860 --> 00:06:12.140
It's tracking where it is.

125
00:06:12.140 --> 00:06:13.770
If I rename the original file,

126
00:06:13.770 --> 00:06:17.290
if I move the original file,
this alias would be okay with that.

127
00:06:17.290 --> 00:06:18.240
It'll follow it.

128
00:06:18.240 --> 00:06:20.617
It'll follow it, and still link to it.

129
00:06:20.617 --> 00:06:25.397
So if I drop to my terminal here,
and I go over to my desktop, and

130
00:06:25.397 --> 00:06:31.193
I take a look at the files that are in
there, notice that Notes link, right?

131
00:06:31.193 --> 00:06:33.790
There's the Notes, and
it just looks like a folder to me.

132
00:06:33.790 --> 00:06:37.880
If I look at my permissions though,
there's no d.

133
00:06:37.880 --> 00:06:39.270
It's not a directory, right?

134
00:06:39.270 --> 00:06:43.603
In UNIX, or Linux, or any of the BSD
UNIX-type environments like we've got

135
00:06:43.603 --> 00:06:47.080
here, if it's a folder,
you'll have a d for directory.

136
00:06:47.080 --> 00:06:49.870
This is a dash,
because it's actually a link file.

137
00:06:49.870 --> 00:06:51.630
It's a file that points somewhere else.

138
00:06:51.630 --> 00:06:54.318
And it's got special attributes attached,
I've got the little @ symbol there,

139
00:06:54.318 --> 00:06:55.040
letting me know that.

140
00:06:55.040 --> 00:06:58.655
So I know that it's got more
than meets the eye here,

141
00:06:58.655 --> 00:07:00.290
than what we've got with just the file.

142
00:07:00.290 --> 00:07:03.040
But the cool thing,
maybe not the cool thing, but

143
00:07:03.040 --> 00:07:05.420
the real indicator I guess, is the size.

144
00:07:05.420 --> 00:07:07.640
Look at the size on that thing.

145
00:07:07.640 --> 00:07:09.968
If we take a look at the size,
oops, I wanted to add-

146
00:07:09.968 --> 00:07:12.005
>> Where's your h, Don?

147
00:07:12.005 --> 00:07:14.700
>> I know, I'm screwing this up here,
my mouse is going crazy.

148
00:07:16.320 --> 00:07:16.835
There we go.

149
00:07:16.835 --> 00:07:23.620
So if we take a look at that,
that little Notes alias, is 1.2M in size.

150
00:07:23.620 --> 00:07:29.620
Why the heck would an alias, a link that
points, supposed to be 1.2M in size?

151
00:07:29.620 --> 00:07:31.950
Well, because it's magic.

152
00:07:31.950 --> 00:07:32.734
>> It's magic dust.

153
00:07:32.734 --> 00:07:33.490
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

154
00:07:33.490 --> 00:07:36.990
if you wanted to do a lot,
it takes a lot to do it.

155
00:07:36.990 --> 00:07:40.660
When you create an alias,
the minimum size I think that I've seen,

156
00:07:40.660 --> 00:07:43.980
is usually around 200k,
they're a decent size.

157
00:07:43.980 --> 00:07:46.110
Because it's almost more
like a database in a way,

158
00:07:46.110 --> 00:07:49.540
it's saying I've gotta track where this
other stuff is, to be able to find it.

159
00:07:49.540 --> 00:07:50.982
So the size can be a little bit large, and

160
00:07:50.982 --> 00:07:53.410
it'll actually reflect the size
of the original Notes file, too.

161
00:07:53.410 --> 00:07:57.407
So if I start adding more stuff to that
notes folder, this will grow and grow and

162
00:07:57.407 --> 00:07:58.571
grow to reflect that.

163
00:07:58.571 --> 00:08:01.309
It's not actually taking double space,
It's just reflecting that size because

164
00:08:01.309 --> 00:08:03.784
it's pointing to the original, so
we're gonna see that reflected too.

165
00:08:03.784 --> 00:08:08.140
So you can't really trust
the size of an alias file.

166
00:08:08.140 --> 00:08:10.460
But if you make an alias
of an empty folder,

167
00:08:10.460 --> 00:08:14.450
it'll still be a good 200K just because
that's kinda the base size of that alias.

168
00:08:14.450 --> 00:08:16.870
And then it'll reflect
the additional size of that folder.

169
00:08:16.870 --> 00:08:19.560
So it is a little bit on the magical side.

170
00:08:19.560 --> 00:08:20.770
It's doing a lot.

171
00:08:20.770 --> 00:08:22.480
Let's see it in action.

172
00:08:22.480 --> 00:08:26.110
So if I go back to my desktop
here I've created this alias.

173
00:08:26.110 --> 00:08:28.950
I know it's an alias because it's
got that little black arrow on it.

174
00:08:28.950 --> 00:08:31.570
That arrow tells me that this is
actually pointing somewhere else.

175
00:08:31.570 --> 00:08:34.510

00:30:02.450 --> 00:30:04.230
dropped into my applications folder.

630
00:30:04.230 --> 00:30:09.240
And if I browse into that, it is just
a folder, and it's got a contents folder,

631
00:30:09.240 --> 00:30:13.870
and it's got everything inside of it
that it needs including the MacOS folder

632
00:30:13.870 --> 00:30:16.240
which is where the real program resides.

633
00:30:16.240 --> 00:30:21.547
And so there's the actual Google Chrome
browser nested inside of that .app file,

634
00:30:21.547 --> 00:30:22.180
right?

635
00:30:22.180 --> 00:30:26.590
That's how most applications are going
to work, is you just have the .app file.

636
00:30:26.590 --> 00:30:29.310
Everything that program needs
is self contained, you drag, and

637
00:30:29.310 --> 00:30:31.150
you drop it, and that's it.

638
00:30:31.150 --> 00:30:32.690
But there are exceptions.

639
00:30:32.690 --> 00:30:35.480
Some programs need more.

640
00:30:35.480 --> 00:30:37.730
Some programs interact with your hardware.

641
00:30:37.730 --> 00:30:40.470
And if they interact with your hardware,
they may need to install drivers.

642
00:30:40.470 --> 00:30:44.020
They may need to install
some system functionality.

643
00:30:44.020 --> 00:30:46.250
And that can't reside in
the applications folder.

644
00:30:46.250 --> 00:30:47.700
It's gotta reside over
in the systems folder.

645
00:30:47.700 --> 00:30:50.570
It's gotta put data in other
places on the hard drive, and

646
00:30:50.570 --> 00:30:51.880
a normal application is
not allowed to do that.

647
00:30:51.880 --> 00:30:53.310
Remember how I said we've got sandboxes.

648
00:30:53.310 --> 00:30:57.310
These things are being walled off and
protected in their own little environment.

649
00:30:57.310 --> 00:30:59.260
What if they need to write somewhere else?

650
00:30:59.260 --> 00:31:00.420
They can't.

651
00:31:00.420 --> 00:31:03.120
Well, for that you won't get a .app file.

652
00:31:03.120 --> 00:31:04.980
Instead you'll get a .pkg.

653
00:31:04.980 --> 00:31:07.650
And what a .pkg is it's a package file.

654
00:31:07.650 --> 00:31:10.990
And a package file contains a lot
more than just an application, and

655
00:31:10.990 --> 00:31:11.570
let me show you.

656
00:31:11.570 --> 00:31:15.240
I've got one that I downloaded before
the show, which was VirtualBox.

657
00:31:15.240 --> 00:31:19.110
So VirtualBox, if you've never heard
of it, it's a visualization software.

658
00:31:19.110 --> 00:31:20.360
It lets you run virtual machines.

659
00:31:20.360 --> 00:31:25.180
So I could run Windows on top of MacOS,
or I could run Linux on top of MacOS and

660
00:31:25.180 --> 00:31:27.110
still have my in tact
operating system beneath it.

661
00:31:27.110 --> 00:31:27.660
It's kinda fun.

662
00:31:27.660 --> 00:31:29.480
I use these things in
the show all the time.

663
00:31:29.480 --> 00:31:33.180
If I need two or three workstations,
I can whip them up as virtual machines.

664
00:31:33.180 --> 00:31:36.500
Well when you install VirtualBox,
it has to install

665
00:31:36.500 --> 00:31:40.380
hardware drivers to allow the virtual
machines to see your network adapters, and

666
00:31:40.380 --> 00:31:42.400
your wireless network, and
all those other good things.

667
00:31:42.400 --> 00:31:45.220
So it's gotta do a lot more
than just create a .app file.

668
00:31:45.220 --> 00:31:49.450
Well if I mount the DMG for VirtualBox,
I'm gonna get that one connected.

669
00:31:50.730 --> 00:31:56.600
And I open it up, it doesn't have a drag
me to the applications folder and drop it.

670
00:31:56.600 --> 00:31:58.562
It has a PKG file.

671
00:31:58.562 --> 00:32:00.554
And PKGs are packages.

672
00:32:00.554 --> 00:32:01.326
They're a package.

673
00:32:01.326 --> 00:32:02.590
They've got the application.

674
00:32:02.590 --> 00:32:04.946
There is a .app inside of there, right?

675
00:32:04.946 --> 00:32:07.439
But there's also a series of scripts and

676
00:32:07.439 --> 00:32:11.850
other files that need to be copied
outside of the Applications folder.

677
00:32:11.850 --> 00:32:15.327
So it's an automated installer
that tells the system what to do.

678
00:32:15.327 --> 00:32:18.890
And when you run a package file,
you gotta be an administrator.

679
00:32:18.890 --> 00:32:21.560
When I dragged Google Chrome and
dropped it in my Applications folder,

680
00:32:21.560 --> 00:32:23.230
did it prompt me for a password?

681
00:32:23.230 --> 00:32:23.970
No.

682
00:32:23.970 --> 00:32:25.790
When I ran it,
did it prompt me for a password?

683
00:32:25.790 --> 00:32:26.560
No.

684
00:32:26.560 --> 00:32:29.710
All it did was tell me, hey,
you downloaded this from the Internet,

685
00:32:29.710 --> 00:32:31.080
are you sure you want to run it?

686
00:32:31.080 --> 00:32:32.590
When I run this .pkg file,

687
00:32:32.590 --> 00:32:36.040
I'm gonna double click on it and
it's gonna tell me it's gonna install.

688
00:32:36.040 --> 00:32:41.180
And as it moves forward on the installer,
it's gonna ask me for

689
00:32:41.180 --> 00:32:42.900
my password, I gotta be the administrator.

690
00:32:42.900 --> 00:32:45.710
Cuz I'm not just writing
to the Applications folder.

691
00:32:45.710 --> 00:32:47.190
Now I'm writing outside.

692
00:32:47.190 --> 00:32:48.830
And I've gotta have permission to do that.

693
00:32:48.830 --> 00:32:52.270
It's got more data than just a .app file.

694
00:32:52.270 --> 00:32:55.680
>> So these aren't sandboxed
like the apps that were before.

695
00:32:55.680 --> 00:32:56.490
>> That's exactly right.

696
00:32:56.490 --> 00:32:59.340
I mean, technically the app is still
sandboxed, but it doesn't matter cuz it's

697
00:32:59.340 --> 00:33:02.720
got access to the underlying system,
which means it can bypass the sandbox.

698
00:33:02.720 --> 00:33:04.125
>> So it's a sifty sandbox.

699
00:33:04.125 --> 00:33:07.530
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it's more of a guideline, and

700
00:33:07.530 --> 00:33:08.750
like a suggestion.

701
00:33:08.750 --> 00:33:10.910
Let me suggest you don't
mess with the other apps.

702
00:33:10.910 --> 00:33:13.970
So when that installs,
that's a good bit different, right?

703
00:33:13.970 --> 00:33:18.750
And if I drop back to my file system, and
I go into my applications folder, and

704
00:33:18.750 --> 00:33:21.350
I browse around in here, okay.

705
00:33:21.350 --> 00:33:26.330
I can see way up here,
here's Google Chrome, right.

706
00:33:26.330 --> 00:33:28.210
And so Google Chrome,
I dragged and dropped it and

707
00:33:28.210 --> 00:33:29.790
it shows it is being owned by me.

708
00:33:29.790 --> 00:33:31.860
It's a directory, there it is.

709
00:33:31.860 --> 00:33:36.810
And if I look down here, somewhere,
I can find VirtualBox and

710
00:33:36.810 --> 00:33:38.720
notice who VirtualBox is owned by?

711
00:33:38.720 --> 00:33:41.170
Not dpezet, it's owned by root.

712
00:33:41.170 --> 00:33:44.025
When it installed,
it installed as the system account.

713
00:33:44.025 --> 00:33:47.018
It's got a lot more access than
an application owned by dpezet.

714
00:33:47.018 --> 00:33:49.520
All right, if it's owned by me,
it has the same permissions as me.

715
00:33:49.520 --> 00:33:51.810
If it's owned by root,
it has full access to the system.

716
00:33:51.810 --> 00:33:53.270
It can bypass the sandbox.

717
00:33:54.340 --> 00:33:55.490
And it's still a directory.

718
00:33:55.490 --> 00:33:57.080
It's still a .app file.

719
00:33:57.080 --> 00:34:00.430
If I were to browse inside of it,
I'll see that.

720
00:34:00.430 --> 00:34:03.860
So if I browse into Applications and
I find VirtualBox in the list,

721
00:34:03.860 --> 00:34:06.686
I can right-click on it and
do Show Package Contents.

722
00:34:06.686 --> 00:34:11.402
And now I've got the Contents folder and
I've got the MacOS folder, and holy moly,

723
00:34:11.402 --> 00:34:15.180
there is a lot more in here than
just one application, right?

724
00:34:15.180 --> 00:34:21.564
So in here somewhere, somewhere in here,
here we go is the VirtualBox service.

725
00:34:21.564 --> 00:34:24.350
That's what runs in the background,
that's what the system is going to run.

726
00:34:24.350 --> 00:34:27.800
And then somewhere in here is the user
interface, which is this guy right here,

727
00:34:27.800 --> 00:34:29.820
the VirtualBox user interface.

728
00:34:29.820 --> 00:34:34.090
Each of these are individual programs that
make up a part of this bigger program.

729
00:34:34.090 --> 00:34:37.680
And it's copied additional files into
my system libraries and other places.

730
00:34:37.680 --> 00:34:41.580
So it's done a lot more than
a typical program, all right?

731
00:34:41.580 --> 00:34:46.300
So these are all different kinds of files
that we might see on our system, and

732
00:34:46.300 --> 00:34:47.820
I know I talked about aliases,

733
00:34:47.820 --> 00:34:51.420
which are kind of like
a miniature tracking database.

734
00:34:51.420 --> 00:34:55.450
We talked about hard links and soft links,
which aren't real files, they're pointers.

735
00:34:55.450 --> 00:34:58.310
And then we talked about applications and
the bundles and

736
00:34:58.310 --> 00:35:01.430
the packages that are part of those and
how they really break the rules.

737
00:35:01.430 --> 00:35:02.740
They're not a single file anymore.

738
00:35:02.740 --> 00:35:04.630
They're a directory and
there's a ton of stuff inside of them.

739
00:35:04.630 --> 00:35:07.950
So those are all different types of
files that we'll get exposed to as we

740
00:35:07.950 --> 00:35:08.830
work with Mac OS.

741
00:35:08.830 --> 00:35:11.400
>> Well Don, I don't know about our
viewers, but I'm sure they would agree,

742
00:35:11.400 --> 00:35:15.740
like myself, I could listen to you
wax eloquent about this all day long.

743
00:35:15.740 --> 00:35:20.140
But I'm looking at our clock, and
it's definitely expired in its time.

744
00:35:20.140 --> 00:35:21.250
We'll have to do another part two,

745
00:35:21.250 --> 00:35:25.290
cuz I know you've got plenty more to talk
about when it comes to files themselves.

746
00:35:25.290 --> 00:35:26.780
>> Yeah, I focused on files this time.

747
00:35:26.780 --> 00:35:29.740
I wanna talk more about folders in
the next episode, so stay tuned for that,

748
00:35:29.740 --> 00:35:32.150
cuz we're gonna take a look at some of
the different folders that are present.

749
00:35:32.150 --> 00:35:35.340
Some are system folders, some are hidden
folders, and kinda how they work, so

750
00:35:35.340 --> 00:35:39.060
we've got a little bit of that to see and
a bit more on those extensions.

751
00:35:39.060 --> 00:35:40.620
I know I mentioned frameworks but
didn't get into it, and

752
00:35:40.620 --> 00:35:42.650
I wanna tackle those two, so
definitely stay tuned for those.

753
00:35:42.650 --> 00:35:43.420
>> Yeah, that'll be awesome.

754
00:35:43.420 --> 00:35:44.650
Hopefully, you guys will enjoy that.

755
00:35:44.650 --> 00:35:45.840
Don, thanks for stopping by.

756
00:35:45.840 --> 00:35:47.940
We look forward to seeing you in part two.

757
00:35:47.940 --> 00:35:49.470
Hopefully, we'll see you there as well.

758
00:35:49.470 --> 00:35:51.610
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

759
00:35:51.610 --> 00:35:53.440
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

760
00:35:53.440 --> 00:35:54.240
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

761
00:35:54.240 --> 00:35:56.480
>> We'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue looking at file management in Mac OS 10.11. Here they explain how to work with and create hidden system files and folders. They also show you the 4 file domains which includes the User, Local, Network, and System domains. Finally they guide you through some important system resources like extensions, fonts, frameworks, logs, preferences, and Startup items.

WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

2

All right, greetings everyone and welcome

episode we're continuing on with our

00:00:20.853 --> 00:00:23.311
Apple Certified Support

Joining us back in the studio again today,
none other than our good friend and

00:00:27.454 --> 00:00:28.868

00:00:28.868 --> 00:00:30.280

Ready to jump right back into

we got a chance to see aliases and

links, symbolic links, hard links,

kinda tinker around
a bit with those files.

There's a few other special types

15

And actually,
I guess I should stop saying files,

16
00:00:51.910 --> 00:00:55.690
cuz there's really some special folders

17

And again, these are things that your

00:01:01.530 --> 00:01:04.780
But for us as administrators, as support
professionals, we have to deal with it.

20
00:01:04.780 --> 00:01:07.580
So, let's dive in, and

21
00:01:07.580 --> 00:01:09.880
Now, for your average end user experience,
right, so

22
00:01:09.880 --> 00:01:14.110
I've got a stock install of El Capitan,
whatever it was, this is fired up here.

23
00:01:14.110 --> 00:01:15.890
And for your average end user,

24
00:01:15.890 --> 00:01:19.270
their world kind of just rotates
around their home directory.

25
00:01:19.270 --> 00:01:23.155
When they fire up the Finder, the Finder
starts with All My Files, and All My Files

26
00:01:23.155 --> 00:01:26.880
is showing them, well, all of their
files that are in their home directory.

27
00:01:26.880 --> 00:01:30.690
So, in their Downloads,
their Documents, their Desktop, and

28
00:01:30.690 --> 00:01:32.080
it can get littered pretty fast.

29
00:01:32.080 --> 00:01:34.200
But, they can go over here and
say, just show me my Desktop, or

30
00:01:34.200 --> 00:01:36.860
just show me my Documents,
just show me my Downloads.

31
00:01:36.860 --> 00:01:39.257
All of these folders exist
in their profile, and

32
00:01:39.257 --> 00:01:41.430
we've seen the profile in other episodes.

33
00:01:41.430 --> 00:01:45.130
If you ever wanna see it,
you can go up here to your Go menu and

34
00:01:45.130 --> 00:01:47.723
you've got the Home option right there.

35
00:01:47.723 --> 00:01:50.855
So they can go to their Home and
here's their Home folder where they've got

36
00:01:50.855 --> 00:01:53.452
Desktops, Documents, Downloads,
those three main ones.

37
00:01:53.452 --> 00:01:56.283
Now they've also got Movies,
Music, Pictures, and Public and

38
00:01:56.283 --> 00:01:58.850
we've talked about those
in other episodes also.

39
00:01:58.850 --> 00:02:03.000
But these are just places for
them to store their stuff, right?

40
00:02:03.000 --> 00:02:05.800
But these are a little bit special,
these are system folders.

41
00:02:05.800 --> 00:02:07.867
I mean they're not part of
the underlying operating system,

42
00:02:07.867 --> 00:02:09.330
they're part of the user profile.

43
00:02:09.330 --> 00:02:12.600
But I know they're special because
they have little pictures on them.

44
00:02:12.600 --> 00:02:16.780
If I make a folder, so I decide I wanna
create a folder called TopSecret, right?

45
00:02:16.780 --> 00:02:20.380
This is where I'm gonna
store all my awesome stuff.

46
00:02:20.380 --> 00:02:23.980
It's just a folder and
it's blue and that's it.

47
00:02:23.980 --> 00:02:28.780
There's no special camera or
music symbol or anything like that on it,

48
00:02:28.780 --> 00:02:29.840
just a regular old folder.

49
00:02:29.840 --> 00:02:32.880
So that's one way that we kinda spot
that these folders are special,

50
00:02:32.880 --> 00:02:33.570
they're different.

51
00:02:33.570 --> 00:02:36.980
They're created by the operating system
and there's many that are like that,

52
00:02:36.980 --> 00:02:39.280
some we see, some we don't see.

53
00:02:39.280 --> 00:02:42.397
So some of them are not present,
for example, if a user installs

54
00:02:42.397 --> 00:02:46.292
an application, they may not want the
application to be visible to everybody.

55
00:02:46.292 --> 00:02:50.193
Maybe they want the application
just to be visible to them, right?

56
00:02:50.193 --> 00:02:54.833
If you wanna do that, you can create
an Applications folder in your own profile

57
00:02:54.833 --> 00:02:58.240
and when you do that,
see what happened there?

58
00:02:58.240 --> 00:03:02.915
When I made TopSecrets,
it just was a blue folder.

59
00:03:02.915 --> 00:03:05.688
But when I made that Application folder,
it got the pretty little pencils, or

60
00:03:05.688 --> 00:03:08.160
whatever, to let me know that
it's an application folder.

61
00:03:08.160 --> 00:03:10.750
The operating system recognized it,
and said hey, I'm ready for

62
00:03:10.750 --> 00:03:12.200
you to start throwing apps in here.

63
00:03:12.200 --> 00:03:14.840
So it's special, it didn't exist,
I had to make it.

64
00:03:14.840 --> 00:03:18.634
There's other ones that do exist that
we just can't see, so for example,

65
00:03:18.634 --> 00:03:19.730
the Library folder.

66
00:03:19.730 --> 00:03:23.023
Everybody has a Library folder that stores
all of their preferences and settings,

67
00:03:23.023 --> 00:03:24.750
the application support stuff.

68
00:03:24.750 --> 00:03:28.882
But we don't see it,
it is here if I go over to my Go menu and

69
00:03:28.882 --> 00:03:34.414
I choose Go to Folder, right, where I
can manually type in a folder to go to.

70
00:03:34.414 --> 00:03:42.564
I can type it in and
I can say go to /Users/dpezet/Library.

71
00:03:42.564 --> 00:03:47.210
I didn't see that a minute ago, but
when I browse to it now, there it is.

72
00:03:47.210 --> 00:03:51.260
I'm browsing into it and if I turn on my,
where's that pathbar thing?

73
00:03:51.260 --> 00:03:55.985
There we go, and look at my pathbar, I'm
in Users, dpezet, I'm in my Home folder,

74
00:03:55.985 --> 00:03:57.903
and then I'm in a Library folder.

75
00:03:57.903 --> 00:04:01.870
A folder that wasn't visible a second ago,
it exists, it's just hidden.

76
00:04:01.870 --> 00:04:04.594
Cuz your average user doesn't
need to dink around in there.

77
00:04:04.594 --> 00:04:07.353
If you start messing around in there,
you can break programs,

78
00:04:07.353 --> 00:04:10.910
you can lose your preferences, go back
to default settings for an application.

79
00:04:10.910 --> 00:04:13.500
You can do all sorts of stuff
that you're not supposed to do.

80
00:04:13.500 --> 00:04:15.065
>> That's my favorite place
to delete files, Don.

81
00:04:15.065 --> 00:04:16.631
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

00:04:16.631 --> 00:04:17.651
I prefer the system folder personally.

83
00:04:17.651 --> 00:04:19.797
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,
that's a good one as well.

84
00:04:19.797 --> 00:04:24.143
>> So usually the stuff where people
can do damage is hidden away from them.

85
00:04:24.143 --> 00:04:26.310
All right, so
let's talk about hiding files.

86
00:04:26.310 --> 00:04:27.810
How do we hide stuff?

87
00:04:27.810 --> 00:04:31.050
Well there's two different ways
we can hide things in Mac OS.

88
00:04:31.050 --> 00:04:34.180
Now it hides things for you,
things like that Library folder, and

89
00:04:34.180 --> 00:04:36.500

that one will come up a little bit later.

763
00:36:53.685 --> 00:36:56.115
I just wanna talk about disk images and
file archives, kind of a useful thing.

764
00:36:56.115 --> 00:37:00.335
But, as far as the built-in system files,
the various folders we expect to see,

765
00:37:00.335 --> 00:37:02.482
how to hide things,
it's all pretty important,

766
00:37:02.482 --> 00:37:06.067
your average end user doesn't see it,
you as the support professional.

767
00:37:06.067 --> 00:37:07.097
You're expected to know it.

768
00:37:07.097 --> 00:37:10.337
>> All right, well thank you so much for
dropping by and showing us how to work

769
00:37:10.337 --> 00:37:13.557
with these extensions, these file types,
and the folders, as well.

770
00:37:13.557 --> 00:37:15.992
That being said, looks like we're
wrapping up yet another great episode.

771
00:37:15.992 --> 00:37:18.607
Hopefully you guys enjoyed it,
and maybe even learned something.

772
00:37:18.607 --> 00:37:21.537
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

773
00:37:21.537 --> 00:37:22.337
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

774
00:37:22.337 --> 00:37:23.382
>> And we'll see you next time.

775
00:37:23.382 --> 00:37:29.941
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you how to utilize the built-in file archiving and disk imaging systems. These systems will allow you to bundle files together into one file, as well as provide options like compression, encryption, and compatibility with other systems.
episodes.title: Archives and Images
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.149 --> 00:00:10.149
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.098 --> 00:00:16.162
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.162 --> 00:00:18.070
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:18.070 --> 00:00:20.660
And in today's episode we're
moving forward with our Appril,

5
00:00:20.660 --> 00:00:22.780
our Appril,
I cannot get that word out of my mouth.

6
00:00:22.780 --> 00:00:25.860
Apple Certified Support Professional
series.

7
00:00:25.860 --> 00:00:29.020
Joining us back in the studio again today
to give us a little more help with that

8
00:00:29.020 --> 00:00:30.760
is none other than our good friend Mr.
Don Pezet.

9
00:00:30.760 --> 00:00:32.070
Don, welcome back to the show sir.

10
00:00:32.070 --> 00:00:33.390
>> Thanks for having me back Daniel and

11
00:00:33.390 --> 00:00:36.529
it is almost April so I'm ready to start
our April Certified Support Professional.

12
00:00:36.529 --> 00:00:37.318
>> Yeah [LAUGH].

13
00:00:37.318 --> 00:00:40.778
>> And so we're gonna be diving
back into the world of Mac OS.

14
00:00:40.778 --> 00:00:44.540
And we spent the last few episodes talking
about file systems and folders and so on.

15
00:00:44.540 --> 00:00:46.210
So we're just gonna keep
going with that theme.

16
00:00:46.210 --> 00:00:49.460
And this time we're gonna talk
about archives and images.

17
00:00:49.460 --> 00:00:51.120
So most of the time when
we deal with files and

18
00:00:51.120 --> 00:00:52.980
folders is really right
here on our own system.

19
00:00:52.980 --> 00:00:57.470
But occasionally we want to take a folder
or folder and send it to somebody else.

20
00:00:57.470 --> 00:00:59.460
Well, if it's just a file,
maybe that's not a big deal.

21
00:00:59.460 --> 00:01:01.530
Maybe it's a small file,
you make an email attachment,

22
00:01:01.530 --> 00:01:03.090
you send it to somebody and you're done.

23
00:01:03.090 --> 00:01:05.000
But if it's a collection of files,

24
00:01:05.000 --> 00:01:08.700
like an entire folder, well now we
need a way to group them together.

25
00:01:08.700 --> 00:01:11.250
And there's two main ways that
we can do that in Mac OS.

26
00:01:11.250 --> 00:01:13.590
The first way is to create an archive,

27
00:01:13.590 --> 00:01:17.700
which is a single file that basically
compresses and stores other files.

28
00:01:17.700 --> 00:01:19.960
And the other way is with a disk image.

29
00:01:19.960 --> 00:01:25.690
Now a disk image technically takes
an entire disk and creates a copy of it.

30
00:01:25.690 --> 00:01:28.480
But many vendors use this as
a way to distribute files, so

31
00:01:28.480 --> 00:01:29.880
they use it like an archive.

32
00:01:29.880 --> 00:01:33.290
So disk images and archives actually
kind of perform the same behavior.

33
00:01:33.290 --> 00:01:37.400
The big difference between the two is that
a disk image doesn't normally compress

34
00:01:37.400 --> 00:01:39.495
contents cuz the contents
are typically already compressed.

35
00:01:39.495 --> 00:01:43.472
Versus an archive that really is
designed to compress those contents and

36
00:01:43.472 --> 00:01:45.243
make them as small as possible.

37
00:01:45.243 --> 00:01:48.130
So that we can send them over the network
it doesn't take a lot of bandwidth.

38
00:01:48.130 --> 00:01:52.260
So I'm gonna show you examples of both
today and kinda how they get used.

39
00:01:52.260 --> 00:01:55.744
Now the compression side, Apple has
built in compression support right into

40
00:01:55.744 --> 00:01:59.100
the operating system,
as most modern operating systems have.

41
00:01:59.100 --> 00:02:03.450
And the main default compression
algorithm you see out there is the zip

42
00:02:03.450 --> 00:02:04.160
algorithm, right?

43
00:02:04.160 --> 00:02:06.978
So zip is an archive format
that's been around since,

44
00:02:06.978 --> 00:02:10.425
I don't even know, the 1980s,
I've used it for a long time.

45
00:02:10.425 --> 00:02:13.895
And you can take any file,
group of files, or folder,

46
00:02:13.895 --> 00:02:18.810
put them together into a single archive
file, and compress them if you want.

47
00:02:18.810 --> 00:02:21.870
You don't have to compress, but
the default is to compress, right?

48
00:02:21.870 --> 00:02:25.960
So for example, here on my desktop
I've got a little text file, right?

49
00:02:25.960 --> 00:02:28.890
It's just full of junk text,
is not anything too spectacular, but

50
00:02:28.890 --> 00:02:31.300
the point is I've got it.

51
00:02:31.300 --> 00:02:36.013
And that text file, even though it's
full of junk text, is 61 KB in size.

52
00:02:36.013 --> 00:02:39.539
Right, so that's its size and
if I look down here it's actually

53
00:02:39.539 --> 00:02:43.545
60,625 bytes which rounds up to
about 61 KB on the disk, right.

54
00:02:43.545 --> 00:02:45.228
So that's the size of that file.

55
00:02:45.228 --> 00:02:47.520
Now that's a pretty small file.

56
00:02:47.520 --> 00:02:50.470
If I needed to send this to Daniel,
I probably wouldn't compress it,

57
00:02:50.470 --> 00:02:52.360
I'd just attach it to the email and
off you go.

58
00:02:52.360 --> 00:02:56.270
Files under about 10 MB in size can
go as email attachments pretty easy.

59
00:02:56.270 --> 00:02:59.430
Once you get over 10 MB,
a lot of mail servers will drop those.

60
00:02:59.430 --> 00:03:02.340
So I might need to make a file
smaller to fit that limit.

61
00:03:02.340 --> 00:03:07.210
And if I want that, all I've gotta
do is Ctrl+Click on my file.

62
00:03:07.210 --> 00:03:10.270
And when you Ctrl+Click on
the file you get a lot of options.

63
00:03:10.270 --> 00:03:15.560
But the one I'm looking for is this
guy right here, Compress "file.txt".

64
00:03:15.560 --> 00:03:16.830
It's just the name of the file.

65
00:03:16.830 --> 00:03:20.720
If I had picked a folder it would say
Compress and the name of the folder.

66
00:03:20.720 --> 00:03:25.770
And if we choose that, what's gonna happen
is it's gonna archive that file and

67
00:03:25.770 --> 00:03:27.640
you'll see a new file up here.

68
00:03:27.640 --> 00:03:32.004
Right, and so I see that file.txt
appear and it's file.txt.zip.

69
00:03:32.004 --> 00:03:37.915
Let me open this is the finder cuz it's
a little bit easier to see in here.

70
00:03:37.915 --> 00:03:42.350
So now I have file.txt and
I've got file.txt.zip.

71
00:03:42.350 --> 00:03:45.920
All the zip did was compress it together,
okay?

72
00:03:45.920 --> 00:03:51.140
If I had chosen more than one file,
like this, when I go to compress it,

73
00:03:51.140 --> 00:03:53.800
see how it says Compress 2 Items?

74
00:03:53.800 --> 00:03:55.630
So I can compress two things,
not just one.

75
00:03:55.630 --> 00:03:58.180
I can compress 100 or
1,000 things, it doesn't matter.

76
00:03:58.180 --> 00:04:01.060
And when you compress those,
now it's gonna create a zip.

77
00:04:01.060 --> 00:04:02.877
And see how it called it Archive.zip?

78
00:04:02.877 --> 00:04:05.360
Cuz it's got more than one file in there,
right?

79
00:04:05.360 --> 00:04:08.026
So more than one file is stored inside
of it and they're compressed together.

80
00:04:08.026 --> 00:04:11.220
So now I can send them all as one file
instead of a bunch of separate ones.

81
00:04:11.220 --> 00:04:14.500
>> Now Don,
that Archive is a little nondescript.

82
00:04:14.500 --> 00:04:17.000
Are we able to change that,
and it doesn't break anything?

83
00:04:17.000 --> 00:04:19.040
>> Yeah, yeah, the name doesn't really
matter, you can come in here and

84
00:04:19.040 --> 00:04:20.140
rename that thing.

85
00:04:20.140 --> 00:04:26.340
And so I might want to call it Files for
Daniel.zip, and there we go.

86
00:04:26.340 --> 00:04:27.520
And so now I can send it to you and

87
00:04:27.520 --> 00:04:30.590
when you receive it all you have to do
is double-click on the thing, right.

88
00:04:30.590 --> 00:04:34.461
So if you just double-click
it will extract the files.

89
00:04:34.461 --> 00:04:36.741
And so it makes a folder called Files for
Daniel,

90
00:04:36.741 --> 00:04:39.923
and inside of it are those files
that are uncompressed, all right.

91
00:04:39.923 --> 00:04:42.100
Now let's take a look
at the archives itself.

92
00:04:42.100 --> 00:04:48.250
So I had file.txt, and we saw when I
pulled it up that it was 61 KB in size.

93
00:04:48.250 --> 00:04:53.497
I've file.text.zip where it's archived,
and if I pull that one up,

94
00:04:53.497 --> 00:04:59.096
now when I look at it, as opposed to
61 KB that it was before, 389 bytes.

95
00:04:59.096 --> 00:05:03.350
I mean that file got really small,
we had huge compression on this.

96
00:05:03.350 --> 00:05:05.040
It's definitely gonna be easier
to send over the network,

97
00:05:05.040 --> 00:05:08.060
should take far less bandwidth,
is a fraction of the size.

98
00:05:08.060 --> 00:05:12.000
It's over 60 times smaller,
it's actually more like 120 times smaller.

99
00:05:12.000 --> 00:05:14.455
It is a tiny, tiny file, right?

100
00:05:14.455 --> 00:05:16.450
That's what compression does for us.

101
00:05:16.450 --> 00:05:18.810
But be careful,
cuz it doesn't always work out.

102
00:05:18.810 --> 00:05:21.820
A lot of files are already compressed.

103
00:05:21.820 --> 00:05:26.028
So for example, if you have images, right,
like JPEGs, JPEGs are already compressed.

104
00:05:26.028 --> 00:05:29.100
PNGs are already compressed.

105
00:05:29.100 --> 00:05:31.530
Disk images a lot of times
are already compressed, right.

106
00:05:31.530 --> 00:05:37.118
So if I go back here to my desktop, I've
got that googlechrome.dmg file, right.

107
00:05:37.118 --> 00:05:40.100
That's a disk image that Google is
attributing with Google Chrome in it.

108
00:05:40.100 --> 00:05:44.625
Well, if I look at it, it's 67.6 MB.

109
00:05:44.625 --> 00:05:45.960
All right, well I'm gonna compress it.

110
00:05:45.960 --> 00:05:49.710
So let me take that,
I will compress googlechrome.dmg.

111
00:05:49.710 --> 00:05:52.140
It's gonna zip it up, there it goes.

112
00:05:52.140 --> 00:05:59.145
Now it's compressed and when I pull it up,
it was 67.6 MB, now it's 67.5 MB.

113
00:05:59.145 --> 00:06:00.510
Whoo, big savings!

114
00:06:00.510 --> 00:06:02.435
>> Mm-hm.
>> Not really, right?

115
00:06:02.435 --> 00:06:07.790
If I look at the raw data down here,
it saved me 70 KB?

116
00:06:07.790 --> 00:06:10.400
It really didn't save me much at all.

117
00:06:10.400 --> 00:06:12.070
It's not even worth
compressing at this point.

118
00:06:12.070 --> 00:06:15.360
And the reason is the file
is already compressed.

119
00:06:15.360 --> 00:06:16.980
Google already compressed it for me.

120
00:06:16.980 --> 00:06:20.760
When you compress something that's already
compressed, you don't get a savings.

121
00:06:20.760 --> 00:06:22.920
All right, it's already as
small as it's gonna get, and

122
00:06:22.920 --> 00:06:24.820
sometimes it can even get bigger.

123
00:06:24.820 --> 00:06:28.071
If you compress a JPEG, it's very common
for the file to get bigger once it's

124
00:06:28.071 --> 00:06:30.187
compressed than it was
when it was uncompressed.

125
00:06:30.187 --> 00:06:33.260
Cuz it was never actually uncompressed,
it was already done.

126
00:06:33.260 --> 00:06:34.140
So be careful of that,

127
00:06:34.140 --> 00:06:37.780
don't expect to get huge gains all
the time when you compress something.

128
00:06:37.780 --> 00:06:41.430
A lot of times when we do an archive
like this, it's not to compress it.

129
00:06:41.430 --> 00:06:44.810
It's simply to gather multiple files
together into a single file and

130
00:06:44.810 --> 00:06:46.570
that's why they call it an archive, right?

131
00:06:46.570 --> 00:06:50.320
It's a collection of data that can
then be distributed as a single piece.

132
00:06:50.320 --> 00:06:53.590
So those are the way that we
can do those compressions.

133
00:06:53.590 --> 00:06:56.470
Now when Google sent me
Google Chrome though,

134
00:06:56.470 --> 00:06:58.360
they didn't send it to me as a zip.

135
00:06:58.360 --> 00:07:00.790
They sent it to me as a DMG.

136
00:07:00.790 --> 00:07:03.340
I downloaded that, got it as a DMG,
that's a disk image.

137
00:07:03.340 --> 00:07:04.670
What's a disk image?

138
00:07:04.670 --> 00:07:05.480
Well originally,

139
00:07:05.480 --> 00:07:10.940
back in the day, a disk image was
designed to make a copy of a hard drive.

140
00:07:10.940 --> 00:07:14.720
And that way if you ever had a failure,
you could restore from that copy and

141
00:07:14.720 --> 00:07:16.440
you were back in business, right.

142
00:07:16.440 --> 00:07:18.510
Or if I had 100 machines to sep up,

143
00:07:18.510 --> 00:07:22.290
I could create one image, and
then deploy that on all 100 machines.

144
00:07:22.290 --> 00:07:23.450
Now they're all set up identically.

145
00:07:23.450 --> 00:07:26.450
That's what disk images were
originally designed for.

146
00:07:26.450 --> 00:07:28.845
But today we use them
to distribute software.

147
00:07:28.845 --> 00:07:30.540
Then we can take a collection of files and

148
00:07:30.540 --> 00:07:33.900
put it inside of a DMG and
distribute it that way, right.

149
00:07:33.900 --> 00:07:35.280
So remember an application,

150
00:07:35.280 --> 00:07:39.760
like Google Chrome,
an application is actually a .app file.

151
00:07:39.760 --> 00:07:45.470
So if I mount this Google Chrome installer
and we get inside of it, that I see this

152
00:07:45.470 --> 00:07:48.620
Google Chrome app and it wants me to drag
and drop it into the applications folder.

153
00:07:48.620 --> 00:07:53.059
But if I right-click on it and choose Show
Package Contents, I can browse inside.

154
00:07:53.059 --> 00:07:56.852
And I see it's actually a collection
of folders and files, right.

155
00:07:56.852 --> 00:08:00.638
So they're distributing more than
just one file here, it's a folder.

156
00:08:00.638 --> 00:08:04.008
So they can't just send me a folder over
the internet, that's not gonna work.

157
00:08:04.008 --> 00:08:09.730
So instead, they wrap it up in a DMG so
they can send it all at once, right?

158
00:08:09.730 --> 00:08:11.670
Not so much worried about compression,

159
00:08:11.670 --> 00:08:15.050
as they are worried about just
keeping the folders together.

160
00:08:15.050 --> 00:08:18.130
Well, as people started using those
DMGs more and more, and more for

161
00:08:18.130 --> 00:08:20.870
that purpose, Apple and

162
00:08:20.870 --> 00:08:23.958
the Unix organizations decided to roll
out the ability to do compression too.

163
00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:28.560
And so, DMGs can now compress
as well as store data, but

164
00:08:28.560 --> 00:08:30.060
that's not their default function.

165
00:08:30.060 --> 00:08:30.650
Let me show you.

166
00:08:30.650 --> 00:08:32.410
If you ever want to make
one of these DMGs, right.

167
00:08:32.410 --> 00:08:35.980
So, maybe I, let me clean up my mess here.

168
00:08:35.980 --> 00:08:38.250
So I've got my file.txt.

169
00:08:38.250 --> 00:08:43.600
And we've already talked about
file.txt and how it was 61 KB in size.

170
00:08:43.600 --> 00:08:46.680
So it's 61K and I want to
distribute it out to some people.

171
00:08:46.680 --> 00:08:50.657
So I know the size of it is 61K and
that's great, right.

172
00:08:50.657 --> 00:08:53.280
So let me just get this where
you can see it all, right here.

173
00:08:53.280 --> 00:08:55.835
Okay, so its 61K in size.

174
00:08:55.835 --> 00:08:59.968
I want to send it out to people, and so
I want to create a DMG for it, all right.

175
00:08:59.968 --> 00:09:02.220
When you create a DMG, it's a disc image.

176
00:09:02.220 --> 00:09:05.540
And the disc images have
a fixed size by default.

177
00:09:05.540 --> 00:09:08.141
So I have to tell it what
size I want that drive to be.

178
00:09:08.141 --> 00:09:09.883
You're basically creating
a fake hard drive.

179
00:09:09.883 --> 00:09:12.832
And you give it a certain size, and
you put your files in it, right.

180
00:09:12.832 --> 00:09:16.338
So, I'm gonna make a fake hard drive for
file.txt.

181
00:09:16.338 --> 00:09:19.403
I'm going to, first off, create a folder.

182
00:09:19.403 --> 00:09:21.490
And I'm gonna call it,
this is will be my manuscript.

183
00:09:21.490 --> 00:09:25.050
So this is gonna be Don's Great
American Novel that I'm gonna write.

184
00:09:25.050 --> 00:09:27.350
And I'll put file.txt in it.

185
00:09:27.350 --> 00:09:30.246
And this folder will contain all
the stuff that I want to distribute out.

186
00:09:30.246 --> 00:09:34.400
So I might have 100 files in here,
you just put whatever, right.

187
00:09:34.400 --> 00:09:37.160
And then, you can jump into Disk Utility.

188
00:09:37.160 --> 00:09:39.780
I know that seems weird, the other one I
just right-clicked and chose to compress,

189
00:09:39.780 --> 00:09:43.490
but here I gotta go to Disk Utility
because I'm creating a fake hard drive.

190
00:09:43.490 --> 00:09:46.280
And where better to do that
than in the Disk Utility?

191
00:09:46.280 --> 00:09:47.550
And so, in the Disk Utility,

192
00:09:47.550 --> 00:09:51.990
you actually don't see anything related
to disk images right here in the main UI.

193
00:09:51.990 --> 00:09:54.470
But if I go up here to my
Disk Utility menu, and

194
00:09:54.470 --> 00:09:57.370
I go to File, you can create a new image.

195
00:09:57.370 --> 00:09:59.150
And that new image is a DMG.

196
00:09:59.150 --> 00:10:00.830
I'm gonna create a new image.

197
00:10:00.830 --> 00:10:04.690
Now I can create a blank one that's
just empty, and I can copy stuff to it.

198
00:10:04.690 --> 00:10:07.920
Or I can say Image from Folder.

199
00:10:07.920 --> 00:10:10.190
And I'm gonna choose Image from Folder.

200
00:10:10.190 --> 00:10:13.410
And I'm going to take my manuscript
folder, the one on my desktop.

201
00:10:13.410 --> 00:10:14.512
I've got two manuscript folders.

202
00:10:14.512 --> 00:10:18.498
I'm gonna take that folder right there and
I'm going to open that up,

203
00:10:18.498 --> 00:10:21.930
and it's gonna start to create a DMG.

204
00:10:21.930 --> 00:10:26.410
Now, I've got some choices I'm going
to have to make when I define this, and

205
00:10:26.410 --> 00:10:28.728
the choices make a big difference, okay.

206

00:21:11.017 --> 00:21:14.297
I was at 1 KB on that one Versus 27,
100, or

430
00:21:14.297 --> 00:21:17.904
20.3 megs,
each one getting larger and larger.

431
00:21:17.904 --> 00:21:19.509
Well I guess that one's not larger.

432
00:21:19.509 --> 00:21:20.809
I figure I'll sort it by size,
there we go.

433
00:21:20.809 --> 00:21:22.380
So we'll make it get that way.

434
00:21:22.380 --> 00:21:25.870
So that zip, that gave me the best
results for individual files, right.

435
00:21:25.870 --> 00:21:27.390
So that's kinda
the difference we got there.

436
00:21:27.390 --> 00:21:29.450
>> The right tool,
right method for the job.

437
00:21:29.450 --> 00:21:31.330
You've got a couple of
options available for you.

438
00:21:31.330 --> 00:21:32.880
So, if you learn each one,

439
00:21:32.880 --> 00:21:36.930
then you'll be able to use the correct one
at the right time for your environment.

440
00:21:36.930 --> 00:21:39.560
Don, very cool stuff,
and very helpful stuff.

441
00:21:39.560 --> 00:21:43.490
It seems like nowadays,
it's two gigs, big deal.

442
00:21:43.490 --> 00:21:44.998
But size is still
a really important thing,

443
00:21:44.998 --> 00:21:48.000
especially when it comes to things like
what you were talking about before.

444
00:21:48.000 --> 00:21:51.290
Email attachments, there are still
limits to those types of things.

445
00:21:51.290 --> 00:21:56.050
So, knowing how to make it a little bit
smaller, make it a little easier to

446
00:21:56.050 --> 00:21:59.200
transfer, make it easier for
somebody else to get it from you.

447
00:21:59.200 --> 00:22:01.090
It's still a viable option.

448
00:22:01.090 --> 00:22:04.200
>> Yeah, absolutely it's there, and people
are gonna send you these files, too.

449
00:22:04.200 --> 00:22:06.770
When you download programs,
you're downloading DMGs.

450
00:22:06.770 --> 00:22:09.530
What if you work for
a company that you're a developer?

451
00:22:09.530 --> 00:22:11.300
You need to create your own DMGs.

452
00:22:11.300 --> 00:22:12.820
You've got the tools, they're right there.

453
00:22:12.820 --> 00:22:14.340
There's third party utilities
that can do it, too.

454
00:22:14.340 --> 00:22:16.910
There's plenty of them, I know I
use a program called Entropy a lot.

455
00:22:16.910 --> 00:22:19.540
But for the exam you need to know
what's built into the operating system.

456
00:22:19.540 --> 00:22:21.180
So those are the tools
that are right there.

457
00:22:21.180 --> 00:22:23.140
>> Really cool stuff though Don,
we thank you for stopping by.

458
00:22:23.140 --> 00:22:26.260
Is there anything else that you wanna add
to this program before we wrap it up?

459
00:22:26.260 --> 00:22:26.820
>> That's about it.

460
00:22:26.820 --> 00:22:29.180
I know we've been going on about files for
like four episodes now.

461
00:22:29.180 --> 00:22:30.746
>> [LAUGH]
>> I think we've pretty much run through

462
00:22:30.746 --> 00:22:31.777
all the different options there.

463
00:22:31.777 --> 00:22:34.189
But it is key stuff to note things
that you'll encounter out there in

464
00:22:34.189 --> 00:22:34.793
the real world.

465
00:22:34.793 --> 00:22:36.390
>> All right,
well thanks again for stopping by.

466
00:22:36.390 --> 00:22:37.740
Thank you guys for watching.

467
00:22:37.740 --> 00:22:39.730
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

468
00:22:39.730 --> 00:22:41.580
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

469
00:22:41.580 --> 00:22:42.240
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

470
00:22:42.240 --> 00:22:43.992
>> And we'll see you next time.

471
00:22:43.992 --> 00:22:51.770
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you how to backup your data using the Mac OS 10.11 utility, Time Machine. Here they show you how to setup Time Machine on an external hard drive and walk you through it's use.
episodes.title: Time Machine
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.018 --> 00:00:10.018
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.099 --> 00:00:16.140
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.140 --> 00:00:18.030
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:18.030 --> 00:00:21.420
In today's episode, we are continuing
on with our Apple certified support

5
00:00:21.420 --> 00:00:23.450
professional series that
we've been working on.

6
00:00:23.450 --> 00:00:27.025
Joining us back in the studio again today
is our good friend Dr. Emitt Brown.

7
00:00:27.025 --> 00:00:29.550
[LAUGH] Welcome to the show, Dr. Brown.

8
00:00:29.550 --> 00:00:30.520
How's it going today, Don?

9
00:00:30.520 --> 00:00:31.680
>> It's going just swell, Daniel.

10
00:00:31.680 --> 00:00:32.930
Thanks for having me back on the show.

11
00:00:32.930 --> 00:00:35.700
And yep,
it's back to the future time, right?

12
00:00:35.700 --> 00:00:38.540
Because we're gonna be jumping in
the time machine in this episode and

13
00:00:38.540 --> 00:00:41.470
looking at how to back up our macs,
how to restore our macs, and

14
00:00:41.470 --> 00:00:43.890
some of the different ins and
outs that are involved in that.

15
00:00:43.890 --> 00:00:46.440
Some of the things that are behind
the scenes that we don't normally pay

16
00:00:46.440 --> 00:00:47.040
attention to, but

17
00:00:47.040 --> 00:00:50.042
we're gonna get a chance to see them
right here and see it in action.

18
00:00:50.042 --> 00:00:53.070
Now most of you are probably
pretty familiar with time machine.

19
00:00:53.070 --> 00:00:54.350
Apple's been promoting
this pretty heavily.

20
00:00:54.350 --> 00:00:55.360
It's a great feature.

21
00:00:55.360 --> 00:00:59.770
It's gotta be one of the easiest to use
backup systems that I've worked with, and

22
00:00:59.770 --> 00:01:03.220
I've worked with a lot of them in
the Windows world and the Linux world.

23
00:01:03.220 --> 00:01:05.300
Backups are always a nightmare.

24
00:01:05.300 --> 00:01:10.090
Time Machine is specifically designed to
make back up super easy, super convenient,

25
00:01:10.090 --> 00:01:12.820
because Apple knows that if you don't
make it easy, people aren't gonna do it.

26
00:01:12.820 --> 00:01:16.180
And if people don't do it,
eventually they have a failure and

27
00:01:16.180 --> 00:01:18.260
boy do they regret that.

28
00:01:18.260 --> 00:01:21.290
I can't tell you the horror
stories I've seen over the years.

29
00:01:22.570 --> 00:01:24.330
Way back in the beginning of my IT career,

30
00:01:24.330 --> 00:01:27.110
I started out doing warranty repairs for
a company.

31
00:01:27.110 --> 00:01:29.000
Well, do you remember Packard Bell?

32
00:01:29.000 --> 00:01:30.860
>> Yes, I do.
>> So, I was doing warranty repair for

33
00:01:30.860 --> 00:01:34.420
Packard Bell and if you remember
the company you know I was a busy person.

34
00:01:34.420 --> 00:01:36.090
>> Yeah.
>> Because those were terrible computers,

35
00:01:36.090 --> 00:01:40.870
so we had this lady came in one day and
she was a doctoral

36
00:01:40.870 --> 00:01:45.690
student at the university in town and she
had her doctoral, I want to say, thesis.

37
00:01:45.690 --> 00:01:46.960
>> Dissertation.
>> Dissertation, that's it.

38
00:01:46.960 --> 00:01:51.293
It was her dissertation on her laptop and
she had dropped it and

39
00:01:51.293 --> 00:01:52.968
it wouldn't power on.

40
00:01:52.968 --> 00:01:55.230
And we open it up and
sure enough it was a hard drive failure.

41
00:01:55.230 --> 00:01:58.580
And so I had to tell her the drive is
dead we can't get the data off of it.

42
00:01:58.580 --> 00:02:01.150
Do you have a backup?

43
00:02:01.150 --> 00:02:01.800
And she didn't.

44
00:02:01.800 --> 00:02:05.560
She didn't have a backup and
that was her doctoral dissertation.

45
00:02:05.560 --> 00:02:06.590
That was a big deal.

46
00:02:06.590 --> 00:02:12.140
Fortunately she was able to go
to her her graduate advisor and

47
00:02:12.140 --> 00:02:16.050
they had a printed copy she had turned in
as a draft not too long before, so she

48
00:02:16.050 --> 00:02:19.660
lost some of her newer data, but she had
to sit there and retype that whole thing.

49
00:02:19.660 --> 00:02:21.628
And I saw it, it was a giant stack.

50
00:02:21.628 --> 00:02:23.248
I mean, it was a massive amount of data.

51
00:02:23.248 --> 00:02:24.008
It was terrible.

52
00:02:24.008 --> 00:02:26.100
It could have been a lot worse,
she could have lost that.

53
00:02:26.100 --> 00:02:28.200
That was years of research and study.

54
00:02:28.200 --> 00:02:31.520
So, that's the type of thing you
don't want to have happen to you.

55
00:02:31.520 --> 00:02:33.730
Time Machine helps prevent that.

56
00:02:33.730 --> 00:02:37.050
All right, well, let's take a look
at how to get Time Machine set up.

57
00:02:37.050 --> 00:02:38.820
And I'm gonna get a back
up running on this machine.

58
00:02:38.820 --> 00:02:42.240
And while the back up's running,
we'll talk about what it's doing and

59
00:02:42.240 --> 00:02:43.080
how it functions.

60
00:02:43.080 --> 00:02:48.360
Now, the key secret here is that
Time Machine is supposed to be easy.

61
00:02:48.360 --> 00:02:50.250
And when I say easy,
I mean it's really easy.

62
00:02:50.250 --> 00:02:52.100
You start off by getting
an external hard drive.

63
00:02:52.100 --> 00:02:53.760
You want to have an external hard drive.

64
00:02:53.760 --> 00:02:55.620
Don't try and
back up to something inside your system,

65
00:02:55.620 --> 00:02:58.430
because there's the potential
your system could be dead.

66
00:02:58.430 --> 00:03:00.190
And you don't want to rely on
the hardware inside of it.

67
00:03:00.190 --> 00:03:01.960
So you get a removable drive.

68
00:03:01.960 --> 00:03:03.560
When you plug it into the system,

69
00:03:03.560 --> 00:03:05.930
the system will immediately
recognize that drive.

70
00:03:05.930 --> 00:03:09.500
And it will offer to turn on time machine
for you, just like that, just turn it on.

71
00:03:09.500 --> 00:03:12.308
Let me show you here on this machine.

72
00:03:12.308 --> 00:03:16.758
So I've got a hard drive on this machine
that is not formatted right now, so

73
00:03:16.758 --> 00:03:21.580
I'm gonna just jump into disc utility and
I am going to take that hard drive, and

74
00:03:21.580 --> 00:03:25.320
I'm just going to erase it, and
I'll call this my Time Machine drive.

75
00:03:25.320 --> 00:03:26.870
Now, it doesn't really
matter what you call it.

76
00:03:26.870 --> 00:03:28.860
You can name it anything,
it doesn't matter.

77
00:03:28.860 --> 00:03:32.150
I'm going to call it Time Machine, so
I can remember that's what it is, right.

78
00:03:32.150 --> 00:03:35.590
And then I'm going to format
it OS X Extended (Journaled).

79
00:03:35.590 --> 00:03:38.540
It does need to be formatted
OS X Extended (Journaled).

80
00:03:38.540 --> 00:03:42.030
If it's formated Fat 32 or XFat, or
whatever, it's not going to work.

81
00:03:42.030 --> 00:03:45.470
Now If you plug in the drive,
the system will recognize it and

82
00:03:45.470 --> 00:03:46.530
offer to set up Time Machine.

83
00:03:46.530 --> 00:03:49.330
If you choose yes and
it's a different format, it'll erase it.

84
00:03:49.330 --> 00:03:50.530
So you'll lose the data that's on there.

85
00:03:50.530 --> 00:03:51.670
You don't want that.

86
00:03:51.670 --> 00:03:55.550
But usually, you want the drive to be
dedicated for Time Machine anyway.

87
00:03:55.550 --> 00:03:56.600
So I'm gonna erase that.

88
00:03:56.600 --> 00:03:58.040
And so there it goes, it's erasing it.

89
00:03:58.040 --> 00:03:58.980
It mounts it on the system.

90
00:03:58.980 --> 00:04:02.490
And I immediately get
this popup right here.

91
00:04:02.490 --> 00:04:04.386
Hey, we just noticed you've
put in a new hard drive.

92
00:04:04.386 --> 00:04:06.246
Do you wanna use it for Time Machine?

93
00:04:06.246 --> 00:04:08.826
It's got 274 gigs of storage space on it.

94
00:04:08.826 --> 00:04:11.280
We can use it to back
up with Time Machine.

95
00:04:11.280 --> 00:04:12.070
Let's do it.

96
00:04:12.070 --> 00:04:16.520
All right, now, if we do it, it's
gonna start immediately using this for

97
00:04:16.520 --> 00:04:19.740
Time Machine, and all I have to do is
click this little button right here,

98
00:04:19.740 --> 00:04:21.460
Use as Backup Disk, and I'm done.

99
00:04:21.460 --> 00:04:23.160
It's the simplest thing in the plant.

100
00:04:23.160 --> 00:04:26.390
Now if you've already got a hard
drive that you've been using and

101
00:04:26.390 --> 00:04:27.490
you don't get this little pop up.

102
00:04:27.490 --> 00:04:31.050
I'm just going to say decide later,
or no I'll say don't use.

103
00:04:31.050 --> 00:04:32.870
Don't use it for Time Machine.

104
00:04:32.870 --> 00:04:35.870
So now I've just got a second
hard drive added here, and

105
00:04:35.870 --> 00:04:38.830
while I did name it Time Machine,
the name doesn't really mean anything.

106
00:04:38.830 --> 00:04:40.550
So it's just a removable drive.

107
00:04:40.550 --> 00:04:42.870
So I've got this removable drive attached.

108
00:04:42.870 --> 00:04:46.920
And If I browse into a regular hard drive,
nothing special here.

109
00:04:48.190 --> 00:04:52.390
But I can turn on Time Machine whenever I
want, by going into my system preferences

110
00:04:53.490 --> 00:04:56.120
and finding Time Machine
in my system preferences.

111
00:04:56.120 --> 00:04:58.450
So when that pops up,
you can kind of scan around and

112
00:04:58.450 --> 00:05:00.020
find it way down here at the bottom.

113
00:05:00.020 --> 00:05:03.040
A little green clock is
what we're looking for.

114
00:05:03.040 --> 00:05:06.420
And when you click on that it's
gonna fire up time machine and

115
00:05:06.420 --> 00:05:08.540
there's really just two steps.

116
00:05:08.540 --> 00:05:12.790
One, you pick the drive you want to
back up to, and two, you turn it on.

117
00:05:12.790 --> 00:05:14.870
It's designed to be that easy.

118
00:05:14.870 --> 00:05:19.130
So I'm gonna select a back up disk and
I'm gonna pick that USB hard drive.

119
00:05:19.130 --> 00:05:22.320
Now, notice I see more than
just the USB hard drive,

120
00:05:22.320 --> 00:05:25.610
I also see an Airport Time Capsule.

121
00:05:25.610 --> 00:05:28.810
And you may even see other
things in your list.

122
00:05:28.810 --> 00:05:31.648
Typically we're gonna back
to our hard drive, right?

123
00:05:31.648 --> 00:05:33.470
But what's the weakness there?

124
00:05:33.470 --> 00:05:36.485
The weakness is, I have to remember
to plug that hard drive in.

125
00:05:36.485 --> 00:05:37.920
Well, I have a laptop.

126
00:05:37.920 --> 00:05:38.960
So when I leave here
at the end of the day,

127
00:05:38.960 --> 00:05:41.410
I'm gonna unplug that hard drive and
am gonna go home.

128
00:05:41.410 --> 00:05:44.670
When I come in the next day, I've got to
remember to plug that hard drive in again.

129
00:05:45.730 --> 00:05:47.660
What if I forget to plug it in?

130
00:05:47.660 --> 00:05:50.040
Then Time Machine can't back up my system,
right?

131
00:05:50.040 --> 00:05:53.160
So when you deal with a removable drive,
your chore,

132
00:05:53.160 --> 00:05:56.297
your assignment is to make sure that drive
is plugged in, so it can run its back ups.

133
00:05:57.350 --> 00:05:59.215
If you know you're not good at that.

134
00:05:59.215 --> 00:06:00.465
People recognize their weaknesses.

135
00:06:00.465 --> 00:06:03.670
>> John, we don't have wireless
data transfer to hard drives now?

136
00:06:03.670 --> 00:06:05.165
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it's not there,

137
00:06:05.165 --> 00:06:06.295
you have a USB Drive, or

138
00:06:06.295 --> 00:06:09.395
a Thunderbolt drive, it's kinda
gotta be plugged in for it to work.

139
00:06:09.395 --> 00:06:14.415
So, if you recognize that weakness in the
solution here, there's other alternatives.

140
00:06:14.415 --> 00:06:16.255
You can buy an Airport Time Capsule.

141
00:06:16.255 --> 00:06:19.775
And what an Airport is,
is one of Apple's wireless access points,

142
00:06:19.775 --> 00:06:22.490
it's really an Airport Extreme.

143
00:06:22.490 --> 00:06:23.880
But it's got hard drives in it.

144
00:06:23.880 --> 00:06:24.520
It'll have two hard,

145
00:06:24.520 --> 00:06:26.410
well it depends on how you buy it
it might have one hard drive, but

146
00:06:26.410 --> 00:06:28.070
usually it has two hard drives in it.

147
00:06:28.070 --> 00:06:30.350
And it'll give you one or
two terabytes of storage.

148
00:06:30.350 --> 00:06:33.040
Well, as of the filming of this episode,
by the time you've watched this episode,

149
00:06:33.040 --> 00:06:33.860
maybe they've introduced more.

150
00:06:33.860 --> 00:06:37.510
But right now you can get it with one or
two terabytes and it's on your network.

151
00:06:37.510 --> 00:06:38.710
It's on your wireless.

152
00:06:38.710 --> 00:06:40.540
So when you bring your
laptop into the office and

153
00:06:40.540 --> 00:06:43.480
you connect to that wireless network,
it sees those drives and

154
00:06:43.480 --> 00:06:45.960
it can start backing up, you don't
have to remember to plug in anything.

155
00:06:45.960 --> 00:06:48.910
You just have to remember to turn your
computer on, which you're going to do,

156
00:06:48.910 --> 00:06:51.430
unless you like looking at
a black screen all day.

157
00:06:51.430 --> 00:06:53.550
So that makes it super easy.

158
00:06:53.550 --> 00:06:55.450
There is a third option
that I don't see here,

159
00:06:55.450 --> 00:06:58.840
which is you might have
a server on your network.

160
00:06:58.840 --> 00:07:02.350
If you have an El Capitan box
that's running the server app,

161
00:07:02.350 --> 00:07:06.030
you can set it up to be a central
time machine back up server.

162
00:07:06.030 --> 00:07:08.670
And you would see the server right
here and you could click on that and

163
00:07:08.670 --> 00:07:10.130
choose to back up to the server.

164
00:07:10.130 --> 00:07:13.670
Again, just like the AirPort, all you
have to do is connect to the network.

165
00:07:13.670 --> 00:07:16.150
And once you're on the network,
the back up happens automatically.

166
00:07:16.150 --> 00:07:18.310
So that makes it a lot easier on us.

167
00:07:18.310 --> 00:07:21.250
But for this machine, I'm just gonna
use this internal drive because

168
00:07:21.250 --> 00:07:23.280
network back ups are slower, right.

169
00:07:23.280 --> 00:07:26.430
Your internal drives or your USB drives,
you could write to those pretty fast.

170
00:07:26.430 --> 00:07:28.860
But when you start going over the network
things are a little bit slower, and

171
00:07:28.860 --> 00:07:30.500
I don't want this show
to be a 10 hour show.

172
00:07:30.500 --> 00:07:33.390
So I'm just going to go with
the regular local drive.

173
00:07:33.390 --> 00:07:37.260
Now when I choose it, I do have
the choice to encrypt the back ups.

174
00:07:37.260 --> 00:07:38.990
Why is that important?

175
00:07:38.990 --> 00:07:42.491
Well, if I have a back up drive,
like this guy right here,

176
00:07:42.491 --> 00:07:46.788
this is the back up of my laptop,
of my actual laptop that I use for work.

177
00:07:46.788 --> 00:07:50.330
And so this is my data, right?

178
00:07:50.330 --> 00:07:54.649
I've got my personal email backed up,
in my laptop, this is a back up of it.

179
00:07:54.649 --> 00:07:58.167
So I plug this in everyday and
I back up my Time Machine right here.

180
00:07:58.167 --> 00:07:59.710
This is my Time Machine back up.

181
00:07:59.710 --> 00:08:01.162
What if you were to steal this drive?

182
00:08:01.162 --> 00:08:03.565
If you were to come and
grab this drive and take it home,

183
00:08:03.565 --> 00:08:05.680
you could plug it into any Mac.

184
00:08:05.680 --> 00:08:06.925
