00:28:52.150 --> 00:28:55.770
that's what turns on the ability
to do the local Time Machine.

637
00:28:55.770 --> 00:28:59.270
So that's gonna turn it on, doesn't
necessarily mean I'm gonna use it, but

638
00:28:59.270 --> 00:28:59.980
it'll turn it on.

639
00:28:59.980 --> 00:29:03.250
And in fact, assuming that works,
let's see if it'll do a backup for me.

640
00:29:04.520 --> 00:29:07.900
And that's still gonna complain, but
that'll turn that functionality on so

641
00:29:07.900 --> 00:29:09.870
it can backup to that
Mobile Backups folder.

642
00:29:09.870 --> 00:29:14.868
And then the other one is tmutil,
actually I still need to do a sudo

643
00:29:14.868 --> 00:29:19.860
tmutil disable local.

644
00:29:19.860 --> 00:29:21.970
So if you're like Ronnie and
you're running out of hard drive space and

645
00:29:21.970 --> 00:29:24.470
you wanna turn that off, you can turn
it off and now you won't have it.

646
00:29:24.470 --> 00:29:25.896
And I know why this one's not doing it,

647
00:29:25.896 --> 00:29:29.710
I'm in a VMware virtual machine,
it thinks it's a desktop.

648
00:29:29.710 --> 00:29:31.260
It doesn't know it's a laptop.

649
00:29:31.260 --> 00:29:34.770
That's why you might have noticed,
the power nap option wasn't here,

650
00:29:34.770 --> 00:29:36.980
because again, it didn't think it was
a laptop, it thought it was a desktop.

651
00:29:36.980 --> 00:29:38.290
You don't need power nap there.

652
00:29:38.290 --> 00:29:39.860
So, that's why it's not showing up.

653
00:29:39.860 --> 00:29:42.250
Laptops are the ones that need this,
the mobile backup.

654
00:29:42.250 --> 00:29:46.030
So, on my laptop, I could turn it on, but
in this virtual machine it's not there,

655
00:29:46.030 --> 00:29:47.360
so that's why it's not showing up.

656
00:29:47.360 --> 00:29:51.870
But, tmutil enablelocal or
disablelocal, turn it on or off.

657
00:29:51.870 --> 00:29:54.470
And that'll appear so you can
continue to do Time Machine backups,

658
00:29:54.470 --> 00:29:56.670
even when the drive is not plugged in.

659
00:29:56.670 --> 00:29:58.660
>> Now Don, we got a quick
question from our chatroom there,

660
00:29:58.660 --> 00:30:01.520
asking if you get
infected with a virus and

661
00:30:01.520 --> 00:30:05.890
you wanna go back and use Time Machine
as a backup, is that now infected?

662
00:30:05.890 --> 00:30:07.110
Do viruses infect that?

663
00:30:07.110 --> 00:30:11.130
Or maybe I've taken a few backups
with that virus on my system?

664
00:30:11.130 --> 00:30:12.288
What do I do in that scenario?

665
00:30:12.288 --> 00:30:15.437
>> All right, so
if your machine gets infected,

666
00:30:15.437 --> 00:30:18.910
if a Time Machine backup
runs after the infection,

667
00:30:18.910 --> 00:30:23.980
those backups are infected, but
your previous backups are not.

668
00:30:23.980 --> 00:30:26.210
And so the previous back-ups
don't have the virus in them.

669
00:30:26.210 --> 00:30:30.640
And if you were to boot to recovery and
restore the Time Machine backup,

670
00:30:30.640 --> 00:30:33.530
format your hard drive, restore the Time
Machine backup, the virus would be gone.

671
00:30:33.530 --> 00:30:34.460
You'd be rolled back.

672
00:30:34.460 --> 00:30:37.360
Now, however you got that virus is
a vulnerability in the system and

673
00:30:37.360 --> 00:30:40.700
the vulnerability is still there so
you can always get re-infected, but

674
00:30:40.700 --> 00:30:42.190
the virus itself is gone.

675
00:30:42.190 --> 00:30:47.630
Let's say the virus copies itself
all over the Time Machine backup.

676
00:30:47.630 --> 00:30:48.680
If that happens,

677
00:30:48.680 --> 00:30:52.980
you still have to execute the virus in
order to cause that infection to occur.

678
00:30:52.980 --> 00:30:55.410
So when you restore your backup,

679
00:30:55.410 --> 00:31:01.030
well you'd have to trigger that
virus to run somehow to reinfect.

680
00:31:01.030 --> 00:31:03.980
So when you restore,
you're actually clean, you would need to

681
00:31:03.980 --> 00:31:06.800
then patch the vulnerability to make sure
you didn't get that virus back again.

682
00:31:06.800 --> 00:31:08.420
But you would actually be clean.

683
00:31:08.420 --> 00:31:09.630
Time Machine can roll you back and

684
00:31:09.630 --> 00:31:13.370
you can roll back your whole system
if you just boot your recovery.

685
00:31:13.370 --> 00:31:14.690
>> Awesome stuff,

686
00:31:14.690 --> 00:31:18.560
well viruses are typically bound
when they, in the Apple world.

687
00:31:18.560 --> 00:31:20.990
So it shouldn't be too much of a problem,
right?

688
00:31:20.990 --> 00:31:24.600
>> Yeah, and one other little secret,
let me mention this one.

689
00:31:24.600 --> 00:31:28.450
If you have a virus, you wanna make sure
that you completely cleanse your hard

690
00:31:28.450 --> 00:31:33.880
drive before you jump back in and
start restoring and all of that.

691
00:31:33.880 --> 00:31:36.640
So when we boot to recovery, technically
you're booting from recovery from your

692
00:31:36.640 --> 00:31:39.310
internal hard drive, so
you might not wanna do that.

693
00:31:39.310 --> 00:31:43.180
Remember that most Macs do support
Internet recovery these days.

694
00:31:43.180 --> 00:31:47.050
So when you boot, instead of doing Cmd+R
which boots off your local recovery,

695
00:31:47.050 --> 00:31:48.451
you can do Cmd+Option+R.

696
00:31:48.451 --> 00:31:51.964
And that will make it boot Internet
recovery, where it will download

697
00:31:51.964 --> 00:31:55.903
the recovery partition from Apple so
that you know it's clean and clear, and

698
00:31:55.903 --> 00:31:58.352
then you can restore
your Time Machine backup.

699
00:31:58.352 --> 00:32:01.689
The other thing is, Apple doesn't
really promote this a whole lot, but

700
00:32:01.689 --> 00:32:04.807
your Time Machine drive When you
format it and turn on Time Machine,

701
00:32:04.807 --> 00:32:08.630
it actually puts a recovery partition
on the Time Machine drive too.

702
00:32:08.630 --> 00:32:12.890
So you could boot off of your Time Machine
drive, and restore it, and so you know

703
00:32:12.890 --> 00:32:16.480
you've got a good, clean recovery there,
versus the one that's in your system.

704
00:32:16.480 --> 00:32:18.040
So definitely be aware of those.

705
00:32:18.040 --> 00:32:20.978
And then also, don't be afraid to
browse into the Time Machine drive.

706
00:32:20.978 --> 00:32:22.038
Let me show you guys.

707
00:32:22.038 --> 00:32:24.460
If I browse into my
Time Machine hard drive,

708
00:32:24.460 --> 00:32:28.979
there's a folder called Backups.backupdb,
so this is my backup database, and

709
00:32:28.979 --> 00:32:32.907
if I browse in there, DPLAPTOP-OSX,
right, that's my laptop, and

710
00:32:32.907 --> 00:32:36.000
when I browse into there,
I see a bunch of dates.

711
00:32:36.000 --> 00:32:39.690
These are the backups, March 7,
March 8, March 9, and so on.

712
00:32:39.690 --> 00:32:43.450
And then it goes down to, here's March 29,
and see how I've got a ton of backups?

713
00:32:43.450 --> 00:32:45.350
Those are the hourly backups,
they're all right here.

714
00:32:45.350 --> 00:32:47.680
And they're just folders,
you can browse right into them.

715
00:32:47.680 --> 00:32:51.710
And here's my Macintosh HD, and
I can see what's changed, right, so

716
00:32:51.710 --> 00:32:57.090
I can go into Users, donpezet, Desktop,
and see what's changed, right?

717
00:32:57.090 --> 00:33:00.680
And, sorry, I was trying to go into
Desktop, which is apparently empty.

718
00:33:00.680 --> 00:33:02.550
So my desktop was blank that day.

719
00:33:02.550 --> 00:33:03.328
I don't see anything.

720
00:33:03.328 --> 00:33:06.216
I should have paid attention to what
day this data claim was stored on.

721
00:33:06.216 --> 00:33:07.895
But, yeah, I can't get to that now.

722
00:33:07.895 --> 00:33:09.815
But you can browse it and
you can see what changed.

723
00:33:09.815 --> 00:33:11.866
If you go all the way back
to your original one,

724
00:33:11.866 --> 00:33:14.140
this one should be a full
backup to your hard drive.

725
00:33:14.140 --> 00:33:15.180
It should be everything.

726
00:33:15.180 --> 00:33:18.510
So if you browse in,
you'll see a lot of stuff in there and

727
00:33:18.510 --> 00:33:20.600
be able to pull that data out.

728
00:33:20.600 --> 00:33:22.960
If you just want an individual file,
you might wanna browse it that way and

729
00:33:22.960 --> 00:33:24.480
find it and get it.

730
00:33:24.480 --> 00:33:27.420
If you choose to encrypt it, that's why
it's so important to encrypt it, right?

731
00:33:27.420 --> 00:33:28.500
This is protected.

732
00:33:28.500 --> 00:33:31.050
If not, anybody could grab this drive and
plug it in,

733
00:33:31.050 --> 00:33:34.240
and they can just browse right
through my hard drive contents.

734
00:33:34.240 --> 00:33:35.600
They don't even have to have
a username and password.

735
00:33:35.600 --> 00:33:37.588
That's the danger with
the Time Machine backups.

736
00:33:37.588 --> 00:33:39.869
>> Get your Steam login information,
that'll be fun.

737
00:33:39.869 --> 00:33:41.171
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it's, you know,

738
00:33:41.171 --> 00:33:42.148
mission critical information.

739
00:33:42.148 --> 00:33:43.108
>> That's very much setup.

740
00:33:43.108 --> 00:33:46.660
[LAUGH] Well, Don,
you've done a great job of stopping by and

741
00:33:46.660 --> 00:33:49.420
letting us learn how Time Machine works.

742
00:33:49.420 --> 00:33:51.468
Super easy,
you'd be a great propaganda man for them.

743
00:33:51.468 --> 00:33:52.651
So-
>> [LAUGH]

744
00:33:52.651 --> 00:33:53.572
>> I'll reference if you

745
00:33:53.572 --> 00:33:54.518
need it, so [LAUGH].

746
00:33:54.518 --> 00:33:57.190
Well, you know, Dan, you and
I, we work with Windows a lot.

747
00:33:57.190 --> 00:33:58.710
>> We do.
>> And we work with Linux a lot,

748
00:33:58.710 --> 00:34:00.890
you know how hard it is to get
those backups up and running.

749
00:34:00.890 --> 00:34:02.080
This really is super easy.

750
00:34:02.080 --> 00:34:06.730
>> Yeah, this is by far the easiest
backup system I've ever had to deal with.

751
00:34:06.730 --> 00:34:08.260
And like Don said,

752
00:34:08.260 --> 00:34:12.390
I have to overcome my own inertia
[LAUGH] to actually do backups.

753
00:34:12.390 --> 00:34:15.360
If you make it as easy as humanly
possible, well then I'm probably,

754
00:34:15.360 --> 00:34:17.230
I'm more likely to do it than not.

755
00:34:17.230 --> 00:34:21.530
And because data is important, we wanna
make sure that it is safe and secure.

756
00:34:21.530 --> 00:34:23.000
Time Machine does that for us.

757
00:34:23.000 --> 00:34:26.272
Don, thanks again for stopping by and
explaining how to use Time Machine for

758
00:34:26.272 --> 00:34:28.900
us and all the cool,
little ways in which we can use it.

759
00:34:28.900 --> 00:34:33.340
Not just to take a backup but
more advance features are awesome as well.

760
00:34:33.340 --> 00:34:35.500
And thank you, guys, for
stopping by and joining us.

761
00:34:35.500 --> 00:34:38.010
Hopefully you guys got a lot
of information out of this and

762
00:34:38.010 --> 00:34:40.216
something you can take
into your everyday lives.

763
00:34:40.216 --> 00:34:45.188
Start performing backups, keep that data
safe, and go pass an exam, if you can.

764
00:34:45.188 --> 00:34:48.362
That being said, we're gonna sign off,
we're ITProTV, I've been your host,

765
00:34:48.362 --> 00:34:49.008
Daniel Lowrie.

766
00:34:49.008 --> 00:34:49.888
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

767
00:34:49.888 --> 00:34:52.308
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.158 --> 00:00:10.158
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.121 --> 00:00:13.920
>> All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:13.920 --> 00:00:16.360
And welcome to another
exciting of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.360 --> 00:00:18.370
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:18.370 --> 00:00:21.380
And in today's episode we're continuing
on with our Apple certified support

6
00:00:21.380 --> 00:00:22.620
professional series.

7
00:00:22.620 --> 00:00:25.750
Joining us back in the studio again today
to help us out with that very endeavor,

8
00:00:25.750 --> 00:00:26.950
my good friend Mr Don Pezet.

9
00:00:26.950 --> 00:00:28.360
Don, welcome back to the show sir.

10
00:00:28.360 --> 00:00:29.320
>> Thanks for having me back Daniel.

11
00:00:29.320 --> 00:00:32.240
Ready to jump right back into
the support professional role.

12
00:00:32.240 --> 00:00:34.750
And in this episode we're
going to look at applications.

13
00:00:34.750 --> 00:00:38.420
And this is a pretty important thing
because when you give somebody a brand new

14
00:00:38.420 --> 00:00:43.566
Mac, be it a laptop, desktop, whatever,
it doesn't have a whole heck of a lot.

15
00:00:43.566 --> 00:00:46.760
I shouldn't say that cuz it actually does
have a whole lot of good stuff on there.

16
00:00:46.760 --> 00:00:50.900
So you've got the Safari web
browser which is usable.

17
00:00:50.900 --> 00:00:52.650
You've got-
>> GarageBand.

18
00:00:52.650 --> 00:00:53.890
>> You've got GarageBand.

19
00:00:53.890 --> 00:00:57.336
Maybe you have that whole iLife suite, I
don't think you can call it iLife anymore.

20
00:00:57.336 --> 00:00:59.888
But you might have pages and numbers and

21
00:00:59.888 --> 00:01:04.780
all the other kind of business
productivity applications on there.

22
00:01:04.780 --> 00:01:07.220
And that stuff's really good,
you can use it.

23
00:01:07.220 --> 00:01:10.730
But in an enterprise environment
the odds are you're gonna have a line of

24
00:01:10.730 --> 00:01:11.790
business applications.

25
00:01:11.790 --> 00:01:14.520
Applications that you
need to do your work.

26
00:01:14.520 --> 00:01:18.080
And the odds are they're not gonna be
prepackaged on that Mac when you buy it.

27
00:01:18.080 --> 00:01:20.010
So, we have to install things.

28
00:01:20.010 --> 00:01:22.920
We have to add software, and I know I
do this and it could be simple things.

29
00:01:22.920 --> 00:01:25.630
It could be an alternate web browser.

30
00:01:25.630 --> 00:01:26.620
I like Google Chrome so

31
00:01:26.620 --> 00:01:29.640
I've got to install Google Chrome
on my system to be able to use it.

32
00:01:29.640 --> 00:01:33.740
I might prefer Safari or
Vivaldi or Firefox or whatever, so

33
00:01:33.740 --> 00:01:37.050
you might have to install that
software to get it in place.

34
00:01:37.050 --> 00:01:42.160
I might like Microsoft Office
better than the suite from Apple.

35
00:01:42.160 --> 00:01:45.570
And so I go ahead and
install Microsoft Word and Excel.

36
00:01:45.570 --> 00:01:47.250
I've gotta put those on there, right.

37
00:01:47.250 --> 00:01:50.840
And in an enterprise environment,
you may likely have to do that for

38
00:01:50.840 --> 00:01:53.690
your clients ahead of time, or
your customers, ahead of time.

39
00:01:53.690 --> 00:01:56.830
Now, back in
the Mac Management Basics series,

40
00:01:56.830 --> 00:02:00.690
if you guys watched that series, I showed
you guys how to make OS10 installation

41
00:02:00.690 --> 00:02:04.720
images that already had applications baked
into them and that's really good stuff.

42
00:02:04.720 --> 00:02:07.730
If you haven't seen that,
definitely jump back for those.

43
00:02:07.730 --> 00:02:11.700
If you don't feel like jumping backwards,
when we get to the ACTC shows we'll cover

44
00:02:11.700 --> 00:02:14.690
it again on the server shows so
you'll get a chance to see it there.

45
00:02:14.690 --> 00:02:17.210
But I just want to mention that right here
cuz that's one of the easiest way to do it

46
00:02:17.210 --> 00:02:21.000
is you can build the installation image
that already has all the apps on there.

47
00:02:21.000 --> 00:02:22.630
But let's say you don't
want to go through that.

48
00:02:22.630 --> 00:02:25.680
You just want to install
apps right here on the Mac.

49
00:02:25.680 --> 00:02:29.850
Well, there's two main ways that we
can get apps installed on your Mac.

50
00:02:29.850 --> 00:02:34.030
There's using the App Store which is the
way that Apple would prefer we do it and

51
00:02:34.030 --> 00:02:37.270
then there's what's called sideloading
where we manually install them.

52
00:02:37.270 --> 00:02:41.777
Now, before there was an App Store
there was only sideloading and

53
00:02:41.777 --> 00:02:43.350
they didn't call it
side loading back then.

54
00:02:43.350 --> 00:02:45.400
Back then it was just
called installing an app.

55
00:02:45.400 --> 00:02:46.820
So let's talk about that one first.

56
00:02:46.820 --> 00:02:52.050
If I want to install and app that's
sideloaded, what the heck does that mean?

57
00:02:52.050 --> 00:02:55.510
It means you to the vendor's web site,
you download their software, and

58
00:02:55.510 --> 00:02:56.080
you install it.

59
00:02:56.080 --> 00:02:57.630
You do it by hand.

60
00:02:57.630 --> 00:03:01.420
And if an update comes out for that
program, you need to go and do the update.

61
00:03:01.420 --> 00:03:02.880
And you do it by hand.

62
00:03:02.880 --> 00:03:04.000
And that's just how it runs.

63
00:03:04.000 --> 00:03:07.420
It's all in between you and
the vendor of that software.

64
00:03:07.420 --> 00:03:09.610
Apple really doesn't get
in the mix on that, okay.

65
00:03:09.610 --> 00:03:11.180
So you're dealing
directly with the vendor.

66
00:03:11.180 --> 00:03:15.750
And up until a few years ago, that was
the way to install apps on your Mac.

67
00:03:15.750 --> 00:03:19.980
And so that was just called installing
an app, but now it's called sideloading.

68
00:03:19.980 --> 00:03:21.030
What is that?

69
00:03:21.030 --> 00:03:22.830
It's like we're gonna do this on the side,
right.

70
00:03:22.830 --> 00:03:24.460
>> Yeah, it's like a back alley deal.

71
00:03:24.460 --> 00:03:25.468
That's what it seems like.

72
00:03:25.468 --> 00:03:26.600
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly.

73
00:03:26.600 --> 00:03:28.230
And that's kind of what it is.

74
00:03:28.230 --> 00:03:30.970
Is Apple said, you know what,
there's a better way to do this.

75
00:03:30.970 --> 00:03:34.490
There's a better way than making you have
to update your own software, making you

76
00:03:34.490 --> 00:03:37.992
have to go out and find it, making you
ensure the software is trustworthy.

77
00:03:37.992 --> 00:03:40.360
Cuz do how you gonna
know it's trustworthy?

78
00:03:40.360 --> 00:03:44.570
When you go and down load that software,
it could be infected with malware.

79
00:03:44.570 --> 00:03:45.780
You don't know, right.

80
00:03:45.780 --> 00:03:47.560
And there's been some
real examples of that.

81
00:03:47.560 --> 00:03:52.290
We had that key ranger malware that was
a ransom ware that was pushing out through

82
00:03:52.290 --> 00:03:54.240
the transmission bit torrent client.

83
00:03:54.240 --> 00:03:56.725
So you'd go to the transmission website,
the actual vendor,

84
00:03:56.725 --> 00:03:59.060
you'd download the software
right from them, and

85
00:03:59.060 --> 00:04:02.600
it had the ransom ware installed in
it right when you downloaded it.

86
00:04:02.600 --> 00:04:04.630
And how would you know that it was there?

87
00:04:04.630 --> 00:04:06.530
Well, thousands of people didn't and

88
00:04:06.530 --> 00:04:10.380
they got their systems encrypted
based on that lack of knowledge.

89
00:04:10.380 --> 00:04:14.010
So what Apple said is, hey,
let's set up a central repository.

Root owns it.

00:24:52.210 --> 00:24:54.140
It's owned by Root, not me.

560

561

562

What it does,

So, if i go to my launch pad view,

00:25:10.510 --> 00:25:15.790
If I click and hold my mouse like

568
00:25:19.450 --> 00:25:21.850
Well, if I hadn't zoomed in, there we go.

569
00:25:21.850 --> 00:25:23.990
Everything starts to
shake like on an iPad.

570
00:25:23.990 --> 00:25:24.850
And I got little Xs.

571
00:25:24.850 --> 00:25:27.890
And see how there's no Xs

572
00:25:27.890 --> 00:25:28.640
Those are system apps.

573
00:25:28.640 --> 00:25:29.450
They're part of OS10.

574
00:25:29.450 --> 00:25:30.830
They're part of the system.

575
00:25:30.830 --> 00:25:32.130
I can't mess with those.

576
00:25:32.130 --> 00:25:35.080
But Write,

00:25:35.080 --> 00:25:38.110
And if I click on that X,

00:25:38.110 --> 00:25:39.452
let's get rid of it.

579
00:25:39.452 --> 00:25:41.850
And [LAUGH].

00:25:41.850 --> 00:25:45.620
>> And you can't.
>> I know if I try and click on it.

581
00:25:46.690 --> 00:25:48.390
What is it doing?

00:25:48.390 --> 00:25:49.285
Please go away.

583
00:25:49.285 --> 00:25:49.940
>> [LAUGH]
>> So anyhow,

00:25:49.940 --> 00:25:52.700
what you're supposed to do is click on it

00:25:52.700 --> 00:25:55.585
My mouse is not clicking when I'm
in the shake view for some reason.

586
00:25:55.585 --> 00:25:56.371
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

00:25:56.371 --> 00:25:58.981
normally I click on it and it goes away,
and it doesn't prompt you for

00:25:58.981 --> 00:26:01.240
those admin credentials cuz

00:26:01.240 --> 00:26:02.460
You're doing it through the App Store.

00:26:02.460 --> 00:26:04.610

591
00:26:04.610 --> 00:26:07.330
I apologize,

00:26:07.330 --> 00:26:09.090

00:26:09.090 --> 00:26:13.288

00:26:13.288 --> 00:26:15.300
>> [LAUGH]
>> So [LAUGH] anyhow, so

00:26:15.300 --> 00:26:16.220
we get rid of it that way.

00:26:16.220 --> 00:26:18.440
So it's handled differently, right?

00:26:18.440 --> 00:26:20.750
And this is why we don't

00:26:23.320 --> 00:26:26.980

00:26:26.980 --> 00:26:29.760
different than what we

00:26:29.760 --> 00:26:32.990
So two differences there with

00:26:32.990 --> 00:26:34.810
There's one more thing I wanna mention,

it is something you might

When I talk about an application,

it's normally an application that's

00:26:45.890 --> 00:26:48.860
Something you run, you use it in your user
interface, and you see it and there it is,

00:26:48.860 --> 00:26:49.830
everything's very exciting.

00:26:55.340 --> 00:26:59.810

00:26:59.810 --> 00:27:00.920
what is Don talking about?

00:27:00.920 --> 00:27:02.320
>> Is it like the Charms bar?

00:27:02.320 --> 00:27:03.404
[LAUGH]
>> It is!

00:27:03.404 --> 00:27:09.940
A lot of people don't use this, but

00:27:09.940 --> 00:27:12.050
I'll just show you right
here on my laptop.

617
00:27:12.050 --> 00:27:15.510
I disabled the thing, I hate it, but

00:27:15.510 --> 00:27:17.190

00:27:17.190 --> 00:27:20.310
I'm gonna jump into my system

00:27:20.310 --> 00:27:24.140
In your system preferences, the dashboard,

it's actually controlled

00:27:25.890 --> 00:27:28.330

00:27:28.330 --> 00:27:31.500
And in Mission Control, you can
turn this dashboard on and off, and

624
00:27:31.500 --> 00:27:32.590
you see I've got mine off.

625
00:27:32.590 --> 00:27:34.510
So let me turn it back on,
I'll turn it on as a space.

626
00:27:34.510 --> 00:27:35.810
That's the default.

627
00:27:35.810 --> 00:27:40.370
So by default, there's an extra
desktop space that exists.

628
00:27:40.370 --> 00:27:43.980
And so, when I do my three finger
swipe up, see how I've got my desktop,

629
00:27:43.980 --> 00:27:47.140
I've got VMware Fusion, and
now I've got this dashboard.

630
00:27:47.140 --> 00:27:49.530
I wouldn't have had that a minute
ago cuz I keep it turned off.

631
00:27:49.530 --> 00:27:52.420
But if I swipe over,
here's this dashboard.

632
00:27:52.420 --> 00:27:54.720
This dashboard that I
literally never use and

633
00:27:54.720 --> 00:27:56.720
I turn it off on every
computer that I use.

634
00:27:56.720 --> 00:27:57.619
It's just not something I use, right?

635
00:27:58.980 --> 00:28:03.570
But what it is, is a collection of
widgets, and those widgets, they're apps,

636
00:28:03.570 --> 00:28:04.500
they're programs.

637
00:28:04.500 --> 00:28:07.040
These are programs
running on your computer.

638
00:28:07.040 --> 00:28:11.610
And just like you could get a malicious
app, you can get a malicious widget too,

639
00:28:11.610 --> 00:28:14.500
and so you could have something
here that's doing bad things.

640
00:28:14.500 --> 00:28:17.630
And so we have trusted widgets,
and untrusted widgets.

641
00:28:17.630 --> 00:28:20.980
We have the same kind of restrictions with
apps that apply to these widgets too.

642
00:28:20.980 --> 00:28:25.290
And so by default, I've got this super
awesome calculator, and the weather, and

643
00:28:25.290 --> 00:28:27.940
a clock, and a calendar, and
they're amazing and great, right?

644
00:28:27.940 --> 00:28:30.280
You can hit the little
plus sign down here,

645
00:28:30.280 --> 00:28:32.220
and we can start to add more widgets.

646
00:28:32.220 --> 00:28:34.730
And these are the widgets
that come with the system.

647
00:28:34.730 --> 00:28:35.670
So I can add ESPN.

648
00:28:35.670 --> 00:28:37.820
So I'm gonna add ESPN in.

649
00:28:39.090 --> 00:28:41.700
And it's tied to your iCloud account,
so it remembers that I like hockey.

650
00:28:41.700 --> 00:28:44.830
And so it's showing me hockey
scores by default, right?

651
00:28:44.830 --> 00:28:49.240
But all these widgets have settings
that you can go in and tweak and change.

652
00:28:49.240 --> 00:28:52.220
And so, if I go in here, I can pick
the sport that I want it tied to.

653
00:28:52.220 --> 00:28:55.530
So, maybe I want,
definitely not basketball.

654
00:28:55.530 --> 00:28:56.880
How about football?

655
00:28:56.880 --> 00:28:58.950
So, we'll switch it to football.

656
00:28:58.950 --> 00:29:00.840
And so now it's gonna switch
those football scores.

657
00:29:00.840 --> 00:29:05.198
While on the weather one, if we jump in
to it, we might wanna set our location.

658
00:29:05.198 --> 00:29:08.310
So what you're looking for is when
you float your mouse over the widget,

659
00:29:08.310 --> 00:29:11.530
there's usually a little
italics letter i that appears.

660
00:29:11.530 --> 00:29:13.390
See that's appearing
down there in the corner?

661
00:29:13.390 --> 00:29:15.430
And that's where you can into
your settings and so you can say,

662
00:29:15.430 --> 00:29:20.910
hey we are in Gainesville Florida,
we do Fahrenheit, so that's what I want.

663
00:29:20.910 --> 00:29:22.710
I'll hit Done, and so

664
00:29:22.710 --> 00:29:26.700
now we get the weather here where it is,
according to it, 69 degrees.

665
00:29:26.700 --> 00:29:27.300
>> 69 degrees.

666
00:29:27.300 --> 00:29:28.100
>> I can't believe that's right.

667
00:29:28.100 --> 00:29:28.740
>> That's a lie.

668
00:29:28.740 --> 00:29:30.040
>> That's what it says.

669
00:29:30.040 --> 00:29:33.570
All right, so anyhow, we can start to see
that weather, customize these things.

670
00:29:33.570 --> 00:29:37.780
But when you add those applications,
these are just ones that are built in.

671
00:29:37.780 --> 00:29:39.550
When you install third party applications,

672
00:29:39.550 --> 00:29:41.570
many of them carry along
their own widgets.

673
00:29:41.570 --> 00:29:43.252
And so when you hit this plus sign,

674
00:29:43.252 --> 00:29:46.900
you might start to see widgets from
other programs you've installed.

675
00:29:46.900 --> 00:29:49.480
I haven't installed any,
it's not terribly popular.

676
00:29:49.480 --> 00:29:52.140
In real life land, the odds are you never
even use this, you never even see it,

677
00:29:52.140 --> 00:29:53.700
you never even care about it.

678
00:29:53.700 --> 00:29:54.600
But it is on the exam.

679
00:29:54.600 --> 00:29:57.270
So I wanted to kinda single it out,
and show you guys that these widgets,

680
00:29:57.270 --> 00:30:01.510
they are programs, they are executables,
they are running on your system.

681
00:30:01.510 --> 00:30:03.950
And, if you're like me, and
you never use the darn things?

682
00:30:03.950 --> 00:30:04.890
Turn them off, right?

683
00:30:04.890 --> 00:30:08.630
That's the best way to do it, is just
go into your system preferences, and

684
00:30:08.630 --> 00:30:10.840
go into Mission Control.

685
00:30:10.840 --> 00:30:15.670
And where it says, the dashboard shows up
as a space, I just turn the thing off.

686
00:30:15.670 --> 00:30:18.930
Turn it off and that way the dashboard
doesn't exist, it's not there,

687
00:30:18.930 --> 00:30:23.650
those widgets aren't running unless you
specifically go into Mission Control, and

688
00:30:23.650 --> 00:30:25.130
then you'll trigger that and launch it.

689
00:30:25.130 --> 00:30:27.650
But I just turn the thing off and
that way I don't have to worry about it.

690
00:30:27.650 --> 00:30:32.403
And now it doesn't show up in my desktops,
and it's just not executing.

691
00:30:32.403 --> 00:30:35.470
So that's another example of
an application that you might have

692
00:30:35.470 --> 00:30:36.378
on your system.

693
00:30:36.378 --> 00:30:40.280
I doubt it'll show up on the exam,
but just for the thoroughness,

694
00:30:40.280 --> 00:30:44.760
those widgets are stored not in your
applications folder, but in your library.

695
00:30:44.760 --> 00:30:48.952
So, where you'll expect to see those
if I jump into my terminal here, and

696
00:30:48.952 --> 00:30:53.480
let me see how big I can make this,
probably about that big.

697
00:30:53.480 --> 00:30:57.080
So if I jump into my terminal here and
poke around the two places the widgets

698
00:30:57.080 --> 00:31:02.760
hide out is,
we got /Library/Widgets, right?

699
00:31:02.760 --> 00:31:06.600
That would be the system location,
and so there I see Calculator, ESPN,

700
00:31:06.600 --> 00:31:08.540
Flight Tracker, Web Clip, and so on.

701
00:31:08.540 --> 00:31:11.040
These are the ones that come with OS10.

702
00:31:11.040 --> 00:31:14.450
And then the ones that we install
end up under our user account.

703
00:31:14.450 --> 00:31:21.149
So if I go into
/Users/donpezet/library/widgets,oh,

704
00:31:21.149 --> 00:31:23.510
folder doesn't exist.

705
00:31:23.510 --> 00:31:27.530
So I haven't installed any widgets so I
don't have them, but if I installed some,

706
00:31:27.530 --> 00:31:29.740
they would actually be right
here under that widgets folder.

707
00:31:29.740 --> 00:31:31.740
So be aware that those can show up there.

708
00:31:31.740 --> 00:31:33.330
Same thing goes for applications.

709
00:31:33.330 --> 00:31:36.580
Remember that when an administrator
installs an application,

710
00:31:36.580 --> 00:31:39.210
it shows up under
the /Applications folder.

711
00:31:40.260 --> 00:31:42.160
But if an end user installs
an application and

712
00:31:42.160 --> 00:31:45.390
they don't have admin privileges,
it'll end up going in their user folder.

713
00:31:45.390 --> 00:31:51.910
So it will go under
/users/donpezet/library, or not library.

714
00:31:51.910 --> 00:31:53.040
Just /applications.

715
00:31:53.040 --> 00:31:54.500
There we go.
So it'll show up there.

716
00:31:54.500 --> 00:31:56.530
If they haven't done anything like that,
then it would be separate.

717
00:31:56.530 --> 00:31:58.180
But here you can see where I've installed

718
00:31:58.180 --> 00:31:59.687
some mission critical
apps like GoToMeeting.

719
00:31:59.687 --> 00:32:01.310
>> Gotta have that.
>> GoToMeeting, and

00:32:01.310 --> 00:32:04.750
Baldur's Gate II Enhanced Edition,

00:32:04.750 --> 00:32:09.860
So I installed these, and maybe I was in a
hurry and didn't give it admin privileges.

722
00:32:09.860 --> 00:32:12.740
Or maybe just that app chose
to install in my user space.

723
00:32:12.740 --> 00:32:15.360
Some of the installers will ask you, do
you want to make this available for you or

724
00:32:15.360 --> 00:32:16.390

725
00:32:16.390 --> 00:32:17.860
And maybe I chose just me.

726
00:32:17.860 --> 00:32:20.480
Well, I'm the only one who uses this
laptop, so it didn't really matter.

727
00:32:20.480 --> 00:32:24.660
But now I've got it right here, and
that's tied to just my account.

728
00:32:24.660 --> 00:32:27.910
So just a couple little odds and ends you
might bump into in the real world, but

729
00:32:27.910 --> 00:32:29.390
you'll definitely bump into on the exam.

00:32:29.390 --> 00:32:32.440
>> Yeah, my grandmother will be thrilled

00:32:32.440 --> 00:32:34.500
That's the kind of thing

00:32:34.500 --> 00:32:36.280
Right, I'll just have every
one of them enabled, and

733
00:32:36.280 --> 00:32:39.392
I'll be chomping off
a lid before too long.

734
00:32:39.392 --> 00:32:40.735
[LAUGH]
>> Gotta know those sports cars,

735
00:32:40.735 --> 00:32:41.412
it's important.

736
00:32:41.412 --> 00:32:42.119
>> Very important.

737
00:32:42.119 --> 00:32:44.740
All right Don, well now that we
know how to work with applications,

738
00:32:44.740 --> 00:32:48.240
we know how to get them installed, we
can use the app store, we can side load.

739
00:32:48.240 --> 00:32:50.990
And if you're so inclined,
you can play with the widgets as well.

740
00:32:50.990 --> 00:32:52.390
That's all there for us.

741
00:32:52.390 --> 00:32:55.850
You've done a great job of explaining
to us how we can get things installed,

742
00:32:55.850 --> 00:32:59.250
how we can uninstall them, and
work with those different systems.

743
00:32:59.250 --> 00:33:02.180
Is there anything else that we need to
add to this episode before we wrap it up?

744
00:33:02.180 --> 00:33:03.600
>> That's about it for applications.

745
00:33:03.600 --> 00:33:04.780
Obviously it's a big topic.

746
00:33:04.780 --> 00:33:08.070
There's a lot of things that come in
play that when you deploy a third-party

747
00:33:08.070 --> 00:33:10.620
application, you'll need to read that
vendor's documentation to find out what

748
00:33:10.620 --> 00:33:12.590
they say they've got
their own best practices.

749
00:33:12.590 --> 00:33:15.170
But for the exam, we've seen
everything that Apple recommends, and

750
00:33:15.170 --> 00:33:16.094
it's pretty straight forward.

751
00:33:16.094 --> 00:33:18.820
>> All right, well thank you so
much for explaining this for us, and

752
00:33:18.820 --> 00:33:22.870
showing us the way to get applications
installed onto our Mac systems.

753
00:33:22.870 --> 00:33:25.690
With that being said, looks like we've
wrapped up yet another great episode.

754
00:33:25.690 --> 00:33:27.140
Hopefully you've enjoyed it and
got a lot of it.

755
00:33:27.140 --> 00:33:30.830
We're gonna go ahead and sign off ITProTV,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore the topic of application data in Mac OS 10.11. They begin by showing you where application preferences are stored, which are saved as .plist files. They also show you how to protect files by locking them. Finally, they show you how Mac OS X knows what program to use to open the different file types.

693
00:33:44.360 --> 00:33:47.400
Don, thanks for stopping by,
we'll look forward to seeing you there.

694
00:33:47.400 --> 00:33:49.418
But we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

695
00:33:49.418 --> 00:33:50.780
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

696
00:33:50.780 --> 00:33:51.552
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

697
00:33:51.552 --> 00:33:53.535
>> And we'll see you next time.

698
00:33:53.535 --> 00:34:01.310
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue their look at application data in Mac OS 10.11, picking up with a handy feature called quick look which allows you to preview a file before opening. Finally, they demonstrate the auto-save feature, showing you how to enable/disable and resume which takes the user back to the previous state when app was last closed.
episodes.title: Application Data Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.936 --> 00:00:16.231
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.231 --> 00:00:17.849
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:17.849 --> 00:00:20.429
And in today's episode,
we already continued forward with our

5
00:00:20.429 --> 00:00:22.700
Apple Certified Support Professional
series.

6
00:00:22.700 --> 00:00:26.750
Joining us back in the studio today, for
a little more part two on application data

7
00:00:26.750 --> 00:00:28.460
is none other than our
good friend Don Pezet.

8
00:00:28.460 --> 00:00:29.870
Don, welcome back to the show sir.

9
00:00:29.870 --> 00:00:30.470
How are you doing?

10
00:00:30.470 --> 00:00:31.600
>> Thanks for having me back Daniel.

11
00:00:31.600 --> 00:00:34.970
Ready to jump right back in and
talk about some of our app data.

12
00:00:34.970 --> 00:00:37.895
And in the last episode we focused
on things like preferences,

13
00:00:37.895 --> 00:00:39.673
which we could find them right there.

14
00:00:39.673 --> 00:00:41.722
Well after a while, we could find
them right there on the hard drive.

15
00:00:41.722 --> 00:00:44.720
Those plist files sitting there with
all the data tucked away in them.

16
00:00:44.720 --> 00:00:46.200
Sometimes things are really,

17
00:00:46.200 --> 00:00:50.140
really obvious like that,
similar to the documents themselves.

18
00:00:50.140 --> 00:00:55.260
So if you have a word processor or
a spreadsheet program or whatever,

19
00:00:55.260 --> 00:00:58.940
the data that it generates just goes right
into your documents folder by default.

20
00:00:58.940 --> 00:01:01.010
Really visible, really easy to see.

21
00:01:01.010 --> 00:01:04.610
But there are sometimes where
the data that an application creates

22
00:01:04.610 --> 00:01:08.600
Is mysteriously hidden away in
what would seem like nothing.

23
00:01:08.600 --> 00:01:12.460
And there's some neat features that
are put inside of OS X that can

24
00:01:12.460 --> 00:01:16.050
take advantage of that, they can use that
data to really pull up some good stuff.

25
00:01:16.050 --> 00:01:18.163
So that's what we're gonna take a look at.

26
00:01:18.163 --> 00:01:21.232
I've got quick look on the list and
autosave are two of the big features that

27
00:01:21.232 --> 00:01:23.890
I didn't get to in the last
episode that we need to see.

28
00:01:23.890 --> 00:01:26.150
They show up on the exam but
they show up in real life too,

29
00:01:26.150 --> 00:01:28.710
because they're neat features and
they're definitely useful.

30
00:01:28.710 --> 00:01:30.705
So let's kick things on QuickLook.

31
00:01:30.705 --> 00:01:34.165
QuickLook is one of those features that
was introduced in Mac OS just a few

32
00:01:34.165 --> 00:01:34.914
versions ago.

33
00:01:34.914 --> 00:01:39.783
And it's a really neat system that builds
on the idea of the launch services

34
00:01:39.783 --> 00:01:41.680
we saw in the last episode.

35
00:01:41.680 --> 00:01:45.790
So well launch services if you don't
remember, if I install a word processor.

36
00:01:45.790 --> 00:01:50.720
And it can read PDFs and documents and
so on, like Word documents,

37
00:01:50.720 --> 00:01:55.760
it registers itself with Mac OS
to say hey, I can open that.

38
00:01:55.760 --> 00:01:58.263
And so when Mac OS comes
across one of these files,

39
00:01:58.263 --> 00:02:01.253
you can double-click on it in
nose hook program to open it.

40
00:02:01.253 --> 00:02:03.430
So it's registered that extension.

41
00:02:03.430 --> 00:02:07.300
Well applications where the developers
have really put some effort in

42
00:02:07.300 --> 00:02:09.868
can register it with QuickLook also.

43
00:02:09.868 --> 00:02:13.510
And what QuickLook does is
it lets you see information

44
00:02:13.510 --> 00:02:16.450
about the file without even opening it.

45
00:02:16.450 --> 00:02:20.037
So for example, here on my desktop,
let me just browse here.

46
00:02:20.037 --> 00:02:23.030
I'm gonna browse into my Documents folder.

47
00:02:23.030 --> 00:02:24.300
And or actually,

48
00:02:24.300 --> 00:02:27.840
I'll go to all Documents cuz let's see,
I've got a few different things here.

49
00:02:27.840 --> 00:02:31.640
I've got three different documents,
two of them are RTFs.

50
00:02:31.640 --> 00:02:35.714
They're Rich Text Format files,
and one of them is a PDF.

51
00:02:35.714 --> 00:02:38.710
So an Adobe Portable Document Format.

52
00:02:38.710 --> 00:02:42.870
And when you look at them,
I'm not just seeing generic file icons.

53
00:02:42.870 --> 00:02:47.130
What I'm seeing on the RTFs
is actually a miniature

54
00:02:47.130 --> 00:02:51.400
thumbnail preview of what's
inside of that file.

55
00:02:52.650 --> 00:02:55.480
So it's showing it and
I know it just looks kind of generic, but

56
00:02:55.480 --> 00:02:57.190
that's because of what I put in there.

57
00:02:57.190 --> 00:02:59.310
What I put in there is generic.

58
00:02:59.310 --> 00:03:00.624
Let's make it a little less generic.

59
00:03:00.624 --> 00:03:04.250
So maybe if I take the first three lines,
and I'll make them red.

60
00:03:05.340 --> 00:03:08.950
And I'll take a few more lines down here,
and maybe I'll make them blue.

61
00:03:08.950 --> 00:03:14.240
So I'm just adding a little character
to my file, so now it kinda stands out.

62
00:03:14.240 --> 00:03:17.790
A little patriotic red white and
blue or if you're French,

63
00:03:17.790 --> 00:03:19.970
you can go backwards on it,
blue white red.

64
00:03:19.970 --> 00:03:20.978
They'd say, ours is backwards.

65
00:03:20.978 --> 00:03:22.311
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I do that,

66
00:03:22.311 --> 00:03:26.710
now when I look at the thumbnail, see
how it's showing that, the red and blue?

67
00:03:26.710 --> 00:03:30.200
This is an actual preview
of the file itself.

68
00:03:30.200 --> 00:03:33.760
I haven't even opened the darned thing and
it's showing me what it looks like.

69
00:03:35.020 --> 00:03:40.170
Here's a PDF that I would
normally open in Adobe Acrobat or

70
00:03:40.170 --> 00:03:43.240
the preview client here inside of
Mac OS or something like that.

71
00:03:43.240 --> 00:03:48.520
And I can see there's the little X logo
that's on the first page of that document.

72
00:03:48.520 --> 00:03:50.880
If I open it up, and I go in here and

73
00:03:50.880 --> 00:03:53.490
look at the first page of
the document what do I see?

74
00:03:53.490 --> 00:03:55.650
There it is, there's that big X.

75
00:03:55.650 --> 00:03:57.306
It's a preview of the document itself.

76
00:03:57.306 --> 00:04:01.768
So what it's effectively doing is
opening the document to generate

77
00:04:01.768 --> 00:04:06.230
the thumbnail without actually
running the program itself.

78
00:04:06.230 --> 00:04:08.300
How the heck does it do that?

79
00:04:08.300 --> 00:04:11.238
Well it's all done through
the QuickLook service.

80
00:04:11.238 --> 00:04:12.370
And the QuickLook service,

81
00:04:12.370 --> 00:04:16.850
is a collection of libraries that tell
it how to generate these thumbnails.

82
00:04:16.850 --> 00:04:22.170
So I don't need all of Microsoft Word,
I don't need all of Adobe Acrobat

83
00:04:22.170 --> 00:04:25.040
just to generate a quick
thumbnail of the first page.

84
00:04:25.040 --> 00:04:29.874
And so Adobe and Microsoft or whoever have
released little libraries that Apple can

85
00:04:29.874 --> 00:04:31.955
use to generate these thumbnails.

86
00:04:31.955 --> 00:04:34.024
There's some of them Apple wrote
it themselves, the PDFOne,

87
00:04:34.024 --> 00:04:35.390
Apple wrote it themselves.

88
00:04:35.390 --> 00:04:37.280
The Word one, Microsoft provided that.

89
00:04:37.280 --> 00:04:40.700
And so we're now able to see that and
it looks kinda pretty.

90
00:04:40.700 --> 00:04:44.400
And that little thumbnail,
it shows up in more than one place.

91
00:04:44.400 --> 00:04:48.530
So for example, if I do the Get Info
screen, when I do the Get Info,

92
00:04:48.530 --> 00:04:52.690
see that's the generic icon that we'd
see if we didn't have QuickLook.

93
00:04:52.690 --> 00:04:56.410
Bit if I look down here, I get a Preview.

94
00:04:56.410 --> 00:05:00.680
Here's a preview of that document
right here in my Get Info screen.

95
00:05:00.680 --> 00:05:05.830
And because it's just an RTF, it actually
loads the first handful of lines.

96
00:05:05.830 --> 00:05:11.330
And I can get that preview of the data
right here in the Get Info screen.

97
00:05:11.330 --> 00:05:14.862
I haven't launched TextEdit, but
I'm seeing it here in the Preview.

98
00:05:14.862 --> 00:05:17.520
Let's see if that PDF
will do the same thing.

99
00:05:17.520 --> 00:05:21.210
Sure enough, in the Preview for
the PDF I see the entire first page.

100
00:05:21.210 --> 00:05:24.200
And I've even got little
navigation buttons right here.

101
00:05:24.200 --> 00:05:26.642
So I can sit and start to read.

102
00:05:26.642 --> 00:05:28.173
And if you're crazy you can sit here and

103
00:05:28.173 --> 00:05:30.274
read the whole sticking thing
in the Get Info screen.

104
00:05:30.274 --> 00:05:31.980
>> Well Don,
this is a really cool feature.

105
00:05:31.980 --> 00:05:36.280
We can actually get an idea of what it is
we're gonna look at before we even ever

106
00:05:36.280 --> 00:05:37.215
open the thing.

107
00:05:37.215 --> 00:05:41.790
Does this work with every file
that you throw on a Mac system?

108
00:05:41.790 --> 00:05:43.193
>> Not every one.

109
00:05:43.193 --> 00:05:45.044
It works with a lot of them.

110
00:05:45.044 --> 00:05:48.481
When Apple ships OS X, they package in
some QuickLook libraries to be able to

111
00:05:48.481 --> 00:05:50.680
reference, to be able to pull these up.

112
00:05:50.680 --> 00:05:52.770
Some are built in to the system, but

113
00:05:52.770 --> 00:05:55.670
then there are others you may
need to install by yourself.

114
00:05:55.670 --> 00:05:57.760
As you install applications
you'll find that it grows.

115
00:05:57.760 --> 00:06:00.943
So this is a stock install of OS X,
it's not very exciting.

116
00:06:00.943 --> 00:06:03.130
Let me jump over to my own desktop.

117
00:06:03.130 --> 00:06:06.866
And on my desktop,
I've got El Capitan installed, but

118
00:06:06.866 --> 00:06:10.373
I've obviously installed
a ton of other software.

119
00:06:10.373 --> 00:06:13.982
And as I've installed that software,
it's added more and more and

120
00:06:13.982 --> 00:06:18.493
more of those little QuickLook libraries
to increase what's able to be previewed.

121
00:06:18.493 --> 00:06:22.360
If you wanna see what
ones you have installed,

122
00:06:22.360 --> 00:06:26.140
if you take a look in /library/QuickLook.

123
00:06:26.140 --> 00:06:30.961
So the path is /Library/QuickLook,
and just pull up a listing in there.

124
00:06:30.961 --> 00:06:33.970
And you'll get a listing of all
the things you can do with QuickLook for.

125
00:06:33.970 --> 00:06:35.980
I've got a massive list here.

126
00:06:35.980 --> 00:06:37.193
I work in iBooks.

127
00:06:37.193 --> 00:06:38.880
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's not very spectacular.

128
00:06:38.880 --> 00:06:41.235
Well this isn't the only place
that QuickLook things can go.

129
00:06:41.235 --> 00:06:43.613
This is the main one, /Library/QuickLook.

130
00:06:43.613 --> 00:06:47.150
Some of the other places,
the ones that are built into Mac OS.

131
00:06:47.150 --> 00:06:52.286
They're tucked away in
/System/Library/QuickLook.

132
00:06:52.286 --> 00:06:54.650
And so I go over there,
here's the system ones.

133
00:06:54.650 --> 00:06:56.070
The ones that are built in.

134
00:06:56.070 --> 00:07:02.800
So I'll see Audio, Contact, APS,
that's a printing format, PDF.

135
00:07:02.800 --> 00:07:04.280
So that's the PDFOne that we saw menu.

136
00:07:04.280 --> 00:07:08.532
I don't have Acrobat installed on
that other machine, mail movie notes.

137
00:07:08.532 --> 00:07:10.051
Well, I guess we have two PDFOnes.

138
00:07:10.051 --> 00:07:12.770
Well I'm not quite sure what
the difference is between those two.

139
00:07:12.770 --> 00:07:16.436
Even a Microsoft Office QuickLook
generator is installed.

140
00:07:16.436 --> 00:07:19.743
So each of these are ones that
are gonna work for these file formats.

141
00:07:19.743 --> 00:07:21.865
>> I wonder who's winning
between the two PDF readers?

142
00:07:21.865 --> 00:07:24.463
[LAUGH]
>> Well, I imagine if you install

143
00:07:24.463 --> 00:07:26.597
the Adobe one than that would win-
>> Yeah.

144
00:07:26.597 --> 00:07:27.651
>> But who knows.

145
00:07:27.651 --> 00:07:28.463
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now,

146
00:07:28.463 --> 00:07:30.810
this is still not a whole heck of a lot.

147
00:07:30.810 --> 00:07:33.455
I mentioned that I have
Microsoft Office installed and

148
00:07:33.455 --> 00:07:35.190
I see this generic office one here.

149
00:07:35.190 --> 00:07:36.832
But as you install applications,

150
00:07:36.832 --> 00:07:39.760
the bulk of them will end
up under your user account.

151
00:07:39.760 --> 00:07:46.872
So if I look under
/Users/donpezet/Library/QuickLook.

152
00:07:46.872 --> 00:07:47.772
Do I not have any?

153
00:07:47.772 --> 00:07:52.549
I might not have any, so looking under my
user account in my own library/QuickLook

154
00:07:52.549 --> 00:07:54.541
yeah, I don't have any in there.

155
00:07:54.541 --> 00:07:56.937
So there's none tied to my user,
these are just the only ones that I have.

156
00:07:56.937 --> 00:07:57.835
So you may have a ton.

157
00:07:57.835 --> 00:07:58.644
You may have a few.

158
00:07:58.644 --> 00:08:02.682
It just depends on what all you've
installed on your system, but these little

159
00:08:02.682 --> 00:08:06.966
generators, these libraries, are what's
allowing us to pull up that preview and

160
00:08:06.966 --> 00:08:11.130
see it without actually opening
the application, it's pretty neat stuff.

161
00:08:11.130 --> 00:08:13.890
By default, there's a lot of file
formats that are supported, but

162
00:08:13.890 --> 00:08:19.460
if you're working with AutoCAD or
Adobe Illustrator or something like that,

163
00:08:19.460 --> 00:08:22.270
those aren't included by default,
the vendors will provide those.

164
00:08:22.270 --> 00:08:24.510
And that's when they'll start to
show up on your user account or

165
00:08:24.510 --> 00:08:28.010
in the other folders, and it'll grow
with the applications that you install.

166
00:08:28.010 --> 00:08:30.350
>> Yeah I remember the first
time I actually ran into this.

167
00:08:30.350 --> 00:08:33.370
I thought that obviously Mac
does a lot of things by default.

168
00:08:33.370 --> 00:08:36.250
And I got my first Mac when
I started working here, and

169
00:08:36.250 --> 00:08:38.590
I was working with our markdown editors.

170
00:08:38.590 --> 00:08:40.020
And I had, I started using Atom,

171
00:08:40.020 --> 00:08:43.640
well before that, I tried out a few
others, one of them was Textwrangler.

172
00:08:43.640 --> 00:08:47.240
And when I was looking at the files,
it was showing me that preview,

173
00:08:47.240 --> 00:08:49.600
before I opened the file,
letting me see if I have the right one.

174
00:08:49.600 --> 00:08:53.400
Well then I uninstalled Textwrangler,
and that preview option went away,

175
00:08:53.400 --> 00:08:55.390
and I was like,
why isn't that doing that anymore?

176
00:08:55.390 --> 00:08:57.502
And I ran into this, and
I figured out what was going on.

177
00:08:57.502 --> 00:09:00.080
>> Yeah, Textwrangler,
that was natively written for

178
00:09:00.080 --> 00:09:02.640
Mac OS versus Atom that's multiplatform,
so

179
00:09:02.640 --> 00:09:05.710
they didn't bother with the quick
look stuff, yeah, that happens a lot.

180
00:09:05.710 --> 00:09:08.740
>> I actually have Textwrangler installed,
even though I don't use it, just so

181
00:09:08.740 --> 00:09:10.905
I can get the preview feature.

182
00:09:10.905 --> 00:09:12.425
>> [LAUGH] Well,
that's one way to get around it.

183
00:09:12.425 --> 00:09:15.973
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so that's pretty much it for

184
00:09:15.973 --> 00:09:20.010
quick look, I feel like I'm leaving
something out, but that's about it.

185
00:09:20.010 --> 00:09:24.090
It's not amazingly spectacular,
it's just you get nice little icons.

186
00:09:24.090 --> 00:09:29.600
I guess one thing worth mentioning is
you don't always see these previews,

187
00:09:29.600 --> 00:09:33.000
so, actually, wait a minute,
let me talk about the actual previews.

188
00:09:33.000 --> 00:09:34.801
So depending on the view that we're in, so

189
00:09:34.801 --> 00:09:37.500
the view that I'm in
here is the icon view,

190
00:09:37.500 --> 00:09:41.370
if I switch to my listview it goes to
the generic icon, see how their generic.

191
00:09:41.370 --> 00:09:44.310
And it's just because they're so
small that I don't see the previews, so

192
00:09:44.310 --> 00:09:46.740
we don't always see the preview for that.

193
00:09:46.740 --> 00:09:50.060
When we start going into some
of our other views though

194
00:09:50.060 --> 00:09:52.070
you might get the full on preview.

195
00:09:53.150 --> 00:09:57.820
So when I switch into this view here,
which is the show items as

196
00:09:57.820 --> 00:10:02.550
icons in a list blah blah blah, or cover
view, you got a couple of different views,

197
00:10:02.550 --> 00:10:07.370
some of these views get really detailed
as far as showing what's going on.

198
00:10:07.370 --> 00:10:11.450
So depending on the view that you're
in in the finder, you may not see that.

199
00:10:11.450 --> 00:10:14.070
And you can switch views right
here using these buttons, or

200
00:10:14.070 --> 00:10:20.410
you can always go up top to your view menu
and it's got show preview as an option.

201
00:10:20.410 --> 00:10:24.490
And if you choose show preview, when you
click that, that makes that right bar

202
00:10:24.490 --> 00:10:27.920
appear, and so now I'm able to look
over there and there's that quick view,

203
00:10:27.920 --> 00:10:32.390
same thing that I saw in the get info
screen is now being rendered over here.

204
00:10:32.390 --> 00:10:35.870
And as I click on each one I
can see that preview coming up,

205
00:10:35.870 --> 00:10:39.400
so if you don't see it by default
you can just go and turn it on.

206
00:10:39.400 --> 00:10:43.870
But just remember, it does matter
which view you're in whether or

207
00:10:43.870 --> 00:10:46.180
not you're going to be
able to see this area.

208
00:10:46.180 --> 00:10:49.420
But even in the ones that don't normally
include the preview you can turn it on

209
00:10:49.420 --> 00:10:51.659
by just going to your view menu and
choosing show preview.

210
00:10:53.320 --> 00:10:56.660
All right so, enough about that,
let's talk about another one.

211
00:10:56.660 --> 00:10:59.950
That was really just a quick look

212
00:10:59.950 --> 00:11:02.230
library that's installed that
allows us to preview things.

213
00:11:02.230 --> 00:11:04.880
But there is another thing
that we need to be aware of,

214
00:11:04.880 --> 00:11:10.620
there's an interesting behavior that
happens, let me show you a text edit.

215

save the document and then it's gone.

435
00:22:50.100 --> 00:22:52.889
So I guess it's like a double edged sword.

436
00:22:52.889 --> 00:22:56.129
>> It is, it is, and all right,
obviously I know how this works.

437
00:22:56.129 --> 00:22:59.620
Right, I just explained it, I showed
you guys, I understand how it works.

438
00:22:59.620 --> 00:23:03.290
I still hit Cmd+S all the time when
I'm working, I'm always hitting Save.

439
00:23:03.290 --> 00:23:05.130
And the reason I do it is for
a couple of reasons.

440
00:23:05.130 --> 00:23:07.190
One, I just don't trust computers,
I guess there's that.

441
00:23:07.190 --> 00:23:10.120
But two,
not every application supports it.

442
00:23:10.120 --> 00:23:13.210
So I was pointing out how,
I got on a sidetrack,

443
00:23:13.210 --> 00:23:16.580
but what I was pointing
out was that in TextEdit,

444
00:23:16.580 --> 00:23:21.530
if you go up here to File, I've got
Duplicate, Rename, Move To, Revert To.

445
00:23:21.530 --> 00:23:22.590
Those are the Auto Save options.

446
00:23:23.930 --> 00:23:27.700
Not every application supports Auto Save.

447
00:23:27.700 --> 00:23:32.330
So for example, if I'm editing a document
in a Markdown editor or something,

448
00:23:32.330 --> 00:23:35.218
I think, Daniel,
you mentioned that, right?

449
00:23:35.218 --> 00:23:38.960
So let me take, here,
we'll take some show notes, for example.

450
00:23:38.960 --> 00:23:40.310
So if I take the show notes for
this episode,

451
00:23:40.310 --> 00:23:42.520
we write all our show notes in Markdown.

452
00:23:42.520 --> 00:23:46.260
And Apple doesn't really
have Markdown support.

453
00:23:46.260 --> 00:23:50.170
So when I take a look at the file,
it's got the generic icon for

454
00:23:50.170 --> 00:23:53.400
Markdown and
there's no preview for it, right?

455
00:23:53.400 --> 00:23:56.276
So it doesn't support that,
it doesn't have Quick Look for it.

456
00:23:56.276 --> 00:24:00.035
And if I open it, I use a little
text editor called Sublime Text.

457
00:24:00.035 --> 00:24:06.408
And when I go into Sublime Text, if I go
up here to File, I don't have Rename,

458
00:24:06.408 --> 00:24:11.870
I don't have Move To,
I don't have previous versions.

459
00:24:11.870 --> 00:24:16.320
And that's the indicator right there that
this program does not support autosave.

460
00:24:16.320 --> 00:24:17.275
And so I've gotta be careful,

461
00:24:17.275 --> 00:24:19.480
if I'm working in here I've
gotta remember to hit Save.

462
00:24:19.480 --> 00:24:24.180
So how do we remember which programs
support it and which ones don't?

463
00:24:24.180 --> 00:24:27.340
It's kinda tough to, right,
it's tough to remember that.

464
00:24:27.340 --> 00:24:32.400
And you'd be surprised, even some of the
bigger ones like Microsoft Word, depending

465
00:24:32.400 --> 00:24:35.920
on the version you're running, if you're
running Word 2011 it doesn't support it.

466
00:24:35.920 --> 00:24:38.060
And actually I don't
remember in the new one.

467
00:24:38.060 --> 00:24:42.757
This is 2016 I believe,
let's see what version of Word this is.

468
00:24:42.757 --> 00:24:47.400
This is Microsoft Word,
15.2 which is 2016.

469
00:24:47.400 --> 00:24:51.661
And so if I'm in here working and
I go to File,

470
00:24:51.661 --> 00:24:57.619
I've got their little Restore but
it's not the autosave one.

471
00:24:57.619 --> 00:24:59.530
So it looks like they
have not integrated it.

472
00:24:59.530 --> 00:25:01.862
Let me just actually save this real quick.

473
00:25:01.862 --> 00:25:08.120
I'll just save that wherever and see if I
get those menu options and yeah, I don't.

474
00:25:08.120 --> 00:25:13.310
I don't have it because Microsoft
has chosen not to incorporate it

475
00:25:13.310 --> 00:25:14.560
with the autosave feature.

476
00:25:14.560 --> 00:25:15.910
So it's up to the third parties to do it.

477
00:25:15.910 --> 00:25:19.220
So just beware it's not
supported everywhere.

478
00:25:19.220 --> 00:25:24.042
But Safari, TextEdit, Pages, Numbers,
those applications, the ones from Apple,

479
00:25:24.042 --> 00:25:25.224
they all support it.

480
00:25:25.224 --> 00:25:27.800
And a lot of the third parties
are starting to incorporate that in.

481
00:25:27.800 --> 00:25:30.520
>> Yeah Don, I think of it more as
like a backup parachute, right.

482
00:25:30.520 --> 00:25:34.710
I try to get really good
at doing the Save function.

483
00:25:34.710 --> 00:25:38.130
The, what is that, Cmd+S or
whatever it is for your feature.

484
00:25:38.130 --> 00:25:40.695
But if I forget,
it might be there as a backup.

485
00:25:40.695 --> 00:25:45.690
So I try to do that, but if I forget,
a lot of them will do it for

486
00:25:45.690 --> 00:25:46.900
you with the autosave.

487
00:25:46.900 --> 00:25:48.597
So it can be just like that backup for me.

488
00:25:48.597 --> 00:25:50.586
>> Yeah, and remember,
you can turn it off, right,

489
00:25:50.586 --> 00:25:52.790
it's right there in your preferences.

490
00:25:52.790 --> 00:25:53.960
Let me go back to it here.

491
00:25:53.960 --> 00:25:56.530
So in my System Preferences,
in General and

492
00:25:56.530 --> 00:25:59.970
then right down here, Ask to keep
changes when closing documents.

493
00:25:59.970 --> 00:26:01.520
Close windows when quitting an app.

494
00:26:01.520 --> 00:26:02.898
When you get those set,

495
00:26:02.898 --> 00:26:05.870
then it's gonna work like I just
demonstrated for you, right.

496
00:26:05.870 --> 00:26:09.050
Where I said Ask to keep changes,
it never did ask cuz it didn't have to,

497
00:26:09.050 --> 00:26:10.850
we supported autosave.

498
00:26:10.850 --> 00:26:14.090
But for programs that don't
support autosave it'll still ask.

499
00:26:14.090 --> 00:26:16.670
And then the Close windows, that's the
other important part to turn that on to

500
00:26:16.670 --> 00:26:17.760
make sure you're getting autosave.

501
00:26:17.760 --> 00:26:23.000
But when those two are set, autosave works
great, you never have to hit Save again

502
00:26:23.000 --> 00:26:25.330
unless you're in an application
that doesn't support it.

503
00:26:25.330 --> 00:26:28.030
>> Well Don, do we have any other
cool features when it comes to

504
00:26:28.030 --> 00:26:31.240
application data that we'd like to
show before we wrap up our show?

505
00:26:31.240 --> 00:26:32.400
>> That's about it,

506
00:26:32.400 --> 00:26:35.130
I mean we've obviously got a lot more
support professional stuff to cover.

507
00:26:35.130 --> 00:26:37.810
But as far as our application data,
that's pretty much it.

508
00:26:37.810 --> 00:26:41.100
>> Well, it is really cool and
knowing that's how it turn on autosave,

509
00:26:41.100 --> 00:26:43.500
that's a really good
thing to know how to do.

510
00:26:43.500 --> 00:26:46.756
So Don, we thank you for
explaining this things, showing us, and

511
00:26:46.756 --> 00:26:50.323
walking us through the all cool behind
the scenes features of our Mac OS.

512
00:26:50.323 --> 00:26:52.760
That being said, looks like we've come
to the end of another great episode.

513
00:26:52.760 --> 00:26:54.050
Hopefully you guys have enjoyed it.

514
00:26:54.050 --> 00:26:55.927
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

515
00:26:55.927 --> 00:26:57.344
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

516
00:26:57.344 --> 00:26:58.342
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

517
00:26:58.342 --> 00:27:00.418
>> We'll see you next time.

518
00:27:00.418 --> 00:27:07.700
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain some of the applications you might need to support in Mac OS 10.11. They begin by taking a look at Java. They show you how to install Java and describe when/why you may need a Java environment on your system. They they move on to iCloud; showing you how to get iCloud setup and working with other applications.
episodes.title: Application Support
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.080 --> 00:00:13.904
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

3
00:00:13.904 --> 00:00:16.270
welcome to another great
episode of ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:16.270 --> 00:00:20.090
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and today's
episode we're continuing on with our

5
00:00:20.090 --> 00:00:22.500
Apple certified support
professional series.

6
00:00:22.500 --> 00:00:23.880
Joining us back in the studio again today,

7
00:00:23.880 --> 00:00:26.610
to lend to that effort,
is our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:26.610 --> 00:00:27.710
Don, welcome to the show, sir.

9
00:00:27.710 --> 00:00:28.360
How's it going?

10
00:00:28.360 --> 00:00:29.370
>> It is going great, Daniel.

11
00:00:29.370 --> 00:00:31.880
Ready to jump right back into
the world of Apple support.

12
00:00:31.880 --> 00:00:35.320
And in this episode, we're going
to talk about application support.

13
00:00:35.320 --> 00:00:38.580
[LAUGH] And it's kind of funny that
the whole show is about support.

14
00:00:38.580 --> 00:00:41.430
But what we're gonna do is we're gonna
focus on the applications themselves.

15
00:00:41.430 --> 00:00:44.880
Up until this point, we've really been
talking about the operating system.

16
00:00:44.880 --> 00:00:47.960
And how we make sure our operating
system is up and running and

17
00:00:47.960 --> 00:00:51.050
healthy and all the things
that Apple builds into Mac OS,

18
00:00:51.050 --> 00:00:53.530
and I'll say it's a great
operating system.

19
00:00:53.530 --> 00:00:56.790
It's got a lot of power, a lot of
functionality, but like most operating

20
00:00:56.790 --> 00:01:00.900
systems, out of the box it's really
just a fancy platform for a web browser.

21
00:01:00.900 --> 00:01:02.580
That's what you've got.

22
00:01:02.580 --> 00:01:05.930
So you're gonna end up installing
third party applications.

23
00:01:05.930 --> 00:01:09.260
Everybody does it, you've got things
that you need, you wanna work with.

24
00:01:09.260 --> 00:01:10.920
Maybe it's something
simple like a web browser.

25
00:01:10.920 --> 00:01:13.680
So I don't like Safari, so
I wanna install Google Chrome.

26
00:01:13.680 --> 00:01:15.110
Great you can do that.

27
00:01:15.110 --> 00:01:19.210
Or I need a fully featured office suite so
I install open office, or

28
00:01:19.210 --> 00:01:20.980
Microsoft office or whatever.

29
00:01:20.980 --> 00:01:23.780
Pages and numbers are great but
I prefer one of these other ones.

30
00:01:23.780 --> 00:01:25.584
You have third party
software that you need and

31
00:01:25.584 --> 00:01:29.000
it made me inhouse software developer,
things that you wrote yourself.

32
00:01:29.000 --> 00:01:32.981
So there's a lot that you may need to add
to OS10 to get it working the way that

33
00:01:32.981 --> 00:01:34.020
you want.

34
00:01:34.020 --> 00:01:37.380
And in our last set of episodes, we talked
about application data, where the programs

35
00:01:37.380 --> 00:01:40.880
that we run, where they store their data
and kinda the preferences and things.

36
00:01:40.880 --> 00:01:43.890
Now I wanna talk about just
running those applications at all,

37
00:01:43.890 --> 00:01:45.470
getting them up and going.

38
00:01:45.470 --> 00:01:49.560
And one of the first things I wanna
kick off with, our frameworks.

39
00:01:49.560 --> 00:01:52.800
That a lot of applications,
the authors don't write them from scratch.

40
00:01:52.800 --> 00:01:55.910
They don't write everything
from the bare minimum.

41
00:01:55.910 --> 00:01:58.720
If they did,
everybody would be writing in assembly,

42
00:01:58.720 --> 00:02:00.670
one of the really base core languages.

43
00:02:00.670 --> 00:02:05.120
But people use languages like C++ or

44
00:02:05.120 --> 00:02:09.800
Visual Basic, you got C#, you've got
a ton of the languages out there.

45
00:02:09.800 --> 00:02:11.780
Java and JavaScript and so on.

46
00:02:11.780 --> 00:02:14.280
They write applications in
these programming languages.

47
00:02:14.280 --> 00:02:17.595
And those programming languages have
libraries associated with them that

48
00:02:17.595 --> 00:02:21.060
already have some of the easier,
more mundane tasks already done.

49
00:02:21.060 --> 00:02:27.490
So for example, let's say you have an idea
for the next great golf score app.

50
00:02:27.490 --> 00:02:29.770
I need a program to keep
track of golf scoring.

51
00:02:29.770 --> 00:02:31.042
I hate golf.
So it doesn't really matter, but.

52
00:02:31.042 --> 00:02:32.990
>> [LAUGH].
>> But if that's what you want to write.

53
00:02:32.990 --> 00:02:34.890
Think about what that app is gonna be.

54
00:02:34.890 --> 00:02:36.930
You've got 18 holes in golf.

55
00:02:36.930 --> 00:02:39.880
And you need to be able to store how
many strokes you had on each hole.

56
00:02:39.880 --> 00:02:41.050
So you've gotta write that down.

57
00:02:41.050 --> 00:02:44.050
So, you're gonna need some little
fields to be able to type numbers in.

58
00:02:44.050 --> 00:02:46.730
And you're probably gonna
need a save button, or

59
00:02:46.730 --> 00:02:49.170
a print button to be able to print,
and so on.

60
00:02:49.170 --> 00:02:53.490
Well, you're not the first person
to think of text entry in a field.

61
00:02:53.490 --> 00:02:56.260
You're not the first person to think
of a save button or a print button,

62
00:02:56.260 --> 00:02:59.130
plenty of other people have
already thought of that before.

63
00:02:59.130 --> 00:03:02.780
So why reinvent the wheel,
why do a task that's already been done?

64
00:03:02.780 --> 00:03:06.610
So these libraries that are out
there already have buttons,

65
00:03:06.610 --> 00:03:07.940
they already have text fields.

66
00:03:07.940 --> 00:03:10.645
And so now when you say I need
a text field for hole number seven.

67
00:03:10.645 --> 00:03:15.440
I just add this pre-built text field and
assign a variable name to it and

68
00:03:15.440 --> 00:03:16.250
now I've got it.

69
00:03:16.250 --> 00:03:20.470
It saves a ton of time and it makes
development a lot more consistent and

70
00:03:20.470 --> 00:03:21.450
a lot more fast.

71
00:03:21.450 --> 00:03:23.400
You get things done more quickly.

72
00:03:23.400 --> 00:03:25.050
So applications rely on that.

73
00:03:25.050 --> 00:03:28.890
So when you install a program,
it may or may not be self contained.

74
00:03:29.910 --> 00:03:31.530
Now thanks to Apple sandboxing,

75
00:03:31.530 --> 00:03:34.050
a lot of applications these
days are self contained.

76
00:03:34.050 --> 00:03:36.400
They've got all the components
inside of them that are necessary.

77
00:03:36.400 --> 00:03:38.650
But that's not always the case.

78
00:03:38.650 --> 00:03:42.250
So if I'm gonna be supporting third party
applications that need a framework,

79
00:03:42.250 --> 00:03:44.240
I might need to install that framework.

80
00:03:44.240 --> 00:03:47.090
And one of the best
examples of that is Java.

81
00:03:47.090 --> 00:03:49.790
And I know I've made fun
of Java in other shows.

82
00:03:49.790 --> 00:03:54.040
Java, it started from a company
called Sun Microsystems.

83
00:03:54.040 --> 00:03:58.240
And they had this idea of,
hey when I write a program,

84
00:03:58.240 --> 00:04:02.210
I don't wanna have to write a Windows
version and a Mac version, and

85
00:04:02.210 --> 00:04:05.100
a Linux version, and
a mobile phone version.

86
00:04:05.100 --> 00:04:07.780
Wouldn't it be nice if I get to
write one version of the app and

87
00:04:07.780 --> 00:04:08.598
then it runs every where, right?

88
00:04:09.690 --> 00:04:11.270
Write once, run everywhere.

89
00:04:11.270 --> 00:04:12.940
That was their motto
when they created Java.

90
00:04:12.940 --> 00:04:16.440
And that's exactly what they did, is they
created this Java runtime environment,

91
00:04:16.440 --> 00:04:17.020
a framework.

92
00:04:18.270 --> 00:04:21.170
Sun wrote the framework for Mac, and

93
00:04:21.170 --> 00:04:23.900
they wrote the framework for
Windows and they wrote it for Linux and

94
00:04:23.900 --> 00:04:28.770
they wrote it for mobile devices like
Blackberry iOS and Windows Mobile.

95
00:04:28.770 --> 00:04:31.950
And so and Android and
whatever other ones I've left out.

96
00:04:31.950 --> 00:04:34.720
I mean they really were very
thorough they wrote this engine for

97
00:04:34.720 --> 00:04:36.530
every platform that was out there.

98
00:04:36.530 --> 00:04:40.000
So that if you as a developer wanted to
write an app you could write it in Java

99
00:04:40.000 --> 00:04:42.620
and you now supported all these platforms.

100
00:04:42.620 --> 00:04:45.640
The old argument was, hey, if I'm
gonna write a commercial application,

101
00:04:45.640 --> 00:04:48.290
I'm just gonna write it for
Windows because in the business world,

102
00:04:48.290 --> 00:04:52.360
90% of computers are on Windows, that's
going to be the bulk of the user base.

103
00:04:52.360 --> 00:04:56.270
Mac has a 5% market share, so I'll just
give up those 5% because it's not worth

104
00:04:56.270 --> 00:04:59.520
the expense of rewriting the application
for Mac for just 5% of the users.

105
00:05:00.660 --> 00:05:03.780
But if I can just write it in Java,
and now I support Mac and

106
00:05:03.780 --> 00:05:06.000
Linux anyway, why not?

107
00:05:06.000 --> 00:05:07.060
Right?
Why not go that way?

108
00:05:07.060 --> 00:05:09.260
Now, I make fun of Java for two reasons.

109
00:05:09.260 --> 00:05:11.050
And one reason is that it's slow.

110
00:05:11.050 --> 00:05:12.530
So, their old model was,

111
00:05:12.530 --> 00:05:17.300
write once run everywhere, I always
say write once run slowly everywhere.

112
00:05:17.300 --> 00:05:21.090
It's just not very fast and that's
because it uses a just in time compiler.

113
00:05:21.090 --> 00:05:22.280
It's actually compiling that code for

114
00:05:22.280 --> 00:05:24.340
that operating system as
the application is running.

115
00:05:24.340 --> 00:05:27.400
So it's not as fast as
a natively written app.

116
00:05:27.400 --> 00:05:31.110
>> Yeah, original Blu-Ray players,
their interfaces ran Java, and

117
00:05:31.110 --> 00:05:33.250
they were painfully slow.

118
00:05:33.250 --> 00:05:37.180
>> Yeah, it was that, and then people
would use these cheap hardware components

119
00:05:37.180 --> 00:05:40.710
because they knew that Java would run on
it, and they were doing the bare minimum.

120
00:05:40.710 --> 00:05:41.810
And it was terrible.

121
00:05:41.810 --> 00:05:46.140
Yeah, to this day I've got a,
what is my tv at home?

122
00:05:46.140 --> 00:05:48.410
A Samsung, a Samsung Smart TV.

123
00:05:48.410 --> 00:05:51.590
So I can pull up it's little Smart TV
Dashboard, but you know, I never do it,

124
00:05:51.590 --> 00:05:53.350
because it's so stinking slow.

125
00:05:53.350 --> 00:05:54.650
And it's just frustrating.

126
00:05:54.650 --> 00:05:56.490
So that's one reason I make fun of Java.

127
00:05:56.490 --> 00:05:58.370
The other reason is security.

128
00:05:58.370 --> 00:06:01.350
Because Java applications
can run everywhere,

129
00:06:01.350 --> 00:06:04.830
a lot of hackers target Java for exploits.

130
00:06:04.830 --> 00:06:06.820
They look for vulnerabilities,
they find a way to exploit them so

131
00:06:06.820 --> 00:06:07.540
they can write a virus.

132
00:06:07.540 --> 00:06:10.860
Because if they can write a virus,
the virus can run everywhere.

133
00:06:10.860 --> 00:06:12.700
I can write one virus
that runs everywhere.

134
00:06:12.700 --> 00:06:16.280
So in the Mac world we traditionally
don't have to worry about viruses.

135
00:06:16.280 --> 00:06:17.520
There aren't a lot that are out there.

136
00:06:17.520 --> 00:06:19.520
There are some but there's not a lot.

137
00:06:19.520 --> 00:06:21.250
Now we open ourselves up.

138
00:06:21.250 --> 00:06:23.460
But, you may have
applications that need Java.

139
00:06:23.460 --> 00:06:26.190
And in the past, there were two solutions.

140
00:06:26.190 --> 00:06:27.080
