And I'll just punch that code in.

598
00:27:26.150 --> 00:27:27.976
Mine is 2651.

599
00:27:27.976 --> 00:27:31.728
And I don't mind sharing that with the
world because if you were to try this now,

600
00:27:31.728 --> 00:27:33.390
it's a one time use code.

601
00:27:33.390 --> 00:27:34.560
I just used it once.

602
00:27:34.560 --> 00:27:37.270
So if somebody tries to log in again
I'm gonna have to get a new code.

603
00:27:37.270 --> 00:27:38.990
But now everything's unlocked.

604
00:27:38.990 --> 00:27:42.520
I can get to my mail,
assuming that it's Apple's iCloud mail.

605
00:27:42.520 --> 00:27:46.400
I can get to my Contacts, Calendars,
Photos, iCloud Drive, right?

606
00:27:46.400 --> 00:27:48.130
So if I click on iCloud Drive,
it's gonna browse in there.

607
00:27:48.130 --> 00:27:49.490
I'll see my files and folders.

608
00:27:50.500 --> 00:27:52.070
And there they are.

609
00:27:52.070 --> 00:27:54.900
There's Don's Stuff and
TextEdit and so on.

610
00:27:54.900 --> 00:27:59.250
And I can go into my other applications,
including Find my iPhone and so on.

611
00:27:59.250 --> 00:28:02.060
All right so
I can start to leverage that stuff.

612
00:28:02.060 --> 00:28:04.650
Even better, if I'm on a Mac and

613
00:28:04.650 --> 00:28:09.390
I've logged into iCloud, then what I
can do is I can fire up the Finder.

614
00:28:09.390 --> 00:28:11.300
And no matter where I am,

615
00:28:11.300 --> 00:28:15.630
under Shared I'll see my computers
if I had Back to My Mac turned on.

616
00:28:15.630 --> 00:28:19.380
They'll show up right here and
I can choose that machine.

617
00:28:19.380 --> 00:28:21.860
And, so I've got DPLAPTOP here.

618
00:28:21.860 --> 00:28:24.520
And so I can choose DPLAPTOP.

619
00:28:24.520 --> 00:28:28.110
And I can hit Share Screen, and
it'll connect to that remote system so

620
00:28:28.110 --> 00:28:31.160
I can see its screen and work with it.

621
00:28:31.160 --> 00:28:34.040
And it'll show up even if that
machine's on a different network

622
00:28:34.040 --> 00:28:36.840
because it's synchronizing through
Apple servers, through iCloud.

623
00:28:36.840 --> 00:28:39.020
So those are all different
functions of iCloud.

624
00:28:39.020 --> 00:28:41.372
And their integrated into the OS and

625
00:28:41.372 --> 00:28:43.710
third-party vendors are starting
to integrate that too.

626
00:28:43.710 --> 00:28:48.650
So when you fire up your next application,
you may see where it defaults to iCloud or

627
00:28:48.650 --> 00:28:50.980
it wants to store its
application data in iCloud.

628
00:28:50.980 --> 00:28:54.376
I use a little application called Jump
Desktop to be able to remotely connect to

629
00:28:54.376 --> 00:28:55.718
servers and things like that.

630
00:28:55.718 --> 00:28:58.063
And it stores all its servers in iCloud.

631
00:28:58.063 --> 00:29:01.149
And that's kinda nice because when I go
to different computers I can have all my

632
00:29:01.149 --> 00:29:03.950
servers defined right there to
reach out and connect to them.

633
00:29:03.950 --> 00:29:05.810
That's the power of having
something like iCloud.

634
00:29:05.810 --> 00:29:06.983
>> Yeah that's very cool software, right?

635
00:29:06.983 --> 00:29:09.400
As we're moving into that
whole cloud-based world,

636
00:29:09.400 --> 00:29:12.572
that whole cloud-based environment,
start taking advantage of it.

637
00:29:12.572 --> 00:29:16.180
[COUGH] Apple's been on this train for
quite some time now so go ahead and

638
00:29:16.180 --> 00:29:17.902
make sure that you
understand these things.

639
00:29:17.902 --> 00:29:19.940
Don, you did a great
job of explaining how,

640
00:29:19.940 --> 00:29:22.763
there was a lot on there I didn't
know we could leverage [LAUGH].

641
00:29:22.763 --> 00:29:24.120
But as iCloud user,

642
00:29:24.120 --> 00:29:26.750
I might actually be a little more
of an Apple fanboy than I realized.

643
00:29:26.750 --> 00:29:28.010
That being said,

644
00:29:28.010 --> 00:29:31.130
I know you've got a whole lot more,
as far as application support goes.

645
00:29:31.130 --> 00:29:31.933
But I'm looking at our clock.

646
00:29:31.933 --> 00:29:34.040
Our time is dwindling down quickly.

647
00:29:34.040 --> 00:29:36.130
So it looks like we're
headed to part two land.

648
00:29:36.130 --> 00:29:37.540
>> Yeah, yeah,
we've got some more things to cover.

649
00:29:37.540 --> 00:29:39.030
And I do wanna clarify something.

650
00:29:39.030 --> 00:29:40.870
I can't remember,
cuz it's been more than two minutes.

651
00:29:40.870 --> 00:29:44.450
When I was talking about Back, we talked
about Back to My Mac, where I can remotely

652
00:29:44.450 --> 00:29:48.490
see the screen, and we talked about
Find My Mac, where you can locate it.

653
00:29:48.490 --> 00:29:52.720
I can't remember which one I said
you could use in the iCloud website.

654
00:29:52.720 --> 00:29:54.320
So, let me just clarify that real quick.

655
00:29:54.320 --> 00:29:57.630
When you go to the iCloud website,
you have Find My Mac.

656
00:29:57.630 --> 00:29:59.670
And you can use Find My Mac to figure
out where the heck the thing went.

657
00:29:59.670 --> 00:30:02.570
So, you can go to any computer in
the world, log in to the iCloud website,

658
00:30:02.570 --> 00:30:04.870
and use Find My Mac to figure
out where your Mac is.

659
00:30:04.870 --> 00:30:07.720
But Back to My Mac,
the remote screen sharing,

660
00:30:07.720 --> 00:30:09.840
that's actually not a part
of the iCloud website.

661
00:30:09.840 --> 00:30:12.940
You have to do that from another Mac,
you gotta go to another Mac and

662
00:30:12.940 --> 00:30:15.640
you gotta log into iCloud and
you'll see it in the Finder.

663
00:30:15.640 --> 00:30:18.605
So Find My Mac is in the webpage.

664
00:30:18.605 --> 00:30:20.035
Back to My Mac is in the Finder.

665
00:30:20.035 --> 00:30:22.395
I'm not sure if I was clear
that when I said it earlier.

666
00:30:22.395 --> 00:30:24.215
So I just wanted to make
sure I laid that out.

667
00:30:24.215 --> 00:30:24.790
>> Nice save, Don.

668
00:30:24.790 --> 00:30:25.365
>> [LAUGH]
>> Nice save.

669
00:30:25.365 --> 00:30:26.105
Good job.

670
00:30:26.105 --> 00:30:27.287
All right, well it looks like
we're headed, like I said,

671
00:30:27.287 --> 00:30:28.007
we're headed to the part two land.

672
00:30:28.007 --> 00:30:29.055
We'll see you there.

673
00:30:29.055 --> 00:30:30.425
Thanks for dropping by today.

674
00:30:30.425 --> 00:30:31.545
Thank you guys for watching.

675
00:30:31.545 --> 00:30:33.453
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITPro.TV.

676
00:30:33.453 --> 00:30:35.235
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

677
00:30:35.235 --> 00:30:35.935
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

678
00:30:35.935 --> 00:30:36.541
>> We'll see you next time.

679
00:30:36.541 --> 00:30:45.450
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue discussing Application Support in Mac OS. The pick up here by looking at Voice and Accessibility options, specifically VoiceOver and Dictation&Speech. They show you how to enable and configure VoiceOver to perform Text-to-Speech functions. Then they show you how to enable and configure Dictation which takes input from the user's verbal commands.
episodes.title: Application Support Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.460 --> 00:00:10.460
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.843 --> 00:00:16.396
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITPro TV.

3
00:00:16.396 --> 00:00:19.783
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in
today's episode we're continuing on with

4
00:00:19.783 --> 00:00:21.747
our Apple Certified Support Professional.

5
00:00:21.747 --> 00:00:23.847
And joining us back in
the studio today for

6
00:00:23.847 --> 00:00:27.340
a little more application support
is our good friend Mr. Don Pezet.

7
00:00:27.340 --> 00:00:28.400
Don, welcome back to the show, sir.

8
00:00:28.400 --> 00:00:29.020
How's it going?

9
00:00:29.020 --> 00:00:30.050
>> It is going great, Daniel.

10
00:00:30.050 --> 00:00:33.150
Thanks for having me back, and we're ready
to dive into some neat technologies that

11
00:00:33.150 --> 00:00:36.390
are kinda built into OS X that
a lot of people don't make use of.

12
00:00:36.390 --> 00:00:39.890
So it's kinda cool to talk about,
and that is well, talking, right?

13
00:00:39.890 --> 00:00:41.920
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] We're gonna talk about talking.

14
00:00:41.920 --> 00:00:44.300
So when you work with your computer,
right?

15
00:00:44.300 --> 00:00:48.600
Your traditional way of interacting with
a computer is a keyboard and a mouse.

16
00:00:48.600 --> 00:00:50.770
We're starting to see new things,
we're starting to see touch screens and

17
00:00:50.770 --> 00:00:53.990
touch pads and all sorts of
touchy-feely stuff with your computers.

18
00:00:53.990 --> 00:00:56.550
But at the end of the day,
it's a very tactile experience and

19
00:00:56.550 --> 00:00:58.160
a very visual experience.

20
00:00:58.160 --> 00:01:02.878
Well, in the past, that hasn't worked
out so well for people will visual or

21
00:01:02.878 --> 00:01:04.436
auditory impairments.

22
00:01:04.436 --> 00:01:06.713
So it makes using the computer difficult,

23
00:01:06.713 --> 00:01:10.712
and we've talked in other episodes
about accessibility features in OS X.

24
00:01:10.712 --> 00:01:14.782
There's a lot of stuff that helps make the
operating system more accessible to people

25
00:01:14.782 --> 00:01:16.960
who have various impairments.

26
00:01:16.960 --> 00:01:20.050
Well there's actually some of these
features that have started making it into

27
00:01:20.050 --> 00:01:24.920
the mainstream, things like text
to speech and speech to text.

28
00:01:24.920 --> 00:01:26.170
These are two that are becoming really,

29
00:01:26.170 --> 00:01:29.020
really common place and you see it
more in the mobile devices, right.

30
00:01:29.020 --> 00:01:31.980
So if you have an iPhone or
an iPad you've got Siri.

31
00:01:31.980 --> 00:01:35.390
And Siri, when you receive a text message,
she can read it out to you.

32
00:01:35.390 --> 00:01:37.900
Or you can ask her a question and
she'll answer you.

33
00:01:37.900 --> 00:01:41.300
You can tell her a message to text and
she'll send it.

34
00:01:41.300 --> 00:01:45.170
She's taking text on the phone,
and speaking it to you.

35
00:01:45.170 --> 00:01:46.540
Text to speech.

36
00:01:46.540 --> 00:01:50.130
And you're giving her commands,
and she's turning those into text.

37
00:01:50.130 --> 00:01:52.380
That's speech to text.

38
00:01:52.380 --> 00:01:55.400
That's moving into the desktop world also.

39
00:01:55.400 --> 00:01:58.840
So in OS X, on your MacBook, your MacPro,

40
00:01:58.840 --> 00:02:01.970
whatever, you've got that
same type of functionality.

41
00:02:01.970 --> 00:02:03.070
Now it's not exactly the same.

42
00:02:03.070 --> 00:02:06.410
Siri is really powerful, and
Apples put a lot of work in that.

43
00:02:06.410 --> 00:02:09.870
The functionality on OS X,
is not at that same level.

44
00:02:09.870 --> 00:02:10.950
So it's a much more basic one.

45
00:02:10.950 --> 00:02:12.600
It's more like the predecessor to Siri.

46
00:02:12.600 --> 00:02:15.850
I wouldn't be surprised if we see
Siri like functionality introduced

47
00:02:15.850 --> 00:02:17.940
into OS X before too long.

48
00:02:17.940 --> 00:02:21.860
But for right now we gotta deal with some
of these features that are really just

49
00:02:21.860 --> 00:02:25.332
slightly evolved from the accessibility
features that we had years ago.

50
00:02:25.332 --> 00:02:27.570
All right, so
let's take a look at these and

51
00:02:27.570 --> 00:02:31.690
we'll start with text to speech, right.

52
00:02:31.690 --> 00:02:35.540
If you have a visual impairment,
when you go to use a computer,

53
00:02:35.540 --> 00:02:38.040
there's a lot of text on there and
a lot of it's very small.

54
00:02:38.040 --> 00:02:40.100
And it can be very difficult to read.

55
00:02:40.100 --> 00:02:41.150
And so if you have a visual impairment,

56
00:02:41.150 --> 00:02:43.060
you've got a find a way
to work around that.

57
00:02:43.060 --> 00:02:48.180
The other thing is,
the artsy creative types over at Apple.

58
00:02:48.180 --> 00:02:51.380
They come up with these new themes and
these ways of laying things out.

59
00:02:51.380 --> 00:02:55.710
Their current trend is light
gray text on a white background.

60
00:02:55.710 --> 00:02:57.660
I absolutely hate it.

61
00:02:57.660 --> 00:02:58.880
It's the worst thing in the world.

62
00:02:58.880 --> 00:03:00.970
There's very little contrast to it.

63
00:03:00.970 --> 00:03:01.490
It's hard.

64
00:03:01.490 --> 00:03:05.870
Even without a visual impairment,
it is hard to read that kind of text.

65
00:03:05.870 --> 00:03:10.510
I mean you just have to go to Apple's
website to see this all over the place.

66
00:03:10.510 --> 00:03:14.730
Or right here in the address bar
of Safari is a great example.

67
00:03:14.730 --> 00:03:20.040
In light gray text, on a white background,
search or enter a website name.

68
00:03:20.040 --> 00:03:22.750
And it's a little on the small side,
isn't it?

69
00:03:22.750 --> 00:03:25.400
Right.
I mean it's tough to see that and

70
00:03:25.400 --> 00:03:28.240
I'm actually using one of
the accessibility features right here.

71
00:03:28.240 --> 00:03:30.380
I'm using the zoom function.

72
00:03:30.380 --> 00:03:33.810
So it'll zoom in just so I can read it and
I don't have visual impairment,

73
00:03:33.810 --> 00:03:36.150
I mean I have contact lenses,
that doesn't really count.

74
00:03:36.150 --> 00:03:37.960
And it's hard for me to read.

75
00:03:37.960 --> 00:03:45.440
So imagine if you had tunnel vision or
what is it, ocular degeneration?

76
00:03:45.440 --> 00:03:47.630
One of those various symptoms.

77
00:03:47.630 --> 00:03:48.600
Glaucoma.

78
00:03:48.600 --> 00:03:50.550
Anything that impairs your vision.

79
00:03:50.550 --> 00:03:51.950
Or clinical blindness.

80
00:03:51.950 --> 00:03:54.750
You just can't see then this
absolutely doesn't do any good for you.

81
00:03:56.000 --> 00:04:01.140
So what text to speech does is it
takes these elements on the screen and

82
00:04:01.140 --> 00:04:03.440
it reads them out to you.

83
00:04:03.440 --> 00:04:07.789
And so that functionality, Apple calls
that voice over, but voice over,

84
00:04:07.789 --> 00:04:11.190
it was originally designed
as an accessibility feature.

85
00:04:11.190 --> 00:04:14.013
But over time they pulled
it out of accessibility and

86
00:04:14.013 --> 00:04:15.819
just made it a standard feature.

87
00:04:15.819 --> 00:04:20.421
So text to speech because we have
things like Siri that's reading to us

88
00:04:20.421 --> 00:04:24.640
our notifications, or
our text messages, or whatever.

89
00:04:24.640 --> 00:04:26.750
So people are using it
beyond accessibility.

90
00:04:26.750 --> 00:04:29.780
So if we wanna configure this,
if you wanna configure text to speech,

91
00:04:29.780 --> 00:04:31.610
there's two different places you can go.

92
00:04:31.610 --> 00:04:33.420
If I go into my system preferences,

93
00:04:34.900 --> 00:04:37.310
what you'll notice is way down
here we've got accessibility.

94
00:04:37.310 --> 00:04:40.272
In older versions of Mac OS
that's where all this was.

95
00:04:40.272 --> 00:04:43.610
But now I've also dictation and speech.

96
00:04:43.610 --> 00:04:46.070
And the dictation and speech side,

97
00:04:46.070 --> 00:04:50.880
this has the text to speech functionality
that's designed for everyone, but

98
00:04:50.880 --> 00:04:55.130
then we can go into accessibility and
get to the really advanced features.

99
00:04:55.130 --> 00:04:55.930
The ones that are useful for

100
00:04:55.930 --> 00:05:00.980
people that have a true impairment that
just need the system to be easier to use.

101
00:05:00.980 --> 00:05:03.690
Now for the common person who just
wants to be able to have text read

102
00:05:03.690 --> 00:05:04.260
out to them right?

103
00:05:04.260 --> 00:05:07.515
So I get a notification on my screen and
it reads it out to me.

104
00:05:07.515 --> 00:05:10.090
There's not a whole lot that I need
to configure for that to work.

105
00:05:10.090 --> 00:05:11.830
First off I've got to pick a voice.

106
00:05:11.830 --> 00:05:14.790
The default voice in Mac OS is Alex.

107
00:05:14.790 --> 00:05:16.520
So Alex is our default voice.

108
00:05:16.520 --> 00:05:19.650
And if I play that in my virtual
machine it is a little quiet.

109
00:05:19.650 --> 00:05:21.170
Let me do it on my regular desktop.

110
00:05:21.170 --> 00:05:25.830
So I'm going go into my system preferences
and go into text to speech and

111
00:05:25.830 --> 00:05:28.050
I'll pick old Alex right there.

112
00:05:28.050 --> 00:05:31.230
And let's listen to
a sample of Alex talking.

113
00:05:31.230 --> 00:05:33.360
>> Most people recognize me by my voice.

114
00:05:33.360 --> 00:05:34.870
>> All right.

115
00:05:34.870 --> 00:05:37.750
So the voice, it's a pretty good voice.

116
00:05:37.750 --> 00:05:42.060
It's robotic, you can tell the inflection,
the flow is not quite right.

117
00:05:42.060 --> 00:05:44.110
It's not perfect by any means.

118
00:05:44.110 --> 00:05:44.920
But it's pretty passable.

119
00:05:44.920 --> 00:05:48.000
You could listen to that, and
it wouldn't be too terribly inconvenient.

120
00:05:48.000 --> 00:05:50.352
These types of voices
are very difficult to create.

121
00:05:50.352 --> 00:05:54.789
And so Apple has packaged a few with OS X
and I think Daniel and I both agree,

122
00:05:54.789 --> 00:05:57.307
Alex is probably [CROSSTALK] the best one.

123
00:05:57.307 --> 00:05:58.362
>> By far, yeah.

124
00:05:58.362 --> 00:06:00.170
[LAUGH]
>> If you listen to some of

125
00:06:00.170 --> 00:06:01.680
the other ones, like Bruce, and

126
00:06:01.680 --> 00:06:04.820
Fred, these are some other male voices
that are included with the system.

127
00:06:04.820 --> 00:06:08.190
>> I sure like being inside
this fancy computer.

128
00:06:08.190 --> 00:06:08.820
That one's.

129
00:06:08.820 --> 00:06:09.780
>> That's fantastic right there.

130
00:06:09.780 --> 00:06:10.780
>> Even more robotic.

131
00:06:10.780 --> 00:06:11.390
Fred's not so bad.

132
00:06:11.390 --> 00:06:14.620
>> What's it like being
inside this fancy computer?

133
00:06:14.620 --> 00:06:16.380
>> Kinda like Stephen Hawking's chair,
right?

134
00:06:16.380 --> 00:06:17.710
>> Yeah.
>> Sounds very similar to his.

135
00:06:17.710 --> 00:06:18.560
>> That is very similar.

136
00:06:18.560 --> 00:06:21.986
Yeah, that, so
you can re-create 1970s technology.

137
00:06:21.986 --> 00:06:24.090
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you want.

138
00:06:24.090 --> 00:06:25.690
But there's female voices also.

139
00:06:25.690 --> 00:06:27.700
And I'll be honest with you,
these are even worse.

140
00:06:27.700 --> 00:06:29.190
So if we take, like Kathy.

141
00:06:29.190 --> 00:06:32.940
>> Isn't it nice to have
a computer who will talk to you?

142
00:06:32.940 --> 00:06:34.550
>> That's almost unintelligible [LAUGH].

143
00:06:34.550 --> 00:06:35.260
Let's be honest.

144
00:06:35.260 --> 00:06:36.290
>> Yeah that's pretty bad.

145
00:06:36.290 --> 00:06:38.240
And you can tweak the speed.

146
00:06:38.240 --> 00:06:40.350
So I can make them speak faster or slower.

147
00:06:40.350 --> 00:06:43.150
If I'm just having it read to me
notifications I probably want it at

148
00:06:43.150 --> 00:06:44.370
a normal speed.

149
00:06:44.370 --> 00:06:48.120
But if I have a visual impairment and

00:28:09.600 --> 00:28:13.880
when I choose open a finder item I can
browse and I can find my web browser.

610
00:28:13.880 --> 00:28:17.240
So I can go under applications and
I can find Safari,

611
00:28:17.240 --> 00:28:22.830
it is buried in here somewhere,
there we go, and I can open up Safari.

612
00:28:22.830 --> 00:28:28.210
So now, if I say browse the internet, in
any application it's gonna launch Safari.

613
00:28:28.210 --> 00:28:30.680
And now that will fire up and
I'm now got that command.

614
00:28:30.680 --> 00:28:32.340
And so when I get out,
let's see if I get this to work.

615
00:28:34.260 --> 00:28:35.010
Browse the internet.

616
00:28:37.600 --> 00:28:38.390
And there we go.

617
00:28:38.390 --> 00:28:39.878
It launches Safari, stop listening.

618
00:28:39.878 --> 00:28:41.468
[LAUGH].

619
00:28:41.468 --> 00:28:44.450
Stop listening.

620
00:28:46.417 --> 00:28:47.760
The fun we can have with this.

621
00:28:47.760 --> 00:28:49.600
>> Yeah.
>> So anyhow it launches Safari and

622
00:28:49.600 --> 00:28:51.790
went right to the URL
address bar right there.

623
00:28:51.790 --> 00:28:55.970
So I immediately could of said,
Google.com and

624
00:28:55.970 --> 00:28:58.120
it would of typed that out and
browsed to it.

625
00:28:58.120 --> 00:29:01.960
So now I have to create custom commands to
start working with the system in a more

626
00:29:01.960 --> 00:29:03.030
optimal manner.

627
00:29:03.030 --> 00:29:04.370
It just takes working with it.

628
00:29:04.370 --> 00:29:06.290
You gotta take some time and
sit down with it.

629
00:29:06.290 --> 00:29:09.235
On the exam they want you to
be aware of the two functions.

630
00:29:09.235 --> 00:29:13.970
Voice-over as well as dictation or
text to speech versus speech to text, so

631
00:29:13.970 --> 00:29:15.360
they want you to be aware of that.

632
00:29:15.360 --> 00:29:17.890
And be aware of some of the power and
functionality of it.

633
00:29:17.890 --> 00:29:20.000
They don't want you to
know all the ins and outs.

634
00:29:20.000 --> 00:29:23.320
But just for your own personal benefit,
spend some time learning these.

635
00:29:23.320 --> 00:29:27.730
And let me tell you,
even if you don't have an impairment,

636
00:29:27.730 --> 00:29:30.110
be aware that there
are other people that do.

637
00:29:30.110 --> 00:29:34.200
And it you're able to help them make
using the computer a better experience,

638
00:29:34.200 --> 00:29:34.900
that's a gift.

639
00:29:34.900 --> 00:29:37.550
That is a really rewarding thing.

640
00:29:37.550 --> 00:29:39.340
That you can make somebody
more productive at work.

641
00:29:39.340 --> 00:29:41.080
You can make somebody more
happier in their life.

642
00:29:41.080 --> 00:29:43.710
That their able to use these
functionalities that they wouldn't

643
00:29:43.710 --> 00:29:46.580
normally be able to use, or that would
be extremely frustrating to use so

644
00:29:46.580 --> 00:29:47.640
they choose not to.

645
00:29:47.640 --> 00:29:49.400
So, take the time to learn it.

646
00:29:49.400 --> 00:29:50.100
They're pretty easy.

647
00:29:50.100 --> 00:29:51.740
You just have to know what's there.

648
00:29:51.740 --> 00:29:54.260
Get in and turn them on and
make the best use out of it.

649
00:29:54.260 --> 00:29:55.430
Totally agree with you, Don.

650
00:29:55.430 --> 00:29:57.460
And thank you for
showing us how to use these things.

651
00:29:57.460 --> 00:29:58.280
And, you know what?

652
00:29:58.280 --> 00:30:01.030
I might want to start enabling some of
these features just for my own benefit.

653
00:30:01.030 --> 00:30:02.780
There's a lot of cool stuff in there.

654
00:30:02.780 --> 00:30:05.830
We do want to eventually
get to that Star Trek level

655
00:30:05.830 --> 00:30:09.090
of technology in our everyday
environment so why not start here.

656
00:30:09.090 --> 00:30:10.610
We've already got some of it enabled.

657
00:30:10.610 --> 00:30:11.250
Go ahead and turn it on.

658
00:30:11.250 --> 00:30:11.960
Start playing with it.

659
00:30:11.960 --> 00:30:13.990
And, like Don said,
then somebody comes around and

660
00:30:13.990 --> 00:30:16.220
they need help with that,
you can show them that as well.

661
00:30:16.220 --> 00:30:17.720
So its very cool stuff.

662
00:30:17.720 --> 00:30:19.710
Now that being said Don, guess what?

663
00:30:19.710 --> 00:30:21.590
We are out of time on this show.

664
00:30:21.590 --> 00:30:25.500
We're moving into
a mini-series territory here.

665
00:30:25.500 --> 00:30:29.140
But that is cool, because now we're
going to be the likes of v right?

666
00:30:29.140 --> 00:30:31.861
[LAUGH]
>> Yea, yea.

667
00:30:31.861 --> 00:30:35.256
So, what we got a chance to see
the last two episodes were some

668
00:30:35.256 --> 00:30:39.730
of the the different features in OS10
that other applications can leverage.

669
00:30:39.730 --> 00:30:44.500
So, we talked about Java in the last
episode, we talked about voice over and

670
00:30:44.500 --> 00:30:45.280
stuff here.

671
00:30:45.280 --> 00:30:47.200
Our third party applications
can leverage all that,

672
00:30:47.200 --> 00:30:51.170
they can use it and
it really improves their functionality.

673
00:30:51.170 --> 00:30:54.670
We haven't really talked
about the core OS itself.

674
00:30:54.670 --> 00:30:55.970
And so I do want to get into that and

675
00:30:55.970 --> 00:30:59.240
how we can manage those apps if we
have problems and other things.

676
00:30:59.240 --> 00:31:01.640
So we're gonna see that in our part three.

677
00:31:01.640 --> 00:31:02.760
>> Yeah.
[LAUGHS] All right, Don,

678
00:31:02.760 --> 00:31:04.000
well thanks again for stopping by.

679
00:31:04.000 --> 00:31:07.380
Thanks again for showing us how
to use these really cool features

680
00:31:07.380 --> 00:31:09.350
that we have built into
our operating system.

681
00:31:09.350 --> 00:31:13.020
We thank you guys for stopping by and
enjoying, joining us.

682
00:31:13.020 --> 00:31:16.290
We hope you enjoyed it, and
maybe learned a little bit of something.

683
00:31:16.290 --> 00:31:18.640
That being said, we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

684
00:31:18.640 --> 00:31:20.490
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

685
00:31:20.490 --> 00:31:21.150
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

686
00:31:21.150 --> 00:31:23.307
>> We'll see you next time.

687
00:31:23.307 --> 00:31:30.960
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don finish their exposition on Application Support in Mac OS 10.11 and here they begin with looking at the Mac OS itself. They talk about the benefits of El Capitan when working with Apps. They also talk more about Application Sandboxing. Finally, they go over monitoring by discussing the Activity Monitor, System Information, and Diagnostic Reporting.
episodes.title: Application Support Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.018 --> 00:00:10.018
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.074 --> 00:00:16.461
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:16.461 --> 00:00:19.171
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and
in today's episode that's right,

4
00:00:19.171 --> 00:00:22.390
we're continuing on with more
Apple Certified Support Professional.

5
00:00:22.390 --> 00:00:25.480
Joining us back in the studio again today
for just a little more of that application

6
00:00:25.480 --> 00:00:28.150
support action,
that's our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

7
00:00:28.150 --> 00:00:29.430
Don, welcome back to the show, sir.

8
00:00:29.430 --> 00:00:30.138
>> Thanks for having me back, Daniel.

9
00:00:30.138 --> 00:00:33.490
We're ready to hopefully wrap up our
application support episode here.

10
00:00:33.490 --> 00:00:37.990
So we started talking about some of
the features in OS X that help to

11
00:00:37.990 --> 00:00:40.560
support our applications,
that extend their functionality.

12
00:00:40.560 --> 00:00:41.780
And we saw Java.

13
00:00:41.780 --> 00:00:42.780
We saw iCloud.

14
00:00:42.780 --> 00:00:43.900
We saw Voice Over.

15
00:00:43.900 --> 00:00:45.070
We saw Voice Dictation.

16
00:00:45.070 --> 00:00:46.160
We saw all these different bells and

17
00:00:46.160 --> 00:00:49.000
whistles that extend the function
on their applications.

18
00:00:49.000 --> 00:00:51.770
Now let's talk about what the core
operating system itself does.

19
00:00:52.910 --> 00:00:56.690
Now, there was a big change in
the OS X ecosystem back, well,

20
00:00:56.690 --> 00:00:59.762
it's been a while,
it's been like seven years.

21
00:00:59.762 --> 00:01:03.935
In Mac OSX 10.6.8, back then, that and

22
00:01:03.935 --> 00:01:09.170
earlier, OS X was a 32-bit
operating system.

23
00:01:09.170 --> 00:01:11.260
And as a 32-bit operating system,

24
00:01:11.260 --> 00:01:16.210
it meant that no one program
could use more than 4 GB of RAM.

25
00:01:16.210 --> 00:01:19.540
That if a single program wanted
to use more than 4 GB of RAM,

26
00:01:19.540 --> 00:01:23.160
it had to split itself out into multiple
programs, which most people didn't do.

27
00:01:23.160 --> 00:01:28.920
So it didn't matter if I had 16 gigs of
RAM, no one program could use all of it.

28
00:01:28.920 --> 00:01:32.500
I can have four programs using 4
gigs each and that would work, but

29
00:01:32.500 --> 00:01:34.290
no one program could get more.

30
00:01:34.290 --> 00:01:38.476
Well, after 10.6.8, Apple went 64-bit.

31
00:01:38.476 --> 00:01:42.586
So OS X is now a 64-bit operating system
and El Capitan is no exception, right?

32
00:01:42.586 --> 00:01:44.620
It's still 64-bit.

33
00:01:44.620 --> 00:01:47.940
And that removes that 4 gig limitation.

34
00:01:47.940 --> 00:01:51.180
So now if I have 16 gigs
of memory in my computer,

35
00:01:51.180 --> 00:01:53.560
I can have one app that
uses all of it if it wants.

36
00:01:53.560 --> 00:01:55.830
It can use a ton of extra memory.

37
00:01:55.830 --> 00:01:57.950
And for most of us, it doesn't matter.

38
00:01:57.950 --> 00:01:59.933
If you're firing up Safari or
Chrome or whatever,

39
00:01:59.933 --> 00:02:01.418
you probably don't care about that.

40
00:02:01.418 --> 00:02:06.017
But if you're firing up Adobe Photoshop or
Adobe Illustrator or AutoCAD,

41
00:02:06.017 --> 00:02:09.813
those programms will consume huge
amounts of memory to run and

42
00:02:09.813 --> 00:02:14.630
they will certainly benefit from
having more than 4 gigs of RAM.

43
00:02:14.630 --> 00:02:17.910
So our core operating system by itself,

44
00:02:17.910 --> 00:02:23.350
just by being 64-bit, makes it easier for
programs have access to additional memory.

45
00:02:23.350 --> 00:02:25.108
So 4 gigs is the old limit.

46
00:02:25.108 --> 00:02:29.040
The new limit, there actually is
a new limit, it's 18 exabytes.

47
00:02:29.040 --> 00:02:33.400
Now, most of us, we know what megabytes
are, we know what gigabytes are.

48
00:02:33.400 --> 00:02:35.820
You probably know the next one,
which is a terabyte.

49
00:02:35.820 --> 00:02:38.248
But after a terabyte is a petabyte, right?

50
00:02:38.248 --> 00:02:40.880
And after a petabyte is an exabyte.

51
00:02:40.880 --> 00:02:42.046
>> That's like a skin condition,
right Don?

52
00:02:42.046 --> 00:02:43.066
>> [LAUGH] Where you scratch a bunch.

53
00:02:43.066 --> 00:02:44.786
>> [LAUGH] Rash, irritation.

54
00:02:44.786 --> 00:02:45.906
>> Yeah.

55
00:02:45.906 --> 00:02:50.546
>> So but the exa, it's huge,
it's a massive amount of memory.

56
00:02:50.546 --> 00:02:54.510
And in fact, you can't even buy a computer
today that has a single exabyte of memory.

57
00:02:54.510 --> 00:02:56.860
So the fact that we can
address 18 exabytes of memory,

58
00:02:56.860 --> 00:02:59.900
that means we've got a little bit of
growing room here with 64-bit before

59
00:02:59.900 --> 00:03:01.320
we need to go up to the next one.

60
00:03:01.320 --> 00:03:03.850
So this should carry us at least for
the next ten years.

61
00:03:03.850 --> 00:03:05.176
And then we'll see what happens, right?

62
00:03:05.176 --> 00:03:08.976
Maybe we'll get a 128 bit systems or
maybe it'll skip to 256, who knows?

63
00:03:08.976 --> 00:03:10.556
>> Quantum computing.

64
00:03:10.556 --> 00:03:12.216
>> Well, yeah,
that changes a lot of things too.

65
00:03:12.216 --> 00:03:15.170
So, but 18 exabytes, it's huge, right?

66
00:03:15.170 --> 00:03:17.450
We've got a lot of growth room there.

67
00:03:17.450 --> 00:03:20.450
For applications to take advantage of it,
it's not enough for

68
00:03:20.450 --> 00:03:22.410
just the OS to support it.

69
00:03:22.410 --> 00:03:24.690
The OS is now 64-bit.

70
00:03:24.690 --> 00:03:29.510
But you can run 32-bit or
64-bit applications.

71
00:03:29.510 --> 00:03:31.430
It'll run both, right?

72
00:03:31.430 --> 00:03:34.978
You can run a 32-bit app on a 64-bit OS.

73
00:03:34.978 --> 00:03:36.018
You can't do it the other way around.

74
00:03:36.018 --> 00:03:39.375
I can't run a 64-big app on a 32-bit OS,
that doesn't work.

75
00:03:39.375 --> 00:03:44.530
But 32-bit apps, the old apps,
will run on a 64-bit OS, the new OS.

76
00:03:44.530 --> 00:03:46.250
So you've got backwards compatibility.

77
00:03:46.250 --> 00:03:50.050
But when you run a 32-bit app, it's
still gonna have the 4 gig limitation.

78
00:03:50.050 --> 00:03:51.090
It's still gonna have that,

79
00:03:51.090 --> 00:03:55.360
because it can only see 4 gigs of RAM
no matter how much you actually have.

80
00:03:55.360 --> 00:03:57.940
So on my laptop, I've got 16 gigs of RAM.

81
00:03:57.940 --> 00:04:00.037
A 32-bit app will only see 4 gigs of it.

82
00:04:00.037 --> 00:04:03.950
A 64-bit app will see all 16 gigs and
potentially use it.

83
00:04:03.950 --> 00:04:05.980
Now your app doesn't
have exclusive access.

84
00:04:05.980 --> 00:04:07.520
It's not gonna use all the memory.

85
00:04:07.520 --> 00:04:08.950
It's gotta share it with
the operating system,

86
00:04:08.950 --> 00:04:10.270
it's gotta share it with other programs.

87
00:04:10.270 --> 00:04:12.490
So we have to keep track of that, but

88
00:04:12.490 --> 00:04:16.348
it does have the possibility of
accessing all of that memory.

89
00:04:16.348 --> 00:04:20.407
All right now one problem that you may
bump into as a support professional,

90
00:04:20.407 --> 00:04:21.650
64-bit's great.

91
00:04:21.650 --> 00:04:22.570
It's the way you want to go.

92
00:04:22.570 --> 00:04:27.040
Apple is pushing us that way, most
vendors out there are supporting 64-bit.

93
00:04:27.040 --> 00:04:30.510
The ones that don't, they stay in
32-bit and those still run fine.

94
00:04:30.510 --> 00:04:33.870
So it's pretty easy to support,
most of us don't have to worry about it.

95
00:04:33.870 --> 00:04:36.490
But there is a time where we can
have a little problem with it.

96
00:04:36.490 --> 00:04:40.970
Some vendors have not done a great
job of moving over to 64-bit.

97
00:04:40.970 --> 00:04:43.580
And a great example of that is Firefox.

98
00:04:43.580 --> 00:04:46.495
And it's not their fault necessarily,
I shouldn't say it that way.

99
00:04:46.495 --> 00:04:48.118
Firefox is a web browser.

100
00:04:48.118 --> 00:04:52.645
And as a web browser, it used to have the
4 gig limitation and web browsers, boy,

101
00:04:52.645 --> 00:04:57.170
when you start opening up a bunch of tabs,
they love to get a bunch of memory.

102
00:04:57.170 --> 00:05:00.084
So if I jump into Firefox here, let me
get it, I downloaded it before the show,

103
00:05:00.084 --> 00:05:01.468
let me install it here on my machine.

104
00:05:01.468 --> 00:05:04.902
And so if we take a look at my desktop and
I go into downloads,

105
00:05:04.902 --> 00:05:06.428
I got Firefox right here.

106
00:05:06.428 --> 00:05:10.608
And if I take Firefox and throw it
into my applications, I can launch it.

107
00:05:10.608 --> 00:05:14.027
And notice how it's not
telling me that it's 64-bit,

108
00:05:14.027 --> 00:05:18.977
it just shows us Firefox 45.0.1, and when
I go to install it, I just drag it and

109
00:05:18.977 --> 00:05:22.080
drop it into applications,
it's gonna copy over.

110
00:05:23.330 --> 00:05:27.590
And inside of applications I'm
gonna see it as just any old app.

111
00:05:27.590 --> 00:05:30.187
And when I run it, it looks no different,

112
00:05:30.187 --> 00:05:33.837
I just know it's 64-bit because well,
I've used it.

113
00:05:33.837 --> 00:05:37.960
[LAUGH] So, I know it's 64-bit but
as an end user I don't see that.

114
00:05:37.960 --> 00:05:41.721
As an end user, I don't notice
the difference between it being 64-bit or

115
00:05:41.721 --> 00:05:42.968
32-bit, all right.

116
00:05:42.968 --> 00:05:47.008
Now, where Firefox benefits from the extra
memory, is that every little tab

117
00:05:47.008 --> 00:05:50.720
that I open up in Firefox is kind
of spinning off another process.

118
00:05:50.720 --> 00:05:52.880
And so
each one needs a certain amount of memory,

119
00:05:52.880 --> 00:05:56.520
and it's about 200 megs in some cases,
sometimes a little more.

120
00:05:56.520 --> 00:05:58.330
Google Chrome is the same way.

121
00:05:58.330 --> 00:06:01.463
So the more tabs I have open,
the more memory I need, and

122
00:06:01.463 --> 00:06:04.808
I can hit that 4 gig limit
pretty quick if I'm not careful.

123
00:06:04.808 --> 00:06:09.081
Let me just cancel this import and
get into the stinking browser,

124
00:06:09.081 --> 00:06:11.030
there we go, and there we go.

125
00:06:11.030 --> 00:06:12.890
All right, so now I'm in Firefox,

126
00:06:12.890 --> 00:06:16.450
I'm up and running, and I'm ready to
start browsing the Internet, right?

127
00:06:16.450 --> 00:06:21.010
And each of these little tabs
up top is consuming some memory.

128
00:06:21.010 --> 00:06:26.840
And so the more of these tabs I open,
and the more websites that I browse to,

129
00:06:26.840 --> 00:06:29.980
and so on, each one,
is consuming some RAM.

130
00:06:29.980 --> 00:06:31.200
So the more memory I have,

131
00:06:31.200 --> 00:06:35.140
the more tabs I can open,
this benefits from being 64-bits.

132
00:06:35.140 --> 00:06:40.570
So Mozilla was really fast,
about getting this ported over to 64-bit.

133
00:06:40.570 --> 00:06:42.180
So where's the problem?

134
00:06:42.180 --> 00:06:47.490
The problem is, Firefox supports
a ton of extensions, add-ons.

135
00:06:47.490 --> 00:06:49.850
And if you look up here you'll see
where it's even got some by default.

136
00:06:49.850 --> 00:06:54.440
Save to Pocket, and then I can go in and
install third party ones too.

137
00:06:54.440 --> 00:06:57.530
If we browse in here you'll
find there's add-ons.

138
00:06:57.530 --> 00:07:00.160
And I can go into their
get add-on screens and

139
00:07:00.160 --> 00:07:03.638
I can find a ton of extensions and
add-ons that we can put in place.

140
00:07:03.638 --> 00:07:07.120
Well, these add-ons aren't
written by Mozilla.

141
00:07:07.120 --> 00:07:08.910
They're written by third parties.

142
00:07:08.910 --> 00:07:13.430
And those third parties were really
bad about updating to 64-bit.

143
00:07:13.430 --> 00:07:17.615
Most of these add-ons
are still 32-bit add-ons.

144
00:07:17.615 --> 00:07:24.493
And so if I fire up a 64-bit browser, it
can't talk to 32-bit add-ons, they break.

145
00:07:24.493 --> 00:07:27.600
I need 32-bit add-ons for
a 32-bit browser.

146
00:07:27.600 --> 00:07:30.700
I need 64-bit add-ons for

system.log, okay?

594
00:29:15.960 --> 00:29:17.450
That's the syslog for your computer.

595
00:29:17.450 --> 00:29:19.280
It's got the main stuff in it.

596
00:29:19.280 --> 00:29:21.640
But all these other logs
are pretty useful, too.

597
00:29:21.640 --> 00:29:24.200
If you ever wanna come in here, though,
and monitor the size of your log and

598
00:29:24.200 --> 00:29:26.980
see how big that thing has grown to.

599
00:29:26.980 --> 00:29:30.380
You can spot it and
I'm gonna do an OS dash LAH.

600
00:29:30.380 --> 00:29:32.180
And there's my system log.

601
00:29:32.180 --> 00:29:35.450
You see mine's 1.4 megabytes in size.

602
00:29:35.450 --> 00:29:36.165
I've got a 500 gig drive.

603
00:29:36.165 --> 00:29:37.650
[LAUGHS] I think I can handle that.

604
00:29:37.650 --> 00:29:40.520
But if it grows,
I can spot it here and deal with it.

605
00:29:40.520 --> 00:29:44.440
If it gets too big your Mac will
actually start to do log rotation and

606
00:29:44.440 --> 00:29:45.500
it will change that out.

607
00:29:45.500 --> 00:29:48.980
So like let me take my actual computer
here and show you real quick.

608
00:29:50.310 --> 00:29:53.250
Cuz my actual computer will
have more errors I'm sure.

609
00:29:53.250 --> 00:29:57.960
So if I do an ls -lah and
I'm gonna try and

610
00:29:57.960 --> 00:30:02.030
find my syslog in here.

611
00:30:02.030 --> 00:30:02.900
Here we go.

612
00:30:02.900 --> 00:30:04.620
You can see where mine's rotating.

613
00:30:04.620 --> 00:30:10.350
So I've got system.log, but then I've
system.log.0.gz.1 all the way through .6.

614
00:30:10.350 --> 00:30:15.150
As one fills up it creates another one,
it takes the old one and it gzips it.

615
00:30:15.150 --> 00:30:18.770
It archives it to make it smaller so
it's a compressed log.

616
00:30:18.770 --> 00:30:21.230
And so you'll see my current log is 800k.

617
00:30:21.230 --> 00:30:23.750
These other guys are only 130, 160k.

618
00:30:23.750 --> 00:30:26.200
Well, text compresses really well.

619
00:30:26.200 --> 00:30:29.671
Those things are probably 8 or 9 megabytes
that it compressed all the way down to

620
00:30:29.671 --> 00:30:31.712
160k, so
it's taking care of that for me and

621
00:30:31.712 --> 00:30:35.256
that's why I don't normally have to worry
about coming in and checking on these.

622
00:30:35.256 --> 00:30:38.272
But just be aware that's
where they're stored, so

623
00:30:38.272 --> 00:30:42.454
/var/log If your users have diagnostic
reports, if a program crashes

624
00:30:42.454 --> 00:30:46.650
the diagnostic reports are actually
stored as part of the user account.

625
00:30:46.650 --> 00:30:48.217
Let's see if I can remember
where those things are.

626
00:30:48.217 --> 00:30:55.798
It is /library/log/diagnosticreports
there we go.

627
00:30:55.798 --> 00:30:57.934
That tab auto complete will
help you find the way.

628
00:30:57.934 --> 00:31:00.634
And so I can look in here and
see diagnostic reports that have been

629
00:31:00.634 --> 00:31:03.160
generated from this machine
on the server level.

630
00:31:03.160 --> 00:31:05.960
And then for the user, if they have any,

631
00:31:05.960 --> 00:31:09.670
it'll be in their home
directories library folder/logs.

632
00:31:09.670 --> 00:31:12.890
And so they'll have log files
here that are tied to that user.

633
00:31:12.890 --> 00:31:17.400
So, like, if you look at mine I'm
in /Users/dpezet/Library/Logs

634
00:31:17.400 --> 00:31:18.290
that's the other place.

635
00:31:18.290 --> 00:31:22.435
So three places, /var/Logs,
that's for the whole system,

636
00:31:22.435 --> 00:31:28.230
/library/logs, that's for
the diagnostic reports.

637
00:31:28.230 --> 00:31:33.020
And then /user/theusername/library/logs,
that's for the individual users.

638
00:31:33.020 --> 00:31:34.890
Different places those log files could be.

639
00:31:34.890 --> 00:31:37.080
If you fire up the console app,
it's looking at all three so

640
00:31:37.080 --> 00:31:38.530
you don't have to worry about it.

641
00:31:38.530 --> 00:31:41.100
But just in case that's where
they are on the hard drive.

642
00:31:41.100 --> 00:31:43.222
>> Okay Don, really quick question
coming from the chat room.

643
00:31:43.222 --> 00:31:48.100
They wanna know, can we filter by
severity or something like that?

644
00:31:48.100 --> 00:31:51.330
Get rid of the informational and just give
me the stuff that's actually an error.

645
00:31:51.330 --> 00:31:52.320
>> Yeah, to an extent.

646
00:31:52.320 --> 00:31:55.450
In the console app you can,
here in the command line we can't.

647
00:31:55.450 --> 00:31:59.730
But in the console app when you pull
this up you've got a search box up here.

648
00:31:59.730 --> 00:32:02.450
And the search box is basically a filter.

649
00:32:02.450 --> 00:32:06.600
So if I want to look for you know,
actual errors or crashes.

650
00:32:06.600 --> 00:32:09.820
Like let's say I'm looking for
segment fall segmentation faults.

651
00:32:09.820 --> 00:32:12.070
Seg faults that's when
a program crashes out.

652
00:32:12.070 --> 00:32:15.140
So I could look for
the word fault and filter that out.

653
00:32:15.140 --> 00:32:17.500
Well, then I got default and
all that other stuff.

654
00:32:17.500 --> 00:32:19.960
So maybe I'll search for segmentation.

655
00:32:19.960 --> 00:32:21.530
So I'm gonna search for a segmentation.

656
00:32:21.530 --> 00:32:26.160
I don't have any seg files, so let me do
my actual desktop, it will be more fun.

657
00:32:26.160 --> 00:32:31.670
You could also look for a segv is another
term that's used for those faults.

658
00:32:31.670 --> 00:32:33.570
So let me just look for segment.

659
00:32:34.660 --> 00:32:36.625
I don't have any segment
faults on my computer?

660
00:32:36.625 --> 00:32:39.411
[CROSSTALK] Run a clean shop apparently.
>> Well I'm a person apparently, yeah so.

661
00:32:39.411 --> 00:32:43.162
I could look for the word error,
you could look for the word critical,

662
00:32:43.162 --> 00:32:47.400
you can search for those things and
it will filter this stuff down.

663
00:32:47.400 --> 00:32:50.420
So if I just look for error then
that's gonna filter that down and

664
00:32:50.420 --> 00:32:54.490
I can see where TextEdit had some errors,
failed to update bookmarks.

665
00:32:54.490 --> 00:32:57.190
Other things here that were kind of
crashing out for me for some reason.

666
00:32:57.190 --> 00:32:58.950
And that way you can filter it down a bit.

667
00:32:58.950 --> 00:32:59.950
>> All right, very cool.

668
00:32:59.950 --> 00:33:01.520
Well, Don, thank you so much for

669
00:33:01.520 --> 00:33:04.930
showing us on all these cool features
that are built into El Capitan.

670
00:33:04.930 --> 00:33:08.890
They definitely brought this thing up
into the new world, that is for sure.

671
00:33:08.890 --> 00:33:12.010
It's gotta lot of cool,
under the hood kinda stuff going on.

672
00:33:12.010 --> 00:33:15.670
Thank you, Apple, for hearing our
cries and for fulfilling our needs.

673
00:33:15.670 --> 00:33:17.050
Don, thank you again for stopping by.

674
00:33:17.050 --> 00:33:18.810
We thank our viewers for watching.

675
00:33:18.810 --> 00:33:20.350
Hope you enjoyed this episode.

676
00:33:20.350 --> 00:33:23.280
Signing off for IT PRO TV I've
been your host Daniel Lowery.

677
00:33:23.280 --> 00:33:23.897
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

678
00:33:23.897 --> 00:33:25.694
>> We'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don demonstrate and explain networking concepts and practices in El Capitan. They begin by laying out the foundational knowledge of how networking works. They detail the language or "Protocols" that network devices speak which is typically TCP/IP and the addressing schemes that are utilized by IP version 4(IPv4) and IPv6. They also talk about the physical components of a network.
episodes.title: Network Configuration

the initial setup you do with a Mac.

Networking is extremely important

In this episode we're gonna take

functionality inside of Mac OS that you

you'll likely have to jump in and

Network+ training, we're gonna have

So if you've done that,

you're not gonna hurt my feelings

But if you haven't done Network+,

00:01:59.240 --> 00:02:02.460
if you're just sticking straight

they expect you to know it for the exam.

jumping right into what I'm sure will be

51
00:02:18.770 --> 00:02:21.501
Well, Don, networking,
it's a pretty broad topic.

52
00:02:21.501 --> 00:02:23.692
So it's hard to find
a good starting point, so

53
00:02:23.692 --> 00:02:25.665
I know that you're really great at that.

54
00:02:25.665 --> 00:02:29.015
[LAUGH] Where do we begin when you
start talking about networking?

55
00:02:29.015 --> 00:02:31.741
All right, let's just start with
the different types of networks,

56
00:02:31.741 --> 00:02:32.920
cuz that's really changed.

57
00:02:32.920 --> 00:02:38.200
Back in the 80s, and even the 90s,
you had Apple Talk networks.

58
00:02:38.200 --> 00:02:42.115
And so, if you had a couple of Macs, and
you wanted them to talk to each other,

59
00:02:42.115 --> 00:02:44.966
you stuck those Apple Talk
dongles onto your computer.

60
00:02:44.966 --> 00:02:48.188
And this is way back, a lot of you guys
have probably never even heard of these.

61
00:02:48.188 --> 00:02:50.388
But there were these little
dongles that would plug in, and

62
00:02:50.388 --> 00:02:52.380
they basically had two
phone jacks on them.

63
00:02:52.380 --> 00:02:56.910
And you would daisy chain
these RJ11 phone cables,

64
00:02:56.910 --> 00:03:00.570
four wire category three cable,
running from computer to computer.

65
00:03:00.570 --> 00:03:04.380
And you'd get this insanely slow but
functional network,

66
00:03:04.380 --> 00:03:06.310
and that was how it was done back then.

67
00:03:06.310 --> 00:03:09.590
Well, in the 90s things changed a lot, and

68
00:03:09.590 --> 00:03:13.260
people started moving into one standard
type of network called Ethernet.

69
00:03:13.260 --> 00:03:17.940
And Ethernet networking worked
across Apple, Unix, Windows,

70
00:03:17.940 --> 00:03:20.870
it worked everywhere, and so
people really latched onto that.

71
00:03:20.870 --> 00:03:24.032
And that became the standard, and
so Ethernet networks are common,

72
00:03:24.032 --> 00:03:26.554
that's the one that we're
normally gonna deal with.

73
00:03:26.554 --> 00:03:30.480
Now, in the 90s it was
copper based cabling.

74
00:03:30.480 --> 00:03:33.220
You had these network cables that
would run between your computers and

75
00:03:33.220 --> 00:03:35.130
that's how you got
connected to the network.

76
00:03:35.130 --> 00:03:39.520
And so everybody was connecting
using basically the same technology.

77
00:03:39.520 --> 00:03:43.657
Well, at the end of the 90s things
went crazy, things went nuts, right.

78
00:03:43.657 --> 00:03:46.848
The dot-com boom happened,
tons of money was getting thrown into IT.

79
00:03:46.848 --> 00:03:50.696
And now we find ourselves today with
numerous different networking technologies

80
00:03:50.696 --> 00:03:51.920
that are out there.

81
00:03:51.920 --> 00:03:55.150
So we don't all have the same
standard network connection anymore.

82
00:03:55.150 --> 00:03:59.585
It used to be that everybody had a copper
based network jack in their computer that

83
00:03:59.585 --> 00:04:01.700
you'd plug a physical cable into.

84
00:04:01.700 --> 00:04:07.085
But now you might not be using that, you
might be using Thunderbolt, or Bluetooth.

85
00:04:07.085 --> 00:04:10.850
You might be using FireWire or
wireless networks, right?

86
00:04:10.850 --> 00:04:13.997
Now, I know what you're thinking,
Don, FireWire's not a network,

87
00:04:13.997 --> 00:04:15.844
that's not gonna get me on the Internet.

88
00:04:15.844 --> 00:04:19.040
Or Bluetooth, that's not a network,
that's not gonna get me on the Internet.

89
00:04:19.040 --> 00:04:20.736
Well, for the most part you'd be right.

90
00:04:20.736 --> 00:04:24.654
Normally when I hook something up
the FireWire it's a printer, right, or

91
00:04:24.654 --> 00:04:26.591
a hard drive or something like that.

92
00:04:26.591 --> 00:04:29.718
But FireWire actually
does create a network,

93
00:04:29.718 --> 00:04:33.093
you're using a network to
talk to those devices.

94
00:04:33.093 --> 00:04:36.700
And you can get FireWire network adapters,
there's not many of them, but you can.

95
00:04:36.700 --> 00:04:37.915
Thunderbolt, on the other hand, right,

96
00:04:37.915 --> 00:04:39.518
Thunderbolt we're normally
plugging in hard drives.

97
00:04:39.518 --> 00:04:43.550
But you can plug in monitors,
you can also plug in network adapters.

98
00:04:43.550 --> 00:04:47.158
And I've got one on my laptop right here,
a Thunderbolt Ethernet jack that I just

99
00:04:47.158 --> 00:04:50.150
stick onto my laptop so
I can have a physical connection.

100
00:04:50.150 --> 00:04:54.010
Because my laptop doesn't have a network
card in it, well not a physical one.

101
00:04:54.010 --> 00:04:57.420
It's got a wireless card in it, and so
it's designed to connect to wireless

102
00:04:57.420 --> 00:04:59.580
networks, which most
of us have these days.

103
00:04:59.580 --> 00:05:02.449
But I also have Bluetooth support,
which is a network.

104
00:05:02.449 --> 00:05:05.368
I have Thunderbolt support so
I can plug in a physical Ethernet jack and

105
00:05:05.368 --> 00:05:06.170
connect that way.

106
00:05:06.170 --> 00:05:09.900
I've got several different choices for
how I want to do that networking.

107
00:05:09.900 --> 00:05:13.920
Now the choice for you is largely
gonna be based on whatever hardware's

108
00:05:13.920 --> 00:05:15.650
built into your computer, right?

109
00:05:15.650 --> 00:05:17.250
So what options do you have?

110
00:05:17.250 --> 00:05:23.740
If you get one of the new MacBook Airs,
all it has is a wireless

111
00:05:23.740 --> 00:05:28.440
network adapter and a USB C connector,
and that's it, that's all it's got.

112
00:05:28.440 --> 00:05:29.472
So the wireless connector,

113
00:05:29.472 --> 00:05:31.752
that's gonna be the one that you
use to get out on the Internet.

114
00:05:31.752 --> 00:05:35.470
But it's also got Bluetooth built into it,
and you can do Bluetooth networking.

115
00:05:35.470 --> 00:05:39.984
So for example, you can take an iPhone,
and you can put it in hotspot mode,

116
00:05:39.984 --> 00:05:44.944
what do they call it, personal hotspot,
you can put it in personal hotspot mode.

117
00:05:44.944 --> 00:05:48.536
And so now you can take your laptop and
connect to your cellphone via Bluetooth,

118
00:05:48.536 --> 00:05:52.137
and use your cell phone's Internet access
to go out over the cellular network.

119
00:05:52.137 --> 00:05:56.660
So you can tether, there, that's the word
I was looking for, wireless tethering.

120
00:05:56.660 --> 00:05:58.760
Is that we can tether to our phones, and

121
00:05:58.760 --> 00:06:00.950
that's all done through
networking over Bluetooth.

122
00:06:00.950 --> 00:06:02.840
So a lot of neat little
features out there,

123
00:06:02.840 --> 00:06:05.400
and it's up to you how
you want to support that.

124
00:06:05.400 --> 00:06:09.608
Now, let me just show you an example here,
so I've got a stock install of OS X.

125
00:06:09.608 --> 00:06:16.220
And this is El Capitan, and
you might have a Mac Pro or something that

126
00:06:16.220 --> 00:06:20.820
is just super simple in its configuration,
that it only has one network adapter.

127
00:06:20.820 --> 00:06:24.430
It's pretty rare though, these days Apple
packages multiple adapters in everything.

128
00:06:24.430 --> 00:06:28.870
But this is a virtual machine here and so
when I go into my System Preferences and

129
00:06:28.870 --> 00:06:31.810
I go into my Network Adapters,
I've only got one.

130
00:06:31.810 --> 00:06:32.860
So in System Preferences,

131
00:06:32.860 --> 00:06:38.200
if I go to Network, I'm gonna see
just one connection, Ethernet.

132
00:06:38.200 --> 00:06:40.910
It says I've got an Ethernet connection,
and it's connected, right,

133
00:06:40.910 --> 00:06:42.480

00:41:18.520 --> 00:41:20.900
And when I talk to other
computers on the same network,

814
00:41:20.900 --> 00:41:22.340
I can use that address to talk.

815
00:41:22.340 --> 00:41:24.310
And it is made of two pieces, but

816
00:41:24.310 --> 00:41:29.820
the first piece doesn't identify the
network, it identifies who made the card.

817
00:41:29.820 --> 00:41:34.030
So if I take this address right here,
this is my Mac address,

818
00:41:34.030 --> 00:41:37.980
the last six values here,
that identifies my network card.

819
00:41:37.980 --> 00:41:39.850
That's me, that's Don Pizette.

820
00:41:39.850 --> 00:41:44.500
But the first six characters is just
identifying who made the thing.

821
00:41:44.500 --> 00:41:46.790
Well, you can guess who that is right?

822
00:41:46.790 --> 00:41:50.500
If you're using a Mac,
it's probably made by Apple right?

823
00:41:50.500 --> 00:41:55.646
So if I take my MAC address and punch it
in like an OUI search, that is what they

824
00:41:55.646 --> 00:42:00.705
call equipment identifiers, OUI, and
I do a search I can see right there

825
00:42:00.705 --> 00:42:05.880
3C:15:C2 is Apple Incorporated,
that's who made that adapter.

826
00:42:05.880 --> 00:42:08.810
Right, that's who made it,
it's recognized right there.

827
00:42:08.810 --> 00:42:11.190
You might have one made by Intel or
somebody else.

828
00:42:11.190 --> 00:42:14.060
If you have a USB adapter it might show
as being made by somebody else, but

829
00:42:14.060 --> 00:42:16.650
the one that's built into your
computer will show as Apple and

830
00:42:16.650 --> 00:42:19.360
that's just to identify the manufacturer,
it doesn't help with routing.

831
00:42:19.360 --> 00:42:22.970
So while MAC addresses do exist, they
are there, we don't really use them for

832
00:42:22.970 --> 00:42:25.560
network communications
beyond our local network.

833
00:42:25.560 --> 00:42:29.890
Well Don, obviously networking is
a large barrel of monkeys, right?

834
00:42:29.890 --> 00:42:31.300
There's a lot going on in there.

835
00:42:31.300 --> 00:42:34.660
We've really just scratched
the surface on how we need to--

836
00:42:34.660 --> 00:42:38.698
things that we need to know to make sure
we can support a networked environment.

837
00:42:38.698 --> 00:42:41.760
So,wow, we've completely exhausted.

838
00:42:41.760 --> 00:42:44.820
This is definitely a long episode but
it was good information.

839
00:42:44.820 --> 00:42:47.960
This is foundational stuff
that our viewers need to know.

840
00:42:47.960 --> 00:42:50.320
Fantastic job of demonstrating that and
explaining it for us.

841
00:42:50.320 --> 00:42:51.260
We appreciate it.

842
00:42:51.260 --> 00:42:51.840
Absolutely.

843
00:42:51.840 --> 00:42:54.460
And we talk about addresses,
we never actually use them.

844
00:42:54.460 --> 00:42:57.770
At no point in this episode
did I use my addresses.

845
00:42:57.770 --> 00:43:00.560
So in the next episode, we're gonna
see how to apply those addresses and

846
00:43:00.560 --> 00:43:02.420
actually use them, test them out,
make sure they're working.

847
00:43:02.420 --> 00:43:05.270
So we're gonna get to the little more
practical side in the next episode.

848
00:43:05.270 --> 00:43:06.650
Yeah, really looking forward to that.

849
00:43:06.650 --> 00:43:09.280
Thanks again, Don, for stopping by,
we'll see you in part 2.

850
00:43:09.280 --> 00:43:10.960
Hopefully you guys got
a lot out of this episode,

851
00:43:10.960 --> 00:43:12.860
maybe even learned a little bit,
we're gonna go ahead and

852
00:43:12.860 --> 00:43:15.580
sign off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowery.

853
00:43:15.580 --> 00:43:16.420
And I'm Dan Possette.

854
00:43:16.420 --> 00:43:18.408
We'll see you next time.

855
00:43:18.408 --> 00:43:23.714
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue their discussion of networking in a Mac OS X environment. Here they pick back up with explaining how network client machines get their IP information using the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) as well as setting IP info manually. They also explain some of the other protocols being utilized like Domain Name System(DNS) and Address Resolution Protocol(ARP).
episodes.title: Network Configuration Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.913 --> 00:00:15.571
All right greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:15.571 --> 00:00:18.820
I'm your host Daniel Lowery and
in today's episode we're continuing on

4
00:00:18.820 --> 00:00:22.520
with a little more of that Apple
certified support professional,

5
00:00:22.520 --> 00:00:24.070
let me get them in the right order there.

6
00:00:24.070 --> 00:00:26.840
And, joining us back in the studio again
today to help us out a little more on

7
00:00:26.840 --> 00:00:29.660
the networking side is our good friend,
Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:29.660 --> 00:00:31.150
Don, welcome back to the show sir.

9
00:00:31.150 --> 00:00:32.090
>> Thanks for having me back Daniel.

10
00:00:32.090 --> 00:00:33.640
Ready to dive right back into it.

11
00:00:33.640 --> 00:00:34.670
This is part two.

12
00:00:34.670 --> 00:00:38.250
If you watched the last episode, we talked
about some, kind of network fundamentals.

13
00:00:38.250 --> 00:00:41.370
How IP addresses work, and
what they're made up of.

14
00:00:41.370 --> 00:00:43.970
How the numbers are kind of built and
assigned.

15
00:00:43.970 --> 00:00:47.640
But we spent that whole episode and
we never actually used the numbers.

16
00:00:47.640 --> 00:00:49.450
And so in this episode we're
gonna get a little more hands on,

17
00:00:49.450 --> 00:00:54.030
and we're gonna see using these addresses
to communicate between two computers.

18
00:00:54.030 --> 00:00:56.820
Now in order to get two computers to
talk on the network they have to be

19
00:00:56.820 --> 00:00:57.440
able to see each other.

20
00:00:57.440 --> 00:00:58.600
They have to be able to communicate.

21
00:00:58.600 --> 00:01:02.360
And I mentioned in the last episode,
they have to speak a common language.

22
00:01:02.360 --> 00:01:07.700
And in this, today's IT world,
TCPIP is that common language.

23
00:01:07.700 --> 00:01:10.340
So if you've got a Windows machine,
a Linux machine or

24
00:01:10.340 --> 00:01:15.400
a Mac, they all default to using TCPIP and
if configured properly,

25
00:01:15.400 --> 00:01:18.320
your machines will see each other and
that's the end of the day.

26
00:01:18.320 --> 00:01:20.080
Everything works, everything's great.

27
00:01:20.080 --> 00:01:24.440
Well, a lot of network's leverage a neat
protocol that's out there called DHCP.

28
00:01:24.440 --> 00:01:28.260
DHCP DHC, how do you spell DHCP?

29
00:01:28.260 --> 00:01:30.175
>> I think there's a J in there,
it's silent.

30
00:01:30.175 --> 00:01:35.590
>> [LAUGH] A silent J, so it's stands for
dynamic host configuration protocol.

31
00:01:35.590 --> 00:01:36.340
And what it is,

32
00:01:36.340 --> 00:01:41.060
a little service that runs on your
network that helps people get addresses.

33
00:01:41.060 --> 00:01:43.440
So when you plug in your computer
on the network for the first time,

34
00:01:43.440 --> 00:01:47.280
your computer sends out a message on the
network that says hey guys I'm new here.

35
00:01:47.280 --> 00:01:48.620
I'm new.
I don't know the network.

36
00:01:48.620 --> 00:01:51.290
I don't know the numbers,
can somebody help me?

37
00:01:51.290 --> 00:01:53.550
Can somebody give me an address, please?

38
00:01:53.550 --> 00:01:57.670
And a DHCP server on your network will
reply back and say, hey, I'm here,

39
00:01:57.670 --> 00:02:02.470
I got your back, here is an address
you can use, good luck on the network.

40
00:02:02.470 --> 00:02:05.260
And your computer will
automatically configure itself.

41
00:02:05.260 --> 00:02:07.360
And then you're able to talk and
communicate.

42
00:02:07.360 --> 00:02:10.300
And that's all fine and good but on the
exam obviously it's not going to be that

43
00:02:10.300 --> 00:02:13.490
easy, yeah it's done, shortest exam ever.

44
00:02:13.490 --> 00:02:15.840
Instead, you're going to have to
kinda know the manual side of it.

45
00:02:15.840 --> 00:02:19.160
So let's take a look at that process and
see what's going on.

46
00:02:19.160 --> 00:02:20.460
Now, I've got a Mac here.

47
00:02:20.460 --> 00:02:24.740
This is a stocking stall of El Capitan,
and I haven't really done anything to it.

48
00:02:24.740 --> 00:02:27.390
I just installed it and as part of
the install it asked me for my name, so

49
00:02:27.390 --> 00:02:28.030
I put my name in.

50
00:02:28.030 --> 00:02:29.660
It knows I'm Don Pazzet.

51
00:02:29.660 --> 00:02:31.800
But otherwise,
it's plugged in to the network.

52
00:02:31.800 --> 00:02:35.030
And when I fire up Safari, and
try and browse out to the Internet.

53
00:02:35.030 --> 00:02:38.650
Let's let's see if we can
get to the ITProTV website.

54
00:02:38.650 --> 00:02:41.810
So if I go and browse out to the Internet,
it's gonna reach out.

55
00:02:41.810 --> 00:02:44.890
And it gets to the website, right?

56
00:02:44.890 --> 00:02:45.950
I didn't configure the network at all.

57
00:02:45.950 --> 00:02:47.930
All I did was plug in a cable.

58
00:02:47.930 --> 00:02:52.150
Well, when you plug in that
cable it needs an address and

59
00:02:52.150 --> 00:02:55.070
it had to have gotten
the address from somewhere.

60
00:02:55.070 --> 00:02:56.580
Now even on a wireless network or

61
00:02:56.580 --> 00:02:59.380
maybe you did have to do a little
something right and the wireless network

62
00:02:59.380 --> 00:03:01.930
you might have to pick the network
that you're connected to right?

63
00:03:01.930 --> 00:03:04.490
So if you look at like
my actual laptop here.

64
00:03:04.490 --> 00:03:08.400
I've got that wireless symbol up top and
I've got all the networks that it can see,

65
00:03:08.400 --> 00:03:12.030
and if I wanna connect to a network,
if it has a little lock on it,

66
00:03:12.030 --> 00:03:13.850
it's gonna ask me for a password.

67
00:03:13.850 --> 00:03:15.350
And so I provide a password and

68
00:03:15.350 --> 00:03:17.950
get connected, but then after that
I'm connected, I'm out there,

69
00:03:17.950 --> 00:03:20.030
I'm on the internet, and
everything's working great, right?

70
00:03:21.170 --> 00:03:25.530
But I never see IP addresses,
doesn't mean I don't have an IP address,

71
00:03:25.530 --> 00:03:27.000
I just didn't see it.

72
00:03:27.000 --> 00:03:30.890
So if I go in to my System Preferences,
and I go into networking.

73
00:03:32.810 --> 00:03:37.699
Inside of Network I can choose my adapter,
and I'll see those addresses, all right?

74
00:03:37.699 --> 00:03:41.700
But where do these addresses come from?

75
00:03:41.700 --> 00:03:43.110
I got 192.168.0.150.
Where did I get that?

76
00:03:43.110 --> 00:03:44.455
>> The magic DHCP fairy.

77
00:03:44.455 --> 00:03:45.940
[LAUGH]
>> That's exactly it,

78
00:03:45.940 --> 00:03:47.520
the DHCP fairy visited.

79
00:03:47.520 --> 00:03:51.250
And I got it using DHCP dynamic
host configuration protocol.

80
00:03:51.250 --> 00:03:53.880
Now, it's not a fairy, necessarily.

81
00:03:53.880 --> 00:03:54.770
It certainly could be.

82
00:03:54.770 --> 00:03:58.530
But it's more than likely some kind
of appliance on your network and

83
00:03:58.530 --> 00:04:00.280
it's very commonly your router.

84
00:04:00.280 --> 00:04:03.710
So in homes or small offices,
you normally get these wireless

85
00:04:03.710 --> 00:04:06.980
routers slash access access
point mega combo devices, right?

86
00:04:06.980 --> 00:04:10.420
And you plug your broadband connection
into it and your whole house or

87
00:04:10.420 --> 00:04:12.480
whole office gets internet access.

88
00:04:12.480 --> 00:04:17.420
Well, that router can do DHCP so
it may be a DHCP server.

89
00:04:17.420 --> 00:04:20.960
Or maybe you have a server
that's running OS 10 and

90
00:04:20.960 --> 00:04:23.430
it's got the server app installed on it.

91
00:04:23.430 --> 00:04:25.070
The server app has a DHCP server too.

92
00:04:25.070 --> 00:04:27.990
You can configure it right in there and
set it to hand out these addresses.

93
00:04:27.990 --> 00:04:31.130
But somewhere on your network, somebody
has to be handing out these addresses.

94
00:04:31.130 --> 00:04:32.500
It's not magic.

95
00:04:32.500 --> 00:04:34.120
Somebody has to set that device up.

96
00:04:34.120 --> 00:04:35.930
If you don't have that device
your computer's going to boot up,

97
00:04:35.930 --> 00:04:36.620
it's going to try and

98
00:04:36.620 --> 00:04:40.550
get an address and it's going to fail,
it's not going to get an address.

99
00:04:40.550 --> 00:04:44.550
And at that point it's just going
to create a placeholder address,

100
00:04:44.550 --> 00:04:46.720
one that it hopes works,
but usually doesn't.

101
00:04:46.720 --> 00:04:51.540
So we either need to have
a DHCP server helping us out or

102
00:04:51.540 --> 00:04:54.380
we need to manually specify our addresses.

103
00:04:54.380 --> 00:04:56.500
Well let's see the manual side.

104
00:04:56.500 --> 00:05:00.290
So instead of using DHCP I'm gonna
drop it down and choose Manual, okay.

105
00:05:00.290 --> 00:05:05.260
I'm gonna do a manual connection and
when I do that now I can come in and

106
00:05:05.260 --> 00:05:09.060
I can type in an address and
a Subnet Mask.

107
00:05:09.060 --> 00:05:09.700
All right.

108
00:05:09.700 --> 00:05:12.320
So if I wanna use 192.168.1.150 or
shoot what was it?

109
00:05:12.320 --> 00:05:15.310
0?
I think it's 192, 168 at 0, 150.

110
00:05:15.310 --> 00:05:17.190
I should have paid attention.

111
00:05:17.190 --> 00:05:22.510
So if I wanna use that address and
Subnet Mask, I can type those in.

112
00:05:22.510 --> 00:05:25.930
And so now I've got an address.

113
00:05:25.930 --> 00:05:28.950
Now what if somebody else is
already using that address, right?

114
00:05:28.950 --> 00:05:29.530
Somebody could be.

115
00:05:29.530 --> 00:05:30.480
You know what?

116
00:05:30.480 --> 00:05:34.200
I've actually go another machine, so
this guy, let's see what happens.

117
00:05:34.200 --> 00:05:38.560
So if I take this computer, this is
another El Capitan machine, I've got it

118
00:05:38.560 --> 00:05:43.000
set up as a server so I've turned off
the wallpaper and all that stuff.

119
00:05:43.000 --> 00:05:44.830
This one is 192.168.0.151.

120
00:05:44.830 --> 00:05:45.490
All right.

121
00:05:45.490 --> 00:05:49.080
So what if I take that same address.

122
00:05:49.080 --> 00:05:52.320
I'm gonna take the same address and
pop that right in there, okay.

123
00:05:52.320 --> 00:05:56.090
When I apply it,
my system's gonna go to use that address.

124
00:05:56.090 --> 00:05:58.380
I'm using the same address
as somebody else and so

125
00:05:58.380 --> 00:05:59.870
I get a warning you can't do that.

126
00:05:59.870 --> 00:06:02.090
You can't have two people
using the same address.

127
00:06:02.090 --> 00:06:05.990
So it's already in use, I can't use it.

128
00:06:05.990 --> 00:06:08.840
So my network adapter
is now kind of broken

129
00:06:08.840 --> 00:06:11.070
because I'm using somebody else's IP.

130
00:06:11.070 --> 00:06:12.600
But if I pick an IP that's not in use.

131
00:06:12.600 --> 00:06:14.820
Like I'll pick 152, right.

132
00:06:14.820 --> 00:06:17.340
Nobody else is using that,
I can hit apply.

133
00:06:17.340 --> 00:06:21.370
And now I'm gonna have an address and I'm
gonna be able to talk on the network and

134
00:06:21.370 --> 00:06:22.870
be happy, okay?

135
00:06:22.870 --> 00:06:26.610
So it's applied,
I've got this address and that's it.

136
00:06:26.610 --> 00:06:29.370
Well, what the address lets me do,

137
00:06:29.370 --> 00:06:34.010
is it lets me talk to anybody
else that's on the same network.

138
00:06:34.010 --> 00:06:35.884
My network is 192.168.0.

139
00:06:35.884 --> 00:06:39.231
The server is 192.168.0.

140
00:06:39.231 --> 00:06:41.008
We're on the same network, we can talk.

141
00:06:41.008 --> 00:06:42.670
I'm .152.

142
00:06:42.670 --> 00:06:43.650
The server is .151.

143
00:06:43.650 --> 00:06:45.730
We should be able to see each other.

144
00:06:46.890 --> 00:06:47.390
How do I know?

145
00:06:49.400 --> 00:06:53.180
>> You try to send information [LAUGH]
>> Hopefully the servers doing something.

146
00:06:53.180 --> 00:06:56.150
And we can do whatever that
something is to test it out.

147
00:06:56.150 --> 00:07:00.240
Maybe it's a web server, maybe it's a file
server, maybe it's who knows what, right?

148
00:07:00.240 --> 00:07:02.020
Or we can just try and Ping it.

149
00:07:02.020 --> 00:07:04.510
Ping is a neat little utility that
sends a message out on the network.

150
00:07:04.510 --> 00:07:06.790
It just says hey,
if you're out there, reply to me.

151
00:07:06.790 --> 00:07:08.220
Just let me know you're there, right?

152
00:07:08.220 --> 00:07:09.700
It's a way of saying hi.

153
00:07:09.700 --> 00:07:12.180
So we can use ping to test that out.

154
00:07:12.180 --> 00:07:14.480
And there's a few ways to do it in Mac OS.

155
00:07:14.480 --> 00:07:17.810
I normally drop to the terminal and do it
from there cuz you have a command line

156
00:07:17.810 --> 00:07:22.230
utility for ping but on the exam,
they love the GUI on the exam.

157
00:07:22.230 --> 00:07:25.750
And there is a GUI utility called
the network utility, and we can use that.

158
00:07:25.750 --> 00:07:27.040
So let me fire that up here on my Mac.

159
00:07:27.040 --> 00:07:30.280
So I'm gonna go into my
applications folder.

160
00:07:30.280 --> 00:07:34.120
And in the applications folder you
have a folder called utilities.

161
00:07:34.120 --> 00:07:40.830
And in utilities you have a utility in
here somewhere called The network utility.

162
00:07:40.830 --> 00:07:44.390
And, you know I was pretty certain that
it was in the, did it get moved off?

163
00:07:45.470 --> 00:07:48.708
Back in Mavericks, Apple decided to start
moving some of the utilities off into

164
00:07:48.708 --> 00:07:51.801
the core services folder so it's tucked
away under the system folder now and

165
00:07:51.801 --> 00:07:53.757
it looks like network
utility was one of those.

166
00:07:53.757 --> 00:07:56.273
So, the easier way to run it
is just to use Spotlight.

167
00:07:56.273 --> 00:07:59.192
So, I'm just gonna fire up my
Spotlight and I'll just type network.

168
00:07:59.192 --> 00:08:00.413
And utility there we go.

169
00:08:00.413 --> 00:08:02.771
So here's my network
utility I can fire that up.

170
00:08:02.771 --> 00:08:05.180
And let's be one of the ones that got
moved off to the core services folder.

171
00:08:06.190 --> 00:08:09.280
But when you fire up the network utility
you basically see this little screen.

172
00:08:09.280 --> 00:08:11.950
And it's a tool that has
a number of different

173
00:08:11.950 --> 00:08:14.440
things that we can use
to test our network.

174
00:08:14.440 --> 00:08:16.950
It shows our IP address,
it shows our MAC address,

175
00:08:16.950 --> 00:08:19.360
the hardware address assigned
to your network adapter.

176
00:08:19.360 --> 00:08:22.450
You see the speed of your network,
who makes your network adopt.

177
00:08:22.450 --> 00:08:26.250
You see all these details
about your system.

178
00:08:26.250 --> 00:08:28.950
And that's really useful just from
the basic troubleshooting standpoint.

179
00:08:28.950 --> 00:08:30.910
Just to see that information.

180
00:08:30.910 --> 00:08:33.350
But I wanna ping and
you'll see right up here.

181
00:08:33.350 --> 00:08:36.450
I've got a nice Ping button and

182
00:08:36.450 --> 00:08:40.590
