I'm having trouble getting
to our internet site.

638
00:30:43.410 --> 00:30:46.420
How often is it something like
DNS that's causing the issue?

639
00:30:46.420 --> 00:30:47.600
>> It can be pretty common,

640
00:30:47.600 --> 00:30:51.460
except the thing with DNS is if you've got
it wrong, usually everything's broken.

641
00:30:51.460 --> 00:30:53.460
It's not like some things work and
some things don't.

642
00:30:53.460 --> 00:30:56.710
If you got it wrong, everything's broken,
so it's usually easy to spot.

643
00:30:56.710 --> 00:30:59.970
DNS servers you don't change them very
often, you normally set it and forget it.

644
00:30:59.970 --> 00:31:02.776
So sometimes your DNS servers change and
then you gotta remember to go and

645
00:31:02.776 --> 00:31:03.940
update your clients.

646
00:31:03.940 --> 00:31:05.610
If you're using DHCP,
you don't have to worry about it.

647
00:31:05.610 --> 00:31:09.770
>> So would just say probably DHCP
would be our bigger culprit than

648
00:31:09.770 --> 00:31:12.030
just not getting
the information to our clients.

649
00:31:12.030 --> 00:31:12.820
>> Yeah, usually.

650
00:31:12.820 --> 00:31:14.960
Yeah usually something on the server,
something can go wrong.

651
00:31:14.960 --> 00:31:17.190
You know those attacks that people
perform against the DNS servers?

652
00:31:17.190 --> 00:31:19.110
Those can all cause
things to get derailed.

653
00:31:19.110 --> 00:31:22.760
>> All right, well Don we've covered a lot
of ground again here in this episode.

654
00:31:22.760 --> 00:31:23.700
But I'm looking at the clock.

655
00:31:23.700 --> 00:31:25.400
It's starting to dwindle down, and

656
00:31:25.400 --> 00:31:28.620
we haven't even, we're basically
just talking about configuration.

657
00:31:28.620 --> 00:31:31.300
We haven't even got into
things like WiFi and all that.

658
00:31:31.300 --> 00:31:32.900
A lot of other great topics left to go.

659
00:31:32.900 --> 00:31:36.190
Anything that you'd like to add to
this episode before we close it down?

660
00:31:36.190 --> 00:31:39.200
>> One last thing worth mentioning is,
I showed you guys IPv4 addresses.

661
00:31:39.200 --> 00:31:40.450
Cuz that's what you're
gonna use in real life, and

662
00:31:40.450 --> 00:31:41.470
that's what's gonna be on the exam.

663
00:31:41.470 --> 00:31:44.610
But let me just show you
real quick IPv6 addresses.

664
00:31:44.610 --> 00:31:49.650
So, when I went into the settings here,
it's got of this IPv4 stuff to setup.

665
00:31:49.650 --> 00:31:51.820
IPv6 doesn't even show up does it?

666
00:31:51.820 --> 00:31:56.460
But if I go into advanced, inside of the
advanced screens, we get our TCP options.

667
00:31:56.460 --> 00:31:58.410
It's got configure IPv4.

668
00:31:58.410 --> 00:32:01.920
And you can see right
down here on the bottom,

669
00:32:01.920 --> 00:32:06.680
configure IPv6 automatically,
router IPv6 address and prefix length.

670
00:32:06.680 --> 00:32:10.420
IPv6 is turned on by default but it's
not in use, it doesn't have an address.

671
00:32:10.420 --> 00:32:11.880
It's trying to get one on the network but

672
00:32:11.880 --> 00:32:14.720
there's no one on our network that's
running it, so it doesn't get an address.

673
00:32:14.720 --> 00:32:17.928
If you want to manually assign IPv6
addresses, you just change that to

674
00:32:17.928 --> 00:32:21.142
manually and then you can come in here and
you can specify that address.

675
00:32:21.142 --> 00:32:24.550
And in IPv6 you have,
I clicked in the wrong spot.

676
00:32:24.550 --> 00:32:26.050
You have a router, just like in IPv4.

677
00:32:26.050 --> 00:32:27.590
You have an address, and

678
00:32:27.590 --> 00:32:30.390
you have a prefix link,
which is the equivalent of a subnet mask.

679
00:32:30.390 --> 00:32:32.090
So you can plug that data right in there.

680
00:32:32.090 --> 00:32:34.010
So IPv6 is done right along IPv4.

681
00:32:34.010 --> 00:32:36.540
It's just in the advanced screen, right?

682
00:32:36.540 --> 00:32:38.790
So you get to this screen here,
you got to go into advanced.

683
00:32:38.790 --> 00:32:40.540
And that's where IPV6 is tucked away.

684
00:32:40.540 --> 00:32:41.180
>> Awesome.
Well,

685
00:32:41.180 --> 00:32:44.426
we know this was going to be
a multi-part series here.

686
00:32:44.426 --> 00:32:47.210
>> [LAUGH]
>> Networking is not a small topic.

687
00:32:47.210 --> 00:32:51.340
So it's gonna take us at least one
more episode to get through all

688
00:32:51.340 --> 00:32:55.420
the myriad of different elements that
they want you to know for their exam.

689
00:32:55.420 --> 00:32:58.700
And the good thing is it's gonna help you
out in your day to day life as you support

690
00:32:58.700 --> 00:33:00.750
computers on a network system.

691
00:33:00.750 --> 00:33:02.670
So, Don, thanks for dropping by.

692
00:33:02.670 --> 00:33:06.150
Thanks for explaining how the heck
we actually get this information

693
00:33:06.150 --> 00:33:07.950
into our client's systems.

694
00:33:07.950 --> 00:33:08.830
And I look forward to seeing what

695
00:33:08.830 --> 00:33:11.360
else you got up your sleeve
in the upcoming episode.

696
00:33:11.360 --> 00:33:12.520
Thank you guys for watching.

697
00:33:12.520 --> 00:33:13.580
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

698
00:33:13.580 --> 00:33:16.280
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

699
00:33:16.280 --> 00:33:17.010
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

700
00:33:17.010 --> 00:33:17.566
>> We'll see you next time.

701
00:33:17.566 --> 00:33:26.320
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don describes the various network settings involved in configuring a Mac to communicate on a wireless network. He begins by discussing authentication and then moves on to common settings and basic troubleshooting.
episodes.title: Network Configuration Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.427 --> 00:00:15.232
All right good morning,
good afternoon and good evening and

3
00:00:15.232 --> 00:00:17.325
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.325 --> 00:00:18.088
I'm your host,

5
00:00:18.088 --> 00:00:22.121
Don Pezet, back again with another episode
of Apple Certified Support Professional.

6
00:00:22.121 --> 00:00:24.930
And as you might have noticed
I'm kind of all by myself today.

7
00:00:24.930 --> 00:00:26.290
Daniel had to get pulled aside for

8
00:00:26.290 --> 00:00:30.280
another show but that's okay cuz today
we're taking a look at networking.

9
00:00:30.280 --> 00:00:33.460
And networking is all about getting
computers to talk together so

10
00:00:33.460 --> 00:00:34.510
you're never by yourself, right?

11
00:00:34.510 --> 00:00:37.150
There's always somebody else out
there on the network you can talk to.

12
00:00:37.150 --> 00:00:41.020
Well unless things are broken, in which
case we have to figure that out too.

13
00:00:41.020 --> 00:00:44.150
So in this episode though we're gonna
focus back on network configuration.

14
00:00:44.150 --> 00:00:47.180
And I know this is part three,
we've already spent some time doing this.

15
00:00:47.180 --> 00:00:50.520
In part one we learned about IP addresses,
IPv4 and IPv6.

16
00:00:50.520 --> 00:00:53.710
We talked about how network
communications worked.

17
00:00:53.710 --> 00:00:55.240
And in part two we got a set up, right?

18
00:00:55.240 --> 00:00:58.330
We configured IP addresses and
our router and DNS and

19
00:00:58.330 --> 00:01:00.020
we got that configured on a system.

20
00:01:00.020 --> 00:01:03.240
But the whole time,
I was working with a wired connection.

21
00:01:03.240 --> 00:01:04.920
It was my Thunderbolt connection here.

22
00:01:04.920 --> 00:01:08.040
And in this episode, I kind of wanna
change gears a little bit, and

23
00:01:08.040 --> 00:01:10.860
look at that same process,
but for a wireless adapter.

24
00:01:10.860 --> 00:01:12.550
Wireless adapters are different, right?

25
00:01:12.550 --> 00:01:15.770
They're different than Ethernet,
because with Ethernet, you just plug,

26
00:01:15.770 --> 00:01:17.310
you know I should say Ethernet, right?

27
00:01:17.310 --> 00:01:20.330
Because wireless uses Ethernet too,
it's just using it differently.

28
00:01:20.330 --> 00:01:24.860
So a wired connection,
just a regular copper based Ethernet jack.

29
00:01:24.860 --> 00:01:27.820
When you plug that thing in the link
goes hot and you're ready to talk.

30
00:01:28.820 --> 00:01:31.340
On wireless though, it's not like that.

31
00:01:31.340 --> 00:01:34.600
On wireless you've got an antennae and
that antennae is looking at radio

32
00:01:34.600 --> 00:01:37.350
frequency waves that are floating
about there in the air and

33
00:01:37.350 --> 00:01:39.070
we have to tell it which
network to connect to.

34
00:01:39.070 --> 00:01:43.090
And when we tell it to connect, there may
be encryption and authentication enabled.

35
00:01:43.090 --> 00:01:46.070
Extra steps we have to go
through to get connected.

36
00:01:46.070 --> 00:01:50.650
We don't normally see that on the copper
based, the physical Ethernet connections.

37
00:01:50.650 --> 00:01:51.720
You don't normally see it.

38
00:01:51.720 --> 00:01:54.450
You can, right,
let me show you an example.

39
00:01:54.450 --> 00:01:57.750
So if I take this work station,
so this is a virtual machine,

40
00:01:57.750 --> 00:02:00.730
and the virtual machine only
has a physical adapter in it.

41
00:02:00.730 --> 00:02:02.840
It doesn't have wireless at all.

42
00:02:02.840 --> 00:02:05.660
So when I go into its
system preferences and

43
00:02:05.660 --> 00:02:09.800
I go into Networking, I'm gonna see
a physical Ethernet connection.

44
00:02:09.800 --> 00:02:11.920
So right there, Ethernet connected.

45
00:02:11.920 --> 00:02:14.790
And when we go into its settings,
well that's where you can come in here and

46
00:02:14.790 --> 00:02:16.260
say, I'll do this manually.

47
00:02:16.260 --> 00:02:18.130
I'll specify IP addresses and so on.

48
00:02:18.130 --> 00:02:20.740
That's what we expect to
see on a normal connection.

49
00:02:22.220 --> 00:02:25.203
It may be that you've got a DSL modem and

50
00:02:25.203 --> 00:02:30.370
you're plugging this Ethernet jack
directly into your DSL modem.

51
00:02:30.370 --> 00:02:33.860
Now I'll be honest with you guys,
very, very few people do that.

52
00:02:33.860 --> 00:02:35.530
You almost always have
a router these days, and

53
00:02:35.530 --> 00:02:37.550
the router's what the DSL
modem plugs into.

54
00:02:37.550 --> 00:02:42.170
But if you plug your computer directly
into it, most DSL connections

55
00:02:42.170 --> 00:02:44.750
require you to authenticate,
to have a username and password.

56
00:02:44.750 --> 00:02:47.610
And physical jacks don't normally ask for
that.

57
00:02:47.610 --> 00:02:49.880
Wireless does, not wired.

58
00:02:49.880 --> 00:02:53.700
Well, on the wired side there
are actually two exceptions to that rule.

59
00:02:53.700 --> 00:02:58.920
And one is PPPoE, or
point to point protocol over Ethernet.

60
00:02:58.920 --> 00:03:01.280
And DSL uses this a lot.

61
00:03:01.280 --> 00:03:02.926
So if you plug into DSL
modem you'll likely have

62
00:03:02.926 --> 00:03:04.580
to pass that username and password.

63
00:03:04.580 --> 00:03:06.320
It doesn't give me that option here.

64
00:03:06.320 --> 00:03:09.880
Well under configure IPv4,
when I drop that down,

65
00:03:09.880 --> 00:03:14.120
you'll see Create a PPPoE Service.

66
00:03:14.120 --> 00:03:18.810
I can create a virtual adapter
that's tied to this real adapter

67
00:03:18.810 --> 00:03:20.850
that can provide a username and
a password.

68
00:03:20.850 --> 00:03:24.980
So that's one way that I can do
authentication on a physical connection.

69
00:03:24.980 --> 00:03:27.540
If I go into Advanced,
I'll see the other way.

70
00:03:27.540 --> 00:03:29.758
Oops, let me put back DHCP.

71
00:03:29.758 --> 00:03:31.360
All righty, it got happy with it.

72
00:03:31.360 --> 00:03:33.430
Back here in my physical settings.

73
00:03:33.430 --> 00:03:36.720
If you look at the options up top,
when we talked TCP/IP,

74
00:03:36.720 --> 00:03:39.490
we talked about DNS,
we didn't talk about WINS, right?

75
00:03:39.490 --> 00:03:43.740
That's the old Windows naming solution,
and Microsoft doesn't even use it anymore,

76
00:03:43.740 --> 00:03:45.610
so we rarely use that one.

77
00:03:45.610 --> 00:03:47.910
And then, there's 802.1X, okay.

78
00:03:47.910 --> 00:03:50.680
What is 802.1X?

79
00:03:50.680 --> 00:03:55.378
Well it's a standard that's designed
to provide authentication on

80
00:03:55.378 --> 00:03:57.165
a physical network jack.

81
00:03:57.165 --> 00:04:01.990
And 802.1X is part of what provides
authentication on wireless networks also.

82
00:04:01.990 --> 00:04:05.940
A lot of people think that it was created
for wireless and it's true, it is used for

83
00:04:05.940 --> 00:04:07.450
wireless a lot.

84
00:04:07.450 --> 00:04:10.070
But it was actually created for
wired networks first and

85
00:04:10.070 --> 00:04:12.550
then it was moved over
to the wireless world.

86
00:04:12.550 --> 00:04:16.760
So when you plug into that physical jack,
you don't necessarily just get allowed to

87
00:04:16.760 --> 00:04:18.720
talk and you're on the network and
that's it.

88
00:04:18.720 --> 00:04:21.930
Because what if you,
let's say you work for a hospital.

89
00:04:21.930 --> 00:04:23.430
You've got a massive building, right,

90
00:04:23.430 --> 00:04:25.660
thousands of rooms spread
out through this building.

91
00:04:25.660 --> 00:04:28.710
And every room has at least
one network jack in it for

92
00:04:28.710 --> 00:04:31.670
all the computer equipment
the hospitals use.

93
00:04:31.670 --> 00:04:37.130
Well whats to stop a hacker from checking
into the hospital, getting into a room,

94
00:04:37.130 --> 00:04:40.480
unplugging the medical equipment, and
just plugging in their laptop in?

95
00:04:40.480 --> 00:04:42.510
And now they're on your network.

96
00:04:42.510 --> 00:04:45.680
That's a very real risk, and
you can't monitor for that physically.

97
00:04:45.680 --> 00:04:47.670
You can't be watching every single room.

98
00:04:47.670 --> 00:04:49.560
Especially with sensitive patient data.

99
00:04:49.560 --> 00:04:50.940
It's not gonna happen.

100
00:04:50.940 --> 00:04:53.133
So it's very hard to look after that.

101
00:04:53.133 --> 00:04:55.197
So 802.1x looks to solve that.

102
00:04:55.197 --> 00:05:00.710
What 802.1x has is if you plug in to this
jack, you've gotta show me a certificate.

103
00:05:00.710 --> 00:05:03.980
You've gotta show me some kind of
authentication that proves you are who you

104
00:05:03.980 --> 00:05:05.140
say you are.

105
00:05:05.140 --> 00:05:07.800
And then I'll determine whether
you're allowed on the network.

106
00:05:07.800 --> 00:05:09.560
And if you're allowed, yeah, you can talk.

107
00:05:09.560 --> 00:05:10.520
It works great.

108
00:05:10.520 --> 00:05:11.600
But if you're not allowed?

109
00:05:11.600 --> 00:05:14.379
The port just sets they're dead and
your all traffic gets dropped.

110
00:05:14.379 --> 00:05:18.703
That's 802.1x and we've got support for
that right here in Mac OS.

111
00:05:18.703 --> 00:05:19.555
So, PPPoE and

112
00:05:19.555 --> 00:05:25.400
802.1x are two ways that we can provide
authentication on physical network jack.

113
00:05:25.400 --> 00:05:27.458
The other tabs in here
are things like proxies.

114
00:05:27.458 --> 00:05:32.740
Proxies are where I'm not allowed to
go out to the Internet for example.

115
00:05:32.740 --> 00:05:34.960
But I'm allowed to talk
to a proxy server and

116
00:05:34.960 --> 00:05:37.630
the proxy server can go out
to the Internet on my behalf.

117
00:05:37.630 --> 00:05:39.370
It can reach out there for me.

118
00:05:39.370 --> 00:05:42.380
This is neat because all
the computers in your

119
00:05:42.380 --> 00:05:44.350
organization don't need Internet access.

120
00:05:44.350 --> 00:05:47.250
Only one computer needs Internet access
the you have full control of it,

121
00:05:47.250 --> 00:05:48.340
that proxy.

122
00:05:48.340 --> 00:05:51.230
You can dictate what websites
are allowed to go to the what

123
00:05:51.230 --> 00:05:52.620
websites you not allowed to go to.

124
00:05:52.620 --> 00:05:54.990
You can really control that stuff.

125
00:05:54.990 --> 00:05:56.120
And you can require usernames and

126
00:05:56.120 --> 00:05:57.710
passwords to be able to
get out on the Internet.

127
00:05:57.710 --> 00:06:00.990
Now technically you're already
talking on the network.

128
00:06:00.990 --> 00:06:04.320
It would just be a username and
password for passing through the proxy.

129
00:06:04.320 --> 00:06:09.510
So it's not the same level of
security as 802.1x and PPPoE.

130
00:06:09.510 --> 00:06:11.680
And our last tab here is hardware.

131
00:06:11.680 --> 00:06:13.150
There's not much that
will ever configure here.

132
00:06:13.150 --> 00:06:17.320
This is where you can hard set your
speeds and your duplex and your MTUs.

133
00:06:17.320 --> 00:06:19.480
Speed, that's just how fast you talk.

134
00:06:19.480 --> 00:06:23.060
And most Macs these days have
a gigabit adapter in them so

135
00:06:23.060 --> 00:06:28.220
you'll see 1000baseT so we're gonna
communicate at 1000 megabits per second.

136
00:06:28.220 --> 00:06:31.250
You might have a 100 megabit connection or
a 10 megabit connection so

137
00:06:31.250 --> 00:06:33.440
you'll see each of those
are listed in here.

138
00:06:33.440 --> 00:06:37.810
Auto is the default, which means it'll
just figure out what your connection is.

139
00:06:37.810 --> 00:06:42.840
Now if you're a 10 or 100, you can be
in full duplex or half duplex mode.

140
00:06:42.840 --> 00:06:47.180
Full duplex means you can send and
receive data at the same time.

141
00:06:47.180 --> 00:06:52.120
Half duplex means you can only send or
receive, you can only do one at a time.

142
00:06:52.120 --> 00:06:53.870
So if I have a 100 megabit connection, and

143
00:06:53.870 --> 00:06:56.980
I'm a half duplex,
I can only move 100 megs of data.

144
00:06:56.980 --> 00:07:00.150
But if I'm in a 100 megabit and
I'm full duplex,

145
00:07:00.150 --> 00:07:04.200
I could be sending 100 megabits of data
while i'm receiving 100 megabits of data.

146
00:07:04.200 --> 00:07:08.250
It's actually 200 megabits of data so you
can get a lot more bandwidth out of that.

147
00:07:08.250 --> 00:07:12.520
When you're on a gigabit connection,
gigabit only does full duplex so

148
00:07:12.520 --> 00:07:14.820
I lose that option to choose half duplex.

149
00:07:14.820 --> 00:07:19.160
If I leave it on auto, it will
automatically figure out what's supported.

150
00:07:19.160 --> 00:07:21.560
And then MTU is the maximum
transmission unit.

151
00:07:21.560 --> 00:07:26.545
When you send data on the network,
if it's under 1,500 bytes, or I'm sorry,

152
00:07:26.545 --> 00:07:31.256
1,500 k, if it's under 1,500 k,
no actually I was right, 1,500 bytes.

153
00:07:31.256 --> 00:07:32.960
[LAUGH] I had straight in my head.

154
00:07:32.960 --> 00:07:38.840
If it's under 1,500 bytes, it'll send it
in one packet, one segment on the network.

155
00:07:38.840 --> 00:07:39.990
If it's bigger than that,

156
00:07:39.990 --> 00:07:43.760
it breaks it up into multiple packets to
send it in pieces across the network.

157
00:07:43.760 --> 00:07:45.410
And so this is the size.

158
00:07:45.410 --> 00:07:47.110
Most systems, Linux, Windows,

159
00:07:47.110 --> 00:07:50.360
Mac, they pretty much all default
to 1500 bytes these days.

160
00:07:50.360 --> 00:07:51.260
You can tweak that.

161
00:07:51.260 --> 00:07:56.488
You can come in and change it and set it
to other values, but the default is 1500.

162
00:07:56.488 --> 00:07:58.737
All right now,
I know what you're thinking.

163
00:07:58.737 --> 00:08:01.443
I said we are going to talk about
wireless and this is all wired stuff.

So those are all different things that
we need to be aware of with wireless.

626
00:28:23.220 --> 00:28:26.950
Last thing I wanna mention is that if
you're having problems with wireless,

627
00:28:26.950 --> 00:28:30.270
the number one problem with
wireless is signal strength.

628
00:28:30.270 --> 00:28:34.630
That your access point might
be right next to you, but

629
00:28:34.630 --> 00:28:37.005
there's things that can
cause Interference.

630
00:28:37.005 --> 00:28:39.465
So a lot of modern access points
running more than one frequency.

631
00:28:39.465 --> 00:28:42.795
A lot of them run at 2.4 gigahertz and
some of them run 5 gigahertz but

632
00:28:42.795 --> 00:28:44.385
most of them run at both.

633
00:28:44.385 --> 00:28:48.625
And so your access point will reflect
that and we've got it's an Apple airport.

634
00:28:48.625 --> 00:28:53.525
It is literally if I can walk straight to
it it's about 15 feet away from here so

635
00:28:53.525 --> 00:28:55.720
it is not far away at all.

636
00:28:55.720 --> 00:28:58.870
But I've got the studio wall
right here about six feet away,

637
00:28:58.870 --> 00:29:02.320
and then there's a four foot hallway,
and then there's another wall.

638
00:29:02.320 --> 00:29:04.090
And on the other side of that
wall is the access point is.

639
00:29:04.090 --> 00:29:07.220
So there are two walls in between me and
that access point.

640
00:29:07.220 --> 00:29:10.700
At only 15 feet away,
I take signal degradation.

641
00:29:10.700 --> 00:29:14.330
Let me show you,
I've got a little program called NetSpot.

642
00:29:14.330 --> 00:29:18.930
In Mac OS you get these
little status bars here.

643
00:29:18.930 --> 00:29:20.690
And see how it shows me with four bars?

644
00:29:20.690 --> 00:29:23.480
I've got the strongest signal possible,
right?

645
00:29:23.480 --> 00:29:27.580
But if I go into NetSpot I can see that
my signal actually isn't that strong.

646
00:29:27.580 --> 00:29:29.830
So the network that I'm connected
to is this one right here.

647
00:29:29.830 --> 00:29:30.750
It's in bold.

648
00:29:30.750 --> 00:29:32.520
So this is the ITProTV
network I'm connected to.

649
00:29:32.520 --> 00:29:35.270
And see how there's four ITProTV networks?

650
00:29:35.270 --> 00:29:36.670
Why are there four?

651
00:29:36.670 --> 00:29:41.240
Well, we have two airports,
one at each end of the studio.

652
00:29:41.240 --> 00:29:46.043
And each airport is running at 2.4 GHz and
5 GHz.

653
00:29:46.043 --> 00:29:49.597
They're running at both frequencies and
because they're doing that I can connect

654
00:29:49.597 --> 00:29:52.095
on either frequency which
ever one is stronger.

655
00:29:52.095 --> 00:29:55.540
2.4 GHz gets longer range but
slower speeds.

656
00:29:55.540 --> 00:29:58.960
5 GHz has a shorter range but
higher speeds.

657
00:29:58.960 --> 00:30:02.020
So hopefully I'm connected 5 GHz but
I might not be.

658
00:30:02.020 --> 00:30:04.820
And so
when I scroll over here I'll see I am.

659
00:30:04.820 --> 00:30:06.130
I'm connected to the 5 GHz one.

660
00:30:06.130 --> 00:30:09.150
And I hope so cuz the access point's
right there, it's just 15 feet away.

661
00:30:10.410 --> 00:30:12.730
But when I go and look at the strength.

662
00:30:12.730 --> 00:30:16.830
Apple is telling me I've got four bars,
I got the strongest signal possible.

663
00:30:16.830 --> 00:30:20.550
But you can see right here my
signal strength is only about

664
00:30:20.550 --> 00:30:22.490
half is good as it should be.

665
00:30:22.490 --> 00:30:25.980
If I were standing right next to that
access point with no interruptions

666
00:30:25.980 --> 00:30:28.390
this green bar would be
all the way over here.

667
00:30:28.390 --> 00:30:31.270
But instead I'm right on the cusp
where it's turning orange and

668
00:30:31.270 --> 00:30:34.040
green because I have two
walls in between me.

669
00:30:34.040 --> 00:30:36.520
So walls really impact wireless.

670
00:30:36.520 --> 00:30:40.000
And that's why a lot of us
prefer the wired connection.

671
00:30:40.000 --> 00:30:44.460
With a wired connection you plug it in,
you got 100% signal strength all the time.

672
00:30:44.460 --> 00:30:46.090
Wireless depends on other things.

673
00:30:46.090 --> 00:30:50.070
It depends on how many obstructions
are between you and the access point.

674
00:30:50.070 --> 00:30:53.410
How many other people are on the network.

675
00:30:53.410 --> 00:30:57.620
And whether there's other wireless
devices generating interference.

676
00:30:57.620 --> 00:30:59.820
Notice when I look at this network,

677
00:30:59.820 --> 00:31:03.180
I scroll over here it shows
that channels it's running on.

678
00:31:03.180 --> 00:31:04.760
So I'm running on channel 157.

679
00:31:04.760 --> 00:31:07.220
If somebody else was on channel 157,

680
00:31:07.220 --> 00:31:11.780
they would be battling my signal,
they would weaken my signal.

681
00:31:11.780 --> 00:31:14.530
See how there's more than one
access point on channel 11?

682
00:31:14.530 --> 00:31:17.595
Those three guys are all
fighting against each other.

683
00:31:17.595 --> 00:31:21.110
They're bumping in each other and
it's weakening their signal as a result.

684
00:31:21.110 --> 00:31:24.410
So those are things that we need to
be aware of in the wireless world

685
00:31:24.410 --> 00:31:26.541
that kind of are different
than on a wired connection.

686
00:31:28.250 --> 00:31:31.520
All right, well that's a pretty good
run down of wireless network and

687
00:31:31.520 --> 00:31:32.610
the things we need to know.

688
00:31:32.610 --> 00:31:35.470
We'll talk just a here more about wireless
networking and troubleshooting but

689
00:31:35.470 --> 00:31:38.410
as far as getting us setup once
you attach the wireless network,

690
00:31:38.410 --> 00:31:40.045
it's really just like
any physical networks.

691
00:31:40.045 --> 00:31:41.390
So nothing too crazy there.

692
00:31:41.390 --> 00:31:42.630
All the other settings are present.

693
00:31:42.630 --> 00:31:45.030
You can jump in, make the changes and
do what you need.

694
00:31:45.030 --> 00:31:48.620
So that's pretty much that and this is
a pretty good spot to wrap this one up.

695
00:31:48.620 --> 00:31:51.130
So in this episode we talked
about wireless networking.

696
00:31:51.130 --> 00:31:52.450
We talked about physical too.

697
00:31:52.450 --> 00:31:53.850
All the different settings
in between them and

698
00:31:53.850 --> 00:31:56.020
the concerns we have
with wireless networking.

699
00:31:56.020 --> 00:31:59.530
It's a pretty good run down of all the
things we need to know for the exam and

700
00:31:59.530 --> 00:32:01.330
stuff that you are going
to see in the real world.

701
00:32:01.330 --> 00:32:03.210
Well, I hope you guys enjoyed it.

702
00:32:03.210 --> 00:32:06.550
Stay tuned, cuz we got more Apple
Certified Support Professional coming up.

703
00:32:06.550 --> 00:32:09.530
I know, we still need to talk to about
network locations and troubleshooting, so

704
00:32:09.530 --> 00:32:11.390
we'll see those in the next part.

705
00:32:11.390 --> 00:32:12.420
Hopefully you'll be there for it.

706
00:32:12.420 --> 00:32:13.480
I hope to see you then.

707
00:32:13.480 --> 00:32:14.400
Thank you guys for watching.

708
00:32:14.400 --> 00:32:19.125
And signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet, and I'll see you next time.

709
00:32:19.125 --> 00:32:24.011
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don concludes the network configuration section of the ACSP. This episode focuses on troubleshooting methodology and tools for use when a network connection is not functioning. He demonstrates configuring network locations, VPN connections and using the Network Utility to troubleshoot networks.
episodes.title: Network Configuration Part 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.395 --> 00:00:14.961
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:14.961 --> 00:00:17.280
And welcome back to another
episode of IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:17.280 --> 00:00:20.480
I'm your host Don Pezet,
back again with another episode of

5
00:00:20.480 --> 00:00:24.500
Apple Certified Support Professional,
and once again I'm all by my lonesome.

6
00:00:24.500 --> 00:00:27.011
But that's all right, because we're still
dealing with some network configurations.

7
00:00:27.011 --> 00:00:29.360
We're gonna jump right in,
and start to work with that.

8
00:00:29.360 --> 00:00:31.900
Now this is part three,
or part four actually,

9
00:00:31.900 --> 00:00:34.380
I'm losing track myself,
of network configuration.

10
00:00:34.380 --> 00:00:38.860
And I know what you're thinking, what else
can I even talk about, it's been so much.

11
00:00:38.860 --> 00:00:40.560
And you're right, I've kinda run
out of things to talk about.

12
00:00:40.560 --> 00:00:43.570
So what we're gonna talk about
this time is troubleshooting.

13
00:00:43.570 --> 00:00:46.690
In the first three episodes, we got
a chance to see how to configure things,

14
00:00:46.690 --> 00:00:48.060
how to get them set up.

15
00:00:48.060 --> 00:00:51.170
But what about when things aren't
working the way they're supposed to?

16
00:00:51.170 --> 00:00:54.600
Well, there are a whole collection of
tools and features that are available for

17
00:00:54.600 --> 00:00:56.700
us to use to verify whether or

18
00:00:56.700 --> 00:00:58.500
not the network is functioning
the way that it's supposed to.

19
00:00:58.500 --> 00:01:02.020
So we're gonna look at that and kind of
rehash some of those tools and the stuff

20
00:01:02.020 --> 00:01:05.060
that we can use just to make sure that
things are running the way that we want.

21
00:01:05.060 --> 00:01:08.230
The thing I wanna start out with
first are network locations.

22
00:01:08.230 --> 00:01:10.780
And the reason I wanna start with
network locations is because they're

23
00:01:10.780 --> 00:01:12.170
pretty commonly misconfigured.

24
00:01:12.170 --> 00:01:14.620
In fact people usually
turn them on by accident.

25
00:01:14.620 --> 00:01:19.350
Network locations are not turned on by
default, and so when somebody accidentally

26
00:01:19.350 --> 00:01:22.810
turns them on, it can cause the network
adapters to be configured wrong.

27
00:01:22.810 --> 00:01:25.830
You plug in your computer and
it's not talking.

28
00:01:25.830 --> 00:01:28.630
And so I'm kinda gotten in this habit
where somebody brings me the computer and

29
00:01:28.630 --> 00:01:30.290
says, hey I can't talk on the network.

30
00:01:30.290 --> 00:01:32.640
The first thing I do is check to see
whether network locations are turned on.

31
00:01:32.640 --> 00:01:34.680
All right, now if you're not
familiar with network locations,

32
00:01:34.680 --> 00:01:37.570
I think we covered it
briefly in another episode,

33
00:01:37.570 --> 00:01:40.500
let's just take a quick kind of
tour of that and how that works.

34
00:01:40.500 --> 00:01:44.560
I've got a Mac set up here and
it is stock installed El Capitan,

35
00:01:44.560 --> 00:01:47.318
so I haven't really messed with it,
it's just a base install.

36
00:01:47.318 --> 00:01:50.260
And on a base install the network
location feature is turned off,

37
00:01:50.260 --> 00:01:53.080
it's not on by default and
you can spot it really easily.

38
00:01:53.080 --> 00:01:55.540
Let me show you, so
when I look at this desktop,

39
00:01:55.540 --> 00:01:59.090
if I just go to my Apple menu,
you can spot if network locations

40
00:01:59.090 --> 00:02:03.910
are turned on cuz you actually have an
Apple menu item here that says location.

41
00:02:03.910 --> 00:02:07.100
You can change your network location
right there from the Apple menu and

42
00:02:07.100 --> 00:02:11.560
if it's not there on the menu, it's not
turned on so I can immediately rule

43
00:02:11.560 --> 00:02:14.710
that out as a problem on this
laptop if it's not connecting.

44
00:02:14.710 --> 00:02:16.500
If it is turned on we'll see it, right,

45
00:02:16.500 --> 00:02:20.600
now if you don't remember network
locations, let me explain what it is.

46
00:02:20.600 --> 00:02:23.950
When you have a network adapter
like a wired network adapter,

47
00:02:23.950 --> 00:02:27.210
you might have certain settings you
want when you're at one location, and

48
00:02:27.210 --> 00:02:28.980
different settings at another location.

49
00:02:28.980 --> 00:02:34.200
So, for example, when I'm at home,
I might want a static IP address.

50
00:02:34.200 --> 00:02:37.960
But when I'm here at the office,
I might wanna use DHCP, or vice versa.

51
00:02:37.960 --> 00:02:41.450
I might want DHCP at home, and
a static IP here at the office, right?

52
00:02:41.450 --> 00:02:44.220
So I can configure network
locations to allow that.

53
00:02:44.220 --> 00:02:46.610
With a wireless network,
it happens automatically.

54
00:02:46.610 --> 00:02:49.610
The Mac remembers, when you're on this
wireless network, you want this IP.

55
00:02:49.610 --> 00:02:52.310
When you're on that wireless
network you want another one.

56
00:02:52.310 --> 00:02:53.410
But on a wired network,

57
00:02:53.410 --> 00:02:57.980
when I physically plug in, how does it
know one network apart from another?

58
00:02:57.980 --> 00:03:00.320
Well it has ways,
it has ways to figure that out but

59
00:03:00.320 --> 00:03:01.600
it's only got one configuration.

60
00:03:01.600 --> 00:03:06.640
If I jump into my System Preferences and
I go into Network and

61
00:03:06.640 --> 00:03:11.110
I choose an an Ethernet adapter,
I just have one set of configurations,

62
00:03:11.110 --> 00:03:15.770
one IP address, I can set it to DHCP or
I can set it manual, or that's it.

63
00:03:15.770 --> 00:03:17.440
Well, there's actually
another option here,

64
00:03:17.440 --> 00:03:22.200
use DHCP with the manual address,
that says use DHCP by default, but

65
00:03:22.200 --> 00:03:26.280
if you can't find a DHCP server use
this manual address, and you put one in.

66
00:03:26.280 --> 00:03:27.870
So you can do that.

67
00:03:27.870 --> 00:03:35.520
But what I want is I wanna use DHCP at
work and I wanna use a static IP at home.

68
00:03:35.520 --> 00:03:38.820
So to do that I need to define
locations and by default,

69
00:03:38.820 --> 00:03:40.650
you'll just see location, Automatic.

70
00:03:40.650 --> 00:03:43.025
Which means it works for
wireless networks and for wired networks,

71
00:03:43.025 --> 00:03:43.949
it really doesn't work.

72
00:03:43.949 --> 00:03:47.670
You can drop that down and
create locations.

73
00:03:47.670 --> 00:03:49.790
So I'm gonna create two locations.

74
00:03:49.790 --> 00:03:53.920
I'll create one location
that will be Home.

75
00:03:54.940 --> 00:03:59.390
And I'll create another
location that'll be Work.

76
00:03:59.390 --> 00:04:00.410
And I'm just naming them.

77
00:04:00.410 --> 00:04:01.640
You can name them whatever you want.

78
00:04:01.640 --> 00:04:02.900
They can be airport or

79
00:04:02.900 --> 00:04:07.080
whatever you kind of name them, and all
you can really do is duplicate or rename.

80
00:04:07.080 --> 00:04:10.430
You can't really do anything here from
location menu other than create them and

81
00:04:10.430 --> 00:04:12.180
give them a name, all right.

82
00:04:12.180 --> 00:04:16.240
But once you got that, you're gonna see
your network connections kinda reset.

83
00:04:16.240 --> 00:04:19.770
And if you have virtual connections like
VPN's and stuff, they'd all disappear.

84
00:04:19.770 --> 00:04:22.330
Don't panic, they still exist.

85
00:04:22.330 --> 00:04:25.700
They existed under the Automatic profile.

86
00:04:25.700 --> 00:04:29.400
And now when we go to Home or
Work, that's an all new profile.

87
00:04:29.400 --> 00:04:32.730
So if you want to VPN to work from home,
you'll have to define it again under Home.

88
00:04:32.730 --> 00:04:35.930
You'll have to attach it to the different
locations where you want that to

89
00:04:35.930 --> 00:04:36.770
work from.

90
00:04:37.770 --> 00:04:42.110
So now if I choose Home,
I get one group of settings.

91
00:04:42.110 --> 00:04:45.560
So maybe at home I want to use DHCP,
that's what I want.

92
00:04:45.560 --> 00:04:49.460
But when I'm at work,
I want to use a static IP.

93
00:04:49.460 --> 00:04:52.962
So I can chose Work and I can come
down here and I can say Manually.

94
00:04:52.962 --> 00:04:57.596
And I want to use 192.168.0.222 right,

95
00:04:57.596 --> 00:05:02.540
that's the IP address that I
want to use when I'm at work.

96
00:05:02.540 --> 00:05:06.100
And so I come in and
I punch in all of that information.

97
00:05:06.100 --> 00:05:09.820
And I don't stop there, right, cuz I
probably need DNS servers and things.

98
00:05:09.820 --> 00:05:15.830
So maybe I go into my manual configuration
and DNS and I'll add in some DNS servers.

99
00:05:17.190 --> 00:05:21.760
I get that one punched in and
let me just add another one.

100
00:05:21.760 --> 00:05:24.079
All right, so those are gonna be
the two DNS servers that I use.

101
00:05:25.440 --> 00:05:27.030
And so I've got those defined, all right.

102
00:05:27.030 --> 00:05:29.570
I'm gonna hit apply to
make that take effect.

103
00:05:29.570 --> 00:05:36.590
And now, when I'm at work, I'll have a
static IP address with this configuration.

104
00:05:36.590 --> 00:05:41.635
If I'm at home, I'll choose Home,
and see how it went back to DHCP.

105
00:05:41.635 --> 00:05:44.750
So it says at home use DHCP,
at work use the static IP.

106
00:05:44.750 --> 00:05:49.790
All right, now it'll try and figure out
which network I'm at based on my settings,

107
00:05:49.790 --> 00:05:53.460
but it doesn't necessarily do the greatest
job and that's where the trouble comes in.

108
00:05:53.460 --> 00:05:54.770
Is you get a user that comes in and

109
00:05:54.770 --> 00:05:56.920
they've accidentally turned
on locations like this and

110
00:05:56.920 --> 00:06:00.060
the Mac can't figure out which network
it's on and it picks the wrong one.

111
00:06:00.060 --> 00:06:03.680
And so now,
maybe I'm trying to use my work static IP

112
00:06:04.900 --> 00:06:07.770
while I'm at home and
the IPs don't match up.

113
00:06:07.770 --> 00:06:08.840
The networks aren't the same.

114
00:06:08.840 --> 00:06:12.200
The router isn't the same or
whatever, and things break, right.

115
00:06:12.200 --> 00:06:14.020
Network locations can
cause a lot of problems.

116
00:06:14.020 --> 00:06:16.760
They're very convenient as long
as people are educated to use it.

117
00:06:16.760 --> 00:06:21.010
But if they turn it on by accident,
then, you got a bit of a problem, right.

118
00:06:21.010 --> 00:06:24.720
So, once it's configured properly though,
it's kinda nice because

119
00:06:24.720 --> 00:06:28.890
all the user has to do is when they go to
work, they can hit their Apple menu and

120
00:06:28.890 --> 00:06:31.740
see my Apple menu,
I now have this location item, and

121
00:06:31.740 --> 00:06:35.930
then go to location and they can choose,
hey, I'm at work, let me choose Work.

122
00:06:35.930 --> 00:06:37.770
I'm at home, let me choose Home.

123
00:06:37.770 --> 00:06:41.620
If they choose Automatic,
it's gonna try and figure it out.

124
00:06:41.620 --> 00:06:43.720
Are you at work or at you at home?

125
00:06:43.720 --> 00:06:45.440
Let's figure it out for you.

126
00:06:45.440 --> 00:06:48.260
And then it'll use the settings
that are appropriate, and

127
00:06:48.260 --> 00:06:51.230
it may not pick the right ones, right?

128
00:06:51.230 --> 00:06:52.620
It has a hard time figuring out.

129
00:06:52.620 --> 00:06:54.888
Wireless is easy because
you can use the SSID,

130
00:06:54.888 --> 00:06:56.818
it uses the identifier of the network.

131
00:06:56.818 --> 00:06:59.572
On a wired network, it uses the IP range,

132
00:06:59.572 --> 00:07:03.530
but you could have the same IP
range at home as you do at work.

133
00:07:03.530 --> 00:07:06.080
And so then it relies on DNS suffixes.

134
00:07:06.080 --> 00:07:09.250
Well, I didn't add any
DNS suffixes to mine so

135
00:07:09.250 --> 00:07:11.650
it doesn't know to use those either.

136
00:07:11.650 --> 00:07:15.190
So in my scenario,
it doesn't have a way to tell that apart.

137
00:07:15.190 --> 00:07:15.980
So when I come in here and

00:07:15.980 --> 00:07:20.870

00:29:38.875 --> 00:29:42.031

00:29:42.031 --> 00:29:45.535

00:29:45.535 --> 00:29:48.545

00:29:48.545 --> 00:29:49.575

00:29:49.575 --> 00:29:53.180
you're, like, I wonder if they've

00:29:53.180 --> 00:29:54.166

00:29:54.166 --> 00:29:54.866
I sent them an email.

00:29:54.866 --> 00:29:57.500

00:29:57.500 --> 00:30:00.580
Well, back in the day it would take people
days to reply to emails anyway cuz you're

00:30:00.580 --> 00:30:01.408

00:30:01.408 --> 00:30:03.953
So, you had this tool called Finger.

00:30:03.953 --> 00:30:05.613
And what you can do is

00:30:05.613 --> 00:30:07.021

00:30:07.021 --> 00:30:09.056

00:30:18.500 --> 00:30:20.970

00:30:34.620 --> 00:30:36.040

00:30:39.760 --> 00:30:42.450

647
00:30:42.450 --> 00:30:45.050

648
00:30:45.050 --> 00:30:48.460
So this is kinda a dead utility but

00:30:48.460 --> 00:30:50.740

00:30:50.740 --> 00:30:52.780

651
00:30:54.340 --> 00:30:58.570

652
00:30:58.570 --> 00:31:01.060
Remember I mentioned the firewall,
and how I said if you try and

connection might fail because there might

654
00:31:03.970 --> 00:31:06.070

the destination.

655
00:31:06.070 --> 00:31:07.966
You can use a Port Scan
to figure that out.

656
00:31:07.966 --> 00:31:11.490
If you try and
connect to a host on a particular port and

657
00:31:11.490 --> 00:31:14.010
it gets blocked you'll see it right here.

658
00:31:14.010 --> 00:31:17.246
So, if I try and
connect to something, right?

659
00:31:17.246 --> 00:31:23.183
Like if I wanna do a scan of, let me think
of a device here in the building with me.

660
00:31:23.183 --> 00:31:25.200
I think I've got like a network
appliance that I can scan.

661
00:31:26.700 --> 00:31:27.830

00:31:27.830 --> 00:31:29.758
So, this is a network-attached
storage appliance that's here

00:31:29.758 --> 00:31:30.980

00:31:30.980 --> 00:31:34.160
I can scan it and test the ports.

665
00:31:34.160 --> 00:31:36.130

666
00:31:36.130 --> 00:31:38.511
If I'm trying to connect
to its web server and

667
00:31:38.511 --> 00:31:42.146
I know it's running a web server on
port 80, I could come in here and

668
00:31:42.146 --> 00:31:45.112
just test port 80 and say,
can I connect on port 80?

669
00:31:45.112 --> 00:31:48.100
And I'll run a scan, and
sure enough, I can connect.

670
00:31:48.100 --> 00:31:51.627
If I can't connect that means there's
probably a firewall blocking me.

671
00:31:51.627 --> 00:31:54.175
Or maybe I just have network
connectivity issues in general, but

672
00:31:54.175 --> 00:31:55.252
usually it's a firewall.

673
00:31:55.252 --> 00:31:56.413
Well what about SSL?

674
00:31:56.413 --> 00:31:59.876
I can switch that to 443 and I can test.

675
00:31:59.876 --> 00:32:01.435
And I can connect on 443.

676
00:32:01.435 --> 00:32:04.538
So it's a great way to test whether you
can connect on individual ports and

677
00:32:04.538 --> 00:32:06.590
to rule out a firewall being an issue.

678
00:32:06.590 --> 00:32:11.800
And you can scan ranges of ports to
see what services a device is running.

679
00:32:11.800 --> 00:32:15.290
So when I start to scan it, I can see that
network attached to ours is running FTP,

680
00:32:15.290 --> 00:32:21.300

681
00:32:21.300 --> 00:32:26.100

00:32:26.100 --> 00:32:29.830

683
00:32:29.830 --> 00:32:32.460
The port scan utility is really useful.

684
00:32:32.460 --> 00:32:35.440

685
00:32:35.440 --> 00:32:38.980

686
00:32:38.980 --> 00:32:41.730

687
00:32:41.730 --> 00:32:44.450
But for internal IPs,
you can scan your heart's content.

688
00:32:44.450 --> 00:32:46.836
And you can see some really good
information and you can test things.

689
00:32:46.836 --> 00:32:48.550
If you're going to run
it on a public network,

690
00:32:48.550 --> 00:32:50.260

00:32:50.260 --> 00:32:54.090

692
00:32:54.090 --> 00:32:54.940
So that gets blocked.

00:32:54.940 --> 00:32:56.575
But a single port is normally fine.

00:32:56.575 --> 00:33:00.255

00:33:00.255 --> 00:33:01.295

00:33:18.240 --> 00:33:20.130

00:33:29.390 --> 00:33:30.990
Apple that was me syncing with Apple.

a directly plugged in printer.

487
00:23:17.300 --> 00:23:19.650
And I can print to it, and off I go.

488
00:23:19.650 --> 00:23:20.490
We lose little things.

489
00:23:20.490 --> 00:23:22.590
Like you might have noticed on
the server how it had the right icon,

490
00:23:22.590 --> 00:23:23.780
the icon that looked like my printer.

491
00:23:23.780 --> 00:23:25.120
It's a black printer.

492
00:23:25.120 --> 00:23:27.670
But now since it's over the network
we can't really identify it that way.

493
00:23:27.670 --> 00:23:29.630
And so it just shows a generic
picture of a printer.

494
00:23:32.150 --> 00:23:33.560
All right,
some of the other sharing that we've got.

495
00:23:33.560 --> 00:23:35.230
If we dig in, that was printer sharing.

496
00:23:35.230 --> 00:23:36.700
We've got remote login.

497
00:23:36.700 --> 00:23:38.930
Now what the heck if remote login?

498
00:23:38.930 --> 00:23:42.831
Well, OS X has a very pretty
graphical user interface, right?

499
00:23:42.831 --> 00:23:46.955
We can use it, it's very simple,
everything that we need is right there in

500
00:23:46.955 --> 00:23:49.586
the GUI, but
under the hood it's running BSD.

501
00:23:49.586 --> 00:23:51.629
And BSD is a flavor of UNIX.

502
00:23:51.629 --> 00:23:54.903
And UNIX is powered by a command line.

503
00:23:54.903 --> 00:23:56.369
It is a command line environment.

504
00:23:56.369 --> 00:23:58.989
Deep down under the hood
that's what UNIX is and

505
00:23:58.989 --> 00:24:02.940
we can make it where people can
access that command line remotely.

506
00:24:02.940 --> 00:24:06.660
You can access it right here in your own
machine, I can just run the terminal and

507
00:24:06.660 --> 00:24:09.420
when I run the terminal, here I am.

508
00:24:09.420 --> 00:24:10.830
I'm in the UNIX environment.

509
00:24:10.830 --> 00:24:13.080
I can run UNIX commands.

510
00:24:13.080 --> 00:24:15.264
And I can see it.
And so, when I run uname-a,

511
00:24:15.264 --> 00:24:20.400
uname-a is UNIX command that tells us
what operating system we're running.

512
00:24:20.400 --> 00:24:23.948
And when it comes back it tells me,
not that I'm running OS X,

513
00:24:23.948 --> 00:24:26.146
it tells me that I'm running Darwin.

514
00:24:26.146 --> 00:24:27.710
What the heck is Darwin?

515
00:24:27.710 --> 00:24:32.240
Well, Darwin is the UNIX kernel,
the BSD kernel is running under the hood,

516
00:24:32.240 --> 00:24:33.650
the Darwin OS.

517
00:24:33.650 --> 00:24:36.180
So OS X is actually Darwin.

518
00:24:36.180 --> 00:24:41.420
But OS X adds all the GUI environment and
stuff on top of that so I can see it.

519
00:24:41.420 --> 00:24:44.820
I can now start to work as if
I were in a UNIX environment.

520
00:24:44.820 --> 00:24:50.140
I can issue all the UNIX commands that I
may or may not use on a regular basis,

521
00:24:50.140 --> 00:24:53.330
things like top, and
now I can view performance, and so on.

522
00:24:53.330 --> 00:24:54.470
It's for UNIX.

523
00:24:54.470 --> 00:24:59.050
Well, if I wanna remotely manage
a system using UNIX technologies,

524
00:24:59.050 --> 00:25:00.810
that's what remote login does.

525
00:25:00.810 --> 00:25:02.650
So when we go to turn on
this sharing option for

526
00:25:02.650 --> 00:25:06.040
remote login,
it's going to enable people to use SSH,

527
00:25:06.040 --> 00:25:10.080
the Secure Shell protocol to get
an encrypted terminal on my system.

528
00:25:10.080 --> 00:25:14.840
Or to use SFTP, the Secure File Transfer
Protocol, so I can copy files back and

529
00:25:14.840 --> 00:25:16.940
forth encrypted.

530
00:25:16.940 --> 00:25:20.170
When you turn on file sharing,
file sharing, I know I talked about it in

531
00:25:20.170 --> 00:25:25.140
the other episode but just to recap it,
it uses AFP, the Apple File Protocol,

532
00:25:25.140 --> 00:25:28.910
or SMB, Server Message Block which is
a part of Microsoft's technologies.

533
00:25:28.910 --> 00:25:31.090
So it uses those two protocols.

534
00:25:31.090 --> 00:25:34.500
It also has support for NFS, the Network
File System, that's the UNIX file sharing.

535
00:25:34.500 --> 00:25:36.750
But those are the three
main ones by default.

536
00:25:36.750 --> 00:25:41.380
But FTP, File Transfer Protocol,
that's one that works everywhere.

537
00:25:41.380 --> 00:25:42.320
But it's not encrypted.

538
00:25:42.320 --> 00:25:44.990
It's weak, and so
that's why it's not a default option.

539
00:25:44.990 --> 00:25:48.020
But when I turn on remote login,
it turns on SFTP.

540
00:25:48.020 --> 00:25:50.418
That's file transfer protocol over SSH.

541
00:25:50.418 --> 00:25:52.100
It's encrypted and it's secure.

542
00:25:52.100 --> 00:25:54.240
It's a very reliable
way to transfer files.

543
00:25:54.240 --> 00:25:56.470
Our regular end user is
never going to need it.

544
00:25:56.470 --> 00:26:00.690
But if you're administering a thousand
Macs and you wanted to put an application

545
00:26:00.690 --> 00:26:04.790
on a thousand Macs, you can write a script
that creates a secure encrypted tunnel

546
00:26:04.790 --> 00:26:07.610
to every one of them and drops
an application in the application folder.

547
00:26:07.610 --> 00:26:09.100
And you can have it set permissions,
do other things.

548
00:26:09.100 --> 00:26:10.770
You can really do some cool stuff.

549
00:26:10.770 --> 00:26:13.130
If you're using Apple remote desktop,

550
00:26:13.130 --> 00:26:16.070
Apple Remote Desktop can connect to
run UNIX commands on these systems,

551
00:26:16.070 --> 00:26:19.170
it needs this permission to
be able to connect and run.

552
00:26:19.170 --> 00:26:20.390
So I'm gonna turn that on.

553
00:26:20.390 --> 00:26:22.098
I'm gonna turn on remote login.

554
00:26:22.098 --> 00:26:24.400
And when I turn it on,
I can specify who's allowed to use it.

555
00:26:24.400 --> 00:26:27.328
The default is only administrators,
you probably wanna leave it that way.

556
00:26:27.328 --> 00:26:31.378
You probably don't want your regular
users reaching out and connecting to it.

557
00:26:31.378 --> 00:26:33.120
And then,
it's telling me here how I can connect.

558
00:26:33.120 --> 00:26:36.240
If I wanna connect,
here's the command that I need to run.

559
00:26:36.240 --> 00:26:39.780
SSH, followed by my username, @,

560
00:26:39.780 --> 00:26:42.940
followed by the IP address of
the station I'm connecting to.

561
00:26:42.940 --> 00:26:47.510
So if I jump over to my server, and

562
00:26:47.510 --> 00:26:53.560
drop to a terminal, in the terminal,
I'm normally connected to my own machine.

563
00:26:53.560 --> 00:26:55.660
So on this server,
when I drop to a terminal,

564
00:26:55.660 --> 00:26:59.080
see how it says OSX-SERVER01,
I'm on this machine.

565
00:26:59.080 --> 00:27:03.475
And if I run the hostname command,
I'm on OSX-SERVER01.local.

566
00:27:03.475 --> 00:27:06.235
But if I run ssh dpezet@192.168.0.150,

567
00:27:06.235 --> 00:27:11.945
I'm gonna open up a secure
shell to that other machine.

568
00:27:11.945 --> 00:27:14.585
And it's gonna send me a certificate
that I can use to encrypt data.

569
00:27:14.585 --> 00:27:17.205
And I'm gonna say that I trust it,
so I'll say yes.

570
00:27:17.205 --> 00:27:19.635
And now it's asking for my password.

571
00:27:19.635 --> 00:27:22.660
So I'll punch in my password,
the password for dpezet.

572
00:27:22.660 --> 00:27:26.520
Now, I'm connected to OSX-CLIENT01 and

573
00:27:26.520 --> 00:27:30.040
when I run commands there actually
running on the other machine

574
00:27:30.040 --> 00:27:32.520
that are running on this machine they
are running on the other machine.

575
00:27:32.520 --> 00:27:36.800
I know have the secure shallow connection
open and start to execute programs and

576
00:27:36.800 --> 00:27:38.620
scripts and things like that.

577
00:27:38.620 --> 00:27:40.420
Now, this is a security vulnerability.

578
00:27:40.420 --> 00:27:42.790
If somebody gets my password,
they can remotely connect and

579
00:27:42.790 --> 00:27:43.450
start to mess with it.

580
00:27:43.450 --> 00:27:46.160
So I've gotta be careful with that,
and you can leverage firewalls and

581
00:27:46.160 --> 00:27:48.490
things to protect you and
ensure that doesn't happen.

582
00:27:48.490 --> 00:27:51.450
But the best security here is to make
sure you keep your password safe.

583
00:27:51.450 --> 00:27:52.960
And that you don't let those get out.

584
00:27:52.960 --> 00:27:54.520
So this is off by default.

585
00:27:54.520 --> 00:27:56.500
You can turn it on, and
now you can remotely connect.

586
00:27:56.500 --> 00:27:58.084
We do it with some of our Mac Minis here,

587
00:27:58.084 --> 00:28:00.788
our studio Mac Minis cuz we have
scripts that run remotely on them.

588
00:28:00.788 --> 00:28:02.228
And we turn this functionality on.

589
00:28:05.098 --> 00:28:07.670
The next one in line is Remote Management.

590
00:28:07.670 --> 00:28:10.860
Now, I mentioned Apple Remote Desktop
just a second ago.

591
00:28:10.860 --> 00:28:14.390
Apple Remote Desktop is a pretty,
sweet utility that's set centrally on your

592
00:28:14.390 --> 00:28:17.760
network and let's you remotely
connect out and manage systems.

593
00:28:17.760 --> 00:28:22.490
And it uses remote login, but
it also uses Remote Management.

594
00:28:22.490 --> 00:28:24.900
This piece,
if I wanna use Apple Remote Desktop,

595
00:28:24.900 --> 00:28:27.140
I've gotta have this one turned on.

596
00:28:27.140 --> 00:28:30.360
Now, I wanna show you guys Apple Remote
Desktop and give you kind of a view

597
00:28:30.360 --> 00:28:33.150
of how it works as a really neat
utility if you've never seen it.

598
00:28:33.150 --> 00:28:36.010
And it leverages a lot of the other
things that we've seen here.

599
00:28:36.010 --> 00:28:37.520
But I'm looking at the clock there.

600
00:28:37.520 --> 00:28:38.650
I know I'm running short of time.

601
00:28:38.650 --> 00:28:41.550
So I don't think I can do it justice
in the two minutes that I have left.

602
00:28:41.550 --> 00:28:45.080
So let's set that one aside and
we'll tackle that in part two.

603
00:28:45.080 --> 00:28:46.950
We will come back and visit that one.

604
00:28:46.950 --> 00:28:49.520
The last two are pretty easy though so
let me cover this last two and

605
00:28:49.520 --> 00:28:51.980
we will catch Apple Remote Desktop
in the next one.

606
00:28:51.980 --> 00:28:55.940
So I've got Remote Apple Events,
what the heck is that one?

607
00:28:55.940 --> 00:28:57.572
Well, if you use the automator,

608
00:28:57.572 --> 00:29:01.366
in the automator you can create various
automation activities that are Apple

609
00:29:01.366 --> 00:29:04.128
events that you can cause to
execute on other machines.

610
00:29:04.128 --> 00:29:07.894
So very similar to Remote Login where have
shallows that can run like scripts, here,

611
00:29:07.894 --> 00:29:10.440
I can do with automator or
other Apple Software.

612
00:29:10.440 --> 00:29:13.510
So if I wanna allow Remote Apple Events,
I can turn this on.

613
00:29:13.510 --> 00:29:18.300
And now, other OS X computers will be able
to send Apple Events to this machine.

614
00:29:18.300 --> 00:29:20.370
We can actually get logging
to go this way too,

615
00:29:20.370 --> 00:29:22.760
if you've got like
a centralized console screen.

616
00:29:22.760 --> 00:29:26.390
You can get a lot of different things to
push over this, it's kind of up to you.

617
00:29:26.390 --> 00:29:28.038
You just have to turn that on.

618
00:29:28.038 --> 00:29:30.469
And the last one was probably
the least used of all of these and

619
00:29:30.469 --> 00:29:32.440
that's Internet Sharing.

620
00:29:32.440 --> 00:29:36.460
Back in the day, an Internet connection
was not a terribly common thing.

621
00:29:36.460 --> 00:29:38.810
And when you had it, it was usually
a modem in one computer, and

622
00:29:38.810 --> 00:29:40.660
it would dial up and connect.

623
00:29:40.660 --> 00:29:42.920
Well, if I had five computers and
I wanted all of them to get out,

624
00:29:42.920 --> 00:29:45.630
I didn't wanna get five modems and
five phone lines.

625
00:29:45.630 --> 00:29:47.450
So you could have one
computer dial out and

626
00:29:47.450 --> 00:29:50.400
it could share its connection with
the other computers on the network.

627
00:29:50.400 --> 00:29:53.820
On today's world, you normally get like a
wireless router, a wireless access point,

628
00:29:53.820 --> 00:29:58.410
an Apple AirPort, something like that,
and it does the Internet sharing for you.

629
00:29:58.410 --> 00:30:02.040
But there are some scenarios
where you might still want it.

630
00:30:02.040 --> 00:30:03.920
You can turn that on in OS X.

631
00:30:03.920 --> 00:30:06.660
And you can say,
I've got an Internet connection,

632
00:30:06.660 --> 00:30:08.400
I wanna share it with the other
people on my network.

633
00:30:08.400 --> 00:30:11.280
And we just turn it on right here
by turning on Internet Sharing.

634
00:30:11.280 --> 00:30:14.630
Now, it only works if
you have two adapters.

635
00:30:14.630 --> 00:30:17.620
I've only got one adapter so
I can't really turn it on.

636
00:30:17.620 --> 00:30:21.780
I'm telling you here which connection
of mine is my Internet connection.

637
00:30:21.780 --> 00:30:24.198
Well, I've only got an Ethernet jack and
that's it.

638
00:30:24.198 --> 00:30:28.326
And then, which connection are my
computers on and I would specify that.

639
00:30:28.326 --> 00:30:31.584
Let me show you on my actual laptop.

640
00:30:31.584 --> 00:30:32.959
So if I go into my sharing,

641
00:30:32.959 --> 00:30:35.969
because I do have multiple
network adapters on this one.

642
00:30:35.969 --> 00:30:39.520
So if I go into my Sharing, and
I go under Internet Sharing,

643
00:30:39.520 --> 00:30:42.990
you'll see over here where I can say
who's my Internet connection and

644
00:30:42.990 --> 00:30:44.540
how do I wanna share it with people.

645
00:30:44.540 --> 00:30:45.990
And look at some of the options.

646
00:30:45.990 --> 00:30:49.380
I can say that my Internet connection
is on my Thunderbolt Ethernet or

647
00:30:49.380 --> 00:30:52.720
it's on my Wi-Fi or
on one of these other connections and

648
00:30:52.720 --> 00:30:56.420
then I can share it to people
using Bluetooth if I want.

649
00:30:56.420 --> 00:30:58.680
I can add people Bluetooth
tablet to my laptop and

650
00:30:58.680 --> 00:31:00.330
get Internet access via
my wireless network.

651
00:31:01.390 --> 00:31:03.095
This is something that we use on,

652
00:31:03.095 --> 00:31:06.800
[LAUGH] this is not necessarily
the fairest way to use it.

653
00:31:06.800 --> 00:31:09.760
But let's say you're on the airplane and
you need the gogo in-flight Internet.

654
00:31:09.760 --> 00:31:12.625
So you paid the money so you can get
Internet access on your laptop and

655
00:31:12.625 --> 00:31:13.538
it's using Wi-Fi.

656
00:31:13.538 --> 00:31:15.538
But then you get your cellphone and
your tablet, and

657
00:31:15.538 --> 00:31:18.510
you want them to have Internet access too,
you don't wanna pay three times.

658
00:31:18.510 --> 00:31:21.860
Well, you could share your Internet
connection over Bluetooth.

659
00:31:21.860 --> 00:31:23.410
And your phone and
your tablet could connect up.

660
00:31:23.410 --> 00:31:26.920
And now they're using your laptop to
be able to get out to the Internet.

661
00:31:26.920 --> 00:31:28.810
So you're sharing that
connection between them.

662
00:31:28.810 --> 00:31:30.660
I know I've done that with hotel,
wireless before.

663
00:31:30.660 --> 00:31:33.630
I didn't wanna have to
actually multiple devices.

664
00:31:33.630 --> 00:31:34.560
You can share right there.

665
00:31:34.560 --> 00:31:36.450
So there's several different uses for it.

666
00:31:36.450 --> 00:31:41.090
And because this laptop has Bluetooth,
I see one more item Bluetooth sharing.

667
00:31:41.090 --> 00:31:42.410
There's Bluetooth sharing, I picked that.

668
00:31:42.410 --> 00:31:47.180
Remember, I said that you only see
items that match up with your hardware.

669
00:31:47.180 --> 00:31:49.560
So I have Bluetooth sharing here,
I don't have CD and

670
00:31:49.560 --> 00:31:53.000
DVD sharing cuz I don't have a CD or
DVD drive.

671
00:31:53.000 --> 00:31:54.450
But I do have Bluetooth.

672
00:31:54.450 --> 00:31:58.830
When I looked at my workstation over here,
it has CD and DVD sharing, but

673
00:31:58.830 --> 00:32:00.930
it doesn't have Bluetooth cuz
it's a virtual machine, and

674
00:32:00.930 --> 00:32:03.710
it doesn't have a Bluetooth receiver and
transmitter.

675
00:32:03.710 --> 00:32:08.498
So you only see the sharing options that
match up with the hardware that you have.

676
00:32:08.498 --> 00:32:11.678
Well, that's a pretty good run down of
each of the different sharing options and

677
00:32:11.678 --> 00:32:13.190
what they do and how they work.

678
00:32:13.190 --> 00:32:14.928
There's a little more I
wanna talk about though.

679
00:32:14.928 --> 00:32:16.680
I definitely wanna hit on
Apple Remote Desktop, and

680
00:32:16.680 --> 00:32:19.830
I wanna talk about some of the other
command line ways that we can

681
00:32:19.830 --> 00:32:22.420
connect to network shares cuz
they do turn up on the exam.

682
00:32:22.420 --> 00:32:25.740
So a few more things to cover
before we wrap this one up, but for

683
00:32:25.740 --> 00:32:27.890
now this is a good spot for
us to stop this episode.

684
00:32:27.890 --> 00:32:31.110
So definitely tune back in for
part two, but in this episode we

685
00:32:31.110 --> 00:32:34.390
got a chance to see a good run down
of all the sharing technologies,

686
00:32:34.390 --> 00:32:37.860
each of the ones are available as far
as sharing files, folders, CDs and

687
00:32:37.860 --> 00:32:42.430
DVDs, printers, Internet connections,
all those different bells and whistles.

688
00:32:42.430 --> 00:32:44.390
Which we'll just keep
rolling in the next part.

689
00:32:44.390 --> 00:32:49.504
So for now, signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet, and I'll see you next time.
