00:23:15.813 --> 00:23:17.556
And saw that it was a duplicate, and

464
00:23:17.556 --> 00:23:20.945
when it saw that it was a duplicate
it renamed itself Mac Mini Chat 2.

465
00:23:20.945 --> 00:23:25.430
And then at some point it rebooted again
and it said there's already a chat 2 and

466
00:23:25.430 --> 00:23:27.339
it renamed itself Mac Mini Chat 3.

467
00:23:27.339 --> 00:23:29.004
When you see that parentheses and

468
00:23:29.004 --> 00:23:33.000
a number at the end that means that it
was a duplicate name on the network.

469
00:23:33.000 --> 00:23:35.390
And prior to El Capitan,
it happened all the time, and

470
00:23:35.390 --> 00:23:36.900
you were duplicating with yourself.

471
00:23:36.900 --> 00:23:37.930
It was silly.

472
00:23:37.930 --> 00:23:41.410
At one point my laptop
was Don's Macbook 14.

473
00:23:41.410 --> 00:23:44.908
It had done it 14 times, it's a laptop I
kept coming in and out of the office, and

474
00:23:44.908 --> 00:23:47.208
the name kept changing and
changing, and changing.

475
00:23:47.208 --> 00:23:49.968
So that was a problem with
the old multicast DNS responder.

476
00:23:49.968 --> 00:23:51.528
It's gone in El Capitan.

477
00:23:51.528 --> 00:23:55.248
In El Capitan, we just use Bonjour and
that doesn't happen The problem is,

478
00:23:55.248 --> 00:23:58.272
if you still have even one Yosemite
system on your network, or

479
00:23:58.272 --> 00:24:00.890
even one Mavericks system on your network,
they're

480
00:24:00.890 --> 00:24:05.280
still running the Multicast DNS responder,
and these renames will still happen.

481
00:24:05.280 --> 00:24:06.970
So it's easy to spot that.

482
00:24:06.970 --> 00:24:07.980
It's easy to fix.

483
00:24:07.980 --> 00:24:09.310
You upgrade your systems.

484
00:24:09.310 --> 00:24:12.410
Upgrade your systems to El Capitan,
and once that's done, you can go and

485
00:24:12.410 --> 00:24:15.260
rename your systems back,
get rid of that parentheses number, and

486
00:24:15.260 --> 00:24:16.420
then it's back to normal.

487
00:24:16.420 --> 00:24:20.239
So it's just kind of a weird little
quirk there that you may bump into in

488
00:24:20.239 --> 00:24:21.160
the real world.

489
00:24:21.160 --> 00:24:25.296
All right, the last thing that I need to
mention before we wrap this section up is

490
00:24:25.296 --> 00:24:28.530
troubleshooting, if you can't
connect to another system.

491
00:24:28.530 --> 00:24:31.050
I know way back in he
beginning of the last episode

492
00:24:31.050 --> 00:24:33.960
I showed how if we're not actually sharing
anything out, we're not gonna be seen on

493
00:24:33.960 --> 00:24:36.630
the network cuz we don't have
any services to make available.

494
00:24:36.630 --> 00:24:41.820
But if you know you're sharing something
out and people aren't still seeing you,

495
00:24:41.820 --> 00:24:43.620
then you probably got a network
connectivity issue and

496
00:24:43.620 --> 00:24:46.480
you need to test your network connection.

497
00:24:46.480 --> 00:24:49.600
If it's somebody on the same network
as you, it's really easy to do that.

498
00:24:49.600 --> 00:24:51.640
You just ping their IP address.

499
00:24:51.640 --> 00:24:54.990
But if they're on a different network,
it gets a little more difficult.

500
00:24:54.990 --> 00:24:59.730
So, for example I know there's
an FTP server out there,

501
00:24:59.730 --> 00:25:03.480
at a particular IP address, 10.1.10.4.

502
00:25:03.480 --> 00:25:07.390
So maybe I fire up my terminal,
and I go to connect to it.

503
00:25:07.390 --> 00:25:10.580
And so I say FTP 10.1.10.4, right.

504
00:25:10.580 --> 00:25:13.250
And I go to connect and it fails.

505
00:25:13.250 --> 00:25:15.949
I cant' get to it, but
I know there's an FTP server there.

506
00:25:16.960 --> 00:25:19.100
Where's my problem, where's the breakdown?

507
00:25:19.100 --> 00:25:20.420
Okay, where did that stop?

508
00:25:21.510 --> 00:25:22.910
It's kind of hard to say.

509
00:25:22.910 --> 00:25:27.230
So what you need to do is
leverage the network utility, and

510
00:25:27.230 --> 00:25:30.250
you need to what I call
pinging from the inside out.

511
00:25:30.250 --> 00:25:31.990
There's a number of places where
you can have a failure and

512
00:25:31.990 --> 00:25:33.300
we need to figure out where.

513
00:25:33.300 --> 00:25:35.350
I always start with my own machine.

514
00:25:35.350 --> 00:25:38.890
So looking at this machine
it's 192.168.0.150.

515
00:25:38.890 --> 00:25:42.570
You can rung ping and
you can ping yourself.

516
00:25:42.570 --> 00:25:44.380
Now why would you ping yourself?

517
00:25:44.380 --> 00:25:48.320
Well, it's possible that you've got
a software problem on your own system.

518
00:25:48.320 --> 00:25:51.030
If the TCPIP stack is broken, for example.

519
00:25:51.030 --> 00:25:53.350
And pinging yourself is
a great way to test that.

520
00:25:53.350 --> 00:25:56.818
So I'm gonna run a quick test,
I'll just do four pings, and

521
00:25:56.818 --> 00:25:59.009
I'll ping it, and I can ping myself.

522
00:25:59.009 --> 00:26:01.070
So TCPIP is working on my system.

523
00:26:02.520 --> 00:26:06.275
Next I'm on the 192.68.0 network.

524
00:26:06.275 --> 00:26:09.105
I'm trying to contact an FTP
server that's on the 10.1.10,

525
00:26:09.105 --> 00:26:10.800
that's a different network.

526
00:26:10.800 --> 00:26:12.350
I'm gonna have to go through my router.

527
00:26:12.350 --> 00:26:15.050
So let me see if I can ping my router.

528
00:26:15.050 --> 00:26:19.430
Well my router is 192.168.0.2,
so I'm gonna try and

529
00:26:19.430 --> 00:26:22.140
ping that, and
when I ping it I can pick it.

530
00:26:22.140 --> 00:26:25.180
So I can see my router,
my router is not the problem.

531
00:26:25.180 --> 00:26:26.170
Or is it?

532
00:26:26.170 --> 00:26:28.810
A router has two interfaces,
an inside and an outside.

533
00:26:28.810 --> 00:26:30.410
This is the inside.

534
00:26:30.410 --> 00:26:35.030
So if I really want to test it I need
to test the outside of that also, and

535
00:26:35.030 --> 00:26:41.630
the outside on this one is 10.1.230,
tough, I think it's .1.

536
00:26:41.630 --> 00:26:46.740
So the outside on that particular
router is this IP, can I ping that?

537
00:26:46.740 --> 00:26:49.860
This shows me not only can
I get to the router, but

538
00:26:49.860 --> 00:26:52.960
I'm able to be routed from the inside
interface to the outside interface.

539
00:26:52.960 --> 00:26:55.250
I'm able to pass through the router.

540
00:26:56.990 --> 00:27:01.020
Then can I get to the remote host?

541
00:27:01.020 --> 00:27:05.064
Now the host in this case is 10.1.10.4,
right?

542
00:27:05.064 --> 00:27:06.790
So can I get to that?

543
00:27:06.790 --> 00:27:08.427
And if I fire up a ping here,

544
00:27:08.427 --> 00:27:12.940
if this fails then it's more than
likely a problem on the other end.

545
00:27:12.940 --> 00:27:13.930
It's a problem on their end.

546
00:27:13.930 --> 00:27:16.820
I can get to my router,
I can get through my router.

547
00:27:16.820 --> 00:27:18.460
But it could be an addressing problem.

548
00:27:18.460 --> 00:27:20.150
It could be a problem out on the Internet.

549
00:27:20.150 --> 00:27:23.560
So there could be a problem
in-between me and that destination.

550
00:27:23.560 --> 00:27:26.000
So the best thing to do there
is to go to Traceroute.

551
00:27:26.000 --> 00:27:29.823
And take a look and see what other systems
are between you and that destination.

552
00:27:29.823 --> 00:27:33.350
If I punch in 10.1 10.4
what's in between me and

553
00:27:33.350 --> 00:27:37.150
that IP and we can try and
trace that out and find it out.

554
00:27:37.150 --> 00:27:39.878
The only negative with Traceroute is
that it does get blocked sometimes,

555
00:27:39.878 --> 00:27:40.735
like this one is.

556
00:27:40.735 --> 00:27:43.185
And that's because I've got the firewall
on my own laptop is killing it.

557
00:27:43.185 --> 00:27:45.145
And you see,
it's kind of stopping right here.

558
00:27:45.145 --> 00:27:48.355
So I'm not able to get past it and
find out those other hops.

559
00:27:48.355 --> 00:27:52.909
So if that is the case you could always
just try other Internet hosts, like,

560
00:27:52.909 --> 00:27:53.989
can I ping Apple?

561
00:27:53.989 --> 00:27:55.095
Let's just try and ping Apple.

562
00:27:55.095 --> 00:27:56.965
Well, actually,
I think Apple blocks their pings.

563
00:27:56.965 --> 00:27:58.775
Let's take an Internet DNS server.

564
00:27:58.775 --> 00:28:00.255
So I'll take one of Google's DNS servers.

565
00:28:00.255 --> 00:28:01.415
Can I ping that?

566
00:28:01.415 --> 00:28:06.110
So I'm gonna try to ping 8.8.8.8,
and if I can, great.

567
00:28:06.110 --> 00:28:10.070
If I can't, then I've got
Internet connectivity issues.

568
00:28:10.070 --> 00:28:12.590
And shoot, I'm on the Traceroute tab.

569
00:28:12.590 --> 00:28:15.960
Let me get to the right tool for
the job here and get back to Ping.

570
00:28:15.960 --> 00:28:20.280
And I'll try that ping,
and I can ping to Google.

571
00:28:20.280 --> 00:28:21.900
So I can get out to the Internet.

572
00:28:21.900 --> 00:28:23.790
I just can't get to this FTP server.

573
00:28:23.790 --> 00:28:27.320
But in troubleshooting,
I ruled out everything in between.

574
00:28:27.320 --> 00:28:32.260
That we need to find out what hops we
go through to get to that destination.

575
00:28:32.260 --> 00:28:34.030
And let me just show you with Traceroute.

576
00:28:34.030 --> 00:28:35.580
Oops, that's not what I wanted.

577
00:28:35.580 --> 00:28:38.560
Let me get back to my network
utility here on my actual laptop.

578
00:28:38.560 --> 00:28:42.448
And I'll traceroute to
the ITProTV website, right.

579
00:28:42.448 --> 00:28:45.970
When I traceroute to the ITProTV website

580
00:28:45.970 --> 00:28:50.180
I pass through a number of systems and
we see them all right here.

581
00:28:50.180 --> 00:28:52.790
Any one of these systems could
be where the problem is.

582
00:28:52.790 --> 00:28:55.920
It may not be the destination, this is
the destination right here the ITProTV

583
00:28:55.920 --> 00:28:59.070
website, but
the problem could be anywhere in-between.

584
00:28:59.070 --> 00:29:01.940
So, Traceroute and Ping,
those are your friends.

585
00:29:01.940 --> 00:29:04.480
And Traceroute's really just
pinging all these hops.

586
00:29:04.480 --> 00:29:07.810
So you could use Traceroute to
knock this all out at once, right.

587
00:29:07.810 --> 00:29:09.470
But doing a ping from the inside out,

588
00:29:09.470 --> 00:29:12.650
ping yourself,
ping your router's inside interface,

589
00:29:12.650 --> 00:29:15.150
ping your router's outside interface,
then try and ping the destination.

590
00:29:15.150 --> 00:29:18.460
Those four will help you
establish where that fault is.

591
00:29:18.460 --> 00:29:21.390
And then Traceroute would show you where
on the Internet, if you were having some

592
00:29:21.390 --> 00:29:25.430
kind of breakdown in here, like in Miami,
or Washington, or wherever.

593
00:29:25.430 --> 00:29:27.990
You'd be able to spot that, and
then go through and fix it.

594
00:29:27.990 --> 00:29:31.160
So, that's kind of how we
troubleshoot these issues.

595
00:29:31.160 --> 00:29:31.940
If it's not one these,

596
00:29:31.940 --> 00:29:35.210
if I can ping the host, then it usually
just comes down to permissions.

597
00:29:35.210 --> 00:29:37.290
Go and check your sharing settings and
look at the permissions.

598
00:29:37.290 --> 00:29:39.750
Make sure that your user account is
allowed to access those resources.

599
00:29:39.750 --> 00:29:43.780
As long as they are, you'll get in and
everything will work fine.

600
00:29:43.780 --> 00:29:45.955
So that's basically it for
sharing resources.

601
00:29:45.955 --> 00:29:47.520
Obviously, some of it is self-explanatory,

602
00:29:47.520 --> 00:29:49.640
some of it like file sharing
we've already talked about.

603
00:29:49.640 --> 00:29:51.390
But you probably saw some new stuff there.

604
00:29:51.390 --> 00:29:54.560
The screen sharing is kind of neat,
Apple remote desktop really cool,

605
00:29:54.560 --> 00:29:56.090
definitely things that
can turn up on the exam.

606
00:29:56.090 --> 00:29:58.020
But things you can use in real life.

607
00:29:58.020 --> 00:30:02.130
So in this episode we wrapped up sharing
resources, we talked about some of

608
00:30:02.130 --> 00:30:05.200
those last bells and whistles that we
didn't cover in the first episode.

609
00:30:05.200 --> 00:30:07.650
Hopefully, you guys enjoyed it but
looking at the clock, I'm out of time.

610
00:30:07.650 --> 00:30:10.400
And it's a good spot to wrap this one
up anyways, so we'll go ahead and

611
00:30:10.400 --> 00:30:12.040
wrap this one up right here.

612
00:30:12.040 --> 00:30:16.745
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

613
00:30:16.745 --> 00:30:24.480
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don describes the various peripheral devices supported by OS X 10.11 El Capitan. He shows how to determine what devices are connected, and how to verify hardware and software functionality. He also demonstrates how OS X uses system integrity protection to ensure unsigned drivers are not installed.
episodes.title: Peripheral Devices
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.548 --> 00:00:13.584
All right, ladies and gentlemen.

3
00:00:13.584 --> 00:00:16.621
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.621 --> 00:00:18.500
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

5
00:00:18.500 --> 00:00:21.720
Back again with more
Apple Certified Support Professional.

6
00:00:21.720 --> 00:00:24.930
And in this episode,
we're gonna take a look at not so

7
00:00:24.930 --> 00:00:26.480
much what's built into our Mac.

8
00:00:26.480 --> 00:00:30.592
But what we can add to it,
those peripheral devices.

9
00:00:30.592 --> 00:00:32.846
The computers, they keep getting
smaller and smaller each year.

10
00:00:32.846 --> 00:00:36.571
And the way they get them smaller,
in a large part, is by leaving stuff out.

11
00:00:36.571 --> 00:00:39.706
Laptops got smaller when they
can leave optical drives out.

12
00:00:39.706 --> 00:00:42.976
And then desktops got smaller when
they can put smaller hard drives in or

13
00:00:42.976 --> 00:00:45.443
less hard drives or
even no hard drives in some cases.

14
00:00:45.443 --> 00:00:50.007
These are making devices get small,
slim, and

15
00:00:50.007 --> 00:00:53.210
a lot more generalized, right?

16
00:00:53.210 --> 00:00:57.038
It's harder to get a PC or laptop or
desktop that is specifically design for

17
00:00:57.038 --> 00:00:57.842
what you need.

18
00:00:57.842 --> 00:01:01.393
And if you want to customize it,
to add hardware that you need,

19
00:01:01.393 --> 00:01:02.868
it's got to be external.

20
00:01:02.868 --> 00:01:07.174
So peripheral devices, those are devices
that we hook up to the outside of our Mac,

21
00:01:07.174 --> 00:01:09.350
those become really important.

22
00:01:09.350 --> 00:01:10.529
And depending on your Mac,

23
00:01:10.529 --> 00:01:13.771
you may have more than one different
way that you can attach those devices.

24
00:01:13.771 --> 00:01:16.280
In the exam we need to know them, and
in real life we need to know them.

25
00:01:16.280 --> 00:01:18.445
So we're gonna run through
those right here and

26
00:01:18.445 --> 00:01:20.401
see how we can expand that functionality.

27
00:01:20.401 --> 00:01:23.037
Now, my laptop, for example,
I've got a Macbook Pro.

28
00:01:23.037 --> 00:01:27.102
And it's got a hard drive,
it's got a keyboard, it has a touchpad,

29
00:01:27.102 --> 00:01:31.536
it's got a monitor, it's got a wireless
adapter, and that's about it.

30
00:01:31.536 --> 00:01:33.395
Well, storage and memory, right?

31
00:01:33.395 --> 00:01:37.473
So I've got solid state storage inside
of it, so it's got one hard drive.

32
00:01:37.473 --> 00:01:40.247
But what if I need more?

33
00:01:40.247 --> 00:01:41.433
Let's talk about hard drive.

34
00:01:41.433 --> 00:01:45.441
I've got a 500 gig SSD in this thing,
which is a lot of storage,

35
00:01:45.441 --> 00:01:46.737
it's enough for me.

36
00:01:46.737 --> 00:01:47.825
But what if I need more?

37
00:01:47.825 --> 00:01:51.800
What if I bought this laptop and
I only got the 256 gig storage option?

38
00:01:51.800 --> 00:01:52.960
That's not a lot of storage.

39
00:01:52.960 --> 00:01:56.500
And now I start pressing my limit and
so I need more storage.

40
00:01:56.500 --> 00:01:59.350
Well you can go out and
you can get external storage and

41
00:01:59.350 --> 00:02:02.300
depending on your device, you may have
a few different ways you can connect.

42
00:02:02.300 --> 00:02:06.050
Right, so for example,
one way that we might do it,

43
00:02:06.050 --> 00:02:12.050
I've actually got it here on my Mac right
now, is that I've got a SD card installed.

44
00:02:12.050 --> 00:02:17.360
So you see how I've got Macintosh HD and
then I've got this SD card here.

45
00:02:17.360 --> 00:02:19.860
And it's got the little SD card icon.

46
00:02:19.860 --> 00:02:24.740
So that's a digital card that's plugged
into the SD card slot on the side

47
00:02:24.740 --> 00:02:25.330
of my laptop.

48
00:02:25.330 --> 00:02:28.210
Now, SD cards have
an interesting characteristic.

49
00:02:28.210 --> 00:02:30.960
They're really flexible,
you can use them in darn near everything.

50
00:02:30.960 --> 00:02:32.240
A lot of cameras support them.

51
00:02:32.240 --> 00:02:33.880
A lot of desktops do.

52
00:02:33.880 --> 00:02:37.030
But they're slow,
they are slow at communicating.

53
00:02:37.030 --> 00:02:40.379
SD cards are basically hooked up
to what's called USB 2.0 bus, and

54
00:02:40.379 --> 00:02:41.988
USB 2.0 is not terribly fast.

55
00:02:41.988 --> 00:02:45.982
So it's not a great technology for
speed, when I'm in a hurry.

56
00:02:45.982 --> 00:02:49.190
But it is available, I could throw that
in and I could get some extra memory.

57
00:02:49.190 --> 00:02:53.810
And if I look at mine,
mine is 128 gigs, so

58
00:02:53.810 --> 00:02:56.980
I've added 128 gigs of
storage to my laptop.

59
00:02:56.980 --> 00:02:57.960
But it's just slow storage.

60
00:02:57.960 --> 00:02:59.130
I just have to be aware of that and

61
00:02:59.130 --> 00:03:02.110
say all right, well anything I put there
I need to not be in a hurry about.

62
00:03:02.110 --> 00:03:02.990
And I can get access to it.

63
00:03:02.990 --> 00:03:06.390
So that's a quick,
easy way to add storage to your system.

64
00:03:06.390 --> 00:03:09.180
Well, what if I want it faster?

65
00:03:09.180 --> 00:03:12.380
Your Mac may have a couple of other
ports that are available on it.

66
00:03:12.380 --> 00:03:14.250
The best one is Thunderbolt.

67
00:03:14.250 --> 00:03:16.250
You may well have a Thunderbolt
port on your system.

68
00:03:16.250 --> 00:03:17.240
And you may have more than one.

69
00:03:17.240 --> 00:03:20.050
So my Macbook Pro,
I have two Thunderbolt ports.

70
00:03:20.050 --> 00:03:22.340
And so I can plug in Thunderbolt devices.

71
00:03:22.340 --> 00:03:24.880
And Thunderbolt devices
are not just hard drives.

72
00:03:24.880 --> 00:03:27.780
I'm talking about hard drives, but
you can get all sorts of things.

73
00:03:27.780 --> 00:03:30.840
There's Thunderbolt network adapters,
I've got one of those right here.

74
00:03:30.840 --> 00:03:34.780
There's Thunderbolt monitors, I mean you
can do display port over Thunderbolt

go for that SATA for internal storage.

753
00:36:26.040 --> 00:36:26.860
You'll usually see that.

754
00:36:26.860 --> 00:36:31.585
You got printers in here Parallel SCSI,
you really don't see on Macs anymore.

755
00:36:31.585 --> 00:36:35.955
The old old iMacs, the ones that were
colorful those used SCSI on the inside.

756
00:36:35.955 --> 00:36:39.695
All the really old Macs,
if you ever used the SE20s or

757
00:36:39.695 --> 00:36:43.115
the Quadras,
those guys all had SCSI storage in them.

758
00:36:43.115 --> 00:36:45.430
Apple went to SATA many many years ago.

759
00:36:45.430 --> 00:36:48.600
PCI, that's where you'll start
to see cards that are inserted.

760
00:36:48.600 --> 00:36:52.260
So if you had a built-in
adapter of some sort.

761
00:36:52.260 --> 00:36:54.870
You'll have your memory,
your other things there.

762
00:36:54.870 --> 00:36:56.780
But you don't really add things to memory.

763
00:36:56.780 --> 00:36:58.860
FireWire, I don't have a FireWire port.

764
00:36:58.860 --> 00:36:59.720
So that's not gonna work for me.

765
00:36:59.720 --> 00:37:02.170
But if I had FireWire devices
they would show up here.

766
00:37:02.170 --> 00:37:04.790
And then he also got your
card reader that turns up.

767
00:37:04.790 --> 00:37:07.670
You got that built in SD card
reader that shows up here.

768
00:37:07.670 --> 00:37:11.520
Camera, your Bluetooth and
Bluetooth devices that are attached.

769
00:37:11.520 --> 00:37:13.210
They all kinda get listed down here.

770
00:37:13.210 --> 00:37:16.620
You'll see things like my
Don Pezet's Trackpad work.

771
00:37:16.620 --> 00:37:18.220
Actually, I have two Magic Pads.

772
00:37:18.220 --> 00:37:21.350
One here at the office and one at home,
so I have to label them that way.

773
00:37:21.350 --> 00:37:25.790
So this is my work one that shows up,
so I can see those and they're visible.

774
00:37:25.790 --> 00:37:27.240
Under ATA, I don't see anything.

775
00:37:27.240 --> 00:37:29.820
Those are the really old
parallel ATA drives.

776
00:37:29.820 --> 00:37:33.550
Serial ATA is what we use now, so that's
why all the storage is under Serial ATA,

777
00:37:33.550 --> 00:37:34.920
and that's where we'll spot those.

778
00:37:34.920 --> 00:37:39.220
So there's many different bus types inside
of your Mac, and depending on which bus

779
00:37:39.220 --> 00:37:42.570
you plug a device in it may show up under
one of those different ones, all right.

780
00:37:42.570 --> 00:37:47.630
Just be aware, having hardware is one
thing, having the bus is another but

781
00:37:47.630 --> 00:37:48.680
we've gotta have a driver.

782
00:37:48.680 --> 00:37:50.790
You've gotta have a kernel
extension to make it all work.

783
00:37:50.790 --> 00:37:54.260
And without that, you end up like my
network card here, no link lights,

784
00:37:54.260 --> 00:37:55.870
I can't talk on the network, right.

785
00:37:55.870 --> 00:37:59.170
So that's the key thing to
remember about peripherals.

786
00:37:59.170 --> 00:38:03.505
Well I took what's as simple as plugging
in a USB cable and turned it into a 30

787
00:38:03.505 --> 00:38:06.775
minute episode here, so it's probably
a good spot for me to wrap up on that one.

788
00:38:06.775 --> 00:38:09.775
It is important on the exam,
absolutely remember,

789
00:38:09.775 --> 00:38:12.615
system integrity protection is important.

790
00:38:12.615 --> 00:38:15.335
El Capitan requires drivers
that are designed to work

791
00:38:15.335 --> 00:38:16.995
with system integrity protection.

792
00:38:16.995 --> 00:38:19.485
If they aren't, they just don't work.

793
00:38:19.485 --> 00:38:20.530
Absolutely be aware of that.

794
00:38:20.530 --> 00:38:23.060
All right, well ladies and gentleman
this is a good spot to wrap this up.

795
00:38:23.060 --> 00:38:25.780
In this episode we went over
our peripheral devices,

796
00:38:25.780 --> 00:38:28.710
some of the different buses we
could use to get connected.

797
00:38:28.710 --> 00:38:32.240
We got them in place, they're up and
going and we saw how to report on that.

798
00:38:32.240 --> 00:38:34.120
So pretty much a good wrap on that one.

799
00:38:34.120 --> 00:38:36.410
So right here I'll go and
sign off for ITProTV.

800
00:38:36.410 --> 00:38:40.796
I've been your host Don Pezet and
I'll see you next time.

801
00:38:40.796 --> 00:38:48.360
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don walks the viewers through configuring printers on a Mac. He demonstrates using local and network enabled printers. He wraps up the show demonstrating trouble shooting procedures.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.531 --> 00:00:15.311
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening,

3
00:00:15.311 --> 00:00:17.431
and welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.431 --> 00:00:19.130
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

5
00:00:19.130 --> 00:00:23.090
Back again with another episode of Apple
certified support professional and

6
00:00:23.090 --> 00:00:25.990
I'm back by my lonesome again, Daniel
had to be pulled off for another show.

7
00:00:25.990 --> 00:00:27.060
But that's okay.

8
00:00:27.060 --> 00:00:28.710
Cuz we're kind of winding down on ACSP.

9
00:00:28.710 --> 00:00:30.860
We've only got a couple episodes left and

10
00:00:30.860 --> 00:00:34.230
in this episode,
it's a flash from the past.

11
00:00:34.230 --> 00:00:38.200
We're gonna reach back in time to
the days where printers were relevant.

12
00:00:38.200 --> 00:00:40.200
That's right,
we're gonna talk about support printers.

13
00:00:40.200 --> 00:00:43.250
And I know, for someone like myself,
and probably like you,

14
00:00:43.250 --> 00:00:46.990
we really don't use printers
nearly as much as we used to.

15
00:00:46.990 --> 00:00:50.860
But they are still out there and they
are still important to a lot of people.

16
00:00:50.860 --> 00:00:53.900
There are many people out there that,
their printer goes down,

17
00:00:53.900 --> 00:00:55.390
that's the end of their work day.

18
00:00:55.390 --> 00:00:57.050
It's so important for them to have that.

19
00:00:57.050 --> 00:01:00.120
Then a lot of times they wouldn't even
complain about their computer being slow.

20
00:01:00.120 --> 00:01:03.110
But the moment their printer doesn't work,
you'll never hear the end of it.

21
00:01:03.110 --> 00:01:05.790
There's all over you about
getting that printer.

22
00:01:05.790 --> 00:01:07.590
It happens,
it is still important to people and

23
00:01:07.590 --> 00:01:10.290
so we need to be able to
support those inside of Mac OS.

24
00:01:10.290 --> 00:01:13.670
Now, in OS10 there's all sorts of
features that try to make where you don't

25
00:01:13.670 --> 00:01:14.380
need a printer.

26
00:01:14.380 --> 00:01:19.360
For example every application inside
of OS10 can save their output as a PDF.

27
00:01:19.360 --> 00:01:23.220
So you can create electronic documents
right from inside of the OS,

28
00:01:23.220 --> 00:01:25.420
you never have to mess with printers.

29
00:01:25.420 --> 00:01:28.050
But if you're in one of those
organizations where you still need

30
00:01:28.050 --> 00:01:29.970
printers, you still need that support,

31
00:01:29.970 --> 00:01:32.280
you're gonna have to
know how to handle those.

32
00:01:32.280 --> 00:01:35.420
I say I don't use printers but
I'll tell you every day I

33
00:01:35.420 --> 00:01:38.140
print my show notes before the show so
I know what I talk about.

34
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:41.330
And to have that as a piece of paper
sitting right here in front of me,

35
00:01:41.330 --> 00:01:43.665
that keeps me on track and
make sure I know to talk about.

36
00:01:43.665 --> 00:01:47.045
So even I still use printers
even though personally,

37
00:01:47.045 --> 00:01:50.455
like outside of the show,
everything I do is electronic.

38
00:01:50.455 --> 00:01:54.505
Now, the printing inside of Mac OS
actually has a neat little history to it.

39
00:01:54.505 --> 00:01:57.695
Because remember I know I've mentioned
it more than once on the show,

40
00:01:57.695 --> 00:02:01.705
is that while we look at Mac OS we see
this nice graphical user interface,

41
00:02:01.705 --> 00:02:03.125
it super easy to use.

42
00:02:03.125 --> 00:02:06.580
That under the hood, It's BSD Unix.

43
00:02:06.580 --> 00:02:10.650
So it's running an operating
system that was developed back in

44
00:02:10.650 --> 00:02:14.380
the 1970s that was commandline only.

45
00:02:14.380 --> 00:02:16.220
And it makes it pretty amazing,
doesn't it?

46
00:02:16.220 --> 00:02:17.580
You wouldn't know that from looking at it.

47
00:02:17.580 --> 00:02:20.770
But it's technology that's been around
a long time that's very tried and true and

48
00:02:20.770 --> 00:02:22.330
very stable.

49
00:02:22.330 --> 00:02:25.140
But, one of the big
problems in the Unix-world

50
00:02:25.140 --> 00:02:27.210
was it was originally developed for
servers.

51
00:02:27.210 --> 00:02:29.250
It wasn't designed for end-users like us.

52
00:02:29.250 --> 00:02:32.210
Where people that have workstations,
and laptops, and mobile devices.

53
00:02:32.210 --> 00:02:33.690
It wasn't designed for that.

54
00:02:33.690 --> 00:02:36.790
And so in the Unix-world,
as those operating systems progressed and

55
00:02:36.790 --> 00:02:38.950
started to be used for desktops.

56
00:02:38.950 --> 00:02:40.920
We started to see this real problem.

57
00:02:40.920 --> 00:02:43.570
The problem came with hardware support.

58
00:02:43.570 --> 00:02:47.420
If I'm a manufacturer and I decide
that I'm going to make a new printer.

59
00:02:47.420 --> 00:02:50.310
Well, computers need to know
how to talk to my printer and

60
00:02:50.310 --> 00:02:52.910
there's several different languages
out there that printers talk.

61
00:02:52.910 --> 00:02:53.630
So in order for

62
00:02:53.630 --> 00:02:57.100
a computer to talk to my printer I'm
going to have to write some software.

63
00:02:57.100 --> 00:02:59.570
I'm going to have to write a little driver

64
00:02:59.570 --> 00:03:01.866
that tells the computer
how to talk to my printer.

65
00:03:01.866 --> 00:03:05.400
And if I'm gonna have to go through
the trouble of creating a driver,

66
00:03:05.400 --> 00:03:08.460
I'm gonna look at who the number
one operating system is out there.

67
00:03:08.460 --> 00:03:09.810
And in the business and the home world,

68
00:03:09.810 --> 00:03:12.900
right now,
Microsoft Windows has that market share.

69
00:03:12.900 --> 00:03:15.200
So every printer,
if you go to the store and

70
00:03:15.200 --> 00:03:18.249
buy a printer, every printer will
have drivers for Microsoft Windows.

71
00:03:19.310 --> 00:03:22.880
But very few of them will have drivers for
Linux or

72
00:03:22.880 --> 00:03:27.400
Unix, because people don't run Linux and
Unix at home on their computer or

73
00:03:27.400 --> 00:03:29.100
even at their office, for the most part.

74
00:03:29.100 --> 00:03:31.330
They just aren't that widely deployed.

75
00:03:31.330 --> 00:03:36.440
So, when Apple decided to switch Mac OS
from being proprietary to being based

76
00:03:36.440 --> 00:03:39.720
on BSD,
they had a real problem with printing.

77
00:03:39.720 --> 00:03:43.200
And instead of coming up with
something crazy, it's isolated and

78
00:03:43.200 --> 00:03:45.920
unique to Apple,
they did something really neat.

79
00:03:45.920 --> 00:03:51.175
Apple formed an organization,
they created a product called CUPS.

80
00:03:51.175 --> 00:03:55.315
Which is the common UNIX printing system.

81
00:03:55.315 --> 00:03:59.545
And the common UNIX printing system was
designed to allow UNIX based systems,

82
00:03:59.545 --> 00:04:03.035
not just UNIX, but BSD micros, LINUX and

83
00:04:03.035 --> 00:04:07.035
anybody was based on an infrastructure
to be able to easily print to printers.

84
00:04:08.045 --> 00:04:11.400
Now a manufacturer could write one driver.

85
00:04:11.400 --> 00:04:16.530
Right one caps driver and
that would allow Linux users to print ESD,

86
00:04:16.530 --> 00:04:19.640
Unix and MAc they can knock
all those OSs all at once.

87
00:04:19.640 --> 00:04:22.370
So if I'm a manufacturer now and
I go to create a printer and

88
00:04:22.370 --> 00:04:23.850
I know I have the right software.

89
00:04:23.850 --> 00:04:26.410
Well yeah I'm gonna create a Windows
driver that's a given you gotta support

90
00:04:26.410 --> 00:04:28.310
the major user base out there.

91
00:04:28.310 --> 00:04:31.640
But now I can write one caps driver.

92
00:04:31.640 --> 00:04:35.440
And that will enable everybody else to
print all the other major operating

93
00:04:35.440 --> 00:04:36.920
systems that are out there.

94
00:04:36.920 --> 00:04:39.800
So Apple developed this in-house and
they very well could have

95
00:04:39.800 --> 00:04:42.430
just kept it to themselves and
say, yeah this is an Apple thing.

96
00:04:42.430 --> 00:04:45.080
And so now if a developer
wants to write a driver for

97
00:04:45.080 --> 00:04:47.260
a printer they can write it for
Apple's system.

98
00:04:47.260 --> 00:04:49.080
But instead,
Apple gave it back to the community.

99
00:04:49.080 --> 00:04:51.980
And they said,
here we just created this printing system.

100
00:04:51.980 --> 00:04:56.330
If you guys use it, too, and
we use it, we could group together and

101
00:04:56.330 --> 00:04:58.160
now we are a bigger part
of that market share.

102
00:04:58.160 --> 00:04:59.470
And boy, did it really take off.

103
00:04:59.470 --> 00:05:04.120
And so if you deploy any of
the Linux distributions like Ubuntu,

104
00:05:04.120 --> 00:05:07.520
Debian, Red Hats, CentOS,
any of those guys.

105
00:05:07.520 --> 00:05:12.300
If you deploy true Unix, which really I
don't think you can truly do anymore.

106
00:05:12.300 --> 00:05:14.730
SCO Unix was the last
true version of Unix.

107
00:05:14.730 --> 00:05:20.150
But BSD, the FreeBSD, NetBSD,
OpenBSD or Mac OS, OS 10.

108
00:05:20.150 --> 00:05:24.040
And really, it's been this way since OS X
in the early days when it switched over to

109
00:05:24.040 --> 00:05:28.110
being BSD-based,
that all of those use CUPS.

110
00:05:28.110 --> 00:05:31.060
They all use it,
they all use that same printer driver.

111
00:05:31.060 --> 00:05:33.290
And that makes it super convenient.

112
00:05:33.290 --> 00:05:36.470
So, when we go to attach
a printer to our system.

113
00:05:37.590 --> 00:05:40.060
We may or may not need that driver.

114
00:05:40.060 --> 00:05:42.840
Apple may have already built
in support for your printer.

115
00:05:42.840 --> 00:05:45.990
For example, Apple has a really
close relationship with HP.

116
00:05:45.990 --> 00:05:51.450
And so, every time HP puts out a new
printer, HP shares the driver information

117
00:05:51.450 --> 00:05:55.620
with Apple, and Apple builds the printer
driver into the operating system.

118
00:05:55.620 --> 00:05:58.530
So when you plug in a Hewlett Packard
printer into your Mac,

119
00:05:58.530 --> 00:06:01.750
it's almost always supported right out of
the box, you don't have to load drivers.

120
00:06:01.750 --> 00:06:02.310
It's kind of nice.

121
00:06:03.340 --> 00:06:04.620
But if it's not,

122
00:06:04.620 --> 00:06:07.690
if you have a printer from some
brand that you've never heard of.

123
00:06:07.690 --> 00:06:09.880
So Don brand printer, right?

124
00:06:09.880 --> 00:06:13.950
And you buy my printer that I just
sold you Apple doesn't know who I am.

125
00:06:13.950 --> 00:06:16.180
They don't have that built in
to their operating system.

126
00:06:16.180 --> 00:06:18.500
So you'll need to go out and get a driver.

127
00:06:18.500 --> 00:06:21.070
And so that's the first thing that
I want to point out is that not

128
00:06:21.070 --> 00:06:24.100
every printer needs a driver but
many of them do.

129
00:06:24.100 --> 00:06:25.980
And so if we need to get it we've
got to go to the web site and

130
00:06:25.980 --> 00:06:26.700
we've got to find it.

131
00:06:26.700 --> 00:06:29.460
So for example, here in our office.

132
00:06:29.460 --> 00:06:33.710
I never use it, but we have this gigantic
office printer that the business side of

133
00:06:33.710 --> 00:06:35.878
the company uses and
it prints this thing like crazy.

134
00:06:35.878 --> 00:06:39.510
Different thousands of pages and
anything, multi sided and

135
00:06:39.510 --> 00:06:43.760
it's got like a booklet attachment so
it can do pamphlets and a stapler and

136
00:06:43.760 --> 00:06:46.600
a hole puncher and all sorts of
magic built into this printer.

137
00:06:46.600 --> 00:06:48.720
It's a lot more than
just a regular printer.

138
00:06:48.720 --> 00:06:53.230
So if your computer is expecting to print
in just a regular old printer that's fine,

139
00:06:53.230 --> 00:06:55.230
but if you've got a stapler and

140
00:06:55.230 --> 00:06:59.220
hole puncher built in your printer how
did your computer know to use that?

141
00:06:59.220 --> 00:07:00.920
You gonna have to get a driver for that.

142
00:07:00.920 --> 00:07:03.790
So let's go and find one of those drivers,
what I'm gonna do is I'm wanna pull out

143
00:07:03.790 --> 00:07:06.260
Canon website I pulled
it up before the show.

144
00:07:06.260 --> 00:07:09.420
And here is the printer that we have
like I said it's a gigantic thing,

145
00:07:09.420 --> 00:07:10.830
this master printer.

146
00:07:10.830 --> 00:07:12.420
And it's got all sorts of bells and

147
00:07:12.420 --> 00:07:14.950
whistles in it now we don't
have whatever this box is but

148
00:07:14.950 --> 00:07:20.110
we've got the rest of it and it can staple
and hole punch and all that craziness.

149
00:07:20.110 --> 00:07:23.240
So we're gonna need a driver for it and
when I go to the Website and look for

150
00:07:23.240 --> 00:07:26.810
drivers, well it gives me
information about the printer and

151
00:07:26.810 --> 00:07:30.990
I can go to Drivers & Downloads and
it's detecting my operating system.

152
00:07:30.990 --> 00:07:34.780
And so, I can see right here it
detected I'm running OS X El Capitan.

153
00:07:34.780 --> 00:07:39.540
And so, some manufacturers have
really good support for that.

154
00:07:39.540 --> 00:07:42.450
If you look, these guys, they've been
supporting printers a long time.

155
00:07:42.450 --> 00:07:46.070
You see OS8, OS9,
which are ancient these days.

156
00:07:46.070 --> 00:07:48.500
OS10, and
all the various versions of OS10.

157
00:07:48.500 --> 00:07:52.850
This is almost like
a history of large cats.

158
00:07:52.850 --> 00:07:55.400
So [LAUGH] you can go back and
look at all of those.

159
00:07:55.400 --> 00:07:58.385
But you'll see the other operating
systems here like Linux 64bit,

160
00:07:58.385 --> 00:07:59.556
Linux 32bit, and so on.

161
00:07:59.556 --> 00:08:02.350
These are all drivers for
different operating systems.

162
00:08:02.350 --> 00:08:03.066
And of course,

163
00:08:03.066 --> 00:08:06.658
you always see a big selection of Windows
cuz that one's gonna be supported.

164
00:08:06.658 --> 00:08:08.530
But then when you start
getting into Mac and

165
00:08:08.530 --> 00:08:11.188
Linux is where things get a little
bit more iffy, all right.

166
00:08:11.188 --> 00:08:12.635
Now, when I first click on it,

167
00:08:12.635 --> 00:08:15.420
see where it says no recommended
download for the OS?

168
00:08:15.420 --> 00:08:17.210
Well, that's not always true.

169
00:08:17.210 --> 00:08:20.520
It just means they haven't necessarily
matched it up and if I click on drivers,

170
00:08:20.520 --> 00:08:24.470
right off the bat I can see where there's
all these Mac drivers that are here.

171
00:08:24.470 --> 00:08:29.940
The one that I'm looking for
is this guy right here, this PPD.

172
00:08:29.940 --> 00:08:33.750
All right, PPDs,
those are printer definition files.

173
00:08:33.750 --> 00:08:38.300
With CUPS, with the Unix printing system,
that Common Unix Printing System,

174
00:08:38.300 --> 00:08:43.290
CUPS uses PPD files that define how to
talk to the printers or the drivers.

will go away because I don't need it in my
queue anymore, I've successfully printed.

634
00:29:44.380 --> 00:29:47.720
And so if I pull that directory
back up again, sure enough,

635
00:29:47.720 --> 00:29:50.510
that d0003-001 is gone now.

636
00:29:51.905 --> 00:29:53.605
It printed, and that's it.

637
00:29:53.605 --> 00:29:58.565
So, these guys up here, the c00001, 2 and
3, those mostly identify my printers.

638
00:29:58.565 --> 00:29:59.937
Cuz remember, I added one and deleted it.

639
00:29:59.937 --> 00:30:01.412
And then I added two more,
so that would make sense.

640
00:30:01.412 --> 00:30:02.457
There's my three printers.

641
00:30:02.457 --> 00:30:06.315
But these d's, that was my print job,
and now it's gone.

642
00:30:06.315 --> 00:30:10.995
So that queue is stored right there on
your hard drive, and that's why you can

643
00:30:10.995 --> 00:30:15.539
close a program or delete a document and
the print job can still go through.

644
00:30:15.539 --> 00:30:19.138
All right, so the only other thing I
really need to hit on on printers,

645
00:30:19.138 --> 00:30:23.400
the only other thing that can turn up on
the exam, really, is printer sharing.

646
00:30:23.400 --> 00:30:25.310
And we've kinda already talked
about it a little bit, but

647
00:30:25.310 --> 00:30:27.220
let's just rehash that real quick.

648
00:30:27.220 --> 00:30:30.170
When I add a printer to my computer,
I can turn around and

649
00:30:30.170 --> 00:30:31.140
share it with other people.

650
00:30:31.140 --> 00:30:33.560
And you normally only do that
with direct attached printers.

651
00:30:33.560 --> 00:30:36.930
So if I have a USB attached printer,
I'm the only one who can see it.

652
00:30:36.930 --> 00:30:39.958
So I can then share of the network for
everybody else so they can see it, right?

653
00:30:39.958 --> 00:30:43.892
But with a network printer like these
that I've been using in this show, well,

654
00:30:43.892 --> 00:30:46.680
I think everybody can see that it's on the
network, so they can just connect direct.

655
00:30:46.680 --> 00:30:49.050
They don't have to go through me, right?

656
00:30:49.050 --> 00:30:52.980
Well, maybe you wanna
set up a print server.

657
00:30:52.980 --> 00:30:56.580
You might want to have a centralize place
where people print so its all goes to

658
00:30:56.580 --> 00:30:59.960
one server instead of everybody
connecting directly to the printers.

659
00:30:59.960 --> 00:31:02.570
Now, why would we wanna do that?

660
00:31:02.570 --> 00:31:05.520
There's a few reasons,
the main reason is centralized management.

661
00:31:05.520 --> 00:31:07.700
That if I wanna pause a printer and

662
00:31:07.700 --> 00:31:11.555
make sure nobody's printing to it,
if everybody prints direct,

663
00:31:11.555 --> 00:31:14.514
I'd to go to everybody's computer and
pause their print queue, right?

664
00:31:14.514 --> 00:31:18.626
Or I'd have to call everybody on the phone
and say, hey, don't print to that printer.

665
00:31:18.626 --> 00:31:22.727
But if everybody goes through one central
server, I could pause the printer on

666
00:31:22.727 --> 00:31:26.340
that central server and
everybody's print jobs would queue up.

667
00:31:26.340 --> 00:31:29.880
They'd just start building up in the queue
on that server until I resumed it.

668
00:31:29.880 --> 00:31:31.147
So it would give me control.

669
00:31:31.147 --> 00:31:32.410
It would give me monitoring.

670
00:31:32.410 --> 00:31:34.980
I can control who was
going to that printer.

671
00:31:34.980 --> 00:31:37.610
That's the main reason for
having centralized printing.

672
00:31:37.610 --> 00:31:38.860
There are other reasons.

673
00:31:38.860 --> 00:31:42.050
Maybe for auditing purposes,
you need to keep a record of that.

674
00:31:42.050 --> 00:31:44.931
Think about all the big data leaks
that had happened for companies.

675
00:31:44.931 --> 00:31:48.951
A lot of companies spend a ton
of money putting firewalls and

676
00:31:48.951 --> 00:31:52.571
VPNs in place and
making sure that their customers and

677
00:31:52.571 --> 00:31:56.208
their employees don't leak
data out of the company.

678
00:31:56.208 --> 00:32:01.022
But, once I print something on a piece
of paper, I could leave it in a cab.

679
00:32:01.022 --> 00:32:02.288
I could leave it at a bus station.

680
00:32:02.288 --> 00:32:06.020
I could sell it to a foreign government.

681
00:32:06.020 --> 00:32:06.650
You could do whatever.

682
00:32:06.650 --> 00:32:09.660
Once it's on paper, it's kind of
outside of that monitoring system.

683
00:32:09.660 --> 00:32:13.870
And so you might want to be auditing
everything that gets printed.

684
00:32:13.870 --> 00:32:17.560
Well, if you've got a centralized server,
you can record those cues.

685
00:32:17.560 --> 00:32:20.290
You can keep track of all
the print jobs that go through it.

686
00:32:20.290 --> 00:32:22.790
Who did the print job,
what they printed, and you can see it.

687
00:32:22.790 --> 00:32:24.430
You get a historical record.

688
00:32:24.430 --> 00:32:26.100
If you're centrally managing it.

689
00:32:26.100 --> 00:32:28.600
If people are printing to the printers
directly, you'd have to go to each

690
00:32:28.600 --> 00:32:31.050
printer and configure that
type of recording on each one.

691
00:32:31.050 --> 00:32:32.590
And it's not the easiest thing to do.

692
00:32:32.590 --> 00:32:34.200
Some printers don't even support it.

693
00:32:34.200 --> 00:32:36.140
So having it centralized can help.

694
00:32:36.140 --> 00:32:38.430
So on those scenarios,
we'll want to share that printer out.

695
00:32:38.430 --> 00:32:39.480
And sharing is really easy.

696
00:32:39.480 --> 00:32:41.409
If we go back in our system preferences,

697
00:32:42.670 --> 00:32:45.490
you can do it right here
from inside of printing.

698
00:32:45.490 --> 00:32:47.130
I showed you in the sharing episode,
right?.

699
00:32:47.130 --> 00:32:49.340
We went into
the Sharing System Preference.

700
00:32:49.340 --> 00:32:50.880
And you can turn on printer sharing.

701
00:32:50.880 --> 00:32:53.310
And when you turn it on,
you can pick your printers and

702
00:32:53.310 --> 00:32:54.280
pick your preferences, right?.

703
00:32:54.280 --> 00:32:55.910
So that's one way to do it.

704
00:32:55.910 --> 00:32:58.850
The other way to do it is from
the Printer System Preference.

705
00:32:58.850 --> 00:33:03.080
So if I go in here and I find my printer,
you actually have the option right here.

706
00:33:03.080 --> 00:33:06.260
Do I want to share it on the network and
what are my preferences?

707
00:33:06.260 --> 00:33:07.640
If I choose to share it,

708
00:33:07.640 --> 00:33:11.800
it's now being shared on the network
with it's default settings.

709
00:33:11.800 --> 00:33:13.820
And then I can go to
Sharing Preferences and

710
00:33:13.820 --> 00:33:17.820
it just takes me right over to the sharing
screen and I can pick my printer.

711
00:33:17.820 --> 00:33:20.450
Now, I didn't hit Apply so
it didn't actually check it so

712
00:33:20.450 --> 00:33:21.940
I'll have to turn it on here again.

713
00:33:21.940 --> 00:33:23.150
And now I can set my permissions.

714
00:33:23.150 --> 00:33:26.790
The default is that everybody
is allowed to print.

715
00:33:27.920 --> 00:33:31.180
Everybody can't see each other's
print jobs but everybody can print.

716
00:33:31.180 --> 00:33:35.240
I can change that and I can add other
people with access so I might add, for

717
00:33:35.240 --> 00:33:37.610
example, me.

718
00:33:37.610 --> 00:33:39.310
So I'm gonna add me to the list, right?.

719
00:33:39.310 --> 00:33:42.060
And when I do that, notice what happens.

720
00:33:42.060 --> 00:33:43.700
Well,actually, two things happen.

721
00:33:43.700 --> 00:33:47.030
One, everyone's switched to no access and
two, I didn't show up.

722
00:33:47.030 --> 00:33:48.870
Well, there's a little
quirk in El Capitan.

723
00:33:48.870 --> 00:33:51.840
I'm sure they're gonna fix this with
an update, but I'm in the list.

724
00:33:51.840 --> 00:33:54.490
I'm just not showing up,
for whatever reason, and

725
00:33:54.490 --> 00:33:56.450
I think I showed this to you
in an episode the other day.

726
00:33:56.450 --> 00:33:59.100
So, all you do is close out of
System Preferences and go back in,

727
00:33:59.100 --> 00:34:00.470
and then that'll show up.

728
00:34:00.470 --> 00:34:03.240
It's kind of an annoying
quirk of the sharing screen.

729
00:34:03.240 --> 00:34:05.090
And so, sure enough, there I am.

730
00:34:05.090 --> 00:34:06.620
And so, I can choose me.

731
00:34:06.620 --> 00:34:08.610
Notice I don't have permissions over here.

732
00:34:08.610 --> 00:34:11.080
And cuz it is really only one
permission to allow me to print.

733
00:34:11.080 --> 00:34:13.900
So, I'm allowed to print that's
why I don't have a choice and

734
00:34:13.900 --> 00:34:15.740
everyone now get no access.

735
00:34:15.740 --> 00:34:19.330
Cuz I mean everyone, so
if everyone had access to print all ready,

736
00:34:19.330 --> 00:34:20.910
then why add me specifically?

737
00:34:20.910 --> 00:34:26.090
So it assumes that if I added me, that I
must be wanting to exclude everybody else.

738
00:34:26.090 --> 00:34:28.930
And I can add more people in here as I
want and those people will be able to

739
00:34:28.930 --> 00:34:30.910
print and everybody else will
not be allowed to print.

740
00:34:30.910 --> 00:34:32.660
We can tweak those permissions.

741
00:34:32.660 --> 00:34:35.300
Aside from that,
there's not really much to change here.

742
00:34:35.300 --> 00:34:37.350
And you've only got this other button
that just takes you right back to

743
00:34:37.350 --> 00:34:39.870
the printing screens,
and that's it, right?

744
00:34:39.870 --> 00:34:41.720
Supporting printers is pretty easy.

745
00:34:41.720 --> 00:34:45.110
Really what it comes down to is
getting the right driver loaded, and

746
00:34:45.110 --> 00:34:46.730
sharing it on the network
if that's what you desire.

747
00:34:46.730 --> 00:34:48.499
So otherwise,
they're pretty straightforward.

748
00:34:49.540 --> 00:34:52.250
All right, well, I know printers
are not the most exciting topic, and

749
00:34:52.250 --> 00:34:54.460
somehow I just managed to
spend 30 minutes on it.

750
00:34:54.460 --> 00:34:55.640
But we'll wrap it up here.

751
00:34:55.640 --> 00:34:57.710
That's all we've got for
printers, I promise.

752
00:34:57.710 --> 00:35:01.810
But in this episode,
we got a chance to see printer drivers and

753
00:35:01.810 --> 00:35:04.700
what they are, how they get installed,
the PPD and the CUPS system.

754
00:35:04.700 --> 00:35:06.720
We got a chance to see all of that.

755
00:35:06.720 --> 00:35:10.240
And we saw adding a printer
into Mac OS and sharing it out,

756
00:35:10.240 --> 00:35:11.740
making available on the network.

757
00:35:11.740 --> 00:35:15.190
And just some like basic troubleshooting
of pausing and resuming a printer,

758
00:35:15.190 --> 00:35:18.320
looking at that status light to see
how that printer is functioning, and

759
00:35:18.320 --> 00:35:19.760
making sure we've got that communications.

760
00:35:19.760 --> 00:35:21.630
So that's basically for printers.

761
00:35:21.630 --> 00:35:22.870
Not the most exciting thing in the world.

762
00:35:22.870 --> 00:35:25.530
But something that you'll have to deal
with in the business world because

763
00:35:25.530 --> 00:35:29.360
printers are still really,
really common In the business world.

764
00:35:29.360 --> 00:35:31.440
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed that episode.

765
00:35:31.440 --> 00:35:34.510
Signing off for ITPro.TV, I'm Don Pezet.

766
00:35:34.510 --> 00:35:35.990
Hope you guys enjoyed it.

767
00:35:35.990 --> 00:35:37.152
And hope to see you next time.

768
00:35:37.152 --> 00:35:45.581
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses the boot process for OS X. He explains each step and highlights some of the problems that can arise as the boot process continues. He demonstrates the Safe Mode, Safe Boot, Single User Mode, Verbose Mode trouble shooting tools.
episodes.title: System Troubleshooting
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.823 --> 00:00:15.564
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:15.564 --> 00:00:17.819
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.819 --> 00:00:19.047
I'm your host, Don Pezet,

5
00:00:19.047 --> 00:00:22.334
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Support Professional.

6
00:00:22.334 --> 00:00:25.790
And I'm actually pretty excited about
this one cuz we're gonna jump into

7
00:00:25.790 --> 00:00:27.080
system trouble shooting.

8
00:00:27.080 --> 00:00:29.857
And you'll find that Apple has given
us a ton of different tools for

9
00:00:29.857 --> 00:00:33.010
trouble shooting our system and
making sure that it runs smooth.

10
00:00:33.010 --> 00:00:35.770
We've talked about trouble shooting
a little bit throughout the whole show.

11
00:00:35.770 --> 00:00:39.270
Trouble shooting shared folders or
trouble shooting printers or whatever.

12
00:00:39.270 --> 00:00:43.710
But we're gonna talk about troubleshooting
the entire operating system here.

13
00:00:43.710 --> 00:00:46.820
When you can't even boot and
get into Mac OS, what do you do?

14
00:00:48.070 --> 00:00:49.780
How's that process work?

15
00:00:49.780 --> 00:00:52.130
So we need to understand all the tools
that are available to us and

16
00:00:52.130 --> 00:00:53.700
how to use them.

17
00:00:53.700 --> 00:00:57.830
A key piece of information you need when
it comes to troubleshooting the system is,

18
00:00:57.830 --> 00:00:59.590
how the system boots up?

19
00:00:59.590 --> 00:01:03.150
What happens when I power on that computer
and we go through the boot process?

20
00:01:03.150 --> 00:01:07.473
Because when we boot up, for the most
part everything's behind the scenes,

21
00:01:07.473 --> 00:01:09.013
we don't really see much.

22
00:01:09.013 --> 00:01:12.660
Think about the boot process
that you see as an end user.

23
00:01:12.660 --> 00:01:15.060
You push the power button on the Mac.

24
00:01:15.060 --> 00:01:17.110
And a little Apple logo appears, and

25
00:01:17.110 --> 00:01:18.940
a little bar scrolls across
the bottom of the screen.

26
00:01:18.940 --> 00:01:22.581
And when that bar gets all the way to
the sign then you get to a login Window.

27
00:01:22.581 --> 00:01:25.881
And you punch in your password and
then you see your desktop and

28
00:01:25.881 --> 00:01:29.230
you work all right, so
sounds pretty simple.

29
00:01:29.230 --> 00:01:32.800
Apple logo, login screen,
desktop, three steps.

30
00:01:32.800 --> 00:01:36.370
But in reality there's a lot of
stuff going on behind the scenes.

31
00:01:36.370 --> 00:01:40.366
Then it's actually more like a six step
process, we just don't see it all.

32
00:01:40.366 --> 00:01:44.154
It's hidden from us what's going
on when that system boots up.

33
00:01:44.154 --> 00:01:45.900
It doesn't have to be hidden from us.

34
00:01:45.900 --> 00:01:48.970
We can actually make it show some
of the things that are going on.

35
00:01:48.970 --> 00:01:52.744
And then so that some of the neat
stuff that happen behind the scenes.

36
00:01:52.744 --> 00:01:55.974
And once you know about it, you just
ignore it and you enjoy how easily

37
00:01:55.974 --> 00:01:59.890
the operating system works with little to
no interference or maintenance needed.

38
00:02:01.100 --> 00:02:04.154
But when something goes wrong,
you've gotta troubleshoot.

39
00:02:04.154 --> 00:02:06.527
You've gotta figure out
where that something is,

40
00:02:06.527 --> 00:02:07.970
where did this thing go wrong?

41
00:02:07.970 --> 00:02:11.790
I just turned the computer on and
now I can't get into my applications, so

42
00:02:11.790 --> 00:02:12.679
where did the problem happen?

43
00:02:13.820 --> 00:02:17.290
And a problem can happen
anywhere along the line.

44
00:02:17.290 --> 00:02:19.990
And so on the exam,
they expect you to know

45
00:02:19.990 --> 00:02:23.950
all the steps that happen between
you hitting the power button.

46
00:02:23.950 --> 00:02:27.010
And you getting to your application and
using your computer.

47
00:02:27.010 --> 00:02:28.990
Because any one of those
could be a problem and

48
00:02:28.990 --> 00:02:32.590
identifying the step will identify how
to solve it, how to fix that problem.

49
00:02:33.620 --> 00:02:35.780
So let's walk through the process.

50
00:02:35.780 --> 00:02:40.560
If you've got a Mac that's turned off and
you push that power button

51
00:02:40.560 --> 00:02:44.050
the very first thing that happens
is your firmware is fired up.

52
00:02:44.050 --> 00:02:45.830
Now, what is firmware?

53
00:02:45.830 --> 00:02:49.670
If we were on any other computer from any
other vendor, we would call this our BIOS.

54
00:02:49.670 --> 00:02:54.690
The basic input/output system or
basic input/output operating system.

55
00:02:54.690 --> 00:02:59.800
And the BIOS is part of your hardware and
it does things like powering up your CPU

56
00:02:59.800 --> 00:03:05.530
and powering up your video card, testing
your fans, doing a power on self test.

57
00:03:05.530 --> 00:03:09.850
A basic hardware test just to make
sure that your system functions

58
00:03:09.850 --> 00:03:12.600
before going and
finding the operating system.

59
00:03:12.600 --> 00:03:16.490
This is not your operating system,
this is not Mac OS or OS X.

60
00:03:16.490 --> 00:03:20.520
The firmware is its own
proprietary little system, very,

61
00:03:20.520 --> 00:03:23.990
very small built right into
the motherboard in your system.

62
00:03:23.990 --> 00:03:26.500
And whereas other vendors
let you see this,

63
00:03:26.500 --> 00:03:30.510
let you actually see the subsystem,
Apple doesn't let you do that.

64
00:03:30.510 --> 00:03:33.780
The firmware on an Apple device
is completely hidden and

65
00:03:33.780 --> 00:03:37.970
obstructed away from you, so
you can't see and interact with it.

66
00:03:37.970 --> 00:03:41.900
Well you can interact with it just a hair,
if things go wrong.

67
00:03:41.900 --> 00:03:44.590
If things are working right,
it's completely hidden, you never see it.

68
00:03:44.590 --> 00:03:46.557
There's no press F1 to enter BIOS or

69
00:03:46.557 --> 00:03:49.800
press Delete to configure system
settings when you boot up.

70
00:03:49.800 --> 00:03:53.460
You don't see any of that, you just
see an Apple logo, and off you go.

71
00:03:53.460 --> 00:03:55.930
So if I've got a problem
with my system and

72
00:03:55.930 --> 00:04:00.490
it's hardware, if the processor is bad,
if the memory is bad, when I go and

73
00:04:00.490 --> 00:04:03.800
push that power button usually
things go south really fast.

74
00:04:03.800 --> 00:04:06.930
Things break really early on,
you push the power button and

75
00:04:06.930 --> 00:04:08.550
you never see the Apple logo.

76
00:04:08.550 --> 00:04:10.510
It just sits there, and
you got a black screen,

77
00:04:10.510 --> 00:04:12.186
maybe the monitor never even powers on.

78
00:04:12.186 --> 00:04:14.209
Your monitor goes into sleep mode,
and never even wakes up, so

79
00:04:14.209 --> 00:04:16.280
you got a little amber light
there on your monitor.

80
00:04:16.280 --> 00:04:18.190
The video card never gets powered on.

81
00:04:18.190 --> 00:04:20.918
That used to happen a lot where
people would get these Mac minis and

82
00:04:20.918 --> 00:04:23.706
they'd say it's so small,
I can move it around all the time.

83
00:04:23.706 --> 00:04:26.750
And they would move it around, and
they'd knock the memory loose.

84
00:04:26.750 --> 00:04:28.910
And the memory chips inside would
start to get a little loose.

85
00:04:28.910 --> 00:04:32.410
And now, when you got to power
on it wouldn't see RAM, and

86
00:04:32.410 --> 00:04:33.350
you wouldn't be able to power on.

87
00:04:34.370 --> 00:04:38.421
So what all is going on behind
the scenes when that occurs?

88
00:04:38.421 --> 00:04:41.255
Well a newer Mac you don't have to worry
about cuz Apple doesn't let us add

89
00:04:41.255 --> 00:04:41.950
memory anymore.

00:27:02.800 --> 00:27:06.800

00:31:11.940 --> 00:31:15.920
They're all being called by launchd,

00:31:15.920 --> 00:31:17.052

00:31:40.000 --> 00:31:43.510
So the system boots up, launch D fires up.

00:31:43.510 --> 00:31:48.340
It launches all the background services,

00:31:48.340 --> 00:31:50.590

00:32:27.170 --> 00:32:30.870
